claimReview_claimReviewed: The Pfizer and Moderna Covid-19 vaccines use lipid nanoparticles to deliver an mRNA load into cells.
extra_title: No evidence that nanoparticles in Covid-19 vaccines affect fertility
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: These lipid nanoparticles may have adverse effects on fertility for both men and women.
extra_title: No evidence that nanoparticles in Covid-19 vaccines affect fertility
rating_alternateName: Nanoparticles are a broad spectrum of different materials that only have their small size in common. There’s no evidence that the lipid nanoparticles in these vaccines will have any effect on fertility.

claimReview_claimReviewed: ONS data shows huge falls in non-Covid causes of death in December 2020.
extra_title: ONS death figures not averaged correctly
rating_alternateName: The data was wrong. It claimed to show a huge fall in 2020 against the previous five-year average. But that five-year “average” hadn’t in fact been divided by five, meaning it was five times too high.

claimReview_claimReviewed: You can't have the Pfizer vaccine if you're allergic to penicillin.
extra_title: Penicillin allergies don’t rule out Pfizer vaccine
rating_alternateName: Official advice in the UK is that having penicillin allergies doesn’t rule out having any of the approved Covid-19 vaccines.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A leaked letter shows the government has a deliberate plan to damage the economy with the help of a public health campaign.
extra_title: Fake letter from Cabinet Office spreads on social media
rating_alternateName: The letter is fake.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Sir Keir Starmer has never said that he wanted the UK to remain in the European Medicines Agency after Brexit.
extra_title: Keir Starmer did want the UK to remain in the European Medicines Agency
rating_alternateName: This is not true. He said at least twice that the UK should seek to remain in the European Medicines Agency.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Inhaling steam can cure Covid-19 by killing the virus that causes it when it is in the sinuses, before it reaches the lungs.
extra_title: There’s no proof steam inhalation cures Covid-19
rating_alternateName: There’s no evidence that this is the case.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Two Pfizer doses are 99.96% effective.
extra_title: Pfizer vaccine effective, though not as effective as newspapers suggest
rating_alternateName: The Pfizer vaccine has an efficacy rate of over 90%. The 99.96% figure is not an efficacy rate but the proportion of people vaccinated in Israel who did not later test positive for the virus.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Two Pfizer doses 'are 99.96% effective': Double jab weeks apart prevents almost ALL cases of Covid-19, research in Israel suggests”.
extra_title: Pfizer vaccine effective, though not as effective as newspapers suggest
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Scotland’s bill for HS2 is £17 billion.
extra_title: HS2 will not cost Scotland £17 billion
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. There is no evidence for this claim. In effect, all money spent by Scotland on HS2 is returned through the Barnett formula.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 53 people have died in Gibraltar in 10 days after vaccinations with the Pfizer Covid-19 started.
extra_title: 53 people have not died in Gibraltar because of the Covid-19 vaccine
rating_alternateName: As of 27 January, out of more than 11,000 vaccinated, six have died after receiving the vaccine, but there’s no evidence these deaths were related to the vaccine. 54 have died with or of Covid-19 in Gibraltar since vaccinations started on 10 January.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Article 42 of the Magna Carta 'enshrines' the right to free movement at home and across borders in peacetime.
extra_title: “Article 42” of Magna Carta only existed for a short time
rating_alternateName: Wrong. This provision existed in 1215 but it's not part of the most recently signed Magna Carta or modern law.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Pfizer is using children as lab rats to test the Covid-19 vaccine.
extra_title: Adolescents have been recruited for Covid-19 vaccine trials in the US
rating_alternateName: 2,000 children in the US have been enrolled in Covid-19 vaccine trials in the US.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Research shows that only 11% of people self-isolate when asked to do so by NHS Test and Trace.
extra_title: Why are people not self-isolating?
rating_alternateName: This is correct for those who were close contacts of people who had tested positive. A survey in the summer found that only 11% of these people stayed in their homes for the full period required.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Research shows that people do not follow self-isolation rules because they cannot afford to.
extra_title: Why are people not self-isolating?
rating_alternateName: Based on the available evidence, this is not a major factor reported by people who do not self-isolate correctly. Just 8.9% said that they broke the rules in order to go to work.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Only 11% of people who need to self-isolate are being contacted.
extra_title: Why are people not self-isolating?
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. We do not have a precise figure for this. Official statistics show that the proportion of known contacts being reached is much higher.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Research conducted for the Department of Health found that only 11% of people asked to self-isolate by NHS Test and Trace have done so.”
extra_title: Why are people not self-isolating?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “It is estimated that only about 11% of people self-isolate when they are asked to do so—11%. That is not because they do not want to; it is because many do not feel that they can afford to do so.”
extra_title: Why are people not self-isolating?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “At the moment only 11% of people who are asked to self-isolate through the NHS app are actually able to do so, many of them not eligible for a one-off payment to help them do that.”
extra_title: Why are people not self-isolating?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We still need to fix the gaps in contact tracing and in financial support for those who need to self-isolate. Only 11% of people are being contacted, according to the figures that I am getting.”
extra_title: Why are people not self-isolating?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A million children have been gang raped and groomed in the UK.
extra_title: Many children have been the victims of grooming gangs, but there’s no evidence for a figure of one million
rating_alternateName: This figure is not reliable. It appears to come from assuming that the number of suspected cases of child sexual exploitation in 2018/19 can be multiplied by 30 years—which still does not reach one million. We don’t know what the true number is.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Football players will display Black Lives Matter on their shirts but weren’t allowed to display the poppy symbol.
extra_title: Footballers aren’t banned from wearing the poppy
rating_alternateName: Footballers in the Premier League have displayed the words Black Lives Matter on their shirts recently, and have always been allowed to wear the poppy. Home nations teams were fined in 2016 for wearing the poppy in an international fixture, but this rule has since been changed.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A new law to speed up the installation of 5G technology was quietly passed on March 23.
extra_title: The 5G And Beyond Act is not a British law
rating_alternateName: This law was passed in the US, not the UK, after going through Congress for a year. It’s intended to ensure the security of 5G infrastructure, not to speed up the installation.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 5G technology is dangerous for human health.
extra_title: The 5G And Beyond Act is not a British law
rating_alternateName: This is not true.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Iceland has declared all religions are mental disorders.
extra_title: Iceland has not declared that all religions are mental disorders
rating_alternateName: This is false and originated from satirical article online. The Evangelical Lutheran Church is the official state church of Iceland.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The justice budget has fallen by 40% since 2010.
extra_title: Justice spending is down 25% since 2010, not 40%
rating_alternateName: This was a proposal, but is now out of date. The government announced a 40% real terms reduction in the Ministry of Justice budget between 2010/11 and 2019/20, but in the end the reduction was 25%.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We’ve seen 40% cuts to the prison and criminal justice system.”
extra_title: Justice spending is down 25% since 2010, not 40%
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The living wage is £18,000 a year.
extra_title: Post comparing the living wage and pensions needs context
rating_alternateName: This is broadly correct for someone working full time.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Pensioners only receive £8,000 a year and still have to pay for a TV license.
extra_title: Post comparing the living wage and pensions needs context
rating_alternateName: The amount pensioners receive varies depending on a number of factors. Over 75s do now have to pay for a TV license, with some exceptions.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The new UK-Japan trade deal will deliver a £1.5 billion boost to the UK economy.
extra_title: Is the UK's trade deal with Japan better than the EU's?
rating_alternateName: This is the estimate of annual GDP growth after 15 years, relative to 2018, before the existing EU-Japan trade deal took effect.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The old EU-Japan trade deal was estimated to deliver a £2.6 billion boost to the UK economy.
extra_title: Is the UK's trade deal with Japan better than the EU's?
rating_alternateName: This is the estimate of annual GDP growth after 15 years, but it can’t be compared to the estimate for the UK-Japan deal because they used very different calculation methods.

claimReview_claimReviewed: People can get up to £24,000 a year in benefits while working 16 hours a week.
extra_title: £24,000 doesn’t represent what most Universal Credit claimants receive
rating_alternateName: This can happen. However, this amount is considerably higher than the average amount received.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The new UK-Japan trade deal will mean soy sauce imports from Japan will get cheaper.
extra_title: Soy sauce imports from Japan will not be cheaper next year
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. Tariffs on Japanese soy sauce will stay at 0%. Tariffs on soy sauce imports from some other countries may increase, but from others may decrease.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The bakers used a lot of soya sauce in the first challenge on #GBBO so it's a good thing it will be made cheaper thanks to our trade deal with Japan.”
extra_title: Soy sauce imports from Japan will not be cheaper next year
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: People are getting paid £850 a week in benefits.
extra_title: It’s possible to receive financial support above the benefits cap, but this does not apply to the majority of households
rating_alternateName: Most people receiving universal credit or housing support receive less than this figure due to the benefits cap. Some can receive over the benefits cap, but most do not.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are roughly 14 million people living in relative poverty this year. In 2000, there were roughly 14 million people living in relative poverty.
extra_title: How poverty rates are cherry-picked to score political points
rating_alternateName: The latest government figures show 14.5 million people (22% of the population) living in relative low income households after housing costs in the UK. In 2000/01 it was 13 million across Great Britain (23% of the population).

claimReview_claimReviewed: In 2010-11, there were 3.5 million children living in relative poverty. Today, the figure after housing costs is 4.2 million.
extra_title: How poverty rates are cherry-picked to score political points
rating_alternateName: Broadly correct. In 2010/11 the figure was 3.6 million (27% of children), and in 2018/19 it was 4.2 million (30% of children).However, if you measured from 2009/10, when the proportion was also 30%, there would be no change.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “There are roughly 14 million people living in relative poverty this year. In 2000, there were roughly 14 million people living in relative poverty. Why were Labour not able to fix the problems of relative poverty when they were in power?”
extra_title: How poverty rates are cherry-picked to score political points
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Perhaps the hon. Gentleman would like me to enlighten him on the poverty figures during Labour’s period in office. In 2010-11, there were 3.5 million children living in relative poverty. Today, the figure after housing costs is 4.2 million.”
extra_title: How poverty rates are cherry-picked to score political points
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: An “Australian terms” trade deal could be called a deal on Mongolian or Afghan terms.
extra_title: What does an "Australia style" Brexit deal really mean?"
rating_alternateName: Mongolia and Afghanistan actually have more favourable trade terms with the EU, at least as far as tariffs are concerned, than Australia.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We hope that the EU will change their position [...] But I think it’s only fair also that we communicate one other thing, which is that we are ready, if required, to leave on what have been called Australian terms.”
extra_title: What does an "Australia style" Brexit deal really mean?"
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Could be called Mongolian or Afghan terms as well as Australian.”
extra_title: What does an "Australia style" Brexit deal really mean?"
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: People working in restaurants and bars in Bolton that were closed because of local Covid-19 restrictions could not access any support.
extra_title: Andy Burnham was wrong about furlough on Question Time
rating_alternateName: This is not correct. During the local restrictions in Bolton, businesses were still able to make claims through the furlough scheme on behalf of employees who had already been furloughed for at least three consecutive weeks before July.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Asylum seeker benefits cost the UK taxpayer £60 million per year.
extra_title: This viral post on benefits and tax avoidance is inaccurate
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. In 2019/20 the Home Office spent £470 million on providing accommodation and cash support to people seeking asylum.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Benefit fraud and error costs the UK taxpayer £3 billion per year.
extra_title: This viral post on benefits and tax avoidance is inaccurate
rating_alternateName: It’s estimated that £3.9 billion is overpaid to claimants due to fraud or claimant error, and £1.3 billion is underpaid to claimants due to claimant error. That gives a balance of £2.6 billion.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Tax avoidance costs £90 billion per year.
extra_title: This viral post on benefits and tax avoidance is inaccurate
rating_alternateName: This is an unofficial estimate of the total tax gap. The figures are disputed and do not just cover tax avoidance.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The new UK-Japan trade deal will deliver a £1.5 billion boost to the UK economy.
extra_title: £1.5bn GDP boost from UK-Japan trade deal is not on top of existing EU-Japan deal benefits
rating_alternateName: These estimated benefits are relative to 2018 when the UK (as part of the EU) had no FTA with Japan. It’s not relative to the existing EU-Japan trade deal which currently governs trade between the UK and Japan.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Remaining in the EU means £50 billion more for the government to spend by 2024/25.
extra_title: £50 billion “remain bonus” figure is a reasonable estimate but highly uncertain
rating_alternateName: This is a fair assessment of the best available forecasts, comparing Remain to a Brexit deal scenario. But those forecasts themselves contain a high degree of uncertainty, so we shouldn’t treat £50 billion as definitive.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We know that that remain bonus will be £50 billion that we can spend on our public services, investing in our schools and in the welfare system to help poorest in our society”.
extra_title: £50 billion “remain bonus” figure is a reasonable estimate but highly uncertain
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government’s own research says that Boris Johnson’s Brexit proposals would lead to a 6.7% drop in GDP.
extra_title: This comparison between Brexit’s impact and the financial crisis is flawed
rating_alternateName: The government estimated a free trade agreement Brexit could lead to GDP being 6.7% lower after 15 years than if the UK remained in the EU. That’s not the same as saying this form of Brexit will lead to a drop in GDP compared to now.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government’s own research says that Boris Johnson’s Brexit proposals would lead to a 6.4% drop in real wages.
extra_title: This comparison between Brexit’s impact and the financial crisis is flawed
rating_alternateName: The government estimated a free trade agreement Brexit could lead to real wages being 6.4% lower after 15 years than if the UK remained in the EU. That’s not the same as saying this form of Brexit will lead to a drop in real wages compared to now.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Boris Johnson’s Brexit proposals would lead to the kind of hit to the economy experienced in the financial crash.
extra_title: This comparison between Brexit’s impact and the financial crisis is flawed
rating_alternateName: This is an unfair comparison as it equates real drops in GDP and wages during the financial crisis to the loss of potential earnings over longer time periods as a result of Brexit.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The Government's own research says that Boris Johnson's Brexit proposals would lead to a 6.7% drop in GDP and 6.4% drop in real wages - the kind of hit to the economy experienced in the financial crash.”
extra_title: This comparison between Brexit’s impact and the financial crisis is flawed
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Britons have spent £4bn stockpiling goods in case of no-deal Brexit.
extra_title: £4 billion Brexit stockpiling claim based on flawed survey
rating_alternateName: This is almost certainly an exaggeration. The survey it’s based on likely overestimates the amount that has been stockpiled, and consumer spending data shows no evidence of people stockpiling to this degree.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Britons have spent £4bn stockpiling goods in case of no-deal Brexit”
extra_title: £4 billion Brexit stockpiling claim based on flawed survey
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The EU has decided to increase the size of fisherman’s meshes.
extra_title: There’s no solid evidence to support this Brexit Party MEP’s claim about fishermen’s nets
rating_alternateName: EU regulation has changed and there is now a minimum mesh size in certain areas. That came in place on 1 July 2019.

claimReview_claimReviewed: That change to mesh sizes has reduced fishermen’s income by 40%.
extra_title: There’s no solid evidence to support this Brexit Party MEP’s claim about fishermen’s nets
rating_alternateName: That is based on an unsourced quote reported by a Cornish news website. We don’t know how or if income has been affected yet as the regulation only changed on 1 July 2019.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The powers that be have decided to actually increase the size of fishermen’s meshes thereby reducing their income by 40%.”
extra_title: There’s no solid evidence to support this Brexit Party MEP’s claim about fishermen’s nets
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Lowering the state pension age for women back to 60 would create four million jobs for the younger generation.
extra_title: Lowering the state pension age for women won't create four million jobs for young people
rating_alternateName: This is not accurate. There is no evidence that four million women over the age of 60 are currently employed nor that they would all retire given the opportunity.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Mark Francois has denied the existence of a gender pay gap.
extra_title: Mark Francois did not deny that there is a gender pay gap
rating_alternateName: This is not true. Mr Francois did not say this. It seems the quote was fabricated.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Half of adults are now being paid by the state.
extra_title: Claims about who’s paid by the state aren’t very meaningful
rating_alternateName: There are too many ways to interpret this for any single answer to be meaningful.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “More than half of all adults now paid by the state”
extra_title: Claims about who’s paid by the state aren’t very meaningful
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Average pay has finally surpassed its pre-crisis peak.
extra_title: Whether wages have passed their pre-crisis level depends on whether you include bonuses
rating_alternateName: True, for average weekly earnings in GB, if you don’t count bonuses. Average weekly total earnings including bonuses is still below the pre-crisis peak.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Average UK wages top pre-financial crisis levels.”
extra_title: Whether wages have passed their pre-crisis level depends on whether you include bonuses
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Wages back above pre-economic crisis levels.”
extra_title: Whether wages have passed their pre-crisis level depends on whether you include bonuses
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Average pay has finally surpassed its pre-crisis peak.”
extra_title: Whether wages have passed their pre-crisis level depends on whether you include bonuses
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Universal Credit has got 200,000 people into work.
extra_title: Universal Credit has not got 200,000 people into work
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. This was the government’s estimate of what Universal Credit would do by 2024/5. It may not be reliable, and can never be measured properly.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Universal Credit has in fact succeeded in getting 200,000 people into jobs.”
extra_title: Universal Credit has not got 200,000 people into work
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Just 15% of people who begin low-paid work in the UK will rise out of low pay during their working lives. This is the worst rate in the developed world.
extra_title: Sir Iain Duncan Smith is wrong to say that only 15% of people ever move above low pay
rating_alternateName: This claim is based on EU data from 2004-2011 showing the proportion of workers moving upwards from any skill level over four years, not in their lifetimes. The same data shows 35-40% of people rising out of low pay in the UK over a four-year period. The UK’s rate is low compared with other EU countries, but not the lowest.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “In the UK, if you start work at entry level, only 15% of those who start work at entry level will rise above entry level—that’s the lowest pay—for the rest of their working lives. This is about the worst figure in the developed world.”
extra_title: Sir Iain Duncan Smith is wrong to say that only 15% of people ever move above low pay
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK was able to approve the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine more quickly because of Brexit.
extra_title: Vaccine approval isn’t quicker because of Brexit
rating_alternateName: This is not correct. Under European law, the UK was permitted to act independently to approve the vaccine in an emergency.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Because of Brexit we’ve been able to make a decision [to approve the Pfizer vaccine] based on the UK regulator, a world class regulator, and not go at the pace of the Europeans who are moving a little bit more slowly. We do all the same safety checks and the same processes, but we’ve been able to speed up how they’re done because of Brexit.”
extra_title: Vaccine approval isn’t quicker because of Brexit
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A new YouGov poll shows 62% of people think that Brexit is a bad thing.
extra_title: Daily Mirror misrepresents research on public support for Brexit
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The poll shows that 50% of GB adults think Britain was wrong to leave the EU, and a further 12% don’t know.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Pollster YouGov finding a record low of 38% still believe Brexit’s a good thing while 62% realise it’s bad illuminates why shackling a country to a narrow referendum squeaked on lies four years ago isn’t smart.”
extra_title: Daily Mirror misrepresents research on public support for Brexit
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A majority of the public is against extending the transition period between the UK and the EU.
extra_title: Claim that extending the Brexit transition period could cost £380 billion is not credible
rating_alternateName: The poll found more people are opposed to extension than in favour of it, but less than 50% so it’s not a majority opinion. Many other recent polls have shown the opposite.

claimReview_claimReviewed: It will cost the UK £378 billion to extend the transition period between the UK and the EU.
extra_title: Claim that extending the Brexit transition period could cost £380 billion is not credible
rating_alternateName: This estimate is based on a one-sided analysis which doesn’t seem to factor in any economic benefit of retaining free trade with the EU during the transition period. Most studies suggest these benefits outweigh potential gains from trade agreements and deregulation after the transition period ends.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Get Brexit done! Majority AGAINST Brexit transition extension in close poll”
extra_title: Claim that extending the Brexit transition period could cost £380 billion is not credible
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Britain’s ‘faces £380billion bill’ if Brexit is delayed beyond December
extra_title: Claim that extending the Brexit transition period could cost £380 billion is not credible
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Extension to Brexit bill could cost £378bn”
extra_title: Claim that extending the Brexit transition period could cost £380 billion is not credible
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 7.7% of UK goods exports go to the EU.
extra_title: Claim that 7.7% of UK goods exports go to the EU is a big underestimate
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. 46% of UK goods exports go to the EU, according to the latest data for 2019. Those exports amount to 7.7% of GDP.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Tens of thousands of workers will share in a £1.8 billion pay rise under a US trade deal.
extra_title: The government’s “£1.8 billion pay rise” from a US trade deal doesn’t outweigh the impacts of Brexit on wages
rating_alternateName: Government analysis shows wages could be 0.2% (£1.8 billion) higher after 15 years under a scenario where we sign a free trade deal with the USA compared to a baseline scenario where we don’t. But this baseline assumes wages will be 6.4% lower than they would have been, had we remained in the EU.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Tens of thousands of workers will share in a £1.8 billion pay rise under a US trade deal that is “there for the taking”, the International Trade Secretary says.”
extra_title: The government’s “£1.8 billion pay rise” from a US trade deal doesn’t outweigh the impacts of Brexit on wages
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Treasury expects the UK economy to shrink by 4.9% under a Canada-style deal with the EU.
extra_title: No, the Treasury doesn’t expect the economy to shrink if we sign a Canada-style deal with the EU
rating_alternateName: The Treasury estimated that a free-trade agreement similar to Canada’s would mean the UK economy grows between 4.9% and 6.7% less over 15 years, than it would have if we had remained in the EU. But that doesn’t mean the economy will shrink.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The UK is seeking a Canada-style deal with the EU, which Treasury analysis estimates will shrink the British economy by 4.9 per cent.”
extra_title: No, the Treasury doesn’t expect the economy to shrink if we sign a Canada-style deal with the EU
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The EU did not help Britain during the Falklands War, and instead sent weapons to Argentina.
extra_title: The European Community supported Britain during the Falklands War
rating_alternateName: This is not true. The EC (the predecessor of the EU) applied an arms embargo and an import ban on Argentina.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “37 years ago, During the Falklands War did the EU help us NO they were openly sending Weapons to our AGGRESSOR never forget that
extra_title: The European Community supported Britain during the Falklands War
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Norway has free movement with the EU, despite not being in the single market.
extra_title: You can have freedom of movement outside the EU if you’re in the single market
rating_alternateName: Norway does have free movement, but it is in the single market.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Once the UK leaves the single market, freedom of movement no longer applies.
extra_title: You can have freedom of movement outside the EU if you’re in the single market
rating_alternateName: Correct. Freedom of movement is one of the rules of the single market.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Once we come out of the single market freedom of movement falls.
extra_title: You can have freedom of movement outside the EU if you’re in the single market
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Norway’s not in the single market and yet they have free movement.
extra_title: You can have freedom of movement outside the EU if you’re in the single market
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Under Boris Johnson’s planned withdrawal agreement GDP per capita would fall by up to 7% in 10 years.
extra_title: Think tank did not say GDP per capita will fall by 7% under Boris Johnson’s deal
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. This misreports an estimate by think tank UK in a Changing Europe. It estimated that, in one scenario, GDP per capita would be 7% lower after 10 years, compared to if the UK remained in the EU—not 7% lower than it is now.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“Mr Johnson’s plan is also a much harder Brexit than Theresa May’s.

“GDP per capita would fall by up to 7% in 10 years, says the UK in a Changing Europe think-tank.
extra_title: Think tank did not say GDP per capita will fall by 7% under Boris Johnson’s deal
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Under the new withdrawal agreement, Northern Ireland is effectively annexed by the EU with border in the Irish sea between NI and the UK.
extra_title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal
rating_alternateName: There will be checks on goods crossing from the rest of the UK into Northern Ireland, but Northern Ireland will remain part of the UK’s customs territory. What you deem to be annexing is really a matter of interpretation.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Under the new withdrawal agreement, we have to pay the £39bn Brexit bill we don't legally owe.
extra_title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal
rating_alternateName: The divorce bill is now more like £33 billion, and the UK would be legally obliged to pay it under the terms of newly revised withdrawal agreement.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Under the new withdrawal agreement, EU courts have jurisdiction over the UK.
extra_title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal
rating_alternateName: Nothing has changed on this compared to Theresa May’s withdrawal agreement, but the European Court of Justice would have jurisdiction on some rules in Northern Ireland.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Under the new withdrawal agreement, there is a transition period until 2021, extendable for years longer.
extra_title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal
rating_alternateName: Under the current terms of the agreement, the transition period would end just before 2021 began. It could theoretically be extended by up to two years, provided that’s been settled by half way through 2020.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Under the new withdrawal agreement, UK fishing waters are not returned to the UK and EU members still fish UK waters.
extra_title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal
rating_alternateName: The latest deal doesn’t change anything to do fisheries, compared to Theresa May’s deal. The UK is due to leave the Common Fisheries Policy so will be an independent coast state.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Under the new withdrawal agreement, only the backstop changed so all the other flaws of May's deal continue.
extra_title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal
rating_alternateName: The biggest change was to the Irish backstop, but the non-binding political declaration changed too.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Under the new withdrawal agreement, Boris Johnson agreed to a 'level playing field' meaning the UK will follow many EU laws making us uncompetitive and restricting our future trade.
extra_title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal
rating_alternateName: The level playing field is in the political declaration part of the deal which isn’t legally binding, and the UK hasn’t yet made firm or specific commitments to following EU standards. Northern Ireland will remain aligned to some EU single market rules.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Under the new withdrawal agreement, the UK can't sign trade deals until at least 2021.
extra_title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal
rating_alternateName: The UK can sign trade deals during the transition period but they wouldn’t be able to come into force until the transition period ends on 31 December 2020.

claimReview_claimReviewed: NI effectively annexed by the EU with border in the Irish sea between NI and the UK
extra_title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: £39bn Brexit bill we don’t legally owe
extra_title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: EU courts have jurisdiction
extra_title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Transition period until 2021, extendable for years longer
extra_title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: UK fishing waters not returned to the UK and EU members still fish UK waters
extra_title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Only the backstop changed so all the other flaws of May’s deal continue
extra_title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Boris agreed to a 'level playing field' meaning the UK will follow many EU laws making us uncompetitive and restricting our future trade
extra_title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK can’t sign trade deals until at least 2021
extra_title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 90% of all trade through the Port of Southampton is to and from non-EU countries.
extra_title: Southampton MP gets trade figures wrong
rating_alternateName: In 2016 it was estimated that 90% of exports (by value) from the Port of Southampton went to non-EU countries.

claimReview_claimReviewed: All non-EU trade through the port of Southampton is ‘WTO’.
extra_title: Southampton MP gets trade figures wrong
rating_alternateName: This is misleading. Much non-EU trade through Southampton happens under preferential terms negotiated between the EU and other countries, not on basic WTO terms.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “90% of all trade through the Port of Southampton is from and to the rest of the World not the EU. All that trade is WTO. A deal is by far the best way forward but talk of a huge threat to jobs in Southampton without a deal is complete nonsense.”
extra_title: Southampton MP gets trade figures wrong
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK can sign a three-page trade agreement with the EU and then trade tariff-free under GATT 24.
extra_title: GATT 24: new argument, same old problems
rating_alternateName: In theory such an agreement could satisfy GATT 24, allowing tariff-free trade on most goods with the EU. It would lead to significant wider barriers to trade, and the EU is unlikely to sign up to it.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A three-page trade agreement would mean little obvious would change in terms of our trade when we leave the EU.
extra_title: GATT 24: new argument, same old problems
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. This would be the most basic possible trade agreement. The UK and EU would lose alignment on regulation of goods, with significant non-tariff barriers to trade, and tariffs on trade in services.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A three-page trade agreement under Article 24 would be “enough to avoid delays at borders”.
extra_title: GATT 24: new argument, same old problems
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. This agreement would mean the UK and EU having different regulatory standards, and therefore checks on goods at the border.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Only Whitehall stands in the way of our Gatt 24 'get out of jail free' Brexit card”
extra_title: GATT 24: new argument, same old problems
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The EU puts a 30% tariff on cocoa from Africa.
extra_title: The EU doesn’t have a 30% tariff on African cocoa imports
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The maximum tariff on processed cocoa is 9.6%. The vast majority of African countries can export all cocoa products to the EU tariff-free due to various schemes they’re part of.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The EU puts a 30% tariff on cocoa from Africa.”
extra_title: The EU doesn’t have a 30% tariff on African cocoa imports
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A post claims influenza has been eradicated and seems to suggest this is suspicious.
extra_title: Flu deaths aren’t being miscategorised as Covid-19 deaths
rating_alternateName: While there appears to be very few flu infections due to various reasons, the flu has not been eradicated. Covid-19 deaths are not miscategorised flu deaths.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If all the other lockdowns haven’t worked, why would this one be any different?
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: False. The government estimates locking down in the spring saved thousands of lives compared with doing nothing.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The reason why there are more cases is because they are testing more people.
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: It’s true more people are being tested than ever before, but we also know deaths and hospitalisations have increased.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 65,000 deaths tested positive for coronavirus within 30 days of their death, so they could have died of a heart attack or a stroke or cancer, but it will go down as a Covid death.
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: Some deaths unrelated to Covid-19 may happen within 28 days of a positive test but this makes very little difference to the figures. Up to the week ending 15 January, 85,321 deaths were registered in England and Wales with Covid-19 recorded as the underlying cause of death by a medical professional.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Bacterial pneumonia is caused by people wearing masks and is massively on the rise.
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: There is no evidence that wearing a mask can cause bacterial pneumonia, or that deaths from pneumonia have increased.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Suicides have increased during lockdown.
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: It is too soon to know what impact the pandemic has had on the suicide rate. There is currently no evidence of a dramatic increase.

claimReview_claimReviewed: National Child Mortality Database identified deaths in under 18s increased dramatically in the first lockdown.
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: This is wrong. The NCMD said there had been a slight increase but the numbers were too small to draw definite conclusions.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A survey from Samaritans said one in four people had suicidal thoughts during lockdown.
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: A survey done between March and May 2020 found that 1 in 10 people had suicidal thoughts.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Children aren’t affected by Covid-19 and don’t transmit the virus.
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: This is not true. Children are less affected but some can still become seriously ill or die. They do transmit the virus.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Children won’t be allowed back to school unless they’ve been tested.
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: This is incorrect. Testing in schools is voluntary.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Up to 93% of PCR tests are false positives.
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: This is wrong. It has been estimated that the false positive rate is very low.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government can introduce restrictions on Universal Credit where you can’t get it unless you get tested and unless you get a vaccine.
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: The government has confirmed this is untrue and there are no plans to do this.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 53 million tests means that they have 53 millions people’s DNA on file.
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: This is wrong. No record of the patient’s DNA is taken in the testing process and the majority of test samples are destroyed.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Mental health is an exemption of Tier 4 and Tier 5 -- you can go out and see a friend, you can leave your house.
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: You can leave your house during lockdown for specific reasons, regardless of mental health, for example, to meet one local friend for exercise.

claimReview_claimReviewed: They’ve introduced mandatory masks, social distancing and all these measures, closed primary schools and closed secondary schools, and closed non-essential shops, and yet nothing has worked. If all the other lockdowns haven’t worked, why would this be any different?”
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The reason why there are more cases is because they are testing more people.
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: They are saying in England there has been 2.2 million confirmed cases and 65,000 deaths. So out of those 65,000 deaths, 388 of those were under 60 and no pre-existing conditions. [...] This isn’t 65,000 deaths from covid, this is 65,000 deaths that had tested positive within coronavirus within 30 days of their death. So someone could have died of a heart attack or a stroke or cancer, but if they tested positive within 30 days then it will go down as [a Covid death].
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Bacterial pneumonia, which is caused by people wearing masks, which is massively on the rise.
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: We have the highest rate of suicide since World War Two [...] Our suicides are as high now as they were back then [...] Male suicides are the highest for two decades and suicides in general have increased by up to 145%.
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The National Child Mortality Database identified deaths in under 18s increased dramatically in the first lockdown.
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Samaritans did a study of 3,077 adults from 18 to 60, and one in four said they had suicidal thoughts. [...] three out of four suffered with depression, anxiety, levels of defeat or severe loneliness. So three quarters of the people that they studied suffered from mental health effects of this lockdown
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A Freedom of Information request showed that prescriptions for sleeping pills for under 18s rose by 30% from March 2020 to June 2020.
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Children don’t get affected by [Covid-19] [...] Children aren’t carriers and children aren’t transmitting this virus.
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Now that they’ve closed all the schools, it’s going to be you can’t go back to school until your child has been tested. It’s going to be weekly lateral flow testing.
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Up to 93% of false positives PCR testing...
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The problem is when you’re then relying on the state and you’re on universal credit [...] it’s very, very, very hard to get away from them. When you’re relying on them for your money every single month, they’ve got you. Because then they can do ‘well if you’re not getting tested you’re not getting your money. If you don’t get the vaccine you’re not getting your money’.
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 53 million tests - that means that they have 53 million people’s DNA [the government] now has on file.
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Mental health is an exemption of Tier 4 and Tier 5 -- so if you are suffering with your mental health or you’re alone or you’re a single parent or you’re fleeing domestic violence, you are allowed to go o out your house, you are allowed to see a friend, you are allowed to go and get help. You do not have to stay in your house.
extra_title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The German federal government only expects the AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine to have an effectiveness of eight percent among the over 65s.
extra_title: Report of 8% vaccine efficacy for elderly debunked by German government
rating_alternateName: The German government said it couldn’t confirm the report which may have misunderstood the proportion of trial participants aged 56-69 as the efficacy rate among over 65s. Public data shows older adults had a similar immune response to the vaccine as younger adults.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “According to information from Handelsblatt from coalition circles, the federal government only expects an effectiveness of eight percent among the over 65s.”
extra_title: Report of 8% vaccine efficacy for elderly debunked by German government
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Covid-19 spike protein which the Pfizer vaccine causes an immune response against also trains the body to attack syncytin-1, a protein in the placenta, which could lead to infertility in women.
extra_title: No evidence Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine affects women’s fertility
rating_alternateName: This claim has no basis. The spike protein on the Covid-19 virus and a protein that makes up the placenta have only a small amount in common, almost certainly not enough for the immune system to attack the placenta.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Covid vaccine is an RNA vaccine. This will actually change your DNA.
extra_title: RNA Covid-19 vaccines will not change your DNA
rating_alternateName: Some of the Covid-19 vaccine candidates are RNA vaccines. These don’t alter your DNA, they comprise of mRNA that gives the body instructions on how to make the proteins on the surface of the virus.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The recovery rate from Covid-19 is 99.7% to 99.9%
extra_title: The Covid-19 recovery rate is not 99.9%
rating_alternateName: This is incorrect. The recovery rate is far lower.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The proposed Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine is 90% effective.
extra_title: The Covid-19 recovery rate is not 99.9%
rating_alternateName: This is accurate according to early results, however, this could change when more results come out.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Covid-19 pandemic is caused by radiation
extra_title: Covid-19 is an infectious disease, and a video claiming it isn’t is wrong
rating_alternateName: This is not true. It is caused by a virus.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The World Health Organisation says that the coronavirus that causes Covid-19 is not infectious.
extra_title: Covid-19 is an infectious disease, and a video claiming it isn’t is wrong
rating_alternateName: This is not true. The World Health Organisation says that the coronavirus that causes Covid-19 is infectious.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK recorded just three deaths from respiratory conditions besides Covid-19 in October 2020.
extra_title: Covid-19 is an infectious disease, and a video claiming it isn’t is wrong
rating_alternateName: This is not true. In four weeks of October, 1,239 deaths were recorded just from flu or pneumonia in England and Wales alone.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Walking your pet dog may raise your risk of catching coronavirus by 78 per cent.
extra_title: Research suggesting increased Covid-19 risk for dog-owners may be barking up the wrong tree
rating_alternateName: This is based on research which has many flaws. In particular, suggestions this is down to dogs acting as a Covid-19 vector are based on limited evidence.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “They’re known as ‘man’s best friend’, but if you live with a dog, you may unknowingly be increasing your risk of coronavirus.”
extra_title: Research suggesting increased Covid-19 risk for dog-owners may be barking up the wrong tree
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Walking your pet dog may raise your risk of catching coronavirus by 78 per cent”
extra_title: Research suggesting increased Covid-19 risk for dog-owners may be barking up the wrong tree
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Young people are about twice as likely to suffer from “long Covid” after a coronavirus infection
extra_title: Matt Hancock got the evidence about long Covid wrong
rating_alternateName: This is incorrect, based on the data Mr Hancock mentioned, which suggests that people over 70 have about twice the risk of people under 50.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There is no link between the severity of a Covid-19 infection and the chances of suffering “long Covid” afterwards
extra_title: Matt Hancock got the evidence about long Covid wrong
rating_alternateName: This is incorrect, based on the data Mr Hancock mentioned, which suggests that people who suffer from “long Covid” had more symptoms when they were infected, and were more likely to have visited hospital.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We have two points of evidence; one is the evidence from King’s College London that shows that approximately one in 20 people with coronavirus is likely to have long-term symptoms, but the other evidence implies that in adults under 50, the proportion is more like one in 10. There seems to be some correlation that implies that it is more of a problem among younger people but the understanding of long Covid is still in its early stages and an awful lot more research is needed.”
extra_title: Matt Hancock got the evidence about long Covid wrong
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Make sure you and your family all dig out your NHS number and have a copy of it immediately to hand for the Covid jab. NHS staff on the front line say this is the biggest bottleneck when it comes to administering the vaccine to as many people as quickly as possible.
extra_title: You don’t need your NHS number to get a Covid-19 vaccine
rating_alternateName: You do not need to have your NHS number with you in order to receive the vaccine. A name and date of birth is all that is required, although some trusts have asked patients to bring their NHS numbers if possible.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Just 13,844 people in England and Wales were infected with Covid-19 in 2020.
extra_title: Millions—not thousands—caught Covid last year
rating_alternateName: This is close to the number of NOIDs notifications by doctors, but it is not the total number of infections. Almost 2.5 million people tested positive for Covid-19 in England and Wales last year.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There is pork in Covid-19 vaccines.
extra_title: There isn’t pork in Covid-19 vaccines
rating_alternateName: False. Neither the Pfizer, AstraZeneca, nor the Moderna vaccines contain any animal products.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Covid-19 vaccine will cause infertility in younger men.
extra_title: There isn’t pork in Covid-19 vaccines
rating_alternateName: There is no reason to believe this. If anything, vaccination may help protect any effect on fertility caused by the virus itself.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Vaccines pose a risk of death to the elderly.
extra_title: There isn’t pork in Covid-19 vaccines
rating_alternateName: Vaccine side effects are rarely serious, and the risk of death from the vaccine is much lower than the risk of Covid-19 infection.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 23 people in Norway died after getting the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine.
extra_title: What you need to know about the claims 23 people died after getting the Covid-19 vaccine in Norway
rating_alternateName: True as of 14 January, but we don’t know for certain that getting the vaccine was what caused these people’s deaths. There’s a possibility that side effects of these vaccines, such as nausea and fever, contributed to the deaths of these 23 elderly patients. As of 17 January there had been 33 such deaths.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A 14 year-old girl is missing after being pulled into a car.
extra_title: Viral posts about missing girl are false, again
rating_alternateName: This is false. There are no reports of this happening. The picture is of a 15 year-old girl who briefly went missing in different circumstances in 2019.

claimReview_claimReviewed: In London crime has risen five times faster than the rest of the country since Sadiq Khan became Mayor in 2016.
extra_title: Crime in London has risen less than the rest of England since 2016
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. Recorded crime per person in London has increased by 18% over this period, less than the 31% increase across England overall. These statistics only count crime recorded by police, and it’s estimated that overall crime is decreasing.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Since Boris Johnson stepped down as London mayor, crime in Khan’s London has soared at five times the rate of the rest of the country.”
extra_title: Crime in London has risen less than the rest of England since 2016
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Punishment for breaking lockdown is harsher than for possessing images of child abuse.
extra_title: Punishment for breaking social distancing and possessing indecent images of children can vary
rating_alternateName: Sentencing for both crimes varies greatly. The fine cited for breaking lockdown (£3,400) is roughly correct after numerous breaches, and punishment for possession of indecent images of children can vary depending on the exact offence.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Pressing the cancel button twice before using a cash machine prevents fraudsters from stealing your PIN.
extra_title: Pressing ‘cancel’ does not prevent cash machine fraud
rating_alternateName: This is not true. LINK, which operates the UK’s largest cash machine network, calls it an “urban myth”.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The last time a police officer was successfully prosecuted in the UK concerning the death of somebody in custody was in 1969.
extra_title: We know of no successful convictions of a police officer for the killing of someone in police custody since 1971
rating_alternateName:
There have been successful prosecutions of police officers and police forces concerning the deaths of people in police custody since 1969.

However we have found no successful prosecutions for manslaughter or homicide of someone in police custody.

In 1971 two officers were found guilty of assault relating to the death of a man in 1969.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The last time a police officer was successfully prosecuted in the UK concerning the death of somebody in custody was in 1969.”
extra_title: We know of no successful convictions of a police officer for the killing of someone in police custody since 1971
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: If you are in the UK and under coronavirus lockdown with an abusive partner dial 999, wait to be connected, press 55 & hang up.
extra_title: If you need the police but can’t talk, dial 999 from a mobile, then 55 when prompted and don’t hang up
rating_alternateName: You will only be prompted to press 55 on a silent call from a mobile. And you should not hang up after typing 55. You should try and cough, tap the handset or whisper to communicate on an emergency call if possible.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A government review warns it is almost as easy to buy some drugs as it is to buy pizza.
extra_title: There’s not enough evidence to say it’s as easy to buy drugs as pizza in the UK
rating_alternateName: There is not enough evidence for this claim, which does not appear in the review itself. The Global Drug Survey compared delivery times of cocaine and pizza internationally in 2018 and found 30% of people could get cocaine in under 30 minutes while only 16.5% of people said they could get a pizza delivered in that time. Figures to make this comparison for the UK aren’t available.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Drugs are so widely available they are as easy to buy as pizzas, reveals government review.”
extra_title: There’s not enough evidence to say it’s as easy to buy drugs as pizza in the UK
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Getting drugs in Britain almost easier than ordering pizza, study warns.”
extra_title: There’s not enough evidence to say it’s as easy to buy drugs as pizza in the UK
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Criminals are sent to jail only after committing 55 offences.
extra_title: Context is needed in this article about offences committed prior to prison sentences
rating_alternateName: This is misleading. In prison sentences of less than six months, the average number of previous offences was 60 for females and 57 for males. This includes offences that have previously resulted in a prison sentence and the figures may count the same people more than once.

claimReview_claimReviewed: One offender carried out 93 crimes last year before going to jail for the first time.
extra_title: Context is needed in this article about offences committed prior to prison sentences
rating_alternateName: One person sent to prison for the first time had 93 offences recorded, however there is no data on the time period these offences were committed over. One conviction may include several offences.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There has been a 400% increase in hate crime within the LGBT+ community.
extra_title: Change in LGBT+ hate crime levels not as simple as Dawn Butler suggests
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. There are two sources of data on this type of hate crime. One estimates a 261% increase in hate crime on the basis of sexual orientation and transgender identity, and the other estimates a 40% decrease in hate crimes based on sexual orientation since around 2010. Neither measure is perfect.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We’ve had nearly a 400% increase in hate crime with the LGBT+ community”
extra_title: Change in LGBT+ hate crime levels not as simple as Dawn Butler suggests
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are 2 million illegal immigrants in the UK.
extra_title: There almost certainly aren’t as many as two million unauthorised immigrants in the UK
rating_alternateName: This is much higher than even the upper end of an estimate of how many people were in the UK in 2017 without a permit to be there.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The super-rich and big corporations dodge £90 billion in tax every year.
extra_title: Comparing tax dodging and benefits for people seeking asylum
rating_alternateName: This is an unofficial estimate of the total tax gap. The figures are disputed and do not just cover tax dodging by the super-rich and big corporations.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Asylum seekers have to live on just £37.75 per week.
extra_title: Comparing tax dodging and benefits for people seeking asylum
rating_alternateName: People seeking asylum who are homeless or can’t afford food typically receive £37.75 per week. The level is slightly higher for young children and pregnant women or new mothers. This is in addition to furnished housing and utilities which are provided for no cost.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The super-rich and big corporations dodge £90 billion in tax every year, but we're told to get angry at asylum seekers who have to live on just £37.75 a week?”
extra_title: Comparing tax dodging and benefits for people seeking asylum
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Those who fought on the beaches of Northern France now have to pay for their TV licence.
extra_title: It’s not true that migrants get a free TV licence
rating_alternateName: The free TV licence for most over 75s ended on 1 August 2020.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If you arrive from the beaches of Northern France today you get a TV licence for free, along with a house to watch it in.
extra_title: It’s not true that migrants get a free TV licence
rating_alternateName: This refers to migrants arriving in the UK across the English Channel, and is not correct. Migrants are expected to pay for their own TV licence, and their accommodation can include hostels and bed and breakfasts.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Contributions from health workers paying the immigration health surcharge help us raise about £900 million.
extra_title: How much have healthcare workers paid through the immigration health surcharge?
rating_alternateName: £900 million is the total amount raised by the immigration health surcharge – paid by some international UK residents – over four years. It is not the amount paid solely by health workers and carers.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Every Thursday, we go out and clap for our carers. Many of them are risking their lives for the sake of all of us. Does the Prime Minister think it is right that careworkers coming from abroad and working on our frontline should have to pay a surcharge of hundreds, sometimes thousands of pounds to use the NHS themselves?”
extra_title: How much have healthcare workers paid through the immigration health surcharge?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “…we must look at the realities. This is a great national service—it is a national institution—that needs funding, and those contributions help us to raise about £900 million.”
extra_title: How much have healthcare workers paid through the immigration health surcharge?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 100,000 people have arrived into the UK since the lockdown began.
extra_title: It’s likely that over 100,000 people have entered the UK since the lockdown began
rating_alternateName: The government’s estimates on this subject are opaque, but the latest figures it has been using suggest well over 100,000 people will have entered the country since mid- to late March.

claimReview_claimReviewed: An estimated 0.5% of people arriving into the UK have Covid-19.
extra_title: It’s likely that over 100,000 people have entered the UK since the lockdown began
rating_alternateName: These were remarks by the Home Office’s Chief Scientific Advisor, which were later clarified to be wrong. 0.5% is an estimate for the proportion of reported Covid-19 cases in the UK believed to have been “imported” from abroad as of 23 March.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Last night, the Prime Minister said in his speech that he proposed to impose quarantine on people coming into the country by air. Given that 100,000 people have arrived in the UK since the start of lockdown, why is that only being introduced now?”
extra_title: It’s likely that over 100,000 people have entered the UK since the lockdown began
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 15,000 passengers are arriving into the UK daily at the moment.
extra_title: The government hasn’t provided evidence for its claim that 15,000 arrive per day into the UK
rating_alternateName: The government hasn’t yet provided any evidence to back this up, and the Home Office has said it does not recognise the figure and that in their view it is wrong.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
Matt Hancock: “The number of people coming through has dropped very dramatically, as so there is very very low amounts—”
Piers Morgan: “How many have come in this week?”
Matt Hancock: “It’s about 15,000 a day at the moment from the data that [interrupted]”
extra_title: The government hasn’t provided evidence for its claim that 15,000 arrive per day into the UK
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Romanian workers are being brought in to do seasonal British farm work, despite huge interest in these roles by British people.
extra_title: Some context for the claims that Romanian seasonal workers are taking UK workers’ jobs
rating_alternateName: Farmers and produce companies say although there has been high interest and some roles are filled, experienced farmworkers are still needed to train and supervise new recruits and volunteers.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Under the government’s new immigration rules anyone earning less than £25,600 is regarded as an unskilled worker.
extra_title: Most of these NHS jobs are classed as “skilled” under new immigration rules
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. All workers applying for the skilled worker visa must have a salary of at least £20,480, and if it is below £25,600 they must also fulfil other criteria to gain a visa. Jobs are not classed by the government as “skilled” depending on salary.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Newly qualified NHS nurses, paramedics, midwives, radiographers, care assistants, physiotherapists and occupational therapists are considered unskilled workers under a new set of immigration rules.
extra_title: Most of these NHS jobs are classed as “skilled” under new immigration rules
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. All of the listed jobs apart from care assistants meet the skills threshold under new immigration rules.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Home Office figures suggest new immigration rules will mean a reduction in unskilled EU migration of 90,000.
extra_title: Unpublished Home Office target needs explaining
rating_alternateName: The number of unskilled EU migrants coming to work in the UK is already less than 90,000, so the government cannot cut it by 90,000 with changes to immigration rules.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“Skilled migration to the UK will rise under radical reforms to immigration that Boris Johnson signed off last week…
“Home Office figures suggest the new rules will mean an overnight reduction in unskilled EU migrants of about 90,000 a year, who will no longer have a route into Britain.
extra_title: Unpublished Home Office target needs explaining
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK has taken in 41,000  unaccompanied children since 2010.
extra_title: Since 2010, the UK has granted protection to around 41,000 asylum seekers and refugees under the age of 18
rating_alternateName: Since 2010, the UK has granted protection to 41,396 asylum seekers and refugees under the age of 18. However, at least 40% of these young people were accompanied by parents or carers.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Not only have we taken 41,000 unaccompanied children since 2010…”
extra_title: Since 2010, the UK has granted protection to around 41,000 asylum seekers and refugees under the age of 18
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Coronavirus rates among teachers are 333% above the average.
extra_title: We don’t know whether teachers are more likely to catch Covid
rating_alternateName: This claim comes from incomparable data. We don’t know whether teachers are more likely to catch Covid or not.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Coronavirus rates among teachers are 333% above the average.”
extra_title: We don’t know whether teachers are more likely to catch Covid
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: School funding has increased by a minimum of £5,150 per pupil.
extra_title: School funding hasn’t increased by £5k per pupil
rating_alternateName: This is not true. £5,150 is the minimum amount secondary schools will receive per pupil, not the level of increase.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We've increased school funding by a minimum of £5,150 per pupil.”
extra_title: School funding hasn’t increased by £5k per pupil
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Virus levels are now 50x higher among secondary school pupils than they were in September.
extra_title: Fact-checking claims on coronavirus transmission in schools
rating_alternateName: According to ONS data, this is correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 38% of infections outside of the home are caught in schools
extra_title: Fact-checking claims on coronavirus transmission in schools
rating_alternateName: This data refers to the number of Covid-19 incidents reported by local health teams. It does not represent all non-domestic transmission and it is misleading to suggest this.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “NEU analysis of ONS figures shows that virus levels are now 9 times higher amongst primary pupils and an astonishing 50 times higher amongst secondary pupils.”
extra_title: Fact-checking claims on coronavirus transmission in schools
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Just 4% of infections outside the home trace back to pubs and restaurants. But by contrast, 38% of infections are caught in schools, by far the biggest means of transmission.”
extra_title: Fact-checking claims on coronavirus transmission in schools
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The return to universities could cause 50,000 deaths from Covid-19 without “strong controls”.
extra_title: Reopening universities will almost certainly not cause 50,000 deaths
rating_alternateName: This comes from a research paper that has not been peer-reviewed. It is based on several assumptions, including that every student gets infected, and nothing is done to stop it.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Without strong controls, the return to universities would cause a minimum of 50,000 deaths”
extra_title: Reopening universities will almost certainly not cause 50,000 deaths
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Anxiety levels among young teenagers dropped during the coronavirus pandemic, a study has suggested.
extra_title: Claims of pandemic fall in child anxiety may not apply across the whole country
rating_alternateName: There is nothing wrong with the study, which surveyed year 9 students in the south west of England. But this data may not be representative of children across the country and in other age groups.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said: “The danger is that pupils will be overpromoted into jobs that are beyond their competence.”
extra_title: Gavin Williamson did not say pupils will be overpromoted into jobs that are beyond their competence
rating_alternateName: This is not true and does not accurately reflect comments Mr Williamson made in The Daily Telegraph. This incorrect paraphrasing seems to have begun as a joke.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Boris Johnson announced an extra £14.4 billion in funding for schools over three years.
extra_title: The government’s education funding figures need context
rating_alternateName: £14.4 billion is the cumulative amount schools in England will receive over three years. By the third year (2022/23), school funding will be £7.1 billion higher than it was in 2019/20, or £4.3 billion once inflation is accounted for.

claimReview_claimReviewed: That translates to £135 million a week.
extra_title: The government’s education funding figures need context
rating_alternateName: School funding in England will be £135 million a week higher by 2022/23, not throughout the three years. After adjusting for inflation, this amounts to £82.7 million a week.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “In his first months in office, the Prime Minister announced an extra £14.4 billion in funding for schools over three years. That translates to £135 million a week”.
extra_title: The government’s education funding figures need context
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of British children who need foster care has risen by 44% during the pandemic, children’s charity Barnardo’s has warned.
extra_title: Data from Barnardo’s doesn’t show the number of children needing foster care has grown 44%
rating_alternateName:
Barnardo’s has seen a 44% rise in the number of referrals to its fostering services from councils in England, Wales and Northern Ireland. 

But that doesn’t mean the number of children needing foster care has risen by 44%.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The number of British children who need foster care has risen by 44% during the pandemic, children’s charity Barnardo’s has warned.”
extra_title: Data from Barnardo’s doesn’t show the number of children needing foster care has grown 44%
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The number of children needing foster care has risen by 44% during the coronavirus pandemic, creating a “state of emergency”, a children’s charity said.”
extra_title: Data from Barnardo’s doesn’t show the number of children needing foster care has grown 44%
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 97% of schools who submitted data had children coming back in early June.
extra_title: Boris Johnson overstates number of schools with returning students
rating_alternateName: This is not true. 97% of schools who submitted data were open, but only about two thirds of them had children coming back.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "97% of the schools that have submitted data are now seeing kids come back to school."
extra_title: Boris Johnson overstates number of schools with returning students
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: People with no recourse to public funds are not yet able to claim free school meal vouchers.
extra_title: Some children with no recourse to public funds are eligible for free school meals
rating_alternateName: The government has extended free school meal eligibility in England to some but not all people with no recourse to public funds, temporarily, during the pandemic.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “A million people with no recourse to public funds can’t access the universal credit safety net...will he suspend the no recourse to public funds restrictions for the duration of the crisis and do it before the school summer holidays so that destitute families can at least claim the free school meal vouchers  which he announced yesterday.
extra_title: Some children with no recourse to public funds are eligible for free school meals
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims
