claimReview_claimReviewed: “Well of course they should be eligible for those.
extra_title: Some children with no recourse to public funds are eligible for free school meals
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Recent changes to the law mean killers could avoid whole life terms by pleading guilty.
extra_title: Can killers now avoid life in prison with a guilty plea?
rating_alternateName: The new sentencing guidelines don’t change the law. If a whole life order is made in court, a guilty plea will not reduce the sentence. However, a judge will factor a guilty plea into the decision about whether to make a whole life order in the first place.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The worst murderers should be given a chance to escape staying in prison for life by pleading guilty, according to new rules drawn up for judges.”
extra_title: Can killers now avoid life in prison with a guilty plea?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Under new government plans, murderers of pre-school children will be subject to whole-life sentences for the first time.
extra_title: How long do child killers serve in prison?
rating_alternateName: It’s already possible for people who murder children to be given whole-life sentences, but usually only in certain cases.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Prisoners becoming eligible for early release halfway through their sentences was a Labour policy.
extra_title: How long do child killers serve in prison?
rating_alternateName: It actually first became law in 1991, under a Conservative government. Labour continued it in a major revamp of the law in 2003.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“Life will mean life for child killers … For the first time, murderers of pre-school children will be subject to whole-life orders.

“The Government will also rip up Labour’s policy of prisoners becoming eligible for release at the halfway point of their sentences. Instead, it wants violent and sexual offenders to serve at least two thirds of their full terms.
extra_title: How long do child killers serve in prison?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: We can only sell lamb to Japan because of the EU-Japan trade deal.
extra_title: Lamb exports to Japan aren’t due to EU trade deal
rating_alternateName: We sell lamb to Japan as a result of Japan agreeing to drop an import ban. Japan charges no tariffs on lamb, so farmers will continue to export lamb to Japan tariff free post-Brexit.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Tariffs on exporting lamb and sheep to the EU will be 40% in a no deal Brexit scenario.
extra_title: Lamb exports to Japan aren’t due to EU trade deal
rating_alternateName: The tariff level varies depending on which lamb or sheep product is being exported. But 40% is within that range.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“It [no deal Brexit] is quite possible, indeed it is the government’s central planning horizon and on November 1 there will be a 40% tariff on lamb and sheep meat exports,
—Nick Robinson.
“I would point to the market in Japan that has just been opened to Welsh and British sheep for example,
extra_title: Lamb exports to Japan aren’t due to EU trade deal
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The EU has put up trade barriers with African countries.
extra_title: Most African countries can export goods to the EU tariff free
rating_alternateName: The majority of African countries have no tariffs on exports to the EU, although a handful do face some tariffs.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “As part of the European Union we've put these barriers up against African countries and many others from selling their produce to us, freed from the European Union we can do more good to help Africa and the third world.”
extra_title: Most African countries can export goods to the EU tariff free
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The EU imposes 50% tariffs on rice, maize and other cereals and 300% tariffs on processed sugar imported from African countries.
extra_title: Out of Africa: the facts about EU tariffs on African exports
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The EU does charge tariffs on imports of all these goods, but most African countries aren’t subject to them

claimReview_claimReviewed: “But ‘as strong as we are now’ means that we impose 50% tariffs on rice, maize and other cereals [on African countries]. Over 300% tariffs on processed sugar.”
extra_title: Out of Africa: the facts about EU tariffs on African exports
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “And yet time and again we [in Nigeria] are hit by EU tariffs on products such as sugar cane and rice… Rice, maize and other cereals face tariffs of more than 50 per cent.”
extra_title: Out of Africa: the facts about EU tariffs on African exports
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Six of the world’s ten fastest growing economies are in Africa which means there may be significant economic opportunities there for the UK as we seek to expand our trade relationships outside the European Union
extra_title: Out of Africa: the facts about EU tariffs on African exports
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: If we leave the EU with no deal, the divorce bill is no longer strictly speaking owed.
extra_title: Does a no deal Brexit mean no divorce bill?
rating_alternateName: It’s not clearly set out that the UK would be obliged to pay anything if we left with no deal, but the EU could take the case to the International Court of Justice on the grounds of the UK’s repeated commitments to pay.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "If we come out without an agreement it is certainly true that the £39 billion is no longer strictly speaking owed."
extra_title: Does a no deal Brexit mean no divorce bill?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Only 5% of Northern Ireland’s GDP goes to Ireland.
extra_title: Irish border: how much trade?
rating_alternateName: Roughly correct in terms of goods exports. But goods exports are not normally measured as a percentage of GDP. 33% of Northern Ireland’s goods exports went to the Republic in 2016.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Only 1.6% of Irish exports go to Northern Ireland.
extra_title: Irish border: how much trade?
rating_alternateName: Correct, for goods exports in 2017.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are only about 50 large companies that trade across the Irish border.
extra_title: Irish border: how much trade?
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. Roughly 100 large companies (with 250+ employees) in Northern Ireland made export deliveries to the Republic in 2016, making up 11% of deliveries to Ireland. We don’t have data for those exports going to the North from the Republic.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Only 4% of non-EU goods get checked by the UK and only one per cent by Ireland.
extra_title: Irish border: how much trade?
rating_alternateName: Correct for the UK. The best evidence we’ve seen for Ireland is that it was 6% in 2016.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
"As it happens, the UK and Ireland are already very sparing in their checks on goods entering from outside the EU – only four per cent get checked by the UK and only one per cent by Ireland…
“Only 5 per cent of Northern Ireland’s GDP goes to Ireland, and only 1.6 per cent of Irish exports go to Northern Ireland. There are only about 50 large companies that trade across the frontier
extra_title: Irish border: how much trade?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The withdrawal agreement does not create any form of separation for Northern Ireland.
extra_title: Does the Brexit withdrawal agreement mean Northern Irish separation?
rating_alternateName: Not strictly correct. The withdrawal agreement includes a backstop arrangement. If that kicks in Northern Ireland will operate under different rules to the rest of the UK.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "[The withdrawal agreement] absolutely does not create any form of separation for Northern Ireland."
extra_title: Does the Brexit withdrawal agreement mean Northern Irish separation?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 72% of the goods that leave Belfast port come to Great Britain.
extra_title: Trade across the Irish Sea
rating_alternateName: This claim hasn’t been substantiated and we’ve not seen wider evidence for this. In 2016, 85% of goods which left Belfast port went to the UK, measured by their weight. 56% of all Northern Irish goods sold beyond its borders went to Great Britain, based on the value of those goods.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “72 per cent of the goods that leave Belfast port come to Great Britain.”
extra_title: Trade across the Irish Sea
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Extending the Brexit transition period would cost an estimated 15 billion.
extra_title: Would extending the Brexit transition period cost £15 billion?
rating_alternateName: We can’t know for sure—much will depend on the size of the EU’s next budget and the sum would probably have to be negotiated. But £15 billion a year seems a reasonable estimate for now.

claimReview_claimReviewed: We’ve got 39 billion that we’re going to send to the EU.
extra_title: Would extending the Brexit transition period cost £15 billion?
rating_alternateName: That’s the estimated size of our “divorce bill” which settles outstanding budget contributions, and other financial commitments and liabilities we have towards EU, up to the end of 2020.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We’ve got 39 billion that we’re going to send off to the EU. If we extend the transition period that’s an extra 15 billion, estimated.”
extra_title: Would extending the Brexit transition period cost £15 billion?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: If you have a runny nose and sputum, you have a common cold, not Covid-19.
extra_title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be
rating_alternateName: These are the symptoms for the common cold, but they don’t rule out Covid-19.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Coronavirus pneumonia is a dry cough with no runny nose.
extra_title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be
rating_alternateName: Some Covid-19 patients do get pneumonia, and one of the symptoms is a dry cough. A runny nose doesn’t rule out Covid-19.

claimReview_claimReviewed: This new virus is not heat-resistant and will be killed by a temperature of just 26/27 degrees. It hates the Sun.
extra_title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be
rating_alternateName: There’s no evidence for this. There’s evidence that similar viruses transmit less well in the heat, but many countries with reported Covid-19 cases are experiencing temperatures higher than this.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If someone with the new coronavirus sneezes, it travels about 10 feet before it drops to the ground and is no longer airborne
extra_title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be
rating_alternateName: How far the droplets spread from a sneeze depends on environmental factors, but it is likely to be several metres.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If it drops on a metal surface it will live for at least 12 hours - so if you come into contact with any metal surface - wash your hands as soon as you can with a bacterial soap.
extra_title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be
rating_alternateName: We don’t know how long the virus survives on surfaces yet—it may be between hours and days.

claimReview_claimReviewed: On fabric it can survive for 6-12 hours. normal laundry detergent will kill it.
extra_title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be
rating_alternateName: There’s no evidence yet that the virus can survive in clothing and be transmitted this way. Any soiled clothing should be thoroughly washed.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Drinking warm water is effective for all viruses. Try not to drink liquids with ice.
extra_title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be
rating_alternateName: There’s no evidence that the temperature of liquids consumed can either protect you from or cure diseases caused by viruses.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Wash your hands frequently as the virus can only live on your hands for 5-10 minutes.
extra_title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be
rating_alternateName: We don’t know how long the virus can last on the skin, especially not down to the minute. But you should regularly wash your hands.

claimReview_claimReviewed: You should also gargle as a prevention. A simple solution of salt in warm water will suffice.
extra_title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be
rating_alternateName: There’s no evidence that this works as a preventative or a cure for the virus.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The symptoms of Covid-19 are that it first infects the throat, so you’ll have a sore throat lasting 3 or 4 days. The virus then blends into nasal fluid that enters the trachea and then the lungs causing pneumonia. This takes about 5 or 6 days. With pneumonia comes high fever and difficulty breathing
extra_title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be
rating_alternateName: This is a roughly accurate description of the most common symptoms, although not everyone with Covid-19 gets pneumonia, and the symptoms may not come in this exact order or at these times.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If you have a runny nose and sputum, you have a common cold
extra_title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Coronavirus pneumonia is a dry cough with no runny nose."
extra_title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: This new virus is not heat-resistant and will be killed by a temperature of just 26/27 degrees. It hates the Sun.”
extra_title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: If someone sneezes with it, it takes about 10 feet before it drops to the ground and is no longer airborne.”
extra_title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If it drops on a metal surface it will live for at least 12 hours - so if you come into contact with any metal surface - wash your hands as soon as you can with a bacterial soap.”
extra_title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: On fabric it can survive for 6-12 hours. normal laundry detergent will kill it.”
extra_title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Drinking warm water is effective for all viruses. Try not to drink liquids with ice.”
extra_title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: You should also gargle as a prevention. A simple solution of salt in warm water will suffice.”
extra_title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: THE SYMPTOM
extra_title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are four young people with no underlying illnesses in an intensive care unit in Cork due to Covid-19, who had all been taking anti-inflammatory drugs.
extra_title: That ‘medical alert’ about severe Covid-19 cases in Cork due to anti-inflammatories is fake
rating_alternateName: This is not true. It has been denied by the clinical lead of Ireland’s public health service and the whole message branded ‘misinformation’.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A medical alert says to stop the use of anti-inflammatories for pain or high temperatures.
extra_title: That ‘medical alert’ about severe Covid-19 cases in Cork due to anti-inflammatories is fake
rating_alternateName: This message is fake. Current advice from health authorities in the UK and Ireland say to continue taking previously prescribed medication, including anti-inflammatories unless told otherwise by a healthcare professional. The NHS says there is no strong evidence that taking ibuprofen can make Covid-19 worse, but advises people with symptoms to take paracetamol if they can.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Satellite images showing high levels of sulphur dioxide above China are possible evidence of mass cremations of people who have died from coronavirus.
extra_title: These aren’t satellite images and they don’t show evidence of mass cremations in Wuhan
rating_alternateName: False. The maps are not satellite images, and do not show actual levels of sulphur dioxide. They are simply forecasts based on historical data and weather patterns.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Chilling satellite pics ‘show extent of corpse burning in Wuhan’”
extra_title: These aren’t satellite images and they don’t show evidence of mass cremations in Wuhan
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Coronavirus satellite image: Does THIS image show REAL scale of virus cremations?”
extra_title: These aren’t satellite images and they don’t show evidence of mass cremations in Wuhan
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Children can’t get the new coronavirus.
extra_title: Children aren’t immune from the new coronavirus
rating_alternateName: Children can get Covid-19 but there have been relatively few cases in children and in general, their symptoms tend to be milder.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Covid-19 can be transmitted between humans and pets.
extra_title: Your pets almost certainly won’t give you Covid-19
rating_alternateName: There is one reported case of a pet dog in Hong Kong testing ‘weak positive’ for Covid-19. However, the dog is showing no symptoms and there is some question to whether the positive test is valid. The WHO and NHS says there is no evidence that pets can become infected or pass the virus to people.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Hand sanitiser is effective against Covid-19.
extra_title: Experts say soap and water is preferable, but high alcohol sanitiser does work
rating_alternateName: Hand sanitisers with 60% alcohol content and above are effective against viruses, such as the new coronavirus, but soap and water is the best option.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Rashes are a symptom of the new coronavirus.
extra_title: A rash is now listed as a possible symptom of the new coronavirus
rating_alternateName: A rash was not initially listed as a symptom of the new coronavirus. The World Health Organisation have now said it is a less common symptom.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Some recovered Covid-19 patients catch the disease again
extra_title: It's very rare to catch Covid-19 twice
rating_alternateName: There may have been some rare cases of reinfection with Covid-19, but most people seem to be immune afterwards, at least in the short term

claimReview_claimReviewed: A video shows overcrowding in St Mary’s Hospital, London and Covid-19 patients lying on the floor in corridors.
extra_title: This video supposedly showing Covid-19 patients at St Mary’s Hospital, London was actually filmed in Madrid
rating_alternateName: Incorrect, the clip is actually two videos filmed in hospitals in Madrid in mid-March.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A video showing body bags lying on the floor of various rooms inside a hospital was filmed in St Mary’s Hospital, London.
extra_title: This video of body bags in a hospital was not filmed in St Mary’s, London
rating_alternateName: Incorrect, the hospital trust confirmed it wasn’t filmed there. It was filmed in Ecuador.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A voice recording on WhatsApp claims there will be 900 deaths a day at the peak of the new coronavirus outbreak, one third will be children with no underlying health conditions, ambulances won’t be sent to people struggling to breathe, and all ice rinks are now being used as mortuaries.
extra_title: This viral voice message about ambulances shared on WhatsApp is inaccurate
rating_alternateName: This is incorrect. South East Coast Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust, where the person in the recording suggests they work, and Public Health England have confirmed the information is inaccurate.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Prime Minister may not have had Covid-19 and when he was admitted to hospital staff were asked to sign the Official Secrets Act and two who refused were dismissed.
extra_title: False posts that suggest Boris Johnson didn’t have Covid-19 are based on a blog post now labelled as satire
rating_alternateName: This is incorrect. It is based on a satirical blog post.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There were fewer deaths recorded in the first 15 weeks of 2020 than in the first 15 weeks of 2018.
extra_title: Total deaths in the UK in 2020 have now risen above the deaths during the same period in 2018
rating_alternateName: Correct, although the number of deaths in recent weeks far exceeds the number at the same point in any recent year.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A Facebook post defending the government’s role in current NHS equipment shortages was written by Jennifer Saunders.
extra_title: No, Jennifer Saunders did not write this statement about PPE shortages
rating_alternateName: No, this post was not written by Jennifer Saunders.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Professor Dr Tasuku Honjo, caused a sensation today in the media by saying that the corona virus is not natural.
extra_title: A Nobel Prize-winning immunologist has not said coronavirus is manmade, as claimed
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. Professor Honjo has denied saying this and there is no evidence that he ever did.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Captain Tom and his charity walk has raised 15.5 million with over 750,000 people donating.
extra_title: The Maytrix Group receives no money from Captain Tom’s fundraiser
rating_alternateName: The fundraiser was at around £15 million on 16 April. It is now at over £31 million. This doesn’t include Gift Aid.

claimReview_claimReviewed: For every donation the charity organisers take 1.98% off the fee plus 20p per each donation.
extra_title: The Maytrix Group receives no money from Captain Tom’s fundraiser
rating_alternateName: JustGiving charges payment processing fees for card and Paypal payments, charged at 1.9% of the donation plus 20p. The charge is 2.9% plus 20p for donations in other currencies.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If you request gift aid, the charity organisers take 5% of the gift aid before passing it on.
extra_title: The Maytrix Group receives no money from Captain Tom’s fundraiser
rating_alternateName: If a donor adds Gift Aid onto their donation, JustGiving deducts a 5% Gift Aid processing service fee. This is collected separately from the donations made.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The charity organisers on JustGiving are called Maytrix. The people who own or set up Maytrix are Captain Tom’s daughter and son in law.
extra_title: The Maytrix Group receives no money from Captain Tom’s fundraiser
rating_alternateName: While Captain Tom’s daughter did help him set up his fundraiser, and along with her husband is a director of the Maytrix Group, the company receives no money from the fundraiser.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Captain Tom and his charity walk has raised 15.5 million with over 750,000 people donating
extra_title: The Maytrix Group receives no money from Captain Tom’s fundraiser
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: for every donation the charity organisers take 1.98% off the fee plus 20p per each donation
extra_title: The Maytrix Group receives no money from Captain Tom’s fundraiser
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: then if you request gift aid they take 5% of the gift aid before passing it on
extra_title: The Maytrix Group receives no money from Captain Tom’s fundraiser
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: so in total the charity organisers have made £600,000, not bad eh.. from what I can gather the charity organisers on just giving I believe are called maytrix.. oh the people who own/set up matrix is only captain toms daughter and son in law
extra_title: The Maytrix Group receives no money from Captain Tom’s fundraiser
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The lockdown began on 16 March 2020, when Matt Hancock told the House of Commons that all unnecessary social contact should cease.
extra_title: When did lockdown begin in the UK?
rating_alternateName: Mr Hancock did say this, but it was not until 23 March 2020 that Boris Johnson told the country that people ‘must’ stay at home and certain businesses must close. Government ministers have previously described this second date as the start of lockdown. There is no official government definition of ‘lockdown’.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The 16th of March is the day that I came to this House and said that all unnecessary social contact should cease. That is precisely when the lockdown was started.”
extra_title: When did lockdown begin in the UK?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Covid-19 kills no more than 0.1% of the people who catch it
extra_title: Covid-19 kills far more than 0.1% of the people who catch it
rating_alternateName: This is incorrect. The real death rate is probably about five or ten times higher.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Lockdown happened because we were told that Covid could kill one percent. But Covid was never going to kill more than about 0.1 percent – max.”
extra_title: Covid-19 kills far more than 0.1% of the people who catch it
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Testing creates some revealing anomalies: the virus seems to understand the soft border between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland, for example, crediting those to the north with a far higher rate of infection.
extra_title: Several coronavirus claims made by MP in newspaper are inaccurate
rating_alternateName: It is true that the UK is testing more than the Republic of Ireland. The Republic of Ireland had the world’s highest infection rate at the time of the claim.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Our mortality rate remains much the same as others.
extra_title: Several coronavirus claims made by MP in newspaper are inaccurate
rating_alternateName: In the week to 11 January, Our World in Data reported the UK had the fourth highest rate of Covid-19 death in the world. John Hopkins University said it had the eighth highest.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Excess deaths over the past year have not been statistically higher than the average for previous years. The ONS shows that, in terms of deaths per 100,000 of population, since 1993 ten previous years have had higher rates than 2020.
extra_title: Several coronavirus claims made by MP in newspaper are inaccurate
rating_alternateName: Excess deaths in 2020 were higher than the average over previous years. Eight years since 1993 have had higher death rates.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The ONS have estimated that the restrictions across 2020 will have resulted in 200,000 non-Covid excess deaths.
extra_title: Several coronavirus claims made by MP in newspaper are inaccurate
rating_alternateName: The ONS and other public bodies estimated there may be 12,500 non-Covid early deaths due to delays in treatment in the long term. The 200,000 figure was from an earlier estimate.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Even when including those with pre-existing conditions, for the under 60s there is a 1 in 300,000 chance of death, for the over 60s there is a 99% survival rate and for the over 80s it’s still 90%.
extra_title: Several coronavirus claims made by MP in newspaper are inaccurate
rating_alternateName: The death rate given for under 60s is definitely far too low. The survival rate for over-60s appears to be too high, while the survival rate for the over 80s is more plausible. It is impossible to calculate a true death rate because we do not know how many people have been infected.

claimReview_claimReviewed: And testing also creates some revealing anomalies: the virus seems to understand the soft border between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland, for example, crediting those to the north with a far higher rate of infection. Our mortality rate – dreadful though it is - remains much the same as others’.
extra_title: Several coronavirus claims made by MP in newspaper are inaccurate
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: It is important to see, I think though, that excess deaths over the past year have not been statistically higher than the average for previous years. And the ONS reveals that, in terms of deaths per 100,000 of population, since 1993 ten previous years have had higher rates than 2020.
extra_title: Several coronavirus claims made by MP in newspaper are inaccurate
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: As I’ve said before, the ONS have estimated that the restrictions across 2020 will have resulted in 200,000 non-Covid excess deaths.
extra_title: Several coronavirus claims made by MP in newspaper are inaccurate
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Given that – even when including those with pre-existing conditions - for the under 60s, there is a 1 in 300,000 chance of death, or the over 60s, there is a 99% survival rate and for the over 80s, it’s still 90%, there is a clear alternative to hand – based on individual responsibility that we exercise in our own lives anyway.
extra_title: Several coronavirus claims made by MP in newspaper are inaccurate
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Flu is killing many more people than Covid-19 at the moment.
extra_title: Flu isn’t the underlying cause of death for more people than Covid-19
rating_alternateName: There isn’t evidence for this. Although we don’t have detailed data on recent deaths, there are almost certainly fewer deaths where flu is identified as the underlying cause compared to Covid-19.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Flu killing six times more people than coronavirus”
extra_title: Flu isn’t the underlying cause of death for more people than Covid-19
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “FLU has killed more people in the UK than coronavirus for eight weeks in a row”
extra_title: Flu isn’t the underlying cause of death for more people than Covid-19
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “In the week to the end of July, five times more people died of influenza than Covid-19 in the UK.”
extra_title: Flu isn’t the underlying cause of death for more people than Covid-19
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Boris Johnson has the support of more than half of the public to deliver Brexit by any means, including suspending Parliament, according to a poll.
extra_title: The Telegraph’s poll figures on suspending parliament are misleading
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The poll showed that 44%, not a majority, agreed with the statement. There are also other problems with the poll.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Boris Johnson has the support of more than half of the public to deliver Brexit by any means, including suspending Parliament, according to a poll.”
extra_title: The Telegraph’s poll figures on suspending parliament are misleading
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK could pay £500 million more per week for drugs following a post-Brexit trade deal with the USA.
extra_title: Paying £500 million more a week for drugs post-Brexit is based on a fairly extreme scenario
rating_alternateName: It’s certainly possible that drug prices could increase following a trade deal as this fits with US priorities from past negotiations. But the £500 million figure is a rough calculation based on a scenario that the Nuffield Trust has said is fairly extreme.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Wales has 11% of the UK railway track and gets 1% of investment.
extra_title: How much rail investment goes to Wales?
rating_alternateName: Wales has about 11% of the rail network in England and Wales. Research suggests it gets 1% of only a subset of investment spending. When you consider other investment spending, Wales gets a higher share.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We've got 11% of the railway track of the UK in Wales... How much of the government investment do we get? 1%.”
extra_title: How much rail investment goes to Wales?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Wearing a mask can cause hypercapnia, by making you breathe in too much carbon dioxide.
extra_title: Ordinary face masks are not harmful
rating_alternateName: This is not true. Wearing a mask is safe for most people. There may be rare instances of harm involving  tight-fitting N95 or FFP2 masks.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Article 61 of Magna Carta allows for lawful dissent and rebellion. It also means that businesses don’t have to close under Covid-19 regulations.
extra_title: “Article 61” of Magna Carta doesn’t allow you to ignore Covid-19 regulations
rating_alternateName: This is all incorrect. Clause 61 of the 1215 Magna Carta set out rules for 25 specific barons. It did not allow the general population to rebel, and it was also removed from subsequent versions of the document.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Covid-19 and influenza statistics are being combined to make the numbers look worse.
extra_title: Flu and Covid-19 statistics are not being added together
rating_alternateName: This is not true. Statistics about the two diseases are being published separately in the same document. This has no effect on the numbers.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Hey, why not combine Covid *and flu* statistics together to make the Covid numbers look worse than they really are! This is not a joke. This is what Public Health England is doing.”
extra_title: Flu and Covid-19 statistics are not being added together
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Aborted male foetal cells called MRC-5 are in the Covid-19 vaccine.
extra_title: There are no foetal cells in the AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine
rating_alternateName: The cell strain referenced isn’t used to manufacture the vaccine. A different cell strain, derived from kidney cells taken from a female foetus aborted in the 1970s was used to propagate the virus for the vaccine. These cells don’t make it to the final product.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Share [this video] to...anybody that doesn’t want aborted foetal tissue fragments put into them or their DNA changed
extra_title: There are no foetal cells in the AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 400,000 people are being paid to be tested every week.
extra_title: This post telling healthy people to stop getting tested is full of inaccuracies
rating_alternateName: This seems to be based on target figures for the ONS infection survey, which measures how many people currently have or have already had the virus. Participants are given vouchers. This is a different program to tests conducted under the Test & Trace scheme.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 90% of infected people have no symptoms
extra_title: This post telling healthy people to stop getting tested is full of inaccuracies
rating_alternateName: The asymptomatic rate is uncertain, although one recent study suggested that 76% of infected people had no symptoms on the day of their test.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 93% of positive tests are false.
extra_title: This post telling healthy people to stop getting tested is full of inaccuracies
rating_alternateName: No test is 100% accurate, and it’s hard to know the precise false positive rate for Covid-19 tests, but all the evidence suggests that the number is extremely low.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Lockdowns will end when healthy people stop getting tested.
extra_title: This post telling healthy people to stop getting tested is full of inaccuracies
rating_alternateName: People not getting tested will not stop lockdowns from happening. The number of tests, positive cases and things like test positivity are all used to measure the outbreak. A lack of testing might lead to an extended pandemic.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The most serious violent and sexual offenders receive automatic early release from prison halfway through their sentence.
extra_title: More prisoners to be released two thirds of the way through sentence than halfway
rating_alternateName: This is the default sentence (excluding those given life) though judges in England and Wales are already allowed to keep offenders in prison for two thirds of their sentence if they are considered dangerous.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“For the most serious violent and sexual offenders, I’m announcing this Conservative Government will abolish automatic early release at the halfway point.
“These criminals will be required to serve two-thirds of their sentence behind bars.
extra_title: More prisoners to be released two thirds of the way through sentence than halfway
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: In 2016, 18,477 cyclists were injured in road accidents, including 3,499 who were killed or seriously injured.
extra_title: How many cyclists are killed each year?
rating_alternateName: Correct for Britain. The 18,477 figure includes deaths, of which there were 102.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Of the almost 1,800 deaths that occur on our roads annually, around 450 are pedestrians in incidents where motor vehicles are involved.
extra_title: How many cyclists are killed each year?
rating_alternateName: Correct. Refers to figures for Britain in 2016.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 0.5% of pedestrian deaths are people killed by people on a bike.
extra_title: How many cyclists are killed each year?
rating_alternateName: Roughly correct, for Britain.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “In 2016 — 18,477 cyclists were injured in road accidents, including 3,499 who were killed or seriously injured.”
extra_title: How many cyclists are killed each year?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “of the almost 1,800 deaths that occur on our roads annually, around 450 are pedestrians in incidents where motor vehicles are involved. Despite these overwhelming statistics, the government has chosen to focus their time and resources on the 0.5 per cent of people who are killed by people on a bike.”
extra_title: How many cyclists are killed each year?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Stop and search is achieving a higher arrest rate.
extra_title: Stop and search: higher arrest rate?
rating_alternateName: Correct. The arrest rate in England and Wales rose from 8% in 2009/10 to 17% in 2016/17. The number of stop and searches fell from 1.3 million to 300,000 between those years.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “And what we have seen in the way stop and search is now being used, is it is achieving a higher arrest rate.”
extra_title: Stop and search: higher arrest rate?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Hundreds of convicted killers could be released from prison after a recent change to the law on 'joint enterprise'.
extra_title: Could killers convicted under 'joint enterprise' walk free from jail?
rating_alternateName: People convicted of a 'joint enterprise' killing can appeal but the Supreme Court stressed when changing the law that it wouldn't automatically overturn all such cases. It depends whether the change would be relevant to a particular case and on there being a "substantial injustice".

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Hundreds of convicted criminals including murderers could walk free after the Supreme Court ruled the law of 'joint enterprise' has been wrong interpreted by judges for 30 years”.
extra_title: Could killers convicted under 'joint enterprise' walk free from jail?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “600 prisoners including Stephen Lawrence’s killers may walk under new rules”
extra_title: Could killers convicted under 'joint enterprise' walk free from jail?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Re-offending costs up to £13 billion a year.
extra_title: Does re-offending cost £13 billion a year?
rating_alternateName: This estimate is uncertain and old. It originated in 2000 and has been inflated since then to account for price increases and changes in levels of crime. The researchers themselves say estimating these costs is "inevitably imprecise".

claimReview_claimReviewed: “This failure really matters. It matters to the public purse: this cycle of reoffending costs up to £13 billion a year.”
extra_title: Does re-offending cost £13 billion a year?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are 363 murderers in open prisons; 106 murderers have absconded from open prisons in the last 10 years; and there are 179 offenders in open prisons who've absconded before.
extra_title: Prisoners absconding: an open and shut case?
rating_alternateName: These figures are correct but not up to date. As many as 122 murderers absconded from open prisons in the decade up to 2013/2014.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "It's bad enough that in the latest figures I have there are 363 murderers in open prisons, and that 106 murderers have absconded from open prisons in the last ten years, but these figures also show that there are 179 offenders in open prisons who have previously absconded from an open prison."
extra_title: Prisoners absconding: an open and shut case?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "I can tell him we have already overhauled the process for allowing prisoners out on temporary license and that has led to a 39% drop in the number of those who breach their licence conditions. The rate of prisoners escaping from prison has reached a record low. As I understand it, prisoners with a history of escaping or absconding while on temporary release are prevented from transferring to open conditions other than in the more exceptional cases."
extra_title: Prisoners absconding: an open and shut case?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are 790 more prison officers since the beginning of 2015.
extra_title: The number of frontline prison officers is falling
rating_alternateName: This is wrong because it’s just looking at the number of people being appointed and the number of people leaving. It doesn’t factor in people who are promoted or re-graded within the service, or the hours they work. The number of prison officers is falling.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of frontline prison officers has fallen over the last year.
extra_title: The number of frontline prison officers is falling
rating_alternateName: Correct. There has been a fall of a few hundred officers, with the exact number depending on how you define the frontline.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The number of frontline officers working in public-sector prisons has fallen over the last year”
extra_title: The number of frontline prison officers is falling
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “[The official figures] actually show an improving situation … we’ve actually got a net increase in prison officers since the beginning of last year [which] now stands at 790”
extra_title: The number of frontline prison officers is falling
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are 400,000 fewer families living in poverty now than there were in 2010.
extra_title: Boris Johnson incorrect to say Keir Starmer is “completely wrong” about past trends in child poverty
rating_alternateName: We don’t know where this data comes from and have asked the government.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Absolute poverty and relative poverty have both declined under this government.
extra_title: Boris Johnson incorrect to say Keir Starmer is “completely wrong” about past trends in child poverty
rating_alternateName: Government figures show that relative low income was at the same level in 2018/19 as in 2009/10 while absolute low income fell by one percentage point. Another measure of poverty, produced by the Social Metrics Commission, does show a fall under this government.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government’s Social Mobility Commission said the number of children in poverty is expected to increase to 5.2 million by 2022.
extra_title: Boris Johnson incorrect to say Keir Starmer is “completely wrong” about past trends in child poverty
rating_alternateName: This is based on an estimate made in 2017 which estimated child poverty would be considerably higher by this point than it is. For that reason it shouldn’t be considered relevant today.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government’s Social Mobility Commission concluded there are 600,000 more children living in relative poverty than in 2012.
extra_title: Boris Johnson incorrect to say Keir Starmer is “completely wrong” about past trends in child poverty
rating_alternateName: Correct - this refers to the number of children living in low income households as defined by the government.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 1.3 million children will benefit from the government’s u-turn on funding free school meals over the summer holidays.
extra_title: Boris Johnson incorrect to say Keir Starmer is “completely wrong” about past trends in child poverty
rating_alternateName: Correct, this is roughly how many children receive free school meals in England.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
Keir Starmer: “Can I also welcome the Prime Minister's latest U-turn. This time on free school meals. That was the right thing to do, and it is vital to the 1.3 million children who will benefit.
“A report last week from the government's Social Mobility Commission concluded that there are now 600,000 more children living in relative poverty than in 2012. The report went on to say child poverty rates are projected to increase to 5.2 million by 2022.”
Boris Johnson: “He's completely wrong in what he says about poverty. Absolute poverty, relative poverty have both declined under this government and there are hundreds of thousands, I think 400,000 fewer families living in poverty now than there were in 2010.”
extra_title: Boris Johnson incorrect to say Keir Starmer is “completely wrong” about past trends in child poverty
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are half a million more children in poverty since 2010.
extra_title: No single figure about child poverty tells the whole story
rating_alternateName: This is what’s estimated to have happened to children in relative low income households, comparing 2010/11 to 2017/18. But this is one measure of several and the alternatives show smaller increases or even slight falls.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are 400,000 fewer children in poverty than there were in 2010.
extra_title: No single figure about child poverty tells the whole story
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. Main measures can be used to show anything from a fall of 100,000 to a rise of 500,000.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Actually there are 400,000 fewer children in poverty than there were in 2010.”
extra_title: No single figure about child poverty tells the whole story
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Boris Johnson has lied about the Conservatives’ record on child poverty, telling the Andrew Marr Show that “there are 400,000 fewer children in poverty than there were in 2010”, despite figures showing an increase of half a million.”
extra_title: No single figure about child poverty tells the whole story
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Millions of women have been plunged into poverty because of changes to the pension age made in 2011.
extra_title: Angela Rayner uses exaggerated figure for number of WASPI women in poverty
rating_alternateName: This is an exaggeration. We don’t know the exact number but it is likely substantially lower.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “[On changes to the state pension age made in 2011] It is completely unacceptable and millions of women have been plunged into poverty…”
extra_title: Angela Rayner uses exaggerated figure for number of WASPI women in poverty
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK is the fifth richest country in the world.
extra_title: Claim about UK wealth and poverty is flawed
rating_alternateName: In terms of total GDP, it is the sixth- or ninth-richest, depending on which measure you use. In terms of GDP per capita, it is the 20th- or 27th-richest.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 14 million people are living in poverty.
extra_title: Claim about UK wealth and poverty is flawed
rating_alternateName: Correct for the UK in 2017/18, according to the main measure of relative poverty used in the UK.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “14 million people are living in poverty in ours, the fifth richest country in the world”
extra_title: Claim about UK wealth and poverty is flawed
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The vast majority of the public strongly objects to the government’s plan to pay £39 billion to Brussels.
extra_title: Beer mat Brexit: do the facts stack up?
rating_alternateName: A poll found that 75% of respondents said paying an EU exit fee of up to £40 billion was unacceptable. But responses to these questions depend on how the question is framed.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Lawyers have repeatedly said that there is no legal obligation for the UK to pay to leave the EU.
extra_title: Beer mat Brexit: do the facts stack up?
rating_alternateName: Some lawyers have said this, but there are differing legal views on the matter.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The EU imposes taxes or “tariffs” on rice, oranges, coffee, wine, children’s clothes and other non-EU imports.
extra_title: Beer mat Brexit: do the facts stack up?
rating_alternateName: Correct, though not all non-EU trade is subject to tariffs. The EU has arrangements—including trade deals—with non-EU countries that reduce or remove these tariffs.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Ending tariffs means lower prices in shops and pubs.
extra_title: Beer mat Brexit: do the facts stack up?
rating_alternateName: Not necessarily. The Institute for Fiscal Studies estimates that a reduction in consumer prices from reducing tariffs would be wiped out by extra costs imposed by the UK leaving the EU customs union.

claimReview_claimReviewed: People pay for tariffs set by the EU every time they shop—and the government collects the money and sends it to Brussels.
extra_title: Beer mat Brexit: do the facts stack up?
rating_alternateName: Correct. A proportion of this money is then spent in the UK on EU-funded projects, though less than most other EU countries.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 93% of the world is not in the EU.
extra_title: Beer mat Brexit: do the facts stack up?
rating_alternateName: Correct, looking at the world’s population. About 78% of the world’s economic output is estimated to be outside of the EU.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, Switzerland and Canada have slashed tariffs—their citizens are better off as a result, and their economies have thrived.
extra_title: Beer mat Brexit: do the facts stack up?
rating_alternateName: Uncertain. This is a very broad claim, and it is hard to attribute the performance of any economy to one factor such as reducing tariffs.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The USA and India are keen to do trade deals with the UK.
extra_title: Beer mat Brexit: do the facts stack up?
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: We can leave the EU with no deal and negotiate a free trade agreement during the transition period.
extra_title: Brexit withdrawal deal and future trade deal—what’s the difference?
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The transition period is part of the withdrawal agreement. Leaving the EU with no deal means there’s no transition period – though we could still try and negotiate a free trade agreement following a no-deal Brexit.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Brexit withdrawal deal doesn’t guarantee we’d stay in a customs union.
extra_title: Brexit withdrawal deal and future trade deal—what’s the difference?
rating_alternateName: Technically correct, but the withdrawal agreement isn’t meant to deal with future trade. It does outline a backup trade deal which involves something similar to a customs union, but the permanent future trade relationship is a matter for future negotiations.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If we need to leave with no deal and negotiate a free trade agreement during the transition period, so be it”.
extra_title: Brexit withdrawal deal and future trade deal—what’s the difference?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “May’s deal doesn’t guarantee we’d stay in a customs union”.
extra_title: Brexit withdrawal deal and future trade deal—what’s the difference?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Theresa May should drop her deal, extend the implementation period to the end of 2021 if necessary; use it to negotiate a free trade deal; pay the fee; but come out of the EU now—without the backstop.
extra_title: You can’t have an “implementation period” after Brexit without a deal
rating_alternateName: The implementation period is part of Mrs May’s deal—in order to leave the EU imminently and still have an implementation period the UK would need to pass that deal.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“How will we be able to take back control of our laws? Will we really do free trade deals? And can we really go on with a negotiating team that has so resoundingly failed? If she cannot give that evidence of change—she should drop the deal, and go back to Brussels, and simply set out the terms that so many on both sides—remainers and leavers— now believe are sensible.
“Extend the implementation period to the end of 2021 if necessary; use it to negotiate a free trade deal; pay the fee; but come out of the EU now—without the backstop. It is time for the PM to channel the spirit of Moses in Exodus, and say to Pharaoh in Brussels—LET MY PEOPLE GO.
extra_title: You can’t have an “implementation period” after Brexit without a deal
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: We can get a standstill in our current trade arrangements with the EU under Article 24 of GATT, while we negotiate a free trade agreement.
extra_title: Boris Johnson repeats an old line about “GATT Article 24”
rating_alternateName: Article 24 does not remove the need to strike a deal with the EU, and experts have said an agreement using this is unlikely to happen.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “There will be no tariffs, there will be no quotas because what we want to do is to get a standstill in our current arrangements under GATT 24, or whatever it happens to be, until such a time as we have negotiated the [free trade agreement].”
extra_title: Boris Johnson repeats an old line about “GATT Article 24”
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: If we leave the EU on WTO terms, Article 24 of the World Trade Organisation would allow the UK and EU to maintain zero tariffs for up to 10 years while negotiating a new deal with the EU.
extra_title: Does WTO Article 24 allow us to have tariff-free trade with the EU?
rating_alternateName: This is very unlikely in practice. This refers to Article 24 of the WTO’s General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. It allows countries who are negotiating a free-trade area or customs union to have an interim agreement on trade tariffs for a period of (in most cases) up to ten years provided they have a “plan and schedule” agreed for concluding a final deal. It’s unlikely we could have such a “plan and schedule” in place with the EU before we leave.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "If you are in a negotiation for a free trade agreement, you can maintain your existing standards for ten years under WTO rules. So we have ten years from the point at which we leave the European Union to negotiate a free trade agreement with the EU which would mean we can carry on with our zero tariffs."
extra_title: Does WTO Article 24 allow us to have tariff-free trade with the EU?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If we have a short temporary period in which we have set up a genuine agreement with the European Union, then we can invoke article 24—which I am not sure many people have heard of—of the general agreement on tariffs and trade, which enables us to go on at the current rate of zero tariffs for a reasonable length of time, potentially up to 10 years, so we can carry on exactly as we are.”
extra_title: Does WTO Article 24 allow us to have tariff-free trade with the EU?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “In fact, we will never need to trade on world trade terms with Europe either. Article 24 of the World Trade Organisation treaty allows us to continue to trade with Europe on zero tariffs while we negotiate a free trade arrangement.”
extra_title: Does WTO Article 24 allow us to have tariff-free trade with the EU?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The EU is asking for a 100 billion Brexit divorce bill.
extra_title: The EU "divorce bill"
rating_alternateName: The EU says that the UK should pay a share of money that’s already been committed to various projects. There is no official bill from them yet—and any bill will be a matter for negotiations. €100 billion is much higher than other estimates.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 60% of our trade is through EU trade agreements.
extra_title: Over half of UK exports were via EU trade agreements in 2016
rating_alternateName: In 2016, around 54% of UK exports went to states with which the EU had a full or provisional trade agreement (including EU member states).

claimReview_claimReviewed: “In the modern world, 60% of our trade, if you count all the EU deals that we're members of, 60% of our trade is in trade agreements.”
extra_title: Over half of UK exports were via EU trade agreements in 2016
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Millions of people who voted Leave did not vote for Theresa May’s hard Brexit.
extra_title: Public support for a "hard Brexit"
rating_alternateName: We can’t know for certain. More recent polling could be used to show this—if being against a “hard Brexit” is defined as prioritising free trade over immigration control.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “There were also millions of people who voted Leave but did not vote for Theresa May's hard Brexit”
extra_title: Public support for a "hard Brexit"
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: You can’t be a member of the European single market without being a member of the EU.
extra_title: Can you be in the single market without being an EU member?
rating_alternateName: It’s technically possible for a non-EU member to be in the single market but it requires accepting a lot of rules set by the EU.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "You can't be a member of the single market without effectively still being a member of the European Union."
extra_title: Can you be in the single market without being an EU member?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "The single market is dependent on membership of the EU."
extra_title: Can you be in the single market without being an EU member?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 650,000 jobs in London are dependent on the single market.
extra_title: How many jobs are dependent on the single market?
rating_alternateName: This is wrong. Treasury estimates suggest this many jobs in London are associated with exports to the EU.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “650,000 jobs in London alone are dependent on the single market”
extra_title: How many jobs are dependent on the single market?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Leaving Euratom will not affect the UK’s ability to import medical radioisotopes - which are used to diagnose and treat certain kinds of cancer.
extra_title: Could leaving the European nuclear club put cancer patients at risk?
rating_alternateName: This isn’t certain, and will depend on what future arrangements are negotiated. The UK may find it harder to guarantee a supply after leaving.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“What assessment have the Government made of the effect on radiotherapy for cancer patients of their decision to withdraw from Euratom…?”
Pat McFadden MP
“... Let me set out the position: the import or export of medical radioactive isotopes is not subject to any Euratom licensing requirements. Euratom places no restrictions on exports to countries outside the EU so after leaving Euratom our ability to access medical isotopes produced in Europe will not be affected.”
extra_title: Could leaving the European nuclear club put cancer patients at risk?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Labour Party wouldn't have problems with the Irish backstop because it wants the whole of the United Kingdom to be in a permanent customs union with the EU.
extra_title: Does Labour's Brexit policy mean no Irish backstop?
rating_alternateName: Labour’s proposed Brexit policy may avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic (removing the need for the Irish backstop) in theory. But it seems extremely unlikely that the EU would accept those proposals alongside everything else Labour wants from Brexit.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “[Labour] wouldn’t have all this problem with the backstop etc because we want the whole of the United Kingdom to be in a permanent customs union with the EU.”
extra_title: Does Labour's Brexit policy mean no Irish backstop?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 30,000 British pensioners freeze to death each year.
extra_title: There were 25,260 excess winter deaths across all ages in Great Britain last year
rating_alternateName: About 25,260 excess deaths occurred in GB over winter 2018/19—a lower number than in recent years—and most were in people of pension age. Cold weather is a major contributor to these deaths, but there are a number of causes.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Pets carry no threat and do not carry the new coronavirus.
extra_title: There’s still no evidence that you can catch the new coronavirus from your pet
rating_alternateName: This is correct. At present, there’s no evidence that dogs and cats can be infected.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Pets carry no threat and DONT CARRY THE VIRUS.
extra_title: There’s still no evidence that you can catch the new coronavirus from your pet
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A Radox bath product contains the ingredient clary sage which can induce labour in pregnant women and should never be used during pregnancy, especially in the first and second trimester.
extra_title: Clary sage in Radox isn’t dangerous for pregnant women
rating_alternateName: The Office for Product Safety and Standards told us there’s no evidence that clary sage would be dangerous for pregnant women in the quantities found in bath products.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If you think you’re having a heart attack, coughing repeatedly and vigorously could help you.
extra_title: Don’t attempt ‘cough CPR’ if you think you’re having a heart attack
rating_alternateName: This should not be attempted. If you think you or someone else is having a heart attack you should call 999 immediately.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If you get stabbed, open a tampon and whack it in the wound. The tampon will swell, which creates pressure and stops the bleeding.
extra_title: You shouldn’t put a tampon in a stab wound
rating_alternateName: Several first aid experts told us not to do this, as it may not work and could risk further harm. You should put pressure on the wound with something like a bandage, towel, or even a piece of clothing, and call 999.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If you call 999 in an emergency but can’t speak, press 55 and they can track where you are calling from using new technology.
extra_title: It’s not true that dialling 55 in a silent 999 call lets the police track your location
rating_alternateName: If you can’t talk during a 999 call, dialling 55 should route your call to the police. But it won’t automatically track your location, and it’s not always possible to pinpoint your exact location if calling from a mobile.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The formation of “non-neutralizing antibodies” can lead to an exaggerated immune reaction, especially when the person is confronted with the real, “wild” virus after vaccination. This so-called antibody-dependent amplification, ADE, has long been known from experiments with corona vaccines in cats.
extra_title: Claims about the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine ingredients lack evidence
rating_alternateName: There’s no evidence antibody-dependent amplification is an issue in humans with Covid-19, and the use of plasma therapy suggests that it is not.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The studies into Covid-19 vaccines are too short to see if there are late effects. There were narcolepsy cases after the swine flu vaccination, and similarly this vaccine could put millions at risk.
extra_title: Claims about the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine ingredients lack evidence
rating_alternateName: It’s true that the swine flu vaccine was associated with a small increase in the risk of narcolepsy in children and young people. But the vaccine’s effects will continue to be monitored as it is rolled out, and so far it is not being given to children.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The mRNA vaccines from BioNTech/Pfizer contain polyethylene glycol (PEG). 70% of people develop antibodies against this substance—this means many people can develop allergic, potentially fatal reactions to the vaccination.
extra_title: Claims about the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine ingredients lack evidence
rating_alternateName: It’s true that the vaccine contains this, but in very small amounts. In some rare cases people are allergic to PEG and one study found 72% of samples were found to contain mostly low levels of antibodies against it, but that doesn’t necessarily mean that many will have an allergic reaction.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The mRNA vaccines from BioNTech/Pfizer contain polyethylene glycol (PEG). 70% of people develop antibodies against this substance – this means that many people can develop allergic, potentially fatal reactions to the vaccination.
extra_title: Claims about the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine ingredients lack evidence
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The formation of so-called “non-neutralizing antibodies” can lead to an exaggerated immune reaction, especially when the test person is confronted with the real, “wild” virus after vaccination. This so-called antibody-dependent amplification, ADE, has long been known from experiments with corona vaccines in cats, for example. In the course of these studies all cats that initially tolerated the vaccination well died after catching the wild virus.
extra_title: Claims about the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine ingredients lack evidence
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The much too short duration of the study does not allow a realistic estimation of the late effects. As in the narcolepsy cases after the swine flu vaccination, millions of healthy people would be exposed to an unacceptable risk if an emergency approval were to be granted and the possibility of observing the late effects of the vaccination were to follow.
extra_title: Claims about the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine ingredients lack evidence
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The vaccinations are expected to produce antibodies against spike proteins of SARS-CoV-2. However, spike proteins also contain syncytin-homologous proteins, which are essential for the formation of the placenta in mammals such as humans.
extra_title: Claims about the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine ingredients lack evidence
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 27% of Conservative voters say they will ditch Boris Johnson over bike lanes.
extra_title: Survey doesn’t show voters ditching Conservatives over bike lanes
rating_alternateName: There are too many problems with this survey to draw this conclusion.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We will ditch Boris Johnson over bike lanes, say 27 percent of Tory voters.”
extra_title: Survey doesn’t show voters ditching Conservatives over bike lanes
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Of all the positive Covid tests of the 9,000+ students at Cambridge University tested in the week to 6 December, every single one was found to be a false positive after a second test.
extra_title: Cambridge Covid-19 test results don’t mean PCR tests are inaccurate
rating_alternateName: This is correct for one week of testing. Of the ten group swabs which initially tested positive, none tested positive after a second test carried out later. In previous weeks, most positive tests were confirmed by later tests.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK government no longer considers Covid-19 to be a “high consequence infectious disease”.
extra_title: Covid-19 may not be a “high consequence infectious disease”, but it is a real emergency
rating_alternateName: This is true, because it no longer meets the criteria for an HCID. This doesn’t mean that it is no longer considered dangerous.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The NHS Covid-19 vaccination card will be used to prove who has been vaccinated.
extra_title: The new vaccination card is not a ‘Covid passport’
rating_alternateName: This is not true. The card contains a record of someone’s vaccination and a reminder of their second appointment date, but it does not contain secure personal information so it cannot prove who was vaccinated.

claimReview_claimReviewed: People who receive the NHS Covid-19 vaccination card must keep it with them all the time.
extra_title: The new vaccination card is not a ‘Covid passport’
rating_alternateName: This is not true. People are not required to carry the card.

claimReview_claimReviewed: About 1% of the population is infected with Covid-19 today.
extra_title: The number of people dying right now is not the same as in any other year
rating_alternateName: According to the most recent data, this is about right.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of people dying today is the same as it would be in any other year.
extra_title: The number of people dying right now is not the same as in any other year
rating_alternateName: This is not correct. Deaths in the week to 6 November were 14% higher than the average across the past five years, and higher than the maximum across the past five years.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Deaths from flu and pneumonia have been replaced with Covid-19.
extra_title: The number of people dying right now is not the same as in any other year
rating_alternateName: While the figures point towards a decrease in the number of deaths caused by flu and pneumonia, this has not just been replaced with deaths from Covid-19, which far exceed that possible shortfall.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “I’ll give you the absolute numbers today and people can then take that away and make their own decisions about how scared to be. So in terms of people actually infected today, it’s probably around 1% of the population. But the vast majority of those will have no symptoms and if you’re under about 65 then it’s less risk than regular flu. The number of people dying today is the same as it would be in any other year in total. People are dying of respiratory diseases today, it’s about the same as it normally would be. The thing is they would normally die of flu and pneumonia—those diseases are very, very much reduced this year and it’s been replaced with Covid.”
extra_title: The number of people dying right now is not the same as in any other year
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Blue surgical masks are sprayed with PTFE, which is harmful to humans.
extra_title: PTFE in masks does not pose a health risk, unless you get it very hot
rating_alternateName: Some masks contain PTFE, but ordinary surgical masks are often made from other materials. PTFE is not generally harmful to humans.

claimReview_claimReviewed: PTFE in masks can lead to symptoms such as fever, chest tightness, shortness of breath, headache, cough, chills, sore throat.
extra_title: PTFE in masks does not pose a health risk, unless you get it very hot
rating_alternateName: This appears to be describing polymer fume fever, which only happens if someone is exposed to PTFE heated to high temperatures.

extra_title: No, we are not on track for a normal number of deaths this year
rating_alternateName: Correct. These are the numbers of deaths registered in the UK for each year.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of deaths so far this year in the UK (up to week 39) has been 454,000.
extra_title: No, we are not on track for a normal number of deaths this year
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. This is the figure for England and Wales only. For the UK as a whole it is 513,987.

claimReview_claimReviewed: We are on course to have a death toll this year in line with recent years.
extra_title: No, we are not on track for a normal number of deaths this year
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. Unless deaths decline sharply, the UK death toll is likely to be its highest in decades.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government advice is not to challenge someone who is not wearing a face covering.
extra_title: Challenging someone for not wearing a face mask isn’t against the Equality Act
rating_alternateName: The government says members of the public should not challenge people for not wearing a face covering, but people who work in premises where face coverings are required can. They should be “mindful and respectful” of those who are exempt.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If you do challenge someone, you could be fined under the Equality Act 2010.
extra_title: Challenging someone for not wearing a face mask isn’t against the Equality Act
rating_alternateName: This is not correct. Asking someone to wear a face covering is unlikely to be discrimination, as long as you follow government guidance.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There is only a 0.26% chance of catching Covid-19.
extra_title: The asteroid which might enter Earth’s atmosphere on 2 November will not “hit” Earth
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The US CDC published figures suggesting the chance of dying from Covid-19 after being infected was 0.26% and has since updated these figures. The chance of catching Covid-19 is much higher than that in many countries, including the UK.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There is a 0.42% chance of an asteroid hitting Earth on 2 November.
extra_title: The asteroid which might enter Earth’s atmosphere on 2 November will not “hit” Earth
rating_alternateName: NASA says there is a 0.41% chance of an asteroid entering Earth’s atmosphere but, if so, it is so small it would burn up in the atmosphere before “hitting Earth.”

claimReview_claimReviewed: Covid-19 is no worse than a bad flu season.
extra_title: London Mayor candidate wrong to claim Covid-19 pandemic is no worse than a flu season
rating_alternateName: This is a flawed comparison, as the number of deaths from Covid-19 far exceeds the number of deaths from flu in a given season, despite the much stricter controls in place.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The politicians and the media have a very, very poor understanding of science and mathematics and they’ve pursued and pushed a narrative that the coronavirus—Covid-19—is far, far worse and more dangerous than it actually is. The reality is that it’s no worse than a bad flu season.”
extra_title: London Mayor candidate wrong to claim Covid-19 pandemic is no worse than a flu season
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The truth is that the science and the maths and the statistics show that this whole made up coronavirus pandemic is no worse than in a normal flu season.”
extra_title: London Mayor candidate wrong to claim Covid-19 pandemic is no worse than a flu season
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 18 people died of Covid-19 in one day in England.
extra_title: These figures for non-Covid deaths aren’t accurate
rating_alternateName: This is true.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 1,295 died of a stroke in England in one day.
extra_title: These figures for non-Covid deaths aren’t accurate
rating_alternateName: This is likely not true. Stroke death figures in England are closer to 65 people daily.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 1,852 people died in one day in England from a heart attack.
extra_title: These figures for non-Covid deaths aren’t accurate
rating_alternateName: This is likely not true. About 49 people a day die in England of a heart attack.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 39 people were murdered in one day in England.
extra_title: These figures for non-Covid deaths aren’t accurate
rating_alternateName: This is likely untrue. We could find no evidence of a recent mass homicide, and on average two people die of homicide each day in England.
