claimReview_claimReviewed: The British public believe that 7% of the UK population has died from Coronavirus, a number 100 times higher than the recorded-death reality.
extra_title: Why this poll gives a misleading view on how many people the public think Covid-19 has killed
rating_alternateName: This uses a mean average which isn’t appropriate in this context. Using the median, the average Brit thought that 1% of the GB population had died of Covid-19.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Over 200,000 nurses have quit the NHS since 2010.
extra_title: Have 200,000 nurses quit the NHS?
rating_alternateName: This figure covers all nurses and health visitors who have left the NHS in England in the last eight years, including those with an unknown reason for leaving as well as those who have retired or died in service. Overall the number of nurses working in the NHS is slightly higher than in 2010.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Labour reveals over 200,000 nurses have quit the NHS since 2010.”
extra_title: Have 200,000 nurses quit the NHS?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Leicester is going back into lockdown soon after 5G was rolled out there.
extra_title: Leicester going back into lockdown has nothing to do with 5G
rating_alternateName: 5G coverage was available in Leicester by November 2019, months before Covid-19 was detected in the UK. 5G is not linked to cases of Covid-19. Leicester had some lockdown restrictions re-imposed because the number of cases there was increasing.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A peer-reviewed research paper says that the new coronavirus has been artificially engineered.
extra_title: A Norwegian-British research paper doesn’t claim the virus causing Covid-19 was man-made
rating_alternateName: A Norwegian virologist has made claims about the non-natural origins of the new coronavirus. But this claim is not in a new peer-reviewed paper he co-authored. The scientific community widely agrees that the virus was not artificially engineered.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Sørensen and Dagleish say that the RNA sequence of the virus includes inserts which could not have occurred naturally in zoonotic [animal] transfer. Now for the benefit of non-scientists...that means the coronavirus was engineered in a laboratory.”
extra_title: A Norwegian-British research paper doesn’t claim the virus causing Covid-19 was man-made
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Microsoft and Bill Gates have filed a patent numbered 060606 for a microchip which is inserted into the body and which rewards activity with cryptocurrency.
extra_title: Patent application 060606 does not mention inserting microchips into the body
rating_alternateName: Microsoft's 060606 patent doesn't reference injectable microchips. It is true that Microsoft has a patent application with the numbers 060606 in it, but it's for a system which rewards physical activity with cryptocurrency.

claimReview_claimReviewed: How many who have no other morbidities under the age of 60 have died from this Covid-19? 350
extra_title: It’s not right that you’re more likely to drown than die of Covid-19 if you’re under 60 with no health problems
rating_alternateName: The latest NHS figures for England show that 253 people under the age of 60 with no underlying health conditions have died from Covid-19 in hospitals.

claimReview_claimReviewed: You’re more likely to drown than die from Covid-19.
extra_title: It’s not right that you’re more likely to drown than die of Covid-19 if you’re under 60 with no health problems
rating_alternateName: This is not a valid comparison to make, and the figures it’s based on aren’t accurate.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are 400 people a year who drown
extra_title: It’s not right that you’re more likely to drown than die of Covid-19 if you’re under 60 with no health problems
rating_alternateName: In 2018, 263 people died in accidental drownings in the UK.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK is already in the largest recession for 300 years.
extra_title: It’s not right that you’re more likely to drown than die of Covid-19 if you’re under 60 with no health problems
rating_alternateName: The Bank of England has suggested this could be correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Bank of England has said the economy will shrink 14% - the equivalent of two recessions.
extra_title: It’s not right that you’re more likely to drown than die of Covid-19 if you’re under 60 with no health problems
rating_alternateName: The Bank has predicted this could happen. If it does, the recession would be more than twice as big as in 2008.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“How many people who have no other morbidities under the age of 60 have died from this illness? [...] 350. You’re more likely to drown. There are 400 people a year that drown. 
“I think we have to put things a bit in context. Every death is tragic but believe me we are entering, we are already in, the largest recession for 300 years. In fact, it’s not one recession. The Bank of England have said the economy will shrink by 14%. That’s the equivalent of two recessions, it’s a depression.
extra_title: It’s not right that you’re more likely to drown than die of Covid-19 if you’re under 60 with no health problems
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Boris Johnson refused 50,000 ventilators offered by the EU.
extra_title: No, the UK didn’t turn down 50,000 ventilators offered by the EU
rating_alternateName: This is not true. The UK did not join an EU scheme to stockpile medical equipment, but this is not the same as turning down 50,000 ventilators.The total budget of the scheme wouldn’t have covered this many ventilators.

claimReview_claimReviewed: In June 2017 Conservative MPs voted against a pay rise for nurses.
extra_title: Claim that Conservatives voted against a nurse pay rise needs some context
rating_alternateName:
In June 2017 Conservative MPs voted against a Queen’s speech amendment calling on them to lift a cap on public sector pay rises, but later that year went on to lift the cap anyway. 

In 2018/19 nurse pay rose by more than the previous cap of 1%, but in some cases will still only have stayed at the same level in real terms.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Elephant tusks and rhino horns are being dyed pink to stop poachers killing these animals.
extra_title: The images in this post about the rhino horn and ivory trade have been digitally altered but the scheme is real
rating_alternateName: This claims refers to a real scheme to deter poachers, but dyeing rhino horns does not lead to the bright exterior as the picture suggests—the pictures have been doctored. This scheme has only been used on rhinos, not elephants.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Labour’s planned welfare spending will cost £520 billion.
extra_title: Claim about cost of Labour’s welfare policy is unsubstantiated
rating_alternateName: This is based on the assumption that the Labour Party introduces universal basic income for all adults at a certain level. It has so far only said it will trial such a scheme if it gets into government and not released much detail on how such a scheme would work.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Labour’s universal basic income policy would cost £504 billion.
extra_title: Claim about cost of Labour’s welfare policy is unsubstantiated
rating_alternateName: This is based on the assumption that the Labour Party introduces universal basic income for all adults at a certain level. It has so far only said it will trial such a scheme if it gets into government and not released much detail on how such a scheme would work.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Labour is planning an eye-watering benefits splurge that would cost taxpayers around £520 billion a year, analysis has found..."
extra_title: Claim about cost of Labour’s welfare policy is unsubstantiated
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Greenwich council is set to remove a memorial stone to Lee Rigby.
extra_title: Greenwich Council have removed a Lee Rigby memorial
rating_alternateName: When this article was originally written, Greenwich council told us they didn’t have plans to remove the stone. It has since been removed and replaced with an official memorial.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Diane Abbott said that Chairman Mao did more good than harm.
extra_title: Diane Abbott did say that Chairman Mao did more good than harm
rating_alternateName: Correct. During an episode of This Week in 2008 she said “I suppose that some people would judge that on balance Mao did more good than harm”.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government is only reconfiguring six new hospitals rather than building 40.
extra_title: The government has given six hospitals money to upgrade buildings
rating_alternateName: In its latest announcement the government has committed the money to upgrade six hospitals by 2025. Up to 38 other hospitals have received money to plan for building work between 2025 and 2030, but not to actually begin any work.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government is building 40 new hospitals over the next decade.
extra_title: The government has given six hospitals money to upgrade buildings
rating_alternateName: Six hospitals in England have been given the money to upgrade their buildings within the next five years. Up to 38 hospitals are being given money to develop plans for their hospitals between 2025 and 2030, but not to actually begin any building work.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “I've been launching our programme to build 40 new hospitals in this country”
extra_title: The government has given six hospitals money to upgrade buildings
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Over the next decade we will build, not ten, not twenty, but forty new state of the art hospitals.”
extra_title: The government has given six hospitals money to upgrade buildings
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Yet again a Boris Johnson health announcement has quickly unravelled as spin. This isn’t 40 new hospitals, it is just reconfiguring six.”
extra_title: The government has given six hospitals money to upgrade buildings
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The NHS is getting an extra £34 billion, that’s the biggest increase in modern memory.
extra_title: The £20.5 billion NHS England spending increase is the largest five year increase since the mid-2000s
rating_alternateName: The £34 billion is a spending increase in real terms of £20.5 billion between 2018/19 and 2023/24. The last time spending increased by at least that amount was between 2004/05 and 2009/10.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “This one-nation Tory party that has already embarked on the biggest cash boost for the NHS for a generation.”
extra_title: The £20.5 billion NHS England spending increase is the largest five year increase since the mid-2000s
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “In this one nation conservative government we’re putting record sum in [to the NHS], £34 billion.”
extra_title: The £20.5 billion NHS England spending increase is the largest five year increase since the mid-2000s
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The figure that we're spending is £34 billion - it’s the biggest increase in modern memory in the NHS.”
extra_title: The £20.5 billion NHS England spending increase is the largest five year increase since the mid-2000s
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Labour’s spending plans would cost £1.2 trillion over five years.
extra_title: There are serious problems with the Conservatives’ claim that Labour would spend £1.2 trillion
rating_alternateName: Labour hasn’t published its 2019 manifesto yet, so nobody knows. This is largely based on Labour’s previous policy announcements. Many of the figures behind this estimate are uncertain or based on flawed assumptions.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Corbyn’s Labour would spend £1.2 trillion over the next five years if they get elected”.
extra_title: There are serious problems with the Conservatives’ claim that Labour would spend £1.2 trillion
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Brexit deal has passed Parliament.
extra_title: The Brexit deal has not passed Parliament
rating_alternateName: It has not.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Labour policies would save the average family £6,700.
extra_title: Labour claims about savings under their policies are not credible
rating_alternateName: This figure is not credible and does not represent what an average family would save.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Costs to the average family have risen by almost £6,000 since 2010.
extra_title: Labour claims about savings under their policies are not credible
rating_alternateName: This figure is exaggerated and does not represent what an average family has had to pay.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Conservatives' failure to curb rising bills has cost families almost £6,000 a year since 2010… Labour’s plan for real change will save average families over £6,700.
extra_title: Labour claims about savings under their policies are not credible
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Over 200,000 nurses have resigned since 2010.
extra_title: Claim about social care spending and nurse numbers needs more context
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. This figure covers all nurses and health visitors who have left the NHS in England from 2010 to 2018, including those with an unknown reason for leaving as well as those who have retired or died in service. Overall the number of nurses working in the NHS is higher than in 2010.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Social care has been slashed by £7.7 billion since 2010.
extra_title: Claim about social care spending and nurse numbers needs more context
rating_alternateName: This figure refers to the savings councils in England report having had to make since 2010 on adult social care spending—through things like efficiency measures, renegotiating contracts, innovation, reducing and stopping services. It’s not the amount their budgets were reduced by, which have fallen by much less.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Since 2010, social care has been slashed by £7.7 billion. Over 200,000 nurses have resigned.”
extra_title: Claim about social care spending and nurse numbers needs more context
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Sinn Féin MPs don’t get salaries.
extra_title: Why Sinn Féin MPs don’t get salaries
rating_alternateName: Correct. Sinn Féin MPs and the party do receive other money for expenses.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“There is no desire to be in there and to be part of it… The interests of Ireland have never been represented by a Westminster Parliament
 Chris Hazzard MP
“Why do you take the salary?
 Victoria Derbyshire
“I don’t take the salary... I don’t get a salary from Westminster
extra_title: Why Sinn Féin MPs don’t get salaries
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Nearly 99% of Covid-19 patients who are vitamin D deficient die, according to a research study.
extra_title: Covid-19 study that links deaths to low vitamin D levels is flawed
rating_alternateName: A study from Indonesia did claim to show this, but there are problems with the study methods that mean it doesn’t prove this is the case. The paper has now been removed by the authors from the online research library it appeared on.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Nearly 99 per cent of Covid-19 patients who are vitamin D deficient die, according to a terrifying study”
extra_title: Covid-19 study that links deaths to low vitamin D levels is flawed
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The results revealed 98.9 percent of infected patients who suffer with a vitamin D deficiency lost their lives to COVID-19”
extra_title: Covid-19 study that links deaths to low vitamin D levels is flawed
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Gargling water mixed with salt or vinegar eliminates the new coronavirus from your throat.
extra_title: Drinking and gargling water will not cure the new coronavirus
rating_alternateName: There is no evidence for this.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Drinking lots of water will eliminate the new coronavirus from your throat.
extra_title: Drinking and gargling water will not cure the new coronavirus
rating_alternateName: There is no evidence for this. It is a common myth.

claimReview_claimReviewed: To test for the new coronavirus, take a deep breath and hold for more than 10 seconds. If you complete it successfully without coughing, discomfort, stuffiness or tightness it proves there is no fibrosis in the lungs, basically indicating no infection.
extra_title: Holding your breath is not an indicator of whether you have the new coronavirus, and drinking water doesn’t protect against it
rating_alternateName: There is no evidence to suggest this test can show if you have the new coronavirus.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If the new coronavirus gets into your mouth, drinking water or other liquids will wash them down through the oesophagus. Once they’re in the stomach, the acid will kill the virus. If you don't drink enough water more regularly, the virus can enter your windpipes and into the lungs.
extra_title: Holding your breath is not an indicator of whether you have the new coronavirus, and drinking water doesn’t protect against it
rating_alternateName: This is incorrect. Drinking water does not prevent an infection and there have been cases where the virus has survived in the stomach and affected people’s intestines.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The alkaline diet has benefits based on its combatting of acidic conditions in the body.
extra_title: This post incorrectly claims everyone with cancer has a pH that is too acidic
rating_alternateName: There is no evidence to support this

claimReview_claimReviewed: People with cancer have a pH that is too acidic.
extra_title: This post incorrectly claims everyone with cancer has a pH that is too acidic
rating_alternateName: This is unfounded.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Dr Otto Warburg won the Nobel Prize for showing that cancer cannot survive in an alkaline, oxygen-rich environment, but thrives in an acidic, low oxygen environment.
extra_title: This post incorrectly claims everyone with cancer has a pH that is too acidic
rating_alternateName: This is incorrect, he won for his discovery of the nature and mode of action of the respiratory enzyme.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Dettol antiseptic spray says it kills human coronavirus.
extra_title: The makers of Dettol did not know about the new Wuhan coronavirus before the rest of us
rating_alternateName: That is correct but that doesn’t mean that Dettol spray can kill the new coronavirus identified in Wuhan. Coronavirus is a category of viruses that includes the common cold, and it is likely this the label is referring to.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Bank of England governor says that post-Brexit trade deals could lead to “a golden age of trade”.
extra_title: Mark Carney didn’t say Brexit could usher in “a golden age of trade”
rating_alternateName: Mr Carney’s speech yesterday did not use these words. It did discuss both opportunities and risks from Brexit, but to describe his comments as suggesting a “golden age of trade” is misleading.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “And will [the Prime Minister] also rule out a future customs union arrangement which would prevent us doing those global trade deals, which the Bank of England governor says is a potential golden age of trade?”
extra_title: Mark Carney didn’t say Brexit could usher in “a golden age of trade”
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The European Commission is setting up an EU army to protect the borders.
extra_title: A new EU border agency, or an EU army?
rating_alternateName: This refers to Commission proposals for a new border agency with increased powers, including the ability to operate in a country despite its objections. Most, if not all, of its border guards would be provided by member countries. The UK isn't covered by this plan.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "EU army to protect borders… the European Union's first paramilitary force would have the power to take control of a nation's borders"
extra_title: A new EU border agency, or an EU army?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "British guards will join an armed European Union border force… Critics last night warned the creation of the body... was in effect the formation of an "'EU navy'"
extra_title: A new EU border agency, or an EU army?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The head of the EU law enforcement agency says that 5,000 terrorists have come into the EU because of its migration policy.
extra_title: Have 5,000 jihadis come into the EU?
rating_alternateName: Rob Wainwright denies that he said any such thing. Europol’s official position is that up to 5,000 EU citizens may have been radicalised and travelled to fight in the Middle East, but perhaps a third of those have returned to Europe, of which a majority aren’t considered a threat.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “That same boss of Europol said that the [EU’s] migration policy… has led to up to 5,000 jihadis coming into the European Union in the space of the last 15 months.”
extra_title: Have 5,000 jihadis come into the EU?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are plans for an EU army.
extra_title: The hunt for an EU army
rating_alternateName: EU member countries work together on military matters, but the EU doesn't have its own military capabilities. At least a few European politicians do support the creation of an EU army, but that would need unanimous approval.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "This is a dangerous fantasy. The idea that there's going to be a European air force, a European army, it is simply not true."
extra_title: The hunt for an EU army
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker has called for the creation of a European army"
extra_title: The hunt for an EU army
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "The EU has a long record of creating institutions through the 'back door' and the creation of a EU Army will be no different. All of a sudden, the British public will be presented with a 'done deal' and British troops will find themselves operating under the EU flag rather than the Union flag."
extra_title: The hunt for an EU army
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government has changed the definition of child poverty, meaning that figures showing no significant change since 2010 can’t be trusted.
extra_title: Ask Full Fact: have the Conservatives redefined child poverty?
rating_alternateName: They haven’t changed what’s counted or how it’s counted. They did change the target. We can still use the original measures of child poverty to see whether the numbers are going up or down.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Police numbers fell under Boris Johnson as Mayor of London.
extra_title: Police numbers under Boris Johnson’s time as Mayor
rating_alternateName: Police officer numbers were higher when Boris Johnson left office compared to when he entered office, but were lower since his first budget as Mayor.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Police numbers fell on his [Boris Johnson’s] watch.”
extra_title: Police numbers under Boris Johnson’s time as Mayor
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We maintained police numbers in London above 30,000, at or around 32,000 as it happens.”
extra_title: Police numbers under Boris Johnson’s time as Mayor
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 400,000 more children are in absolute poverty under the Conservatives.
extra_title: Are 400,000 more children in absolute poverty since 2010?
rating_alternateName: This is wrong. The exact change in child poverty under the Conservatives depends on the year you compare from, but none of the absolute measures shows this. Relative child poverty was estimated to have risen by 400,000 between 2010/11 and 2015/16—both including and excluding housing costs.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “400,000 more children are in absolute poverty in this country under the Tories.”
extra_title: Are 400,000 more children in absolute poverty since 2010?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Oh come on, I’m going to call you out on those figures”
extra_title: Are 400,000 more children in absolute poverty since 2010?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Child poverty and pensioner poverty are up since 2010.
extra_title: Is child and pensioner poverty rising?
rating_alternateName: Relative poverty has increased or stayed flat among children and pensioners, depending on how you measure it, but absolute poverty has fallen in some cases. We’ve asked the Department for Work and Pensions whether any of these changes are statistically significant.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Child poverty is up and pensioner poverty is up.”
extra_title: Is child and pensioner poverty rising?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Homelessness reached its peak in 2008 under the last Labour government. Since then it’s down by almost a half.
extra_title: Sajid Javid claims 50% fall in homelessness under Conservatives—homelessness is up since 2010
rating_alternateName: We’re not aware of any data showing this. Statutory homelessness in England fell between 2003 and 2009. It has risen around 39% since then.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Homelessness reached its peak in 2008 under the last Labour government. Since then it’s down by almost a half.”
extra_title: Sajid Javid claims 50% fall in homelessness under Conservatives—homelessness is up since 2010
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The withdrawal agreement means any future free trade agreement between the UK and EU would make the European Court of Justice the ultimate arbiter of disputes.
extra_title: No indication that the European Court of Justice would be the arbiter of all disputes in a future UK-EU trade agreement
rating_alternateName: The UK and EU haven’t started negotiating the free trade agreement yet so we can’t know for sure. Both sides have stated that under a future trade agreement the court would only arbitrate disputes on EU law that couldn’t be resolved by a joint committee.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Any future free-trade agreement, if we signed it, who would be the arbiter of disputes? Can I tell you? The European Court of Justice, who will make binding rulings, it says it in the document.”
extra_title: No indication that the European Court of Justice would be the arbiter of all disputes in a future UK-EU trade agreement
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: An extension to the date of Brexit would cost £1 billion a month.
extra_title: It’s not true to say a Brexit extension would cost £1 billion
rating_alternateName: Wrong. An extension of a few months would cost no more than leaving with a deal in October 2019, which is still the government’s publicly stated policy.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “I think that it would be a mistake to keep the UK bound in beyond the time that the people want to come out… at a cost of £1 billion a month.”
extra_title: It’s not true to say a Brexit extension would cost £1 billion
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: An extension to Brexit would cost the UK £1 billion a month
extra_title: Would an extension to Brexit cost £1 billion a month?
rating_alternateName: This is only compared to a no deal exit in which the UK refuses to pay the “divorce bill”, and it doesn’t include payments back from the EU to the UK. If we leave with a deal, any extension up to the end of 2020 will not cost us extra, as the agreed financial settlement already includes these payments.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If you look at the Bill that Hilary Benn and the Jeremy Corbyn-led opposition have brought forward… It would create paralysing uncertainty, it’s craftily designed not just for one extension but to try and allow serial extensions, it would immediately require the UK to accept any EU conditions however punitive, however harsh, and regardless of those conditions the price tag for the taxpayer would be one billion pounds each month.”
extra_title: Would an extension to Brexit cost £1 billion a month?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed:
Dominic Raab: It would cost the British taxpayer – because it’s seeking an extension – one billion pounds…
Presenter: I think if we’re talking about potential elections, that costs an awful lot itself, doesn’t it?
Raab: Not a billion pounds each day, for sure, which is the price tag.
extra_title: Would an extension to Brexit cost £1 billion a month?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There is a two-year time limit for Brexit negotiations under Article 50, which the UK has no power to extend.
extra_title: Article 50: a two-year limit
rating_alternateName: Correct. The UK will be out of the EU two years after triggering Article 50, unless it reaches an agreement within that time or agrees with all other EU members to extend the negotiation period.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Once we trigger Article 50, it runs for two years. We have no control over extending it. The other 27 member states decide whether there’s an extension or not.”
extra_title: Article 50: a two-year limit
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The EU says chlorine-washed chicken is safe.
extra_title: Does the EU say it's safe to eat chicken rinsed in chlorine?
rating_alternateName: The European Food Safety Authority has said that there are “no safety concerns” with the chlorination of chicken, but it has also said this practice might not be sufficient for maintaining good hygiene standards throughout the slaughter process.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "There's no food safety issue with chlorine-washed goods because the EU themselves say that's perfectly safe,"
extra_title: Does the EU say it's safe to eat chicken rinsed in chlorine?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK will be paying the Brexit divorce bill until 2064.
extra_title: Our Brexit divorce bill will probably be paid off by 2064
rating_alternateName: Correct. The majority of these payments will be made by 2021.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We are going to be paying until 2064, apparently”
extra_title: Our Brexit divorce bill will probably be paid off by 2064
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Most of our trade with the world is based on WTO rules.
extra_title: Does most UK trade happen outside of the EU and trade agreements?
rating_alternateName: Most of our trade (57% of exports and 66% of imports in 2016) is with countries we have EU trade agreements with, not under WTO rules. But trade agreement tariffs on some goods and services are the same as those we have with other countries.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “There are WTO rules which govern world trade, and most of our dealings with most countries in the world are based on WTO rules.”
extra_title: Does most UK trade happen outside of the EU and trade agreements?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The £1.9 billion the government has spent on preparing for no deal so far could pay the salaries of around 85,000 nurses, 50,000 secondary school teachers or 49,000 police constables.
extra_title: What’s the cost of preparing for Brexit?
rating_alternateName: The government hasn’t said how much of the government’s additional Brexit funding is going to no deal preparations specifically. That would pay the salaries of roughly this many staff, but it doesn’t tell us anything useful as these workers would cost more to employ than their salaries alone.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government’s no deal Brexit preparations are costing £171,000 per hour.
extra_title: What’s the cost of preparing for Brexit?
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. This is the total additional funding per hour the government has allocated for Brexit preparations in 2018/19 for several different scenarios including those where the UK leaves with a deal. The government hasn’t said how much of the funding is going to no deal preparations specifically.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“£171,000. That’s how much the Tories’ No Deal preparations are costing our country. Per hour.

“The Tories are spending £171,000 an hour on no deal preparations. That’s £1.9 billion and counting that could be spent on the salaries of approximately 85,000 nurses, 50,000 secondary school teachers or 49,000 police constables
extra_title: What’s the cost of preparing for Brexit?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Rail commuter fares are rising faster than wages.
extra_title: Fair fares? How much are season tickets increasing by?
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Rail commuters squeezed further as season tickets rise faster than wages.”
extra_title: Fair fares? How much are season tickets increasing by?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK has gone from being one of the top economic performers in terms of growth in the G7, Europe and the world to being bottom of the league in the last year.
extra_title: Is the UK economy in the relegation zone?
rating_alternateName: It’s correct the UK had the fastest growing economy in the G7 in 2014 and was faster growing than the EU average in 2015. Various experts have said it is near the bottom of the G7 countries in 2017 and its growth is now lower the the EU average.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “It doesn't matter who you refer to, whether it’s the IFS, whether it’s the ONS, whether it’s the Bank of England. All the indicators are that we have gone from being one of the top [economic] performers in the G7, one of the top performers in the world, one of the top performers in Europe in terms of growth, and we are now nearly at the bottom of the league. And that's happened in the last six or 12 months.”
extra_title: Is the UK economy in the relegation zone?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK economy is growing more quickly than any of the other G7 countries.
extra_title: Is the UK still the fastest growing G7 economy?
rating_alternateName: In 2016, the UK economy seems to have grown faster than any G7 country bar Germany, which grew at essentially the same rate.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We are already… the fastest growing economy in the G7”
extra_title: Is the UK still the fastest growing G7 economy?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Government debt has doubled under the Conservatives.
extra_title: Labour and Conservative records on the national debt
rating_alternateName: Not correct. Public sector net debt, adjusted for inflation, rose by 53% between 2009/10 and 2016/17.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The national debt almost tripled under the last Labour government.
extra_title: Labour and Conservative records on the national debt
rating_alternateName: Correct in cash terms, but after adjusting for inflation it’s more like doubled than tripled. Public sector net debt, adjusted for inflation, rose by 125% between 1996/97 and 2009/10 – mostly after the recession that began in 2008.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Interest payments on the national debt cost the government £46 billion a year.
extra_title: Interest payments on the national debt
rating_alternateName: That’s about right for 2015/16, although the government effectively paid some of that to itself because it went to the state-owned Bank of England. Ignoring these payments, the government spent around £33 billion on debt interest that year.

claimReview_claimReviewed: We spend more on national debt interest payments than we do on education, transport or the police.
extra_title: Interest payments on the national debt
rating_alternateName: This is wrong on education: the government spends £84 billion on education compared to £33 billion on debt interest. Police and transport spending is lower.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Interest payments on the national debt are the fifth biggest item of government expenditure.
extra_title: Interest payments on the national debt
rating_alternateName: Correct. The government spends more on health, benefits, pensions and education (broadly defined) but debt interest takes up about 5% of all government spending (excluding payments to the Bank of England).

claimReview_claimReviewed: "After things like the NHS and pensions, the fifth biggest [government] expenditure, it's not education, it's not transport, it's not the police, it's debt interest on the national debt. It's £46 billion of money I can't spend or nor can anybody else spend on all those goodies that some people think are in the Labour manifesto. We have to live within our means."
extra_title: Interest payments on the national debt
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The deficit is down by nearly two thirds.
extra_title: Is the deficit down by two thirds?
rating_alternateName: This is correct, looking at the deficit as a proportion of GDP. Between 2009/10 and 2015/16 public sector net borrowing decreased from 9.9% of GDP to 3.8%, or by around two thirds.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “I will be taking out to the country in this campaign a proud record of a Conservative government: … an economy with the deficit nearly two thirds down.”
extra_title: Is the deficit down by two thirds?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “In 2010 they promised to eradicate the deficit by 2015. In 2015 they promised to eradicate the deficit by 2020.”
extra_title: Is the deficit down by two thirds?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The budget deficit has fallen by two thirds since 2009/10, just before the Coalition came into power.
extra_title: Best laid plans... for reducing the deficit
rating_alternateName: That's correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: In 2010 the budget deficit was running at over 10% of the UK’s GDP.
extra_title: Best laid plans... for reducing the deficit
rating_alternateName: That's correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We inherited in 2010 a budget deficit that was running at over 10% of our GDP and we have brought that down by two thirds over the last six years.”
extra_title: Best laid plans... for reducing the deficit
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 2% or 3% of lorries going through Dover aren’t going to the EU.
extra_title: Lorries at Dover
rating_alternateName: We haven’t seen the evidence to confirm this. We were told the figures came from the Port of Dover authorities, who have previously given similar figures to parliamentary committees. They have so far been unable to confirm the figures, so we’ve asked for more information.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “There are other lorries, as you will know better than I do, that are not going to the EU. In fact I think it is 2% or 3% of those coming through Dover and they take a lot longer [to be checked]. And that is the reality, if you don’t have a Customs Union there will be queues.”
extra_title: Lorries at Dover
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Leaving the EU means there would have to be border controls between Ireland and Northern Ireland.
extra_title: The Irish border and Brexit
rating_alternateName: That’s a matter of speculation at the moment. Some sort of customs checks on goods crossing the border would be needed, but not necessarily passport checks or stopping everyone.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “There would have to be border controls but not a prevention of genuine Irish from coming in across the border”
extra_title: The Irish border and Brexit
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “I think that the land border we share with Ireland can be as free-flowing after a Brexit vote as it is today”
extra_title: The Irish border and Brexit
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The fear in Dublin is that our border towns would become a backdoor into the UK. In that instance what sort of fortress would the Northern Ireland border have to become to close that backdoor?”
extra_title: The Irish border and Brexit
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Individual EU countries could veto a deal on the UK leaving the EU.
extra_title: Who can veto a Brexit deal?
rating_alternateName: Individual countries can’t veto a treaty governing the UK’s withdrawal from the EU, but could veto a treaty establishing Britain’s new relationship with the EU.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Central Europe would veto any Brexit deal limiting rights to work in Britain: Slovak PM”
extra_title: Who can veto a Brexit deal?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: If Lord Kinnock, Lord Mandelson, or Lord Patten began to publicly criticise the EU, their pensions would be withdrawn.
extra_title: EU staff don’t lose their pensions for criticising the EU
rating_alternateName: All three are ex-EU commissioners. None would lose their pension for criticising the EU.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“Do you know senior employees of the EU lose their pension if they criticise the EU in public.
If Lord Kinnock or… Lord Mandelson… or Chris Patten… began to publicly criticise the EU, their fat cat gold plated pensions would be withdrawn.
extra_title: EU staff don’t lose their pensions for criticising the EU
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“DID YOU KNOW THAT SENIOR EMPLOYEES OF THE EU LOSE THEIR MASSIVE PENSION IF THEY CRITICISE THE EU IN PUBLIC?
“Why do you think people like Blair and Kinnock NEVER say a bad word about the EU?
“It's a "gags for pensions" racket.”
extra_title: EU staff don’t lose their pensions for criticising the EU
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Not a single one of the four nominees to key EU positions was voted on by MEPs.
extra_title: Do MEPs get to vote for the new President of the European Commission?
rating_alternateName: MEPs don’t nominate any of the four candidates, but two of the roles (President of the European Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs) do still need to be approved by MEPs and they are consulted on a third.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Not a single one of [the four nominees to key EU positions] voted on by MEPs, all stitched up behind closed doors.”
extra_title: Do MEPs get to vote for the new President of the European Commission?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Ursula von der Leyen is the new EU President.
extra_title: Was the new President of the European Commission democratically elected?
rating_alternateName: There is no such thing as an “EU president”. Ms von der Leyen has been nominated to be President of the European Commission, one of the EU’s three main institutions. This needs to be confirmed by a majority of MEPs.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There is no route at all for you to get rid of Ursula von der Leyen.
extra_title: Was the new President of the European Commission democratically elected?
rating_alternateName: The President of the European Commission’s office ends after five years, when new EU elections take place. The President also has to be approved by elected MEPs, who can also vote them out of office with a censure motion.

claimReview_claimReviewed: No one voted for Ursula von der Leyen.
extra_title: Was the new President of the European Commission democratically elected?
rating_alternateName: Ms von der Leyen was nominated to be President of the European Commission by the European Council. Her nomination does need to be approved by a majority of MEPs in the EU parliament (who were voted for in May).

claimReview_claimReviewed: Ursula von der Leyen decides on EU laws, which national leaders and MEPs can’t do.
extra_title: Was the new President of the European Commission democratically elected?
rating_alternateName: She is the nominee to become President of the European Commission, which proposes new EU laws. But elected politicians—MEPs in the European Parliament and government ministers from all EU member states—get to review, amend and approve EU laws.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The EU admits its budget will collapse without financial contribution from the UK.
extra_title: The EU hasn’t said Brexit will collapse the EU budget
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The EU is preparing a draft budget for 2021-2027, involving increased contributions and decreased spending in some areas to account for the UK’s departure.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Britain will be forced to join an EU army unless we leave the EU.
extra_title: The UK can’t be forced into an “EU Army”
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The UK has a veto on EU military policy so couldn’t be forced to participate in an EU army.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Young British people would be conscripted into an EU army under EU regulations.
extra_title: The UK can’t be forced into an “EU Army”
rating_alternateName: The EU has no formal plans for an EU army, or for military conscription. The UK has a veto on EU military policy so couldn’t be forced to participate in an EU army.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Poland has lowered its retirement age from 67 to 60.
extra_title: Polish pensions are not directly subsidised by the UK
rating_alternateName: In October 2017, the retirement age in Poland was set at 65 for men and 60 for women. This reversed a 2013 policy which set about gradually raising the retirement age to 67 for both men and women.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Poland lowered its retirement age using money from the EU.
extra_title: Polish pensions are not directly subsidised by the UK
rating_alternateName: There is no evidence for this. Poland gets back more from the EU budget than it pays in, but none of this is spent directly on pensions.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK’s pension age is going up.
extra_title: Polish pensions are not directly subsidised by the UK
rating_alternateName: Correct, the state pension age in the UK is rising from 65 to 66 for both men and women between March 2019 and October 2020. It will then rise again, from 66 to 67, between 2026 and 2028, and then from 67 to 68 between 2044 and 2046.

claimReview_claimReviewed: In 2018, the UK contributed £11 billion to the EU and received EU funding of £6 billion.
extra_title: This post about EU budget contributions is misleading
rating_alternateName: Data is not yet available for 2018. In 2017, the UK paid roughly £12 billion into the EU budget and received around £5.5 billion back in spending from the EU.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK’s EU budget rebate lasts until 2020/22
extra_title: This post about EU budget contributions is misleading
rating_alternateName: There is no fixed end-date for the UK’s rebate. But the EU wants to get rid of rebates for all countries that have one over the course of the next EU budget (2021-27). The UK could potentially block moves to remove its rebate.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK would pay 62% more into the EU budget than it gets back in spending by 2022 if it stays in the EU.
extra_title: This post about EU budget contributions is misleading
rating_alternateName: This can’t be known, because we don’t yet know what the EU budget will look like for 2021-27, and it is being planned on the assumption that the UK is not a part of it.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK takes part in free trade agreements with 50 countries because of our EU membership.
extra_title: How many free trade deals has the EU done?
rating_alternateName: The EU lists 50 countries with which it currently has a trade agreement of one kind or another.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Thanks to our membership of the European Union, we benefit from free trade agreements with 50 countries around the world"
extra_title: How many free trade deals has the EU done?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: We have a trade deficit in the region of 65 to 70 billion annually with the EU.
extra_title: Trade with America: are we getting a good deal?
rating_alternateName: The trade deficit with the EU was about £80 billion in the year to June 2017.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK has a trade surplus with America.
extra_title: Trade with America: are we getting a good deal?
rating_alternateName: Correct. The UK’s trade surplus with the USA was around £34 billion in the year to June 2017.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We have actually a trade surplus at the moment with America, although it’s a fairly modest sum of money involved. Whereas obviously we have something in the region of 65 to 70 billion trade deficit on an annual basis with the EU.”
extra_title: Trade with America: are we getting a good deal?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Bombardier is worth 10% of Northern Ireland’s GDP.
extra_title: How valuable is Bombardier to the economy of Northern Ireland?
rating_alternateName: We’ve seen no evidence for this. Bombardier claims it makes up 10% of Northern Ireland’s manufacturing exports, which is about 2% of its GDP.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If Bombardier were to be lost to Northern Ireland it would be a cataclysmic blow to our economy here, it’s fully 10% of the entire GDP of Northern Ireland.”
extra_title: How valuable is Bombardier to the economy of Northern Ireland?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: This photo shows women working for the Red Cross arriving at Normandy beach in 1944 to assist injured troops.
extra_title: This is not a photo of women of the Red Cross landing at Normandy
rating_alternateName: It is a photo of women working for the Red Cross arriving in Southern France in 1945 to “keep high the spirits” of American soldiers.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Jeremy Corbyn wore a poppy pin that said: “lets forget”.
extra_title: Jeremy Corbyn did not wear a poppy pin that said “lets forget”
rating_alternateName: This is incorrect. An image of Mr Corbyn at PMQs has been edited to include said poppy.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A photo shows Nigel Farage accompanying National Front member Martin Webster.
extra_title: There is no evidence to suggest Nigel Farage was a member of the National Front.
rating_alternateName: We don’t know who the person next to Mr Webster is, but it almost certainly isn’t Mr Farage. There is no evidence to suggest Mr Farage was ever a National Front member.

claimReview_claimReviewed: This man holding a “The UK Invented Racism” sign is the same that tried to burn the Cenotaph’s Union Jack.
extra_title: This person isn’t the one from viral footage of someone trying to burn the Cenotaph’s Union Jack
rating_alternateName: This is incorrect. They are two different people.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Theresa May leads Jeremy Corbyn in the opinion polls.
extra_title: How are Theresa May and Jeremy Corbyn doing in the polls?
rating_alternateName: It’s correct that Theresa May is more favoured as Prime Minister than Jeremy Corbyn in polls generally, though the Express poll only compares the two leaders on their economic credibility.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Britain backs May … Theresa May has kept a commanding opinion poll lead over Jeremy Corbyn despite a bruising few weeks for her Government.”
extra_title: How are Theresa May and Jeremy Corbyn doing in the polls?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: People over six foot tall are twice as likely to get coronavirus.
extra_title: There is no proof you’re more likely to get Covid-19 if you’re tall
rating_alternateName: There is no proof of this. In the UK, taller men were more likely to report having had coronavirus, but this trend was the opposite in the US.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “People over 6ft have double the risk of coronavirus, study suggests.”
extra_title: There is no proof you’re more likely to get Covid-19 if you’re tall
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “People who are over 6ft tall are twice as likely to catch coronavirus, study claims.”
extra_title: There is no proof you’re more likely to get Covid-19 if you’re tall
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Does being tall raise the risk of getting Covid-19? Men over 6ft are TWICE as likely to get infected, study claims”
extra_title: There is no proof you’re more likely to get Covid-19 if you’re tall
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: As part of the Coronavirus Act, children can be detained for 14 days without their parents’ consent, and their parents don’t have to be informed, only a teacher, according to a letter from the Children’s Commissioner.
extra_title: Can children be detained without their parents’ consent if the authorities think they have coronavirus?
rating_alternateName: Although the government had since said a child could not be detained without their parents’ knowledge or consent under the powers in the Coronavirus Act, the law itself seems ambiguous enough that this theoretically could happen. The law says steps should be taken to avoid this, and says a parent or guardian should be contacted, so this scenario seems unlikely.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Act also introduces new powers to detain children on public health grounds, for a period of up to fourteen days. I agree that this may be necessary in order to prevent the further spread of disease, however I am concerned that the Act allows this to be done without consent from someone with responsibility for the child, and only requires ‘reasonable steps’ to be taken to inform someone with responsibility of the detention.
extra_title: Can children be detained without their parents’ consent if the authorities think they have coronavirus?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Figures from the Office for National Statistics show the number of suicides during the peak of the coronavirus pandemic was down from 10.3 per 100,000 to 6.9 per 100,000.
extra_title: There’s no evidence the number of people taking their own life fell during the Covid-19 pandemic
rating_alternateName: This is not correct. These figures show deaths registered during this period, not deaths occurring. Most of these suicides took place before 2020, and the ONS has said lower registrations are likely due to the impact of the pandemic on the coroner’s service.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Some cautiously positive news announced today ​by the Office for National Statistics shows that the number of suicides during the peak of the pandemic was down from 10.3 per 100,000 to 6.9 per 100,000”.
extra_title: There’s no evidence the number of people taking their own life fell during the Covid-19 pandemic
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 800 Sure Start children’s centres have been closed in England since 2010.
extra_title: Not so sure of Sure Start figures
rating_alternateName: This is only part of the story. There are over 1,000 fewer Sure Start centres, but only 300 fewer children’s centres overall. Around 700 sites still operate but no longer meet the official definition of a Sure Start centre.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The Tories have now closed more than 800 Sure Start centres … shutting the door in the faces of our children and their parents.”
extra_title: Not so sure of Sure Start figures
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The tests conducted at the 199 testing centres, as well as the mobile test centres, are all done within 24 hours.
extra_title: New data reveals PM’s testing speeds claims as wrong
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. When this was said, on 3 June, 19% of tests at regional testing sites and 5% of tests at mobile test centres were done within 24 hours.

claimReview_claimReviewed: We already turn around 90% of tests within 48 hours.
extra_title: New data reveals PM’s testing speeds claims as wrong
rating_alternateName: Test times covering early June when the claim was made are only available for around half of antigen tests. That means we can’t say whether or not this is accurate.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We already turn around 90% of tests within 48 hours. The tests conducted at the 199 testing centres, as well as the mobile test centres, are all done within 24 hours, and I can undertake to him now to get all tests turned around in 24 hours by the end of June, except for difficulties with postal tests or insuperable problems like that.”
extra_title: New data reveals PM’s testing speeds claims as wrong
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Covid-19 deaths in care homes are rising.
extra_title: Covid-19 deaths in care homes have started to fall
rating_alternateName: This was true at the time, by one measure. By another measure it was probably not true. Now it seems clearer that deaths in care homes from suspected Covid-19 are falling.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “While, happily, it looks as though deaths in hospitals are falling, deaths in care homes continue to go up.”
extra_title: Covid-19 deaths in care homes have started to fall
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “I can tell him that he is not right in what he just said about the state of the epidemic in care homes. If he looks at the figures in the last few days, there has been a palpable improvement.”
extra_title: Covid-19 deaths in care homes have started to fall
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The deaths of 181 NHS workers have involved Covid-19.
extra_title: We don’t know exactly how many NHS workers have died from Covid-19
rating_alternateName: This figure is correct for England only.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The deaths of 131 care workers have involved Covid-19.
extra_title: We don’t know exactly how many NHS workers have died from Covid-19
rating_alternateName: This is based on data collected on deaths in England and Wales up to 20 April.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Flu is killing many more people than Covid-19 at the moment.
extra_title: Flu isn’t the underlying cause of death for more people than Covid-19
rating_alternateName: There isn’t evidence for this. Although we don’t have detailed data on recent deaths, there are almost certainly fewer deaths where flu is identified as the underlying cause compared to Covid-19.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Flu killing six times more people than coronavirus”
extra_title: Flu isn’t the underlying cause of death for more people than Covid-19
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “FLU has killed more people in the UK than coronavirus for eight weeks in a row”
extra_title: Flu isn’t the underlying cause of death for more people than Covid-19
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “In the week to the end of July, five times more people died of influenza than Covid-19 in the UK.”
extra_title: Flu isn’t the underlying cause of death for more people than Covid-19
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: UK is testing more people for Covid-19 than any country other than China and Italy.
extra_title: There’s limited data on how many Covid-19 tests are being done globally, but the UK doesn’t rank third in the world
rating_alternateName: This is incorrect. As at 13 March, the latest data available when this claim was made, the UK ranked fifth (behind China, South Korea, Italy and Russia) for the number of Covid-19 tests carried out. These statistics only included the 38 countries and regions with official data on Covid-19 tests at that time.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK is doing more Covid-19 tests  than virtually any country in Europe.
extra_title: We still don’t know if the UK does the most Covid-19 tests in Europe
rating_alternateName: The UK appears to be testing fewer people than in Russia. But there isn’t enough data on this to determine for sure where the UK places, and the UK’s data isn’t particularly comparable with other countries.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “This country is now testing more than virtually any other country in Europe.”
extra_title: We still don’t know if the UK does the most Covid-19 tests in Europe
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Coronavirus may have been genetically engineered for “efficient spreading in the human population,” a bombshell new study has claimed.
extra_title: A study has not claimed the new coronavirus was ‘genetically engineered for efficient spread in humans’
rating_alternateName: This is wrong and the study does not claim the new coronavirus has been genetically engineered. It simply compares the genome sequence of SARS-CoV-2 with other coronaviruses, and suggests a reason why it might be spreading relatively efficiently.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Coronavirus may have been genetically engineered for the “efficient spreading in the human population,” a bombshell new study has claimed.”
extra_title: A study has not claimed the new coronavirus was ‘genetically engineered for efficient spread in humans’
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: You can meet with both of your parents at the same time, as long as you stay two metres apart.
extra_title: New lockdown guidance doesn’t mean you can see both parents at once
rating_alternateName: This is wrong. You can only meet with one person from outside of your household at a time.

claimReview_claimReviewed: You no longer have to quarantine if you have returned to England from an exempt country before July 10.
extra_title: Government issues contradictory advice on travel quarantine
rating_alternateName: This has been claimed by the Foreign and Commonwealth Office as well as a government minister. However, advice from the Department for Transport on the government’s official website says you must follow the rules that were in place when you arrived in England.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If your mother arrived in the UK from one of the exempt countries, then she can stop quarantining on the 10th July.”
extra_title: Government issues contradictory advice on travel quarantine
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Self-isolation is subject to current legal requirement for anyone who is returning to England before 10 July. We would not seek to enforce self-quarantine after 10 July.”
extra_title: Government issues contradictory advice on travel quarantine
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: At regional Covid-19 test centres, 98% of results are delivered within 24 hours.
extra_title: Covid-19 testing is not as fast as Matt Hancock claimed
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The most recent figure is about 72%.

claimReview_claimReviewed: At mobile Covid-19 testing units, 97% of results are delivered within 24 hours.
extra_title: Covid-19 testing is not as fast as Matt Hancock claimed
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The most recent figure is about 61%.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Really proud of my amazing testing team who’ve delivered 24-hr turnaround times of: - 98% for drive through testing - 97% for mobile testing units”
extra_title: Covid-19 testing is not as fast as Matt Hancock claimed
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government has announced an unprecedented £84 billion real-terms increase in funding for the NHS.
extra_title: Is £84 billion being spent on the NHS?
rating_alternateName: The increase is £20.5 billion in real-terms for the NHS in England between 2018/19 and 2023/24. There is a way of calculating the figures that gets £84 billion, but it’s unhelpful and contains some potentially misleading figures.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We’ve announced an unprecedented £84 billion real-terms funding boost for the NHS, what the NHS says it needs”.
extra_title: Is £84 billion being spent on the NHS?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: If you live in an area where the council is run by the Labour party, you pay £100 more than under the Conservatives.
extra_title: Labour and Conservative council tax: who costs you more?
rating_alternateName: We haven’t been able to replicate this calculation, and in general it’s difficult to attribute the cost of council tax to a single party.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Conservative councils cost £341 more in council tax on average per household.
extra_title: Labour and Conservative council tax: who costs you more?
rating_alternateName: We haven’t been able to replicate this calculation, and in general it’s difficult to attribute the cost of council tax to a single party.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If the honourable Gentleman worries about what is happening at local council level, he ought to look at the figures that have come out today, which show very clearly that if you live in an area where the council is run by the Labour party, you pay £100 more than under the Conservatives.”
extra_title: Labour and Conservative council tax: who costs you more?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Tory councils cost £341 more in council tax on average per household”
extra_title: Labour and Conservative council tax: who costs you more?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The average cost of a child’s funeral is £3,675.
extra_title: The cost of children's funerals
rating_alternateName: This is the cost of an average funeral in 2016 according to a survey by insurers Royal London. Another firm puts the cost slightly higher. The cost of burying a child may be lower in some areas, as councils often waive or discount burial fees for under-16s.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The average cost of a child’s funeral today is £3,675. Some councils don’t charge anything, some do charge a lot, and the Social Fund is means tested.”
extra_title: The cost of children's funerals
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: It was wrong for a BBC Question Time audience member to say Vote Leave are accused of breaking electoral law.
extra_title: BBC Question Time get themselves in a mess over who broke electoral law
rating_alternateName: This is wrong; the audience member was right. The Metropolitan Police are still investigating Vote Leave, and the Electoral Commission also found Vote Leave had broken electoral law, and fined them.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Leave.EU was cleared of a number of things and no criminal charges were brought against them.
extra_title: BBC Question Time get themselves in a mess over who broke electoral law
rating_alternateName: Both the Metropolitan Police and the National Crime Agency closed investigations into Leave.EU with no charges brought. However Leave.EU was found by the Electoral Commission to have broken electoral law, and paid a fine.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Vote Leave is accused of breaking electoral law.
extra_title: BBC Question Time get themselves in a mess over who broke electoral law
rating_alternateName: Correct it was fined £61,000 by the Electoral Commission for a number of offences.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“I think actually we’ve forgotten that Vote Leave is accused of breaking electoral law.
Dominic Cummings, who is currently an advisor to Boris Johnson, is currently in such a position of power, yet he refused to stand before Parliament and talk about breaking electoral law, he is in contempt of Parliament.” - BBC Question Time audience member
“I think when it comes to the Leave EU campaign, as far as I’m aware they were cleared of a number of things actually. I’m not entirely sure that you’re right about that.” - Fiona Bruce
“So they were accused of overspending…” - BBC Question Time audience member
 “No criminal charges were brought in the end. No criminal charges were against the Leave EU campaign.” - Fiona Bruce
extra_title: BBC Question Time get themselves in a mess over who broke electoral law
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Matt Hancock said there would be 25000 tests a day by mid-April. We’re currently at under 15,000 as of yesterday, so we’re missing that target. He said 100,000 by the end of April.
extra_title: Government misses one of its Covid-19 test targets
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: We hit 10,000 tests a day by the end of March.
extra_title: Government misses one of its Covid-19 test targets
rating_alternateName: We don’t know. Fewer than 10,000 people were tested on each day in March, but that could have involved more than 10,000 tests. Data on the number of tests only started to be published in full on 6 April.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Matt Hancock said there would be 25,000 [tests a day] by mid-April. We’re currently at under 15,000 as of yesterday, so we’re missing that target. He said 100,000 by the end of April.”
extra_title: Government misses one of its Covid-19 test targets
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We committed to 10,000 tests by the end of March which we hit. Then we had previously committed to 25,000 tests by the end of April. I increased that goal to 100,000 so we have hit each of the goals we set on testing.”
extra_title: Government misses one of its Covid-19 test targets
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: CCGs increased their spending on mental health by 6.3% last year while their overall funding increased by 3.7%.
extra_title: NHS spending on mental health
rating_alternateName: This is the increase in spending by CCGs on mental health compared to their overall core services budget allocation. The figures don’t account for inflation. Factoring that in, mental health spending went up by 3.9% over that time and overall CCG budgets went up by 1.5%.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Spending on mental health went up by £575 million last year.
extra_title: NHS spending on mental health
rating_alternateName: This refers to the increase in spending by Clinical Commissioning Groups, but doesn’t account for inflation. Factoring that in the increase was around £368 million. It’s not a complete picture of mental health spending because other money is spent by the NHS on specialised mental health services. The figures on this aren’t regularly published.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Extra staff cost money so this is what the data shows last year alone spending on mental health went up by £575m”
extra_title: NHS spending on mental health
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “...with CCGs increasing spend by 6.3% vs an overall increase of 3.7% in their funding - in other words spending up both in absolute terms and as a proportion of NHS spend”
extra_title: NHS spending on mental health
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The rollout of liaison therapy may have contributed to a 6% fall in suicide rates.
extra_title: Mental health crisis care
rating_alternateName: This fall did happen but the link can’t be proved. Experts say liaison services can play a role in reducing suicides, but there’s no way to prove the extent to which one caused the other, and the rates tend to fluctuate from year to year anyway.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Liaison therapy has been rolled out to over 90% of A&Es;, of which half are open 24/7.
extra_title: Mental health crisis care
rating_alternateName: This is correct, although only 13% of hospitals offer what’s called a ‘core 24’ standard of service.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We have also seen significant improvements in crisis care including the roll-out of liaison psychiatry to over 90% of A&Es, of which half are 24/7. This may have contributed to a 6% fall in suicide rates”
extra_title: Mental health crisis care
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: More than 2,000 more fully qualified staff working in mental health trusts since 2013.
extra_title: Mental health staff in the NHS
rating_alternateName: Working for a mental health trust doesn’t mean you work on mental health. This figure hides the detail: mental health nurse numbers in England are down, while staff in the scientific, therapeutic and technical group has gone up.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 4,300 more staff employed in mental health trusts since 2013.
extra_title: Mental health staff in the NHS
rating_alternateName: This is not how many mental health specialist staff there are. It is the increase in all staff in English trusts with over half their outpatient activity in mental health specialities. Some of the staff were effectively re-categorised into the mental health category during this time, rather than being newly hired.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are fewer doctors and nurses employed in mental health.
extra_title: Mental health staff in the NHS
rating_alternateName: There are around 5,000 fewer nurses specialising mental health between August 2010 and 2017. The number of fully trained doctors specialising in psychiatry and psychotherapy has also gone down by 105 over the same time, but if you count junior doctors the number has increased.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “4,300 more employed by mental health trusts”
extra_title: Mental health staff in the NHS
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“Impressive sounding, but “employed
 is a broad term... In terms of “employed
 DOCTORS and NURSES; fact checkers FullFact.org disagree: we in fact have much FEWER of them, as described here...
“Also according to Fullfact.org we have 14% fewer mental health nurses than we did in 2010. In real terms this amounts to 6000. Six. Thousand. FEWER. Nurses. Psychiatry doctor numbers have remained almost flat, in fact falling slightly: We now have 170 FEWER fully trained doctors now vs 2010.
extra_title: Mental health staff in the NHS
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “here are the tables that show the 4,300 increase in staff at mental health trusts since 2013… ....more than 2,000 of which are fully qualified (e.g. not the reduction of 167 in the fullfact piece you linked).”
extra_title: Mental health staff in the NHS
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A 10% rise in immigration leads to a 2% reduction in wages.
extra_title: Does a 10% rise in immigration lead to a 2% reduction in wages?
rating_alternateName: The Bank of England found that a 10% increase in the proportion of foreign born workers in lower paid service jobs was associated with a near 2% fall in average pay for those jobs, when focusing on particular regions.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “As the Bank of England said, for every 10% growth in immigration there is a 2% reduction in wages. That bears thinking about.”
extra_title: Does a 10% rise in immigration lead to a 2% reduction in wages?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Over 6,000 elderly people a month are kept in hospital beds in England when they are fit to discharge and it costs the NHS £6 billion a year.
extra_title: No source yet for £6bn cost of 'bed blocking' claim
rating_alternateName: 6,000 was the number of people of all ages fit to discharge and still in hospital on one day in June. There were over 170,000 delayed bed days over the month, these are the number of full days each bed could have been used by another patient. The estimates for how much this costs vary, but none seem to be higher than £900 million a year.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “More than 6,000 elderly people are trapped needlessly in hospital beds each month as nursing homes, families and social services fail to provide adequate care. The health service is facing its worst bed-blocking crisis at a cost of nearly £6 billion a year, official figures from NHS England showed yesterday.”
extra_title: No source yet for £6bn cost of 'bed blocking' claim

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Revealed, the truth about UK crime: New official figures give more weight to worst offences... and show they're up by almost a fifth”
