claimReview_claimReviewed: Conservative councils save families around £100 a year more than Labour and Liberal Democrat councils.
extra_title: Do Conservative councils charge £100 less tax than Labour or Liberal Democrat councils?
rating_alternateName: The method the Conservatives have used to make their comparison is flawed in several ways and therefore pretty meaningless.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Conservative councils save families around £100 a year more than Labour and Liberal Democrat councils”
extra_title: Do Conservative councils charge £100 less tax than Labour or Liberal Democrat councils?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: People living in Labour councils pay on average £351 less council tax than those living in Tory councils.
extra_title: Do Labour councils cost you £350 less in council tax?
rating_alternateName: Technically correct for England in 2019/20, based on the average bill per eligible home, but this isn’t very meaningful. Many residents pay council tax to more than one body, so it’s difficult to attribute the cost of council tax to a single council or party.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “People living in Labour councils pay on average £351 less council tax than those living in Tory councils.”
extra_title: Do Labour councils cost you £350 less in council tax?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Campaigners on both sides of the EU referendum made false claims.
extra_title: False claims, forecasts, and the EU Referendum
rating_alternateName: That’s correct. Sometimes they even made false claims about the false claims made by each other.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Remain campaigners predicted that house prices would fall by 10% after a vote to leave.
extra_title: False claims, forecasts, and the EU Referendum
rating_alternateName: Not quite. The UK Treasury expected house prices to be 10-18% lower than they would otherwise have been in 2017/18.

claimReview_claimReviewed: We were promised a ‘punishment budget’ before the referendum.
extra_title: False claims, forecasts, and the EU Referendum
rating_alternateName: Sort of. Remain campaigners published a 7-page ‘Brexit Budget’ which gave rough, hypothetical figures for the kind of cuts that would be needed if the UK voted to leave the EU, the pre-referendum economic forecasts were correct and the government still wanted to run a balanced budget in 2020/21. It was presented by George Osborne, then Chancellor of the Exchequer.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We talk about honesty in the campaigns, both sides were equally guilty. I am still waiting for my house price to fall by 10%... It was supposed to happen the day after we leave the EU, we were promised a punishment budget.”
extra_title: False claims, forecasts, and the EU Referendum
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

extra_title: Labour’s Land Value Tax: will you have to sell your garden?
rating_alternateName: It would depend on how the policy was actually designed. Labour has only committed to considering the idea, as have the Green and Liberal Democrat parties.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Labour (along with similar proposals from the Greens and Lib Dems) proposes to introduce a Land Value Tax. (LVT)—hereafter called the “garden tax
extra_title: Labour’s Land Value Tax: will you have to sell your garden?

claimReview_claimReviewed: Last winter, tens of thousands of sick patients waited on A&E; trolleys.
extra_title: NHS video, factchecked
rating_alternateName: There were 196,000 waits of over four hours in accident and emergencies in England in the winter months of 2016/17. These figures are the closest we have to a count of people on trolleys, which isn’t specifically recorded.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Conservatives have scrapped the nursing bursary.
extra_title: NHS video, factchecked
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: One in three nurses are over 50.
extra_title: NHS video, factchecked
rating_alternateName: This is roughly correct according to NHS figures from 2014.

claimReview_claimReviewed: One in ten nursing posts are vacant.
extra_title: NHS video, factchecked
rating_alternateName: Correct, according to the Royal College of Nursing.

claimReview_claimReviewed: One in four doctors and one in six nurses is an immigrant.
extra_title: NHS video, factchecked
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Health tourism costs £200 million a year—or the cost of running the NHS for 15 hours.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There has been a decade of efficiency savings in the NHS.
extra_title: NHS video, factchecked
rating_alternateName: There have been a number of efficiency initiatives over the years. Trusts have been increasing their efficiency since at least 2008/09, according to official analysis.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The NHS was rated the most efficient health service in the world by the Commonwealth Fund.
extra_title: NHS video, factchecked

claimReview_claimReviewed: We’re seeing the largest sustained drop in NHS funding as a percentage of GDP since the founding of the NHS.
extra_title: NHS video, factchecked
rating_alternateName: Correct. The King’s Fund has found that between 2010 and 2020 UK NHS spending will see the largest ever sustained reduction as a percentage of GDP.

claimReview_claimReviewed: NHS funding is at record levels.
extra_title: NHS video, factchecked
rating_alternateName: Correct. NHS funding in the UK is at record levels, even adjusted for inflation.

claimReview_claimReviewed: [You may be thinking of voting Conservative because] NHS funding is currently at record levels. The truth is that we are experiencing the largest sustained drop in NHS funding as a percentage of GDP since the NHS was founded.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Labour Party plans to increase the basic rate of income tax to 25% to pay for social care for older people.
extra_title: Are the Conservatives right about Labour’s tax plans?
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. Labour hasn’t announced any plans to increase the basic rate of income tax. It’s said that it won’t raise income taxes for those earning less than £80,000. We’ve asked the Conservatives for more information.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Jeremy Corbyn's plan to pay for elderly care: increasing the basic rate of income tax to 25p for millions of working people #GE2017”
extra_title: Are the Conservatives right about Labour’s tax plans?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: £300 million could put 10,000 police officers on the streets.
extra_title: Can £300 million pay for 10,000 police officers?
rating_alternateName: Probably not. There aren’t published estimates for the cost of training and recruiting police officers and Labour hasn’t substantiated its claim publicly. £300 million would cover those officers’ salaries for one year, but it wouldn’t cover the costs of training, equipment, and overheads at the same time.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Reversing recent cuts to Capital Gains Tax will save £2.7 billion.
extra_title: Can £300 million pay for 10,000 police officers?
rating_alternateName: Correct according to official estimates, although the true amount could vary a bit either way.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We are now this morning pledging £300 million from the £2.7 billion we will save by reversing Capital Gains Tax, to put 10,000 more police officers on our streets.”
extra_title: Can £300 million pay for 10,000 police officers?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Conservatives haven’t put a figure on their proposed cap on adult social care costs.
extra_title: Will there be a cap on social care costs?
rating_alternateName: The government hasn’t said what the proposed cap on adult social care costs in England might look like. It will be included in a consultation after the election.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “By failing to put a figure for a cap on social care costs, [the Prime Minister] has only added to the uncertainty for millions of older people and their families.”
extra_title: Will there be a cap on social care costs?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The four-hour accident and emergency target has not been hit in over two years.
extra_title: When was the four-hour A&E target last hit?
rating_alternateName: The four hour A&E; target hasn’t been met in England since July 2015, and the last time it was met over a full year was in 2013/14. The target hasn't been met at “major” A&E; departments since June 2013 and hasn’t been above 95% annually since 2010/11.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The four-hour A&E target has not been hit in over two years.”
extra_title: When was the four-hour A&E target last hit?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK government spent £285 million building an airport on the island of Saint Helena that planes can't use.
extra_title: UK foreign aid, and an airport that never took off
rating_alternateName: About £285 million was spent on a project to design, build, and operate an airport on the island of St Helena for ten years. But due to the extreme winds on the island commercial flights have been unable to run as planned.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We’re giving this large amount [on foreign aid] away to silly things. We’re even giving St Helena Island £285 million to build an airport that no airlines can take off from.”
extra_title: UK foreign aid, and an airport that never took off
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: All major parties, and the Scottish National Party, have been fined for mistakes made on national election expenses.
extra_title: Has the SNP ever been fined for election spending mistakes?
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The Conservatives, Labour, and the Liberal Democrats have all been fined by the Electoral Commission. The Electoral Commission told us it has never issued the Scottish National Party with any kind of fine or sanction.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If you look at the expenses issue, we have seen all the major parties and the Scottish nationalists being fined for mistakes made on national expenses.”
extra_title: Has the SNP ever been fined for election spending mistakes?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “PM should apologise for this attempt to smear @theSNP - unlike Tories, we abide by rules and have never been fined by Electoral Commission.”
extra_title: Has the SNP ever been fined for election spending mistakes?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Conservatives are planning to sell off NHS property by implementing the Naylor Review.
extra_title: Naylor Review: will the Conservatives sell NHS property to developers?
rating_alternateName: The Naylor Review is about how efficiently the NHS uses its land and property. It says some should be sold to fund improvements to the rest. The Conservatives are backing the review's proposals.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “[The Naylor Review] is basically an outline plan for essentially selling off the NHS assets… if you’re a hospital, then you need to sell the land and buildings that your hospital’s built on, and if you don’t they will keep squeezing your budgets and denying you access to cash and funds until you do so.”
extra_title: Naylor Review: will the Conservatives sell NHS property to developers?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: At least a large part of growth in employment has been driven by an increase in insecure, precarious work.
extra_title: Has employment growth been driven by a rise in insecure, precarious work?
rating_alternateName: That doesn’t seem to be the case for the UK jobs market overall. The picture for specific industries, regions and groups might be different and statistics will only ever give a limited insight into questions about job quality.

claimReview_claimReviewed: EU migration is at record levels.
extra_title: Jobs figures can't show record EU migration
rating_alternateName: This is wrong. Figures released today only show the number of EU nationals and EU born in work, not the numbers coming to the UK. The most recent migration estimates don't show record levels, but EU migration is historically high and could hit a record count when figures are released next week.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“Record EU migration figures add to pressure on Cameron"
“Official figures published today show migration from the EU continuing to rise as the UK’s recovering economy sucked in workers from troubled Eurozone states."
“Today’s figures confirm how difficult it will be for the Prime Minister to meet his target of reducing net migration — the difference between those arriving and those leaving the UK for a year or longer — to under 100,000 by 2020 while migration from the EU continues at current levels.”
extra_title: Jobs figures can't show record EU migration
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 79.7% of contacts of people who test positive for Covid-19 are reached.
extra_title: Matt Hancock misstates the proportion of Test and Trace contacts being reached
rating_alternateName:
Incorrect. This is the proportion of people who tested positive in the first place who are reached by the system. 

In the week to 5 August 79.7% of people who were referred to the service after testing positive were reached. Close contacts were identified for 78.6% of those cases. Of those close contacts, 74.2% were reached and asked to self-isolate.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Test and trace is getting better and better and is now performing extremely well. On the main metric that people have challenged us to deliver which is how many of somebody’s contacts can you reach if they test positive…we’re now at 79.7% of contacts reached.”
extra_title: Matt Hancock misstates the proportion of Test and Trace contacts being reached
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: You are allowed to register to vote twice—once at home and once at university.
extra_title: You can register to vote in two places
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If you are registered to vote in two places you are allowed to vote in both places during local elections.
extra_title: You can register to vote in two places
rating_alternateName: Correct, provided that they are in separate local authorities.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If you are registered to vote in two places you are only allowed to vote in one location in national elections but can choose which at the last minute.
extra_title: You can register to vote in two places
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: £1.8 billion of money announced for the NHS over the next five years isn’t all new money.
extra_title: Money for the NHS: is it new or not?
rating_alternateName: This depends on how you define ‘new money’. The Treasury will have to increase spending by this amount—but it is money that NHS trusts had already earned, but were subsequently told they couldn’t spend.

claimReview_claimReviewed: £1.8 billion of ‘new money’ has been announced for the NHS over the next five years.
extra_title: Money for the NHS: is it new or not?
rating_alternateName: £850 million has been announced for 20 hospitals over the next five years and £1 billion for the NHS in capital funding this year. The £1 billion is money that NHS trusts previously earned through a cost-cutting incentive scheme, but were then told not to spend. It is ‘new’ in the sense that the Treasury had not previously budgeted for them spending it.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “BBC reports extra £1bn for NHS capital spending this yr. There’s a catch: The £1bn is cash hospitals and other NHS trusts already have but have been forbidden to spend.”
extra_title: Money for the NHS: is it new or not?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “What it’s beginning to look like is that money hospitals were promised for cutting their costs and cutting back on their spending, they were promised extra money and the ministers came along and blocked them from spending the extra money. It now looks like all Boris Johnson has actually done is that they can spend this extra money after all.”
extra_title: Money for the NHS: is it new or not?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “It’s interesting this debate about is it new money?—it’s an increase in the allocation of money to the NHS of £1.8 billion, every penny of it new money from the Treasury.”
extra_title: Money for the NHS: is it new or not?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Don’t forget this is £1.8 billion of new money, it wasn’t there 10 days ago.”
extra_title: Money for the NHS: is it new or not?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The current withdrawal agreement effectively keeps us in the single market and customs union.
extra_title: The withdrawal agreement is not a trade deal with the EU
rating_alternateName: The withdrawal agreement doesn’t set out the terms of the UK’s future trading relationship with the EU. That would have to be negotiated after Brexit. If the withdrawal agreement passed but no trade deal was then negotiated, the Irish backstop would kick in—keeping Northern Ireland aligned to some of the rules of the single market, but not the rest of the UK. The UK would be in a customs union.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If we continually try to wrap ourselves around the current withdrawal agreement, and we remain in the customs union, and in the single market, which is effectively what is entailed by the present withdrawal agreement...”
extra_title: The withdrawal agreement is not a trade deal with the EU
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Jeremy Corbyn will cost every British worker £2,400 per year.
extra_title: Another flawed “cost of Corbyn” figure from the Conservatives
rating_alternateName: This figure is largely meaningless as the calculations and assumptions behind it have a number of flaws.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The true 'cost of Corbyn': £2,400 a year for every British worker, claim Tories”
extra_title: Another flawed “cost of Corbyn” figure from the Conservatives

extra_title: Conservative claim about immigration under Labour is not credible
rating_alternateName: Labour hasn’t published its manifesto yet, and the methods used to reach this number are not credible.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Under Jeremy Corbyn’s plan for unlimited and uncontrolled immigration, [net migration] could increase to over 840,000 people… coming to the UK every single year.”
extra_title: Conservative claim about immigration under Labour is not credible

claimReview_claimReviewed: Up to a third of millennials face renting their entire lives.
extra_title: Will one third of millennials rent for their entire lives?
rating_alternateName: This is based on a projection made by the Resolution Foundation. Their “pessimistic” UK scenario says 66% of families where the head of household was born from 1981-1995 will own their own home by 2060. Their “optimistic” scenario says 73% will.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Up to a third of millennials 'face renting their entire life'”
extra_title: Will one third of millennials rent for their entire lives?

extra_title: These poll figures are for leave voters - not "most of the nation"
rating_alternateName: The numbers in the graphic refer to opinion among Leave voters only, not the public as a whole. Opinion of the progress of Brexit varies depending on what question is asked.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 76% think the Government are negotiating Brexit badly.
extra_title: These poll figures are for leave voters - not "most of the nation"
rating_alternateName: That's of adults in Great Britain voting 'Leave' in the 2016 referendum, according to one survey. Among all adults in Great Britain, it's 75%.

extra_title: These poll figures are for leave voters - not "most of the nation"
rating_alternateName: That's of adults in Great Britain voting 'Leave' in the 2016 referendum, according to one survey. Among all adults in Great Britain, it's 40%.

extra_title: These poll figures are for leave voters - not "most of the nation"

rating_alternateName: Broadly correct. We don’t have the exact data to confirm this, but high earners and people in professional jobs are more likely to say that they drink weekly than other people.

extra_title: The Pro-sesh-ional classes: Do wealthy people drink more regularly?

claimReview_claimReviewed: Reported crime is rising under the Conservatives.
extra_title: Is crime up under the Conservatives?
rating_alternateName: Crimes recorded by the police have been rising since 2014, but that's partly down to changes in recording practices. Crime in England and Wales is falling over the long term according to the more reliable Crime Survey.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Reported crime is rising under the Tories… almost every police force in the country recorded an increase in crime over the last year.”
extra_title: Is crime up under the Conservatives?

claimReview_claimReviewed: A viral video called “Martinelli” will be shared on WhatsApp tomorrow. It will hack your phone if opened.
extra_title: WhatsApp Gold scams are real, but these other threats are made up
rating_alternateName: This is a hoax. There is no evidence the Martinelli video or virus exists.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A video called “Dance of the Pope” shared on WhatsApp is a virus that will format your phone.
extra_title: WhatsApp Gold scams are real, but these other threats are made up
rating_alternateName: This is a hoax. There is no evidence the Dance of the Pope video or virus exists.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Messages encouraging users to upgrade to WhatsApp Gold should be ignored.
extra_title: WhatsApp Gold scams are real, but these other threats are made up
rating_alternateName: Correct. WhatsApp Gold does not exist, but there are numerous “WhatsApp Gold” scams which encourage people to download the fake app which may be harmful for their computer or mobile device.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The new coronavirus is 400-500 micro and for this reason wide enough to be stopped by masks.
extra_title: Coronavirus graphics you may have been sent on WhatsApp are not actually from Unicef
rating_alternateName: The virus is 50-200 nanometres wide, and a mask, although sometimes necessary, won’t guarantee that you don’t get Covid-19.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The new coronavirus does not settle in the air but is grounded so it is not transmitted by air.
extra_title: Coronavirus graphics you may have been sent on WhatsApp are not actually from Unicef
rating_alternateName: The virus can spread via sneeze and cough droplets that can move a short distance through the air and into someone else’s system.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Coronavirus lives on the hands for 10 minutes, but can be prevented with alcohol hand sanitiser.
extra_title: Coronavirus graphics you may have been sent on WhatsApp are not actually from Unicef
rating_alternateName: It’s not clear how long the virus can ‘survive’ on hands, but hand sanitiser with at least 60% alcohol is a good second choice to washing your hands with soap and water.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Coronavirus lives for 12 hours on metal surfaces.
extra_title: Coronavirus graphics you may have been sent on WhatsApp are not actually from Unicef
rating_alternateName: We don’t know how long the virus can survive on surfaces yet, it could be between hours and days.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Gargling with warm and salt water kills germs on the tonsils and prevents them from leaking into the lungs.
extra_title: Coronavirus graphics you may have been sent on WhatsApp are not actually from Unicef
rating_alternateName: There’s no evidence gargling with saline will cure or prevent Covid-19.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If the new coronavirus is exposed to a temperature of 26-27ºC it will be killed, as it does not live in hot regions. Also drinking hot water and sun exposure will do the trick and staying away from ice cream and cold food is advised.
extra_title: Coronavirus graphics you may have been sent on WhatsApp are not actually from Unicef
rating_alternateName: There have been cases of Covid-19 in areas with warmer temperatures than this, and we don’t know what temperatures the virus can withstand. There’s no evidence that hot water and the sun will cure it or that staying away from cold food can prevent it.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Coronavirus stays on fabric for 9 hours, so washing clothes or being exposed to the sun for two hours meets the purpose of killing it.
extra_title: Coronavirus graphics you may have been sent on WhatsApp are not actually from Unicef
rating_alternateName: We don’t know how long the virus can survive on fabric. There isn’t evidence that it can transmit from fabrics to people, though soiled clothing from Covid-19 patients should be washed normally.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Corona virus (Covid-19) is large in size where the cell diameter is 400-500 micro and for this reason any mask prevents its entry.
extra_title: Coronavirus graphics you may have been sent on WhatsApp are not actually from Unicef
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The virus does not settle in the air but is grounded so it is not transmitted by air.
extra_title: Coronavirus graphics you may have been sent on WhatsApp are not actually from Unicef

claimReview_claimReviewed: Leaving the customs union and single market will cost every person in Scotland £1,600.
extra_title: Claim that Brexit will cost every Scot £1,600 is not right
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. This comes from a dated estimate of how much less Scottish GDP will grow by 2030 in such a scenario, compared to remaining in the EU. It doesn’t represent a cash loss, but is how much smaller Scottish GDP would be per person compared to remaining in the EU.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Under Boris Johnson’s deal, Scotland’s economy would be 6% weaker than if we remained.
extra_title: Claim that Brexit will cost every Scot £1,600 is not right
rating_alternateName: This is a dated estimate and isn’t definitive. 6% is roughly how much smaller the Scottish government estimated the country’s GDP would be in 2030 in the case of a free trade agreement where the UK leaves the EU customs union and single market, compared to if the UK had not left the EU.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Economic analysis says that [Scotland leaving the customs union and single market] will cost every person in Scotland £1,600.”

claimReview_claimReviewed: An independent Scotland wouldn’t be forced to join the euro once it applied to rejoin the EU.
extra_title: It’s unclear whether an independent Scotland could be forced to join the euro as an EU member
rating_alternateName: New member states are officially required to adopt the euro at some point unless they have negotiated specific opt-outs, but in practice it's unclear whether members would or could be forced to.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Guardian said “Lib Dems winning and on the up after by-election victory” in August 2019.
extra_title: Lib Dem leaflet falsely attributes pro-Lib Dem quote to the Guardian
rating_alternateName: This is misleading. The quote is an edited version of the Guardian headline, which made clear that the words originally came from Jo Swinson, not the Guardian itself.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Conservatives are polling 38% in North East Somerset, the Liberal Democrats are on 32%, and Labour are on 8%.
extra_title: You need to read the small print on this Lib Dem voting intention graph
rating_alternateName: These are the results of a poll asking how people in the area would vote if only the Liberal Democrats and Conservatives were competitive.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Headline vote intention figures from a poll of North East Somerset residents have the Lib Dems at 28%, in second place behind the Conservatives on 44%. Labour were third on 14%.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Lib Dems quadrupled renewable power in government.
extra_title: Did the Lib Dems quadruple renewable energy?
rating_alternateName: It was slightly closer to tripling than quadrupling, under the Conservative Lib Dem Coalition. But it’s difficult to attribute energy generation to any one party in government as some generators can take years to commission and build.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We have probably the best record of any political party in government. We nearly quadrupled renewable power for example.”

rating_alternateName: Correct looking at the headcount of GPs (excluding locums) in England between September 2015 and 2018. Looking at the full-time equivalent number of this group, which gives a better idea of staffing levels, the numbers are falling.

claimReview_claimReviewed: GP numbers are experiencing their first sustained fall for 50 years.
extra_title: GP numbers: up or down?
rating_alternateName: Correct, looking at the number of GPs (excluding registrars, retainers and locums) per 100,000 people across the UK since 1964.

extra_title: Express opinion piece wrong to allege evidence of widespread voter fraud in US elections
rating_alternateName: There is no evidence of widespread fraudulent ballots in the US election. It is correct that the predictions of many pollsters were found to be inaccurate.

extra_title: Express opinion piece wrong to allege evidence of widespread voter fraud in US elections
rating_alternateName: It is logical that Mr Biden received so many votes because turnout was relatively high. There is no evidence of widespread invalid votes. There is no evidence that Mr Trump and Mr Biden received the same popular vote. Mr Biden currently leads by around 4.5 million.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 100 companies are responsible for 71% of global emissions.
extra_title: Are 100 companies causing 71% of carbon emissions?
rating_alternateName: Of the estimated greenhouse gas emissions from human activity (excluding certain sources like agricultural methane) between 1988 and 2015, 71% originated from 100 fossil fuel producers. This includes the emissions released when the fossil fuels they sold were subsequently used by their customers.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “But part of the problem is, when you know that 100 companies are responsible for 71% of global emissions…”

extra_title: Child poverty is increasing and decreasing at the same time—here’s why
rating_alternateName: Correct, looking at relative poverty after housing costs. Over the long term, absolute child poverty in the UK is down while relative child poverty is stable, after housing costs.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Relative child poverty has increased for three consecutive years and now stands at 4.1 million, or 30 per cent of children.”
extra_title: Child poverty is increasing and decreasing at the same time—here’s why

claimReview_claimReviewed: Mass immigration has depressed wages, especially on the low skill level.
extra_title: What does immigration do to wages?
rating_alternateName: Studies find that immigration affects low-waged workers the most negatively. They disagree on whether it has been good or bad for wages overall but tend to show that the effect is small and also short-term.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There is little evidence that falling wages are being caused by migration, aside from in construction.
extra_title: What does immigration do to wages?
rating_alternateName: Studies find that immigration affects low-waged workers the most, in low-skilled and semi-skilled jobs generally not just in construction.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “I agree that unfettered mass immigration has been used to depress wages, especially on the low skill level.”

claimReview_claimReviewed: Funding for schools is down by 8% in real terms.
extra_title: Government school spending figures: correct but misleading
rating_alternateName: Correct. The IFS says spending per pupil in England fell by 8% in real terms from 2009/10 to 2017/18, and will be held constant from 2017/18 to 2019/20.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The OECD has ranked the UK as the third highest for education funding.
extra_title: Government school spending figures: correct but misleading
rating_alternateName: This includes private spending, so isn’t an accurate reflection of government funding.  In terms of public spending on education, as a percentage of GDP, the UK ranked joint-fourteenth out of 34 OECD countries that provided data in 2015. Education spending in the UK is devolved.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The IFS found that real terms per pupil funding in 2020 will be over 50 per cent higher than it was in 2000.
extra_title: Government school spending figures: correct but misleading
rating_alternateName: The IFS says: “The average level of spending per pupil by primary and secondary schools rose by around 5% per year in real terms during the 2000s and was then largely protected in real terms under the coalition government. Spending per pupil fell 4% in real terms between 2015–16 and 2017–18, but will be held constant in real terms up to 2019–20.”

claimReview_claimReviewed: There is more money going into our schools than ever before—a record £43.5 billion by 2020.
extra_title: Government school spending figures: correct but misleading
rating_alternateName: That’s not a helpful figure as it doesn’t account for inflation or pupil numbers.  Spending per pupil in England fell by 8% in real terms from 2009/10 to 2017/18, and will be held constant from 2017/18 to 2019/20.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “there is more money going into our schools than ever before—a record £43.5 billion by 2020… the IFS found that real terms per pupil funding in 2020 will be over 50 per cent higher than it was in 2000. It is true to say that the OECD has ranked the UK as the third highest for education funding… this includes tertiary and private education for every country.”
extra_title: Government school spending figures: correct but misleading

claimReview_claimReviewed: "We have consistently argued that funding for schools is down by 8% in real terms. The National Audit Office agrees, the Institute of Fiscal Studies agrees, parents can see it is true, as can the electorate."

claimReview_claimReviewed: We have 100,000 vacancies in our NHS.
extra_title: Are there 100,000 vacancies in the NHS?
rating_alternateName: NHS Improvement says there were 97,000 vacancies in NHS trusts in England between October-December 2017. It’s based on management information and is not an official statistic, so should be treated with some caution. Many of these “vacancies” are currently filled by temporary staff.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Theresa May refuses to allow the very best international doctors to come here to care for our sick.
extra_title: Are there 100,000 vacancies in the NHS?
rating_alternateName: The government limits the number of Tier 2 visas it grants each month. These are what non-EEA medical staff need to work in the UK. Nurses get priority access to these visas, but there are reports of some doctors being refused them due to government caps.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We have 100,000 vacancies in our NHS yet Theresa May refuses to allow the very best international doctors to come here to care for our sick.”
extra_title: Are there 100,000 vacancies in the NHS?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: British old age pensioners get £106 a week.
extra_title: Viral image about pensioners and refugees is wrong on every single number
rating_alternateName: A full British state pension is worth £125.95 or £164.35 a week before top-ups (depending on when you were born).

claimReview_claimReviewed: Immigrants/refugees living in the UK get a weekly allowance of £250.
extra_title: Viral image about pensioners and refugees is wrong on every single number
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. People given refugee status in the UK are not entitled to any special allowances, but can claim the same benefits as any UK citizen. Asylum seekers are entitled to £37.75 per week and accommodation if they are homeless and can’t afford food.

claimReview_claimReviewed: British old age pensioners get a weekly spouse allowance of £25 a week.
extra_title: Viral image about pensioners and refugees is wrong on every single number
rating_alternateName: A state pensioner may get an “Adult Dependency Increase” worth up to £68.35 a week if they have a partner who is financially dependent on them. They must have claimed before 2010 and it will no longer be paid from April 2020.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Illegal immigrants and refugees living in Britain get a weekly spouse allowance of £225.
extra_title: Viral image about pensioners and refugees is wrong on every single number
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. There is no weekly spouse allowance for refugees. People staying in the UK illegally are not entitled to claim any benefits.

claimReview_claimReviewed: British old age pensioners get a weekly hardship allowance of £0.
extra_title: Viral image about pensioners and refugees is wrong on every single number
rating_alternateName: Correct, insofar as the “weekly hardship allowance” doesn’t exist. Pensioners can claim additional benefits to help with their income.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Illegal immigrants and refugees living in Britain get a weekly hardship allowance of £100.
extra_title: Viral image about pensioners and refugees is wrong on every single number
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. This allowance does not exist.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A British old age pensioner gets a yearly benefit of £6,000.
extra_title: Viral image about pensioners and refugees is wrong on every single number
rating_alternateName: A full British state pension is worth up to £6,500 or £8,500 per year. Pensioners may also qualify for top-ups, partner support, and additional benefits.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Illegal immigrants and refugees living in Britain get a yearly benefit of £29,900.
extra_title: Viral image about pensioners and refugees is wrong on every single number
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. People who are staying in the UK illegally cannot claim any benefits. People living in the UK as refugees are entitled to the same benefit and pension payments as any UK citizen. This means it’s theoretically possible for them to get that sum, but it’s highly unlikely due to the benefit cap.

claimReview_claimReviewed: UK sick pay is 28 weeks. The EU does not set a minimum sick pay.
extra_title: UK workers’ rights: what are the rules on sick pay, maternity and annual leave?
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: In the UK we get 5.6 weeks of paid holiday. The EU sets paid holiday at four weeks.
extra_title: UK workers’ rights: what are the rules on sick pay, maternity and annual leave?
rating_alternateName: Correct. Those are minimum standards.

claimReview_claimReviewed: In the UK we get 52 weeks of maternity pay. The EU sets maternity pay at 14 weeks.
extra_title: UK workers’ rights: what are the rules on sick pay, maternity and annual leave?
rating_alternateName: This is incorrect for the UK. Maternity pay can be for up to 39 weeks. The EU minimum standard is 14 weeks of paid maternity leave.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK minimum wage is £8.21, and is soon to be £10.50. The EU hasn’t set a minimum wage.
extra_title: UK workers’ rights: what are the rules on sick pay, maternity and annual leave?
rating_alternateName: That’s the minimum wage for people over 25 in the UK. The Conservatives have pledged to raise the minimum for every over 21 to £10.50 by 2024 but it’s not yet law. It’s correct that the EU doesn’t set a minimum wage.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
What is it that @UKLabour are trying protect? 🥀
🇬🇧 Sick Pay: 28 weeks
🇪🇺: None set
🇬🇧 Holiday Pay: 5.6 weeks
🇪🇺: 4 weeks
🇬🇧 Maternity Pay: 52 weeks
🇪🇺: 14 weeks
🇬🇧 Minimum Wage: £8.21 soon be be £10.50
🇪🇺: None set
extra_title: UK workers’ rights: what are the rules on sick pay, maternity and annual leave?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Our boys” didn’t change the handball and VAR rules in association football.
extra_title: Did “our boys” change the handball rule?
rating_alternateName: Changes to the VAR rules were made unanimously by IFAB. British football associations had the ability to veto this change, but all four voted in favour. Details of the vote to change the handball rule have not yet been released, but at least two of the four British FAs would have had to vote in favour of it.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
[On the VAR decision to disallow a Manchester City goal for handball in their 2-2 draw against Tottenham Hotspur]
“So I don’t think that’s our boys making up that new change of law. I think that’s people telling us what we should do with our game. They should stop doing that. I hope we get out of Brexit because that’s what we all voted for. And sort that out because you cannot have someone telling us how to do our own game.
extra_title: Did “our boys” change the handball rule?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: People in Poland retire at 60.
extra_title: UK taxpayers aren’t subsidising France’s 35-hour working week
rating_alternateName: The retirement age for women in Poland is 60—the lowest level in the EU. For men it’s 65 (which is the most common retirement age for men and women in EU countries).

claimReview_claimReviewed: The working week in France is 35 hours.
extra_title: UK taxpayers aren’t subsidising France’s 35-hour working week
rating_alternateName: Correct. A full working week in France is officially set at 35 hours. Many employees agree to work more than 35 hours per week—but they will be compensated for this, for example through additional holiday.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The working week in Germany is 28 hours.
extra_title: UK taxpayers aren’t subsidising France’s 35-hour working week
rating_alternateName: This is only for some workers. In 2018, Germany’s largest trade union won a two-year deal for its 900,000 members to work a 28-hour week. German employees can work up to 40 hours a week. If they work longer than this, they must be compensated through additional holiday.

claimReview_claimReviewed: We make one of the biggest contributions to the EU budget.
extra_title: UK taxpayers aren’t subsidising France’s 35-hour working week
rating_alternateName: Correct.  The UK contributes roughly the third largest sum of money into the EU budget behind Germany and France, and a similar amount to Italy.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Poland, France and Germany have cheap travel and utilities subsidised by Europe.
extra_title: UK taxpayers aren’t subsidising France’s 35-hour working week
rating_alternateName: Some of the EU budget is invested in transport and energy programmes. But it does not simply subsidise existing services for EU citizens. The UK is also a recipient of this funding.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Theresa May has increased subsidies for grouse shooting from £45 million to £84 million a year.
extra_title: Does the government subsidise grouse shooting?
rating_alternateName:
Moorland in England used for grouse shooting is eligible for agricultural subsidy, though the act of shooting itself isn’t subsidised.

Data on the total subsidy paid to grouse moors isn’t published, though the £45 and £84 million figures are likely to be overestimates.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Why has Theresa May just increased taxpayer subsidies for her wealthy mates’ sport of grouse shooting from £45 million to £84 million a year?”
extra_title: Does the government subsidise grouse shooting?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Since 2000 we’ve given the EU £100 billion more than we’ve got back.
extra_title: This claim about the UK's EU contribution is correct, but meaningless
rating_alternateName: Broadly correct. Since 2000 the UK has made a net contribution in cash terms of £109 billion. That’s £122 billion in real terms.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK gives the EU £12 billion per year.
extra_title: This claim about the UK's EU contribution is correct, but meaningless
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. Last year the UK made a net contribution of up to £9 billion (not counting any money that goes to the UK private sector).

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK’s net EU contribution is larger than 26 EU nations combined (all but Germany).
extra_title: This claim about the UK's EU contribution is correct, but meaningless
rating_alternateName: Technically correct, but this statistic is meaningless. In 2017 the UK’s net contribution to the EU was 18% of all net contributors.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Theresa May has agreed a £39 billion Brexit bill with the EU.
extra_title: This claim about the UK's EU contribution is correct, but meaningless
rating_alternateName: The UK government has agreed to a Brexit bill in principle, though an exact amount hasn’t been confirmed. The latest estimates suggest it will be around £35-39 billion.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The UK’s net EU contribution is larger than 26 EU nations combined (all but Germany).”
extra_title: This claim about the UK's EU contribution is correct, but meaningless
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Since 2000 we’ve given the EU £100bn more than we’ve got back.”
extra_title: This claim about the UK's EU contribution is correct, but meaningless

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The UK gives the EU £12 billion per year.”
extra_title: This claim about the UK's EU contribution is correct, but meaningless
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK is one of the three countries that puts the most money into the EU budget.
extra_title: The UK is one of the biggest contributors to the EU budget
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “With all the money that we put into it (the EU), we are one of the three countries that put the most money into it”.
extra_title: The UK is one of the biggest contributors to the EU budget
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK could not bring in safer lorry designs until the EU legislated on the matter.
extra_title: Do EU rules prevent safer lorries?
rating_alternateName: The EU sets rules on permitted lorry dimensions, which we have to follow. But the EU voted to allow safer lorry designs in 2014, a plan which the UK government initially opposed.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Indeed we seem to have gone backwards since the last Chequers meeting in February, when I described my frustrations, as Mayor of London, in trying to protect cyclists from juggernauts. We had wanted to lower the cabin windows to improve visibility; and even though such designs were already on the market, and even though there had been a horriﬁc spate of deaths, mainly of female cyclists, we were told that we had to wait for the EU to legislate on the matter… If a country cannot pass a law to save the lives of female cyclists - when that proposal is supported at every level of UK government - then I don't see how that country can truly be called independent.”
extra_title: Do EU rules prevent safer lorries?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK gets more in EU research funding than it puts in.
extra_title: EU research funding
rating_alternateName: Correct, although the UK pays more into the EU budget overall than it gets out.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Just in terms of research financing—I’m an academic—8.8 billion is what the UK has gotten from the European Union in the last five years, while they only contributed 5.4 billion. We have been net beneficiaries of the European Union.”
extra_title: EU research funding
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Tax evasion and tax avoidance costs the government £34 billion a year.
extra_title: Tax: evasion and avoidance in the UK
rating_alternateName: This is wrong, according to the estimates it's using. HMRC estimates that £2.7 billion was lost through tax avoidance and £4.4 billion through tax evasion in 2013/14. £34 billion is the total value of tax that goes uncollected.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “HMRC estimates that illegal tax evasion and legal tax avoidance together cost the government about £34 billion a year”.
extra_title: Tax: evasion and avoidance in the UK
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Leaving the EU would or could cut net migration by 100,000
extra_title: Would net migration fall by 100,000 if the UK left the EU?
rating_alternateName: Nobody knows. It’s an unofficial “ball park figure” for one possible exit scenario and the prediction depends on assumptions which might or might not come true.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Leaving EU 'would cut migration by 100,000' - Migration Watch
extra_title: Would net migration fall by 100,000 if the UK left the EU?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: EU immigrants pay £1.34 in taxes for every £1 they receive in state assistance
extra_title: Do EU immigrants contribute £1.34 for every £1 received from the UK?
rating_alternateName: Research has found this for recent immigrants from other EU countries, but counting those who came before 2000 reduces this figure. This is a difficult thing to measure, and other research has different findings.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “EU migrants pay £1.34 in taxes for every £1 they receive in state assistance”
extra_title: Do EU immigrants contribute £1.34 for every £1 received from the UK?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: EU airports are punishing Britain for Brexit with long queues caused by tougher security checks.
extra_title: European airport delays—is Brexit to blame?
rating_alternateName: The stricter EU border controls were proposed six months before the EU referendum in December 2015 and came into force in April 2017. The controls affect all passengers entering and leaving the European border-free Schengen area, not just UK citizens.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “MPs hit back after passengers blame huge passport queues at European airports on decision to leave EU – even though it has nothing to do with vote”
extra_title: European airport delays—is Brexit to blame?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “New border rules are just EU’s bid to punish Britain”
extra_title: European airport delays—is Brexit to blame?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Cuts to tax credits will cost low-paid working families £1,300 a year.
extra_title: Will changes to tax credits cost families £1,300 a year?
rating_alternateName: £1,300 is a "rough" estimate of the average reduction in income next year (2016/17).

claimReview_claimReviewed: "The Tory conference was a feast of spin and deception. Fake claims to be on the side of working people while robbing three million low paid families of £1,300 a year with the Tax Credit cuts."
extra_title: Will changes to tax credits cost families £1,300 a year?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Poverty is being redefined to remove any reference to income.
extra_title: Ask Full Fact: is poverty being redefined to remove any reference to income?
rating_alternateName: A bill going through Parliament contains plans to replace existing income indicators of child poverty with ones that focus on worklessness and educational attainment. The annual statistics on the income measures will still be published but they won't be the government's main poverty indicators.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Per head, Norway pays almost the same amount into the EU budget as the UK.
extra_title: Norway's EU payments
rating_alternateName: Norway’s payments linked to its relationship with the EU are around two thirds of what the UK pays per head of population, before money comes back. Comparing payments after money comes back is difficult, but seems to narrow the gap still further.

claimReview_claimReviewed: In January 2020 a new EU law means anyone who has an offshore bank account will have to “come clean so we can see how much they are hiding”.
extra_title: Claim Brexit is about concealing offshore accounts is baseless
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. There is no such EU law coming into place.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “come January 2020 the EU are bringing in a law saying that anyone who has a Off shore account will have to come clean so we can see how much they are hiding and to see if it can be taxed. No longer being able to get away with tax avoidance & evasion is what Brexit is about”
extra_title: Claim Brexit is about concealing offshore accounts is baseless
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are 26,911 words in the EU regulations on the sale of cabbages.
extra_title: The cabbage myth returns: EU cabbage regulations don’t have 26,911 words
rating_alternateName: This is false. It’s a long-running myth that has been around since the 1951, and was originally about a USA government agency.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The EU is the only place where free ports don’t really exist.
extra_title: What’s a free port, and does the EU have them?
rating_alternateName: Free ports do exist within the EU, although in a more limited form than elsewhere in the world.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The EU has stopped the UK from having free ports.
extra_title: What’s a free port, and does the EU have them?
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. Free ports exist within the EU. The UK had free ports until 2012. However, EU law means free ports exist in a more limited form than elsewhere in the world.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The EU is the only place where these [free ports] really don’t exist…”
extra_title: What’s a free port, and does the EU have them?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “[We can] use that opportunity of Brexit to do the kind of things that we’ve been precluded from doing for decades, including free ports…”
extra_title: What’s a free port, and does the EU have them?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: EU regulation means kipper sellers must package their kippers in ice.
extra_title: Boris Johnson’s kipper claim is a red herring
rating_alternateName: This is incorrect. The EU does not set any requirements on the temperature at which smoked fish must be transported. The temperature requirement is a UK regulation.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “I want you to consider this kipper which has been presented to me just now by the editor of a national newspaper who received it from a kipper smoker in the Isle of Man who is utterly furious because, after decades of sending kippers like this through the post, he has had his costs massively increased by Brussels bureaucrats who have insisted that each kipper must be accompanied by this, a plastic ice pillow .”
extra_title: Boris Johnson’s kipper claim is a red herring
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The overwhelming majority of other EU countries have no steel industry to protect.
extra_title: Does most of the EU have no steel industry?
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. Seven EU countries produce more steel than the UK, including large economies like Germany, Italy, and France. The UK is responsible for 4% of the EU’s crude steel production.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If the UK were in a customs union with the EU, we’ll be reliant on the European Union to protect our steel industry.
extra_title: Does most of the EU have no steel industry?
rating_alternateName: Being in a customs union with the EU means we have to apply the same tariffs on steel imports as the rest of the EU does.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If (Labour MPs) want to protect UK industries such as the steel industry from unfair dumping at below market prices, they should bear in mind that if we’re in a customs union they’ll be reliant on the European Union to protect our industry. And the overwhelming majority of the remaining EU27 probably quite like buying Chinese steel or whatever below world prices because they have no steel industry to protect.”
extra_title: Does most of the EU have no steel industry?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A £20 billion funding increase to the NHS will be paid for in part through the ‘Brexit dividend’.
extra_title: Does the ‘Brexit dividend’ exist?
rating_alternateName: There is no guaranteed extra money to pay for increased NHS funding from stopping our payments to the EU budget. Other costs associated with Brexit are expected to outweigh the savings.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We must fund [the £20 billion boost to NHS spending]. That will be through the Brexit dividend. The fact we are no longer sending vast amounts of money every year to the EU once we leave the EU. As a country we will be contributing a bit more.
extra_title: Does the ‘Brexit dividend’ exist?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Some of the extra funding I'm promising today will come from using the money we will no longer spend on our annual membership subscription to the European Union after we have left.
extra_title: Does the ‘Brexit dividend’ exist?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The EU’s accounts haven’t been signed off for years.
extra_title: Is the EU’s budget ‘signed off’ by auditors?
rating_alternateName: Auditors say the accounts have been accurate since 2007. But they have historically recorded significant errors in how money is paid since their first audit in 1995. In the most recent year, they found a significant part of the EU’s spending was largely error-free for the first time.

claimReview_claimReviewed: After leaving the EU, we will take back control of roughly £350 million per week.
extra_title: £350 million EU claim "a clear misuse of official statistics"
rating_alternateName: This is wrong, it’s more like £250 million a week. In any case the impact on the economy from changes to trade after leaving the EU is likely to be far bigger than savings from the UK’s membership fee.

claimReview_claimReviewed: And yes – once we have settled our accounts, we will take back control of roughly £350 million per week. It would be a fine thing, as many of us have pointed out, if a lot of that money went on the NHS”
extra_title: £350 million EU claim "a clear misuse of official statistics"
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: In three months we fell from being the fastest growing economy in the G7 to the slowest growing in the group.
extra_title: Brexit: is the UK economy growing or slowing?
rating_alternateName: The UK was the fastest growing economy in the G7 in the last three months of 2016. It dropped to one of the three slowest in the first three months of this year, sitting alongside Italy and the USA at the bottom of the pile.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Treasury forecast a recession if the UK voted to leave the EU.
extra_title: Brexit: is the UK economy growing or slowing?
rating_alternateName: That’s correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Forecasts from [the Treasury] said immediately after the vote to leave in the referendum there would be a minus, there would be a reduction in the size of the British economy in the last quarter and the current quarter. What happened? We were one of the fastest growing nations in the G7 in that time.”
extra_title: Brexit: is the UK economy growing or slowing?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “David... just this week it’s been revealed that we have plummeted as a country from the fastest-growing economy amongst developed economies to the slowest in a three-month period”
extra_title: Brexit: is the UK economy growing or slowing?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Mobile roaming fees could return for Brits in the EU after Brexit after Theresa May confirms exit from bloc’s digital market.
extra_title: Mobile roaming fees could be back after Brexit
rating_alternateName: Correct. EU regulations mean we can’t currently be charged roaming fees within the EU. After Brexit, we'll no longer be subject to these regulations. It’s unclear if UK mobile companies will bring back roaming charges, nor if a UK-EU roaming regulation agreement can be reached.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Mobile roaming fees could return for Brits in the EU after Brexit after Theresa May confirms exit from bloc’s digital market”
extra_title: Mobile roaming fees could be back after Brexit
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Halting changes to the Personal Independence Payment will create a £4.4 billion “black hole” in the budget.
extra_title: Does George Osborne have a £4.4bn black hole in his budget?
rating_alternateName: £4.4 billion isn’t a helpful way to describe the budget’s “black hole” caused by the withdrawal of the changes—it adds up all the spending over the five years to 2020/21. Dropping the policy will make public finances £1.3 billion worse off than they would have been by the end of the Parliament. And the government was already relying on £3.5 billion other savings that have yet to be identified.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If the Chancellor halts the attack on disabled people, a £4.4 billion black hole is created in the Budget.”
extra_title: Does George Osborne have a £4.4bn black hole in his budget?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Boris Johnson said "we have wiped out the national debt".
extra_title: This quote attributed to Boris Johnson is not real
rating_alternateName: There is no evidence he said this.

claimReview_claimReviewed: It was this Conservative government that tackled the debt.
extra_title: This quote attributed to Boris Johnson is not real
rating_alternateName: The government’s debt has risen from £1 trillion (or 64% of GDP) in May 2010 to £1.8 trillion (or 81% of GDP) now.

claimReview_claimReviewed: It was this Conservative government that tackled the deficit.
extra_title: This quote attributed to Boris Johnson is not real
rating_alternateName: The deficit (how much the government borrows each year) fell from £158 billion (or 10% of GDP) in 2009/10 to £41 billion (2% of GDP) in 2018/19.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The Tories have taken the national debt to 1.8 trillion pounds. Boris Johnson at conference - "we have wiped out the national debt". Facts don't matter anymore.”
extra_title: This quote attributed to Boris Johnson is not real
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “It was this Conservative government that tackled the debt and the deficit left by the last Labour government.”
extra_title: This quote attributed to Boris Johnson is not real
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Since the Conservatives came to government, national debt has increased from £0.95 trillion to £2 trillion.
extra_title: What is the UK’s public debt?
rating_alternateName: Not quite. Over that period debt has risen from £1 trillion to £1.8 trillion.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “In 2010, when the Conservatives took over, national debt was £0.95trillion. So they promised to reduce it and said we can trust them with the economy. But now it’s £2.0trillion.”
extra_title: What is the UK’s public debt?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The OECD says that jobs and earnings in the UK are good.
extra_title: UK economy; what was the OECD's verdict?
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The OECD says that important steps have been taken in the UK to improve educational outcomes.
extra_title: UK economy; what was the OECD's verdict?
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The OECD says that fiscal sustainability in the UK has improved.
extra_title: UK economy; what was the OECD's verdict?
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The OECD says that the UK has the most efficient, accessible healthcare system.
extra_title: UK economy; what was the OECD's verdict?
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The OECD says that the UK’s healthcare efficiency is weak.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The OECD says about the United Kingdom:  we have the most efficient, accessible healthcare system, fiscal sustainability has improved, important steps have been taken to improve educational outcomes, and jobs and earnings are good. That’s what the OECD says about the strong economy under this Conservative government.
extra_title: UK economy; what was the OECD's verdict?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Young people are in record levels of debt.
extra_title: Young people in record levels of debt?
rating_alternateName: We don’t have enough information to say if debt levels of all young people—including those who don’t go to university—are at record levels. The average debt of university graduates is the highest it has been.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Young people are in record levels of debt. This week, the Financial Conduct Authority warned of a ‘pronounced build-up of indebtedness amongst the younger age group’ to fund ‘essential living costs’.”
extra_title: Young people in record levels of debt?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: We spend nearly £50 billion on debt interest in the UK.
extra_title: Does the government spend £50 billion on debt interest payments?
rating_alternateName: The government’s debt interest bill was £48 billion in 2016/17, although it effectively paid some of that back to itself through the Bank of England. The government actually spent about £39 billion.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Today we spend nearly £50 billion in payments on interest to those we have borrowed from as a result of the legacy of the Labour party. That is more than the NHS pay bill, it is more than our schools budget, more than we spend on defence, as a result of the record we were left by Labour in government”
extra_title: Does the government spend £50 billion on debt interest payments?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Basic rate taxpayers under this government have seen a tax cut equivalent of £1,000.
extra_title: Income tax cuts for basic rate payers
rating_alternateName: This is correct using Treasury analysis comparing a basic rate taxpayer in 2017/18 to 2010/11.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government has taken millions of people out of paying income tax.
extra_title: Income tax cuts for basic rate payers
rating_alternateName: Increases in the personal allowance since 2010 mean four million additional people now below the threshold don’t pay income tax.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “...we have taken millions of people out of paying income tax altogether [and] basic rate taxpayers under this government have seen a tax cut equivalent of £1,000”
extra_title: Income tax cuts for basic rate payers
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Obesity costs the economy £27 billion a year.
extra_title: What does obesity cost the economy?
rating_alternateName: This is the best estimate we’ve got of the total cost of obesity and being overweight to the NHS and the economy. But it’s based on analysis that’s over a decade old and there’s a lot of uncertainty to the numbers.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Obesity drives disease. It increases the risk of cancer, diabetes and heart disease—and it costs our economy £27 billion a year.”
extra_title: What does obesity cost the economy?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A legal judgment over Article 50 doesn’t stop us from leaving the EU.
extra_title: What does the High Court’s Article 50 ruling mean for Brexit?
rating_alternateName: Correct. The judges didn’t, and couldn’t, block Brexit. But they said that the government can’t leave the EU without Parliament passing a law.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “This judgment today has caused a great deal of concern. I think it’s quite significant for a number of reasons. But it’s not significant in that it will stop us from leaving the European Union”
extra_title: What does the High Court’s Article 50 ruling mean for Brexit?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK could change its mind about withdrawing from the EU even after triggering the formal process of leaving under Article 50.
extra_title: Can the UK change its mind about leaving the EU?
rating_alternateName: Article 50 doesn’t say whether or not a country can change its mind, so it’s arguable either way. Some eminent lawyers think that it can, but there are also those – especially within the EU itself – who argue that once a country has triggered Article 50 it can’t then abort the process without permission.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “There is a little-known loophole in Article 50 that would keep the UK in the EU even after the request is triggered. Basically, the UK can change its mind after the Article 50 request is made as long as no final agreement on Brexit has been reached.”
extra_title: Can the UK change its mind about leaving the EU?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The official Leave campaign is getting a similar amount of money as the Remain campaign.
extra_title: Who’s getting taxpayers’ money in the EU referendum?
rating_alternateName: The government is spending an estimated £9 million sending pro-Remain leaflets to all UK households. This is on top of what the official campaign groups on either side of the debate will get in public money, which includes a free mailout.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
John Humphrys: “They [the Leave campaign] cannot access £9 million of taxpayers’ money”
Michael Fallon (Defence Secretary): “But they’re getting around £7 million to produce their leaflet”
John Humphrys: “Ah but you’re [the Remain campaign] getting that as well”
extra_title: Who’s getting taxpayers’ money in the EU referendum?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: After leaving the EU, the UK will be able to abolish VAT on energy bills.
extra_title: NHS, EU funding and VAT: possible effects of leaving the EU
rating_alternateName: EU rules mean we cannot reduce VAT on household energy any lower than the 5% that’s currently charged. If the UK left, it would be possible to reduce VAT on household fuel below this rate.

claimReview_claimReviewed: After leaving the EU and replacing EU funding, the UK will have additional savings to spend on priorities such as the NHS.
extra_title: NHS, EU funding and VAT: possible effects of leaving the EU
rating_alternateName: Most economists forecast that savings on the EU membership fee would be outweighed by slower economic growth. Without raising taxes or borrowing more, the government would have less money to spend on public services.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "…we conclude that leaving the EU would not, as Michael Gove claims we said, leave more money to spend on the NHS. Rather it would leave us spending less on public services, or taxing more, or borrowing more."
extra_title: NHS, EU funding and VAT: possible effects of leaving the EU
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: High levels of EU immigration mean the government hasn't been able to cut net migration to the tens of thousands
extra_title: Is EU immigration to blame for missing the net migration target?
rating_alternateName: Net migration from other EU countries isn't the only reason the government hasn't met its net migration target.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "We have seen many more people from the EU coming to Britain than originally anticipated … as a result, our action has not been enough to cut annual net migration to the tens of thousands"
extra_title: Is EU immigration to blame for missing the net migration target?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "I want to see immigration come down. That's why we've taken all the steps we have. It hasn't worked so far because of the large numbers coming from inside the EU"
extra_title: Is EU immigration to blame for missing the net migration target?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Restricting in-work benefits to EU migrants would make a huge difference to EU migration.
extra_title: Would restricting in-work benefits to EU migrants reduce immigration?
rating_alternateName: This is far from certain. There is no direct evidence that welfare is a prime pull factor for a significant number of EU migrants coming to the UK.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Just to get this clear, you are asking me what impact changing the benefit rules for EU migration, so that it becomes more difficult to obtain, is likely to have? … In my opinion, not much".
extra_title: Would restricting in-work benefits to EU migrants reduce immigration?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "I think it makes a huge difference if you deal with the issue of migrancy through welfare … Taking out part of the pull factor of people coming over, who can declare themselves to be on zero earnings and getting tax credits and maybe doing cash-in-hand elsewhere, these are all problems the country faces and we need to deal with".
extra_title: Would restricting in-work benefits to EU migrants reduce immigration?

claimReview_claimReviewed: Emmanuel Macron said the UK will only be allowed to stay in the EU if they fully adopt all EU rules and regulations including adopting the Euro within six months of stopping Brexit.
extra_title: Emmanuel Macron hasn’t said the UK must join the Euro if it wants to remain in the EU
rating_alternateName: He hasn’t said this. If the UK remained in the EU we would have to continue following EU law, but not in areas where we have opt-outs. This means we wouldn’t have to join the Euro.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Emmanuel Macron said the UK must take its share of migrants, 300,000 now immediately and up to 100,000 every year until the situation is resolved if it wants to remain in the EU.
extra_title: Emmanuel Macron hasn’t said the UK must join the Euro if it wants to remain in the EU
rating_alternateName: He hasn’t said this.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Emmanuel Macron said the UK must pay in full the costs involved for all other member states for Brexit, currently 39 billion euros if it wants to remain in the EU.
extra_title: Emmanuel Macron hasn’t said the UK must join the Euro if it wants to remain in the EU
rating_alternateName: He hasn’t said this. Under the terms of the Brexit withdrawal agreement, we’ll pay the EU an estimated £39 billion “divorce bill” for outstanding commitments and liabilities. If we remain in the EU, we would pay our membership fee each year which would cover all these things.

claimReview_claimReviewed: the UK will only be allowed to stay in the EU if they fully adopt all EU rules and regulations including adopting the Euro with 6 months of stopping Brexit
extra_title: Emmanuel Macron hasn’t said the UK must join the Euro if it wants to remain in the EU
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK must take its share of migrants, 300,000 now immediately and up to 100,000 every year until the situation is resolved.
extra_title: Emmanuel Macron hasn’t said the UK must join the Euro if it wants to remain in the EU
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK must pay in full the costs involved for all other member states for Brexit, currently 39 billion euros.
extra_title: Emmanuel Macron hasn’t said the UK must join the Euro if it wants to remain in the EU
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Lisbon treaty calls for EU member nations to be part of the euro by 2020.
extra_title: The UK won’t have to adopt the Euro by 2020
rating_alternateName: Incorrect.  The treaty aims for the euro becoming the currency of all member states of the Union but it isn’t time limited and the UK has an explicit opt-out.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The Lisbon Treaty which actually calls, within the text, for all EU member nations, hopefully, to be part of the euro by 2020,” Kris Hicks, UKIP Head of Press and Communications.
extra_title: The UK won’t have to adopt the Euro by 2020
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: All EU members have to adopt the Euro after 2020.
extra_title: EU member countries don’t all have to join the Euro by 2020
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The UK and Denmark have opt-outs so don’t have to join the Euro. The seven countries without an opt-out and not already in the Euro are supposed to join it, but only once they meet certain conditions. There is currently no time limit on this process.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “I’ve just been hearing that the European Union is now telling all the other non-Eurozone countries that after 2020 they’re all going to have to abandon their currencies and have the Euro.”
extra_title: EU member countries don’t all have to join the Euro by 2020
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “After 2020, all EU members will have to adopt the euro”
extra_title: EU member countries don’t all have to join the Euro by 2020
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: According to the Lisbon Treaty, in 2022, financial centres will all be moved to Strasbourg.
extra_title: Most of these claims about the EU aren’t true and have nothing to do with the Lisbon Treaty
rating_alternateName: This is not true.

claimReview_claimReviewed: According to the Lisbon Treaty, in 2022, all gas, oil and minerals will become owned by the EU.
extra_title: Most of these claims about the EU aren’t true and have nothing to do with the Lisbon Treaty
rating_alternateName: This is not true. Individual governments decide who can mine and produce these products, and where. The licensing rules for oil and gas are decided by the EU, but the UK is keeping these in place in the case of a no deal Brexit.

claimReview_claimReviewed: According to the Lisbon Treaty, in 2022, our fishing rights become owned by EU.
extra_title: Most of these claims about the EU aren’t true and have nothing to do with the Lisbon Treaty
