rating_alternateName: Being in the EU does mean the amount each country can fish per species is limited. Current policy says countries can limit who fishes in their waters to those who have traditionally done so. The Lisbon Treaty isn’t set to change any of this in 2022.

claimReview_claimReviewed: According to the Lisbon Treaty, in 2022, there will be no more monarch.
extra_title: Most of these claims about the EU aren’t true and have nothing to do with the Lisbon Treaty
rating_alternateName: This is not true. There are no plans for the EU to remove the heads of state of its members.

claimReview_claimReviewed: According to the Lisbon Treaty, in 2022 we have to give up our nationality.
extra_title: Most of these claims about the EU aren’t true and have nothing to do with the Lisbon Treaty
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. There are no developed plans to change the nationalities of member states in any year.

claimReview_claimReviewed: According to the Lisbon Treaty, in 2022 we would have to give up our sovereignty.
extra_title: Most of these claims about the EU aren’t true and have nothing to do with the Lisbon Treaty
rating_alternateName: EU law does has supremacy over domestic law in some areas. The UK has some veto power and several opt-outs. If no EU law is applicable, UK parliament and courts are supreme. The Lisbon Treaty, which came into force in 2009, doesn’t mention anything about this changing in 2022.

claimReview_claimReviewed: According to the Lisbon Treaty, in 2022 we become an EU state.
extra_title: Most of these claims about the EU aren’t true and have nothing to do with the Lisbon Treaty
rating_alternateName: The treaty came into force in 2009, nothing is due to change in 2022. There are no developed plans for the creation of a single EU state.

claimReview_claimReviewed: According to the Lisbon Treaty, in 2022 we would have to give up our currency.
extra_title: Most of these claims about the EU aren’t true and have nothing to do with the Lisbon Treaty
rating_alternateName: Incorrect, nothing is due to change in 2022 and the UK has an opt-out of the euro.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Have you read the Lisbon Treaty – If we stay in – In 2022 we become an EU state, and have to give up our currency, sovereignty, and nationality. No more Queen (or King as it may be). Also our fishing rights become owned by EU, and all gas, oil, minerals, all EU property. Financial centres all moved to Strasbourg – All agreed in the Lisbon Treaty”.
extra_title: Most of these claims about the EU aren’t true and have nothing to do with the Lisbon Treaty
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Norway and Switzerland have to accept EU laws despite not being members in order to trade with it.
extra_title: Norway, Switzerland and EU laws
rating_alternateName: This is about right. Both Norway and Switzerland keep out of some EU activities, such as the Common Agricultural Policy. But they bring many of their laws into line with EU rules, on the single market in particular. Norway incorporates single market rules as they’re made, while Switzerland accepts EU law from time to time in return for more market access.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The government has published an analysis of the UK's options if it left the EU… the document says Norway and Switzerland's trading arrangements outside the EU require them to… be subject to other EU laws.”
extra_title: Norway, Switzerland and EU laws
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “In practice… Switzerland has a similar position to Norway – it is obliged to follow EU rules in its own laws.”
extra_title: Norway, Switzerland and EU laws
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A decision of the European Court of Human Rights means that the police have to warn criminals about serious threats to their life.
extra_title: Human rights law means police warnings for people at risk of being killed
rating_alternateName: ‘Threat to life warnings’ are a police response to the human rights court’s requirement that the state sometimes has to be proactive in protecting people from threats. That decision dates from 1998, and wasn’t about criminals in particular.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Euro judges order police to ‘protect’ gangsters: Officers forced to issue ‘threat to life notices’ to villains and drug lords”
extra_title: Human rights law means police warnings for people at risk of being killed
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Lord Kerr, who sits on the UK Supreme Court, wrote Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union.
extra_title: The Lord Kerr who wrote Article 50 isn’t the Lord Kerr who sits on the Supreme Court
rating_alternateName: Wrong. There are two Lord Kerrs. John Kerr, who was one of the authors of Article 50, does not sit on the Supreme Court. That’s Brian Kerr.

claimReview_claimReviewed: One in six asylum seekers didn’t meet with border officials and have vanished.
extra_title: Have 12,000 asylum seekers vanished in the UK?
rating_alternateName: Almost 12,000 asylum seekers, or around one in six, are listed as having their case “On Hold” but the Home Office says this includes people who missed a first asylum interview and attended later, rather than vanishing. Its data doesn’t make this clear.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “An investigation has shown that of 77,440 asylum cases in progress, one in six skipped their first meeting with border chiefs and vanished.”
extra_title: Have 12,000 asylum seekers vanished in the UK?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “That figure includes people who have attended subsequent meetings after missing their first appointment and doesn’t mean people have dropped off the radar...”
extra_title: Have 12,000 asylum seekers vanished in the UK?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The NHS operates on the wrong part of someone’s body four times a day.
extra_title: Jeremy Hunt muddled the numbers on botched surgeries
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. In the English NHS surgeons operate on the wrong part of someone’s body four times a week, according to figures from April to November 2019.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “NHS operates on the wrong body part four times a day, ex-Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt reveals.”
extra_title: Jeremy Hunt muddled the numbers on botched surgeries
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Each month 22 NHS patients with glaucoma unnecessarily lose their sight due to NHS treatment delays.
extra_title: Up to 260 UK patients per year experience vision loss because of healthcare delays
rating_alternateName: Researchers estimate up to 22 patients per month in the UK experience vision deterioration due to health service delays, but not all from glaucoma.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Patients are now waiting over two weeks on average to see a GP.
extra_title: We can’t say patients are waiting over two weeks to see a GP on average
rating_alternateName: There are no reliable figures that prove this. This refers to non-urgent appointments at GP practices, but the figure isn’t necessarily representative of GP practices nor patients across the UK.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Scandal over 15-day wait for GP”
extra_title: We can’t say patients are waiting over two weeks to see a GP on average
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Patients are now waiting longer than two weeks on average to see a GP”
extra_title: We can’t say patients are waiting over two weeks to see a GP on average
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The NHS has published its very first price lists for treatments.
extra_title: Is the NHS introducing price lists for treatments?
rating_alternateName: The list in question was published last year and offers patients who do not qualify for NHS funding for certain treatments the option to “self-fund”. Some hospitals have been offering similar schemes since at least 2013.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There were 2.7 million more patients every year using good and outstanding hospitals at the end of Jeremy Hunt’s tenure as Health Secretary than at the beginning.
extra_title: Are three million more patients using good or outstanding hospitals?
rating_alternateName: This is how many more admissions there were in 2017/18 to hospital trusts that had improved their rating to good or outstanding (between 2013 and 2019) than admissions to trusts that had dropped their rating to requires improvement or inadequate.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “But as the health secretary… I was even prouder about the improvements in care for individual patients and their families - with 2.7 million more patients every year using good or outstanding hospitals by the end.”
extra_title: Are three million more patients using good or outstanding hospitals?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “By the time I left… nearly three million more patients were being treated in good or outstanding hospitals.”
extra_title: Are three million more patients using good or outstanding hospitals?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “And by the end nearly 3m more patients were using good or outstanding hospitals.”
extra_title: Are three million more patients using good or outstanding hospitals?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The NHS Long Term Plan will save 500,000 lives.
extra_title: It’s unclear exactly how NHS England plans to save 500,000 lives
rating_alternateName: It’s unclear how this will happen. NHS England hasn’t published much detail on how it calculated this figure. We’ve asked them for more information.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The NHS Long Term Plan, published today, will save almost half a million more lives with practical action on major killer conditions and investment in world class, cutting edge treatments including genomic tests for every child with cancer.”
extra_title: It’s unclear exactly how NHS England plans to save 500,000 lives
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The rate of extra investment in the NHS has fallen by 68% since 2010.
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: Correct, although this refers to growth in all UK health spending, rather than just for the NHS. It compares the periods 1955/56 to 2015/16 (when health spending grew by an average of 4% in real terms each year) and 2009/10 to 2015/16 (when it grew by an average of 1.3% a year).

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are 16,481 fewer beds in hospitals since 2010.
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: This is in the right ballpark, but it doesn’t seem to be the best comparison. It seems to compare the number of beds at different times of the year, but the number available fluctuates seasonally. Comparing July-September in 2010 and 2017, the decrease in beds available overnight in England is closer to 13,200.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 66 A&E; and maternity wards have been closed.
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: We don’t know, as this information isn’t collected nationally. In 2014, there were reportedly plans to close or downgrade 66 in England, but while some have been, others have stayed open.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 103 NHS walk-in centres have closed or been downgraded since 2010.
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: We don’t know exactly, as this information isn’t collected centrally. Research from an NHS regulator and from campaign group 38 Degrees suggests more than 90 have been closed or downgraded.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 60 ambulance stations have closed since 2010.
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: We don’t know how many ambulance stations have closed since 2010 as national figures on this aren’t regularly published.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 1,000 GP practices have closed since 2010.
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: There are around 1,000 fewer GP practices in England in 2017 than in 2010. Some practices may have merged together, rather than closing completely, but we don’t know how many have done so.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A&E; four hour targets have been missed more than 10 million times since 2010.
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: Correct. Between 2010/11 and 2017/18, around 12 million A&E; attendances in England took over four hours from arrival to admission, transfer or discharge.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of patients waiting more than 12 hours in A&E; is up 2,700% since 2010.
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: Correct (although not all patients will necessarily have been waiting in A&E;). In 2011/12, 120 patients in England waited 12 hours between the decision to admit them to emergency admissions and their actual admission, compared to 3,500 in 2017/18.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Spending on social care is down 8% since 2010.
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: Analysis by the Institute for Fiscal Studies last year said that between 2009/10 and 2016/17, councils’ spending on adult social care in England fell 8% in real terms. Newer analysis says that it fell by 6% over the same period. We’ve asked it for more information.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are 5,240 fewer mental health nurses since 2010.
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: This seems to be looking at different months in 2010 and 2017, which isn’t the best comparison. Comparing the number of full-time equivalent mental health nurses between January 2010 and January 2018 (the latest figures), the drop is closer to 4,500.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of operations classed as urgent that have been cancelled twice have doubled since 2010.
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: Correct. The number of urgent operations in England cancelled for the second time or more for non-medical reasons more than doubled between 2011/12 and 2017/18.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There has been a 22% drop in ambulances meeting their 15 minute transfer target since 2010.
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: The decrease is actually greater—28%. In 2010/11 in England 80% of ambulance transfers were done in 15 minutes, in 2015/16 it was 58%.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The rate of extra investment has fallen by 68% [since 2010].
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 16,481 fewer beds in hospitals [since 2010].
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 66 A&E and maternity wards closed [since 2010].
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 103 NHS walk-in centres closed or downgraded [since 2010].
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 60 ambulance stations closed [since 2010].
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 1,000 GP practices closed [since 2010].
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A&E 4 hour targets missed more than 10 million times [since 2010].
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Number of patients waiting more than 12 hours in A&E up 2,700% [since 2010].
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Spending on adult social care down 8% [since 2010].
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 5,240 fewer mental health nurses [since 2010].
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of operations classed as urgent that have been cancelled twice have doubled [since 2010].
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 22% drop in ambulances meeting their 15 minute transfer target [since 2010].
extra_title: NHS viral image factcheck
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK Statistics Authority say A&E; performance figures have been fiddled.
extra_title: Fiddled A&E statistics?
rating_alternateName: The Authority hasn't said that the figures have been fiddled. It hasn't said that they haven't yet, either. It has demanded that NHS England explain the impact of emails sent to NHS Trusts about counting A&E; performance last October and how that might have affected the figures since then.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Now the UK Statistics Authority say the [A&E performance] numbers may be worse because the figures have been fiddled."
extra_title: Fiddled A&E statistics?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Each side of protective surgical masks has different functions, indicated by colour, and you should choose the way you wear by whether you are ill or not.
extra_title: You should generally wear a protective face mask with the coloured side pointing outwards
rating_alternateName: This is incorrect. Generally, if they have a coloured side, you should wear your mask with this pointing outward—but always read the manufacturer’s instructions to be sure.

claimReview_claimReviewed: EU Membership costs 34p per person per day.
extra_title: This viral post about the costs of Brexit gets a lot of things wrong
rating_alternateName: Roughly correct, based on the UK’s net payment into the EU budget in 2018.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 91p per person per day has been spent on Brexit since 2016.
extra_title: This viral post about the costs of Brexit gets a lot of things wrong
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. This seems to be derived from an estimate that the Brexit vote reduced UK GDP growth by £66 billion in two and a half years. That is not the same as money spent on Brexit, and it is an estimate based on modelling, not a definitive sum.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The estimated cost of Brexit is £4.15 per person per day.
extra_title: This viral post about the costs of Brexit gets a lot of things wrong
rating_alternateName: This seems to be based on an estimate of how much lower UK GDP could be in 2030, compared to if we remained in the EU. This is a hypothetical model for comparing possible paths: it cannot be used to accurately predict the size of the economy in 2030, or to translate the “cost" of Brexit into a definitive cash sum.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The estimated cost of a no deal Brexit is £5.81 per person per day.
extra_title: This viral post about the costs of Brexit gets a lot of things wrong
rating_alternateName: This seems to be based on an estimate of how much lower UK GDP could be in 2030 if we leave with no deal, compared to if we remained in the EU. This is a hypothetical model for comparing possible paths: it cannot be used to accurately predict the size of the economy in 2030, or to translate the “cost” of Brexit into a definitive cash sum.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Nigel Farage has earned £541.10 per day from TV and radio since 2016.
extra_title: This viral post about the costs of Brexit gets a lot of things wrong
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. This is a based on the outside income Mr Farage declared as an MEP between 2014 and 2018. Half of that period was before Brexit. His estimated outside earnings over that period equate to an average of £359.90-£479.50 per day, and we don’t know if all that was from broadcast deals.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“EU Membership: 34p per person per day.
“Cost spent on Brexit since 2016: 91p per person per day.
“Estimated cost of Brexit: £4.15 per person per day
“Estimated cost of No Deal Brexit: £5.81 per person per day
“Nigel Farage’s earnings from TV and radio since 2016: £541.10 per day”
extra_title: This viral post about the costs of Brexit gets a lot of things wrong
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 915 children were admitted with malnutrition in Cambridge hospitals between 2015 and 2020. There were 656 similar admissions at Newcastle hospitals, and 656 at the Royal Free London hospitals.
extra_title: Layla Moran’s child malnutrition figures are wrong
rating_alternateName: These numbers seem to refer to all admissions, not children only. The correct figures for children are 33, 71 and 11.

claimReview_claimReviewed: More than 11,500 children have been admitted to English hospitals with malnutrition since 2015.
extra_title: Layla Moran’s child malnutrition figures are wrong
rating_alternateName: This is incorrect. The true figure is at least 2,112 lower, and will be much lower still if the same mistake was made with every hospital.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Twice as many children were admitted to English hospitals with malnutrition in the first six months of 2020, compared to the same period the year before.
extra_title: Layla Moran’s child malnutrition figures are wrong
rating_alternateName: This is based on data that is not reliable. We cannot say this with any confidence.

claimReview_claimReviewed: EU rules mean we cannot take VAT off energy bills.
extra_title: What could happen to VAT and energy prices if we leave the EU?
rating_alternateName: That’s right. EU rules mean we cannot reduce VAT on household energy any lower than the 5% that’s currently charged. All EU member countries would have to agree any changes to these rules.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If we leave the EU, fuel bills will be lower.
extra_title: What could happen to VAT and energy prices if we leave the EU?
rating_alternateName: Leaving aside the wider economic impacts of leaving the EU, if we vote to leave the government could choose to remove the 5% VAT rate on fuel as Vote Leave has suggested. Having the power to do this doesn’t necessarily mean energy bills will be lower if we leave.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“…if we leave the EU…fuel bills will be lower.

“In 1993, VAT on household energy bills was imposed. This makes gas and electricity much more expensive. EU rules mean we cannot take VAT off those bills.
extra_title: What could happen to VAT and energy prices if we leave the EU?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: In the last year there has been an 8% increase in murders
extra_title: Have murders in London increased in the last year?
rating_alternateName: Murder is down by 24.1% in 12 months of Feb 2012 when compared to 12 months previously. [17]

claimReview_claimReviewed: While Boris Johnson was mayor of London, crime fell by 20%.
extra_title: Did crime fall while Boris Johnson was Mayor of London?
rating_alternateName: This is a fair estimate using the best available data. The crime rate fell by 23% between 2007/08 and 2015/16, though this only looks at crime recorded by the police and there are other caveats to this data.

claimReview_claimReviewed: While Boris Johnson was mayor, the murder rate fell.
extra_title: Did crime fall while Boris Johnson was Mayor of London?
rating_alternateName: Correct, looking at homicides overall, rather than just murders. The homicide rate fell from roughly 21 per million people in 2007/08 to 13 per million in 2015/16.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We got crime down by 20% [in London]. We got the murder rate down.”
extra_title: Did crime fall while Boris Johnson was Mayor of London?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 7,000 prison officers have been lost from the prison service in recent years due to austerity measures.
extra_title: Fewer prison officers in England and Wales
rating_alternateName: There are 7,000 fewer prison officers now than there were in 2010 on one definition. This fall followed on from the 2010 spending review which reduced funding for the Ministry of Justice.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “In recent years we lost 7,000 prison officers due to austerity measures.”
extra_title: Fewer prison officers in England and Wales
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Prisons are filling up with foreigners.
extra_title: Are our prisons "filling up with foreigners"?
rating_alternateName: About one in eight prisoners in England and Wales is a foreign citizen. The percentage has been falling over the last few years.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Our prisons are filling up with foreigners”
extra_title: Are our prisons "filling up with foreigners"?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK has led the world by committing to “net zero” greenhouse gas emissions by 2050.
extra_title: UK greenhouse gas emissions: fast progress but not yet enough to meet future targets
rating_alternateName: The UK’s stated ambition to reduce emissions goes further than most other countries, and the UK is generally considered to be a world-leader in setting targets into law. A few other countries have set similar or more ambitious targets.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK has made huge progress in cutting greenhouse gas emissions.
extra_title: UK greenhouse gas emissions: fast progress but not yet enough to meet future targets
rating_alternateName: The UK has exceeded its own targets in cutting emissions compared to 1990 levels, and has made bigger cuts than other G7 countries. But this isn’t expected to be enough to meet future targets.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We have made huge progress in growing our economy and the jobs market while slashing emissions”
extra_title: UK greenhouse gas emissions: fast progress but not yet enough to meet future targets
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The UK is already slipping away from its mid-term carbon targets of cutting emissions by 80% by 2050”
extra_title: UK greenhouse gas emissions: fast progress but not yet enough to meet future targets
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "This is the government that has just led the world by committing to a zero carbon economy by 2050."
extra_title: UK greenhouse gas emissions: fast progress but not yet enough to meet future targets
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A&E; waiting times in England hit worst-ever level.
extra_title: A&E waiting times have hit their worst levels on record
rating_alternateName: Correct, looking at data which goes back to 2010.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “A&E waiting times in England hit worst-ever level”
extra_title: A&E waiting times have hit their worst levels on record
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Increasing the international health surcharge to £625 and extending it to all foreign workers, including EU migrants after Brexit, will raise over £500 million a year.
extra_title: Claim that immigrants “only” pay £400 surcharge to use the NHS ignores their tax contributions
rating_alternateName: It’s unclear how the Conservatives have calculated this figure. We’ve asked for more information.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Under the current system, people on a work, study or family visa only pay a £400 surcharge to use the NHS.
extra_title: Claim that immigrants “only” pay £400 surcharge to use the NHS ignores their tax contributions
rating_alternateName: This is the current level the international health surcharge is set at each year, but the taxes that people who come to work in the UK pay also goes towards things like the NHS.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Under the current system, people on a work, study or family visa incur average NHS costs of £625 per year.
extra_title: Claim that immigrants “only” pay £400 surcharge to use the NHS ignores their tax contributions
rating_alternateName: It’s unclear how the Conservatives have calculated this new figure and we’ve asked them for more information.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Under the current system, people on a work, study or family visa incur average NHS costs of £625 per year but only pay a £400 surcharge. This measure will raise over £500m a year, which can be put towards NHS services.”
extra_title: Claim that immigrants “only” pay £400 surcharge to use the NHS ignores their tax contributions
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of nurses in the NHS has declined by 5,000 because of Brexit.
extra_title: Lib Dem claims about EU health workers and the NHS are generally true
rating_alternateName: It is true that nursing and midwifery numbers have dropped by around 5,000 since the referendum, and Brexit is a likely factor driving at least some of this fall.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Tens of thousands of doctors and nurses in the NHS are from other EU countries.
extra_title: Lib Dem claims about EU health workers and the NHS are generally true
rating_alternateName: That is correct. The number of reported other EU nationals working for the NHS in March 2019 was 65,000, of whom around 31,000 were doctors and nurses.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK has led the world by committing to “net zero” greenhouse gas emissions by 2050.
extra_title: UK greenhouse gas emissions: fast progress but not yet enough to meet future targets
rating_alternateName: The UK’s stated ambition to reduce emissions goes further than most other countries, and the UK is generally considered to be a world-leader in setting targets into law. A few other countries have set similar or more ambitious targets.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK has made huge progress in cutting greenhouse gas emissions.
extra_title: UK greenhouse gas emissions: fast progress but not yet enough to meet future targets
rating_alternateName: The UK has exceeded its own targets in cutting emissions compared to 1990 levels, and has made bigger cuts than other G7 countries. But this isn’t expected to be enough to meet future targets.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We have made huge progress in growing our economy and the jobs market while slashing emissions”
extra_title: UK greenhouse gas emissions: fast progress but not yet enough to meet future targets
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The UK is already slipping away from its mid-term carbon targets of cutting emissions by 80% by 2050”
extra_title: UK greenhouse gas emissions: fast progress but not yet enough to meet future targets
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "This is the government that has just led the world by committing to a zero carbon economy by 2050."
extra_title: UK greenhouse gas emissions: fast progress but not yet enough to meet future targets
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Labour did not triple tuition fees.
extra_title: Angela Rayner is wrong on tuition fees
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. Labour tripled fees from £1,000 per year to £3,000 per year in 2006 in England and Northern Ireland and in Wales the following year.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “…we didn't triple tuition fees. They were £1,000 under Labour.”
extra_title: Angela Rayner is wrong on tuition fees
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Identical comments under Boris Johnson’s post are bots.
extra_title: It’s unlikely that these are bots commenting on Boris Johnson’s post
rating_alternateName: It is most likely that these are genuine commenters posting similar messages on purpose.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A picture shows a person installing 5G wearing a hazmat radiation suit.
extra_title: This picture doesn’t show someone wearing a hazmat suit to install 5G
rating_alternateName: The person was probably not installing 5G, but wearing protective clothing to clean a 4G mobile phone tower.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A 5G test in the Netherlands resulted in the death of 297 birds.
extra_title: Hundreds of birds were found dead in the Netherlands but it had nothing to do with 5G
rating_alternateName: Almost 300 starlings were found dead in a park in the Hague in October 2018. There were no 5G tests in The Hague in October 2018. Mass starling death is not unheard of.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The 5G radiation is bad for humans.
extra_title: Hundreds of birds were found dead in the Netherlands but it had nothing to do with 5G
rating_alternateName: Public Health England says it has not found evidence that 5G is a risk to human health.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A picture shows trees that have been cut down before 5G is launched.
extra_title: These trees weren’t cut down because of 5G
rating_alternateName: The picture is of felled trees in Serbia, as part of redevelopment works, which are due to be replaced by new trees. There’s no evidence this had anything to do with 5G.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 5G kills trees.
extra_title: These trees weren’t cut down because of 5G
rating_alternateName: We have found no evidence that’s the case.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Wuhan is where 5G was rolled out first.
extra_title: The Wuhan coronavirus has nothing to do with 5G
rating_alternateName: Wuhan was one of the first places with 5G trials, as well as several other large Chinese cities, like Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou but we don’t know if it was the first.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 5G wrecks immune systems and that is why people in Wuhan are suffering with this illness.
extra_title: The Wuhan coronavirus has nothing to do with 5G
rating_alternateName: There is no evidence that 5G can harm humans, or their immune systems.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Wuhan coronavirus is a more virulent version of the normal cold.
extra_title: The Wuhan coronavirus has nothing to do with 5G
rating_alternateName: The new coronavirus observed in Wuhan is a virus in the same family of viruses as the common cold, but is a different illness.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Scientists believe that coronavirus may have come from bats in a Chinese research facility.
extra_title: There's no evidence that the 2019 coronavirus originated in a Chinese government laboratory
rating_alternateName: Two Chinese scientists have published an article suggesting that the 2019 coronavirus outbreak could have originated from bats in a laboratory in Wuhan. However, apart from maps showing the proximity of laboratories, they offer no evidence to prove this.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Did coronavirus originate in Chinese government laboratory? Scientists believe killer disease may have begun in research facility 300 yards from Wuhan wet fish market”
extra_title: There's no evidence that the 2019 coronavirus originated in a Chinese government laboratory
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “THE coronavirus could have spread from a Wuhan laboratory which housed 600 bats which attacked and “peed on” scientists, experts say.”
extra_title: There's no evidence that the 2019 coronavirus originated in a Chinese government laboratory
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The £20 note shows a 5G tower giving off emissions and a coronavirus symbol.
extra_title: £20 notes don’t have a secret message about 5G and coronavirus
rating_alternateName: The ‘5G tower’ is Margate Lighthouse and the ‘coronavirus’ is based on a famous staircase at the Tate Britain art gallery.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 5G can make you sick.
extra_title: £20 notes don’t have a secret message about 5G and coronavirus
rating_alternateName: There’s no evidence that 5G can harm your health.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Based on ONS data, immigration has put English house prices up by 20% over the last 25 years.
extra_title: Have house prices risen because of immigrants?
rating_alternateName: It’s impossible to say for definite. Government analysis suggests immigration has pushed English house prices up by 20% but says it’s not meant to be a complete answer, and should be used with caution. There is no consensus across other research.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Based on the ONS data, the advice put to me from the department is that in the last 25 years [1991-2016] we have seen immigration put house prices up by something like 20%.”
extra_title: Have house prices risen because of immigrants?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 10,000 jobs have already moved out of the financial services sector following the EU referendum vote.
extra_title: 10,000 finance jobs lost since Brexit?
rating_alternateName: We’ve seen no evidence for this. A survey predicts 10,000 jobs might be moved from the UK if we leave the single market. We don’t know what kind of Brexit deal will be made and the survey has additional limitations.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Quite apart from the actual [Brexit] divorce bill, 10,000 jobs have already moved out of the financial services sector.”
extra_title: 10,000 finance jobs lost since Brexit?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 1,400 more people are accessing mental health services every day, compared to 2010/11.
extra_title: Has the number of people using mental health services increased?
rating_alternateName: NHS figures suggest the number using mental health services is increasing but changes to the way these figures are gathered means we can’t say for sure or put an exact figure on it.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If we look at what is happening in relation to mental health treatment in the National Health Service, we see 1,400 more people every day accessing mental health services.”
extra_title: Has the number of people using mental health services increased?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are over 2,000 more people employed in talking therapies.
extra_title: Mental health: staff working in talking therapies
rating_alternateName: One estimate says at least 2,850 more people worked in IAPT services (a flagship talking therapy programme for those with anxiety and depression) from August 2012 to April 2015. This does not include other NHS talking therapies.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The increase in the number number of talking therapies staff is closer to 3,000 than 2,700.
extra_title: Mental health: staff working in talking therapies
rating_alternateName: One estimate says at least 2,850 more people worked in IAPT services (a flagship talking therapy programme for those with anxiety and depression) from August 2012 to April 2015. This does not include other NHS talking therapies.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “2,700 more employed in talking therapies”
extra_title: Mental health: staff working in talking therapies
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “As far as I can tell it’s actually closer to 3000 more in talking therapies - an INCREASE on the 2700 you claimed.”
extra_title: Mental health: staff working in talking therapies
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “And here’s… the increase in talking therapies staff of over 2000”
extra_title: Mental health: staff working in talking therapies
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There have been about 1,500 deaths in police custody since 1990, and about one third of those who died were from black and minority ethnic backgrounds.
extra_title: Deaths of BAME people in police custody
rating_alternateName: About a tenth of identified deaths in police custody were people from black and minority ethnic backgrounds. This is based on figures from the charity INQUEST, which has identified 1563 deaths in total during or following police contact in England and Wales since 1990

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Reed’s case is one of among 1,500 deaths in police custody since 1990, including more than 500 victims from ethnic minority backgrounds, despite only making up 14% of the UK population”
extra_title: Deaths of BAME people in police custody
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "According to a report from Inquest—a British charity that investigates deaths in custody—over 1,500 people have died in, or following, police custody in the UK since 1990. A report by the Institute of Race Relations (IRR) shows that, of this number, more than 500 were Black and Minority Ethnic (BAME) individuals.”
extra_title: Deaths of BAME people in police custody
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: More than one million people are not receiving the social care they need.
extra_title: Are one million people without social care?
rating_alternateName: The research behind this isn’t published yet, so we can’t say how accurate it is. Age UK has previously produced similar estimates, based on asking people whether they need help with at least one daily task every time they need it.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Part of the reason for the strain on our National Health Service is that more than one million people are not receiving the social care they need.”
extra_title: Are one million people without social care?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A poll shows that UKIP’s Paul Nuttall is set to win in the Stoke Central by-election.
extra_title: Don’t trust this Stoke by-election poll until we know more about it
rating_alternateName: We don’t know if this was a reliable poll. The information we need to assess the poll hasn’t been published.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The BBC lost £150 million a year because the licence fee didn’t cover iPlayer until 1 September 2016.
extra_title: The £150 million BBC licence fee loophole?
rating_alternateName: The BBC has said that it will make £150 million less in 2016/17 from licence fees than it had expected in 2011, which it attributes to fewer people owning TVs and more people watching programmes online. The BBC doesn’t publish these forecasts so nobody can assess the reliability of this claim.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The BBC was apparently losing £150m a year through the so-called ‘iPlayer loophole’, the closure of which the government has been pushing through.”
extra_title: The £150 million BBC licence fee loophole?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “New laws come into force on September 1 which are designed to close the so-called “iPlayer loophole” costs the Beeb a rumoured £150million a year.”
extra_title: The £150 million BBC licence fee loophole?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Over the past 43 years, the EU has taken control over more and more areas which don’t have anything to do with trade—such as our borders, our public services, and whether prisoners have the right to vote.
extra_title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: Taking control?
rating_alternateName: The scope of the EU has expanded, partly due to treaties that the UK has signed up to. It covers aspects of borders and public services but not total control. It covers prisoners voting only when it comes to European elections.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Over the past 43 years, the EU has taken control over more and more areas which don’t have anything to do with trade—such as our borders, our public services, and whether prisoners have the right to vote.
extra_title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: Taking control?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Even the Government’s proposed new EU deal can be overturned after the referendum; it is not legally binding”
extra_title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: EU law
rating_alternateName: European law makers are expected to pass the laws necessary to sign off on the deal later this year. Once that happens, each part of the deal will be legally binding in one way or another. Many parts of it could still be challenged at the EU court in future.

claimReview_claimReviewed: EU law overrules UK law. This stops the British public from being able to vote out the politicians who make our laws. EU judges have already overruled British laws on issues like counter-terrorism powers, immigration, VAT, and prisoner voting.
extra_title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: EU law
rating_alternateName: EU law does override UK law. The EU court has made rulings to that effect on some, but not all, of these issues.

claimReview_claimReviewed: EU law overrules UK law. This stops the British public from being able to vote out the politicians who make our laws. EU judges have already overruled British laws on issues like counter-terrorism powers, immigration, VAT, and prisoner voting. Even the Government’s proposed new EU deal can be overturned after the referendum; it is not legally binding
extra_title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: EU law
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: You don’t have to be a member of the EU to trade with it. Switzerland is not in the EU, and it exports more per person to the EU than we do.
extra_title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: exports
rating_alternateName: That’s correct. Switzerland has some access to the EU’s single market. It pays financially for this and takes on certain EU laws.

claimReview_claimReviewed: You don’t have to be a member of the EU to trade with it. Switzerland is not in the EU, and it exports more per person to the EU than we do.
extra_title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: exports
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The big banks and multinationals might be lobbying to keep us in the EU, but small and medium-sized businesses feel differently
extra_title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: business opinion
rating_alternateName: There aren’t any representative surveys of business opinion generally that we’re aware of, but there is evidence that smaller businesses are more divided on the EU than larger businesses.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The big banks and multinationals might be lobbying to keep us in the EU, but small and medium-sized businesses feel differently”
extra_title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: business opinion
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: More than a quarter of a million people came to the UK from the EU in the 12 months to September 2015 - the equivalent of a city the size of Plymouth or Newcastle in just one year
extra_title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: migration
rating_alternateName: Over a quarter of a million is correct according to official estimates, around the same as Plymouth’s population but not quite as much as Newcastle’s.

claimReview_claimReviewed: More than half of net migration to the UK comes from the EU.
extra_title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: migration
rating_alternateName: Estimated net migration of citizens from the rest of the EU is actually slightly lower than net migration from the rest of the world—not more than half.

claimReview_claimReviewed: More than half of net migration to the UK comes from the EU. More than a quarter of a million people came to the UK from the EU in the 12 months to September 2015 - the equivalent of a city the size of Plymouth or Newcastle in just one year
extra_title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: migration
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: While in the EU the UK can’t make trade deals on its own. This means it has no trade deals with Australia, New Zealand or the USA - or growing economies like India, China or Brazil. Instead of making a deal which is best for the UK, we have to wait for 27 other countries to agree it.
extra_title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: trade
rating_alternateName: EU member countries can’t make trade deals separately from the rest of the EU. The EU doesn’t have trade deals with the countries named but is currently negotiating with some of them.

claimReview_claimReviewed: While we’re in the EU, the UK can’t make trade deals on our own. This means we currently have no trade deals with key allies such as Australia, New Zealand or the USA - or important growing economies like India, China or Brazil. Instead of making a deal which is best for the UK, we have to wait for 27 other countries to agree it
extra_title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: trade
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Only 6 per cent of UK firms export to the EU, yet all have to abide by EU regulations on their business
extra_title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: exporting firms
rating_alternateName: There are no official figures of how many UK businesses export to the EU. This estimate is justifiable and we do know that around 5% of VAT-registered businesses exported to their EU peers in 2014/15.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Only 6 per cent of UK firms export to the EU, yet all have to abide by EU regulations on their business
extra_title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: exporting firms
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Over 200,000 UK businesses trade with the EU, helping them create jobs here in the UK.
extra_title: Stronger In "facts" leaflet: business
rating_alternateName: HMRC figures from 2012 found almost 200,000 VAT-registered traders in the UK which traded goods with other EU member states. They said that the figure could be “significantly higher” if it included companies that traded in services.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Over 3 million UK jobs are linked to our exports to the EU - that’s one in every ten UK jobs.
extra_title: Stronger In "facts" leaflet: jobs
rating_alternateName: Estimates show around 3 million jobs are linked to our trade with other EU countries, but don’t tell us anything about the number of jobs linked to British membership of the EU. Nobody is forecasting that these 3 million jobs would be lost if we left the EU.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK gets £66 million of investment every day from EU countries - that’s more than we pay to be a member of the EU.
extra_title: Stronger In "facts" leaflet: investment
rating_alternateName: £66m a day is the average for the past ten years. Our membership fee was £23m a day in 2015. Investment was £14m a day in 2014.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Leaving the EU would cost the average UK household at least £850 a year, and potentially as much as £1,700, according to research released by the London School of Economics.
extra_title: Stronger In "facts" leaflet: leaving
rating_alternateName: These figures don’t tell you how much you or your family would lose, but they point in the same direction as most other economic analysis seems to.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Being in Europe means lower prices in UK shops, saving the average UK household over £350 a year. If we left Europe, your weekly shop could cost more.
extra_title: Stronger In "facts" leaflet: lower prices
rating_alternateName: This isn’t the impact of being in the EU as such, but one estimate of the impact of the free trade deals the EU has negotiated—a saving of 1.27% for the average household. It’s difficult to say overall what the impact of being in the EU has had on prices in the UK.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Understaffing in hospitals at weekends is responsible for 11,000 deaths according to research.
extra_title: No evidence 11,000 NHS weekend deaths are caused by understaffing
rating_alternateName: The research doesn't say this. It did find 11,000 excess deaths but says to assume these are avoidable "would be rash and misleading".

claimReview_claimReviewed: "According to an independent study conducted by The BMJ, there are 11,000 excess deaths because we do not staff our hospitals properly at weekends."
extra_title: No evidence 11,000 NHS weekend deaths are caused by understaffing
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: £10 billion extra funding for the English NHS will pay for new seven-day services.
extra_title: Can a "seven-day NHS" be paid for?
rating_alternateName: The government maintains this will happen, but experts doubt it’s possible without more money, as the original plans didn’t factor in the cost of seven-day services. It also needs the NHS to meet ambitious savings targets.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The money we have given the NHS to fund its own plan for the future - £10 billion more a year by 2020, and £4 billion just this year – covers our promise to ensure that standards of urgent and emergency care are the same across 7 days.”
extra_title: Can a "seven-day NHS" be paid for?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Between 13,000 and 125,000 operations will be cancelled as a result of upcoming junior doctors’ strikes.
extra_title: Are 125,000 operations predicted to be cancelled?
rating_alternateName: The current estimate is 125,000 operations cancelled, this figure is based on the number of operations which were cancelled over two days during the last strike in April. However, these figures were calculated before the specific dates were announced and before the September strike was suspended

claimReview_claimReviewed: “[T]he industrial action announced by the British Medical Association… will affect an estimated one million appointments and 125,000 operations.”
extra_title: Are 125,000 operations predicted to be cancelled?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “… 125,000 operations and around one million appointments…”
extra_title: Are 125,000 operations predicted to be cancelled?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “[Jeremy Hunt] added: 'Perhaps 100,000 operations will now have to be cancelled, around a million hospital appointments will have to be postponed, causing worry, distress and anxiety for families up and down the country.'”
extra_title: Are 125,000 operations predicted to be cancelled?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Based on the level of cancellations we saw when the BMA took similar action in April we may see, I would say, at least 13 to 15,000 cancellations and rearrangements of planned work for patients.”
extra_title: Are 125,000 operations predicted to be cancelled?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Under Labour, UK steel production and employment in the industry halved.
extra_title: Did UK steel production halve under Labour?
rating_alternateName: Yes, if you compare 1997 to 2010, when the economy was in a slump. Production has been, broadly, in decline for decades.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Under Labour, steel production halved. Under Labour, employment in steel halved. Since I have been Prime Minister, steel production has gone up and steel employment has stayed the same. So before we get a self-righteous lecture from Labour, I would say to them, "Look at your own record!"
extra_title: Did UK steel production halve under Labour?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government has protected the budget for schools.
extra_title: Experts agree school funding is falling per-pupil
rating_alternateName: That was correct in the recent past, and in the near future in terms of the overall amount. But per-pupil funding once inflation is taken into account is set to fall over the next few years.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Institute for Fiscal Studies, National Audit Office, Education Policy Institute and Public Accounts Committee all agree that per-pupil spending in schools will be reduced in real terms over the next few years.
extra_title: Experts agree school funding is falling per-pupil
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We have protected schools budgets and we're putting record funding into schools.”
extra_title: Experts agree school funding is falling per-pupil
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “[The Public Accounts Committee] say that funding per pupil is reducing in real terms and goes on to say schools' budgets will be cut by £3 billion, equivalent to 8% by 2020 […] If the Prime Minister is right then the parents are wrong, the teachers are wrong, the IFS is wrong, the National Audit Office is wrong, the Education Policy Institute is wrong, and now the Public Accounts Committee, which includes eight Conservative members in it, is also wrong.”
extra_title: Experts agree school funding is falling per-pupil
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Unemployment under Labour rose.
extra_title: Unemployment under Labour
rating_alternateName: Correct. The UK unemployment rate and total number of people unemployed was higher when Labour left government than when it entered it. That said, unemployment was relatively low for much of the party’s term.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Under Labour unemployment rose.”
extra_title: Unemployment under Labour
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Funding for rail companies today is four times what British Rail got in the 1970s and 80s.
extra_title: Government funding for the rail industry
rating_alternateName: Government support to the rail industry is roughly three times what it was at the end of the 1980s, varying year to year. We haven’t seen earlier figures.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “I just wanted to make the point about the railways, in terms of my understanding is that the railway companies, the private ones, receive four times as much funding as British Rail did in the 1970s and 80s.”
extra_title: Government funding for the rail industry
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: In the UK, women earn less than men.
extra_title: Do women earn less than men in the UK?
rating_alternateName: This is true overall. The gender pay gap is 9.1% per hour for full time employees in the UK, or £1.32 per hour. It isn’t true just for part-time work or every individual age group, and the size of the gap varies across different types of job.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If you’re a woman, you will earn less than a man.”
extra_title: Do women earn less than men in the UK?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: If we leave the EU, we could introduce a points-based immigration system like Australia’s.
extra_title: What would an Australian-style immigration points system mean for the UK?
rating_alternateName: This is correct. We're likely to need to leave the single market to do so.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The proposal to introduce a points-based system could put up immigration, based on Australia's experience.
extra_title: What would an Australian-style immigration points system mean for the UK?
rating_alternateName: Australia's immigration levels don't tell us anything about what might happen in the UK. Whether or not immigration went up would depend, in part, on how the points-based system was designed by the UK.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The proposal to introduce a points-based system would wreck the economy.
extra_title: What would an Australian-style immigration points system mean for the UK?
rating_alternateName: Setting up a points-based system would likely involve leaving the single market, and most economists say that would have a negative impact on the economy.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "[If the UK votes to leave the EU] by the next general election, we will create a genuine Australian-style points based immigration system."
extra_title: What would an Australian-style immigration points system mean for the UK?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Australia, who have a points based immigration system, have twice as many migrants per head as the UK [...] This system will not work. Vote Leave’s proposal could put up immigration and it would wreck our economy, as it involves leaving Europe’s single market."
extra_title: What would an Australian-style immigration points system mean for the UK?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: One in six secondary schools are at or over capacity.
extra_title: What's happening to secondary school places?
rating_alternateName: 15% of state-funded secondary schools in England were at or over capacity in 2014—one in seven.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 95% of applicants received an offer at one of their top three preferred schools last year.
extra_title: What's happening to secondary school places?
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “One in six secondary schools ‘at or over capacity’”
extra_title: What's happening to secondary school places?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Despite rising pupil numbers, 95 per cent of parents received an offer at one of their top three preferred schools last year and any suggestion to the contrary is nonsense.”
extra_title: What's happening to secondary school places?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Most secondary schools use teachers not trained in their subject
extra_title: Do most secondary schools use non-specialist teachers?
rating_alternateName: Two-thirds of people responding to a survey by a school and college leaders’ union said recruitment problems have led them to have subjects taught by non-specialists. We don’t know how representative that figure is of the experience of schools nationally. Official figures show that about one in six lessons in the key academic subjects in English secondary schools were being taught by teachers without a relevant post A level qualification in 2014. Around 24% of maths teachers and 21% of English teachers didn’t have a relevant post A level qualification in that year.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Most secondary schools ‘use teachers not trained in their subject’”
extra_title: Do most secondary schools use non-specialist teachers?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of people entering teacher training has increased in the last year.
extra_title: Are we recruiting enough trainee teachers?
rating_alternateName: The number of people entering postgraduate teacher training increased in the last year, but is below target. The overall number of people entering at undergraduate and postgraduate level has fallen.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “New figures show we have recruited more trainees than last year
extra_title: Are we recruiting enough trainee teachers?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If you look at the figures this year compared with last year, we are seeing an increasing number… So in absolute terms we are increasing the number of people coming into teaching in those shortage subjects.
extra_title: Are we recruiting enough trainee teachers?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “New analysis shows that for every year under the Tories the number of trainee teachers recruited has fallen. The total number of trainees recruited for 2015/16 is now 7,000 fewer than for 2009/10.
extra_title: Are we recruiting enough trainee teachers?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The majority of free schools have been opened in areas where there is a need for school places and in areas of disadvantage.
extra_title: Are there enough school places being created?
rating_alternateName: 83% of free schools opened since 2013 were in areas where there was a need for places. We’ve asked the Department for Education for more information about the claim that the majority of free schools were opened in areas of disadvantage.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Per pupil spending is falling in real terms.
extra_title: Are there enough school places being created?
rating_alternateName: Correct. It’s expected to fall in real terms over this parliament according to the Institute for Fiscal Studies and National Audit Office.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The National Audit Office has said that 420,000 new school places are needed.
extra_title: Are there enough school places being created?
rating_alternateName: Correct. 420,000 places will be needed in primary and secondary schools between 2016 and 2021, according to the National Audit Office.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The National Audit Office tell us that a very large number of new school places are needed—420,000… At the same time, per pupil spending is falling in real terms.”
extra_title: Are there enough school places being created?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The majority of free schools that have been opened, have been opened in areas where there’s a need for school places. And the majority have been opened, actually, in areas of disadvantage—where they are helping the very children we want to see getting the opportunity to get on in life.”
extra_title: Are there enough school places being created?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government hasn’t delivered even a quarter of the childcare places they claimed they would.
extra_title: 30 hours free childcare: only a quarter of places delivered?
rating_alternateName: This would have been correct based on old government policy, but the number of planned places has been reduced since then. The latest figures show the government has delivered just over half of the places it expects to.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “They (the government) haven’t even provided a quarter of the places they claimed. They have left hundreds of thousands of working parents either ineligible or unable to access the free childcare they were promised.”
extra_title: 30 hours free childcare: only a quarter of places delivered?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 1.1 million food parcels are given out — 1.1 million people who would starve otherwise.
extra_title: Over a million food parcels given by Trussell Trust last year
rating_alternateName: The Trussell Trust did give out 1.1 million parcels last year, but this isn’t the same as the number of people, as people can use food bank vouchers more than once. We don't know how many people nationwide received parcels, but this may be in the right ballpark.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “People are going to food banks, and there were 1,100,000 food parcels given - 1,100,000 people who would starve otherwise and over 400,000 of those went to children.”
extra_title: Over a million food parcels given by Trussell Trust last year
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A million families are dependent on food banks.
extra_title: Food banks, zero hours contracts and falling wages: are we worse off?
rating_alternateName: The most commonly used figures for food bank use come from the Trussell Trust. They show a million uses (not individual users) of food banks in 2013/14. The Trust isn't the only organisation running food banks, so we don't have a figure for the total number of people using food banks.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Wages are lower in 2015 than they were before the crisis.
extra_title: Food banks, zero hours contracts and falling wages: are we worse off?
rating_alternateName: Average weekly earnings (including bonuses) were lower in July 2015 than they were just before the 2008 recession, after accounting for inflation and seasonal movements in pay.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 800,000 of the "2 million jobs created" are zero hour contracts.
extra_title: Food banks, zero hours contracts and falling wages: are we worse off?
rating_alternateName: We have no way of knowing how much of the increase in employment (the "2 million jobs") over last Parliament came from zero hour contracts.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Low-paid workers are trapped in poverty.
extra_title: Factcheck: Measuring low pay isn't the same as measuring poverty
rating_alternateName: This muddles definitions. The report in question didn't discuss poverty. Although the issues are related, not all low-paid workers are in poverty.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
"The extent to which low-paid workers in the UK stay trapped in poverty is highlighted by a report showing only one in four workers who were low-paid in 2001 
 and who have remained in employment for most of the subsequent decade 
 went on to escape poverty and move on to higher pay."
extra_title: Factcheck: Measuring low pay isn't the same as measuring poverty
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: NHS staff will get a pay rise of between 6.5% and 29%.
extra_title: NHS pay: what’s the deal?
rating_alternateName: Pay will rise for some staff by between 4.5% and 29% over the next three years. This includes the increases in salaries staff will get by progressing through their pay band over time, and pay rises would still occur without a new deal. It doesn’t cover doctors, dentists, or very senior managers.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Delighted to confirm pay rise of between 6.5 and 29% for NHS staff who have worked so hard over a tough Winter, in a £4.2bn deal. Rarely has a pay rise been more deserved.”
extra_title: NHS pay: what’s the deal?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 55% of the NHS budget is spent on the over 85s.
extra_title: How much of the NHS budget is spent on people over 85?
rating_alternateName: We can't find any data to support this. Analysis by the Institute for Fiscal Studies suggests that by 2021/22 around 10% of health spending across the UK will go on those aged 85 plus.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “55% of NHS budget is spent on over 85s.”
extra_title: How much of the NHS budget is spent on people over 85?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: £1 in every £10 that goes to the NHS is to pay off debts from Private Finance Initiatives (PFIs).
extra_title: What is the NHS paying for Private Finance Initiatives?
rating_alternateName: This isn’t correct according to the latest cost estimates. These suggest ongoing annual costs are about 2% of the NHS budget, or £1 in every £55.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Another part of the problem that we've got is that Labour decided to sign us up to these crazy PFI deals so for every pound out of every ten that goes into the NHS is going to pay off the debt that you guys saddled us with.”
extra_title: What is the NHS paying for Private Finance Initiatives?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Full-fibre has low maintenance costs once rolled out, which can be estimated at around £230 million a year.
extra_title: Labour corrects broadband cost figure
rating_alternateName: This is based on a miscalculation. Data from the infrastructure agency suggests costs would be two to four times this amount.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Full-fibre has low maintenance costs once rolled out, which can be estimated at around £230 million a year.”
extra_title: Labour corrects broadband cost figure
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK will pay a net £20 billion into the EU budget while it negotiates the terms of exit under Article 50.
extra_title: Article 50 and EU budget payments
rating_alternateName: We can’t replicate the exact figure, but it’s plausible. The UK is set to pay over £9 billion per annum net into the EU budget in the next few years.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“My concern is that we trigger Article 50 in March—that’s what the House of Commons agreed to do [on Wednesday]—and if we spend two years negotiating this that’ll be another net £20 billion we’ve paid away.” 
https://hansard.parliament.uk/Commons/2016-12-07/division/37059D05-6203-44C7-A799-CA62AF77CA85/TheGovernmentSPlanForBrexit?outputType=Names
extra_title: Article 50 and EU budget payments
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Half of everything we sell to the rest of the world goes to the EU.
extra_title: Do half the UK's exports go to Europe?
rating_alternateName: The proportion of all goods and services exported going to the EU was 44% last year.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Half of everything we sell to the rest of the world we sell to Europe"
extra_title: Do half the UK's exports go to Europe?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK is the EU's single largest export market.
extra_title: Where does the EU export to?
rating_alternateName: That's right for the goods market. If you treated the UK as if it were out of the EU it would have made up 16% of the EU's goods exports in 2014. That's just ahead of the United States.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Almost all European countries have a trade surplus with us, apart from five.
extra_title: Where does the EU export to?
rating_alternateName: Over the last ten years all EU countries other than three sold more to us than they bought—Ireland, Luxembourg, and Malta.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“We’re their [the EU’s] largest export market

“Every single country in Europe apart from Ireland, Cyprus, Greece and Malta and Luxembourg have a surplus with us
extra_title: Where does the EU export to?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: In the UK there’s a huge difference in wealth per person between the poorest and richest regions, compared to other countries.
extra_title: One measure of inequality makes the UK look far less equal than other countries—it’s not
rating_alternateName: This is because of the way the data is collected, rather than real world effects. Using other measures the UK’s income inequality is about average compared to similar countries.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Real wages have been growing faster recently than at any time in the past decade.
extra_title: Real wages aren’t growing at their fastest rate in a decade
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. Across Great Britain real wages are growing by about 1% annually—the fastest rate in around two years.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Real wages have been growing faster recently than at any time in the past decade.”
extra_title: Real wages aren’t growing at their fastest rate in a decade
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Wages are rising at the fastest pace in three years.
extra_title: Real wage growth is just above 0%
rating_alternateName: This refers to regular pay, and doesn’t factor in inflation or peoples’ total pay. Total pay in Great Britain is growing in real-terms by 0.2% in the three months to July 2018, the joint fastest pace in 18 months.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Wages are rising at the fastest pace in three years.”
extra_title: Real wage growth is just above 0%
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Wages are rising at their fastest rate for a decade.
extra_title: Wage growth is only the fastest in a decade if you ignore inflation
rating_alternateName: That’s correct but it doesn’t account for inflation. When you factor in rising prices, real wage growth is at its highest in two years.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Wages rises accelerate to fastest pace since 2008”
extra_title: Wage growth is only the fastest in a decade if you ignore inflation
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “UK workers get biggest pay rise in a decade”
extra_title: Wage growth is only the fastest in a decade if you ignore inflation
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are 1.5 million British people employed in businesses owned by EU citizens in the UK.
extra_title: UK jobs and EU-owned businesses
rating_alternateName: In 2014, about 1.6 million people were employed by businesses that were EU-owned, or by businesses whose parent company was EU-owned. We don’t know how many of these employees were British.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “There are 1.5 million Brits employed in EU citizen owned businesses in our country”
extra_title: UK jobs and EU-owned businesses
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A speech by the Home Secretary Amber Rudd has been reported as a hate incident.
extra_title: Hate incidents aren’t the same as hate crimes
rating_alternateName: That’s true, but if someone has reported it to the police and given that reason then they have to record it as ‘hate incident’. They only record a ‘hate crime’ if they think something illegal has probably happened.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Police treat home secretary speech as 'hate incident'
extra_title: Hate incidents aren’t the same as hate crimes
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government has cut police spending by 25% over the last five years.
extra_title: What's happened to police budgets?
rating_alternateName: Direct government grants to police forces have fallen by 25% over the last five years. Funding fell by 18% overall because forces were able to raise more money locally.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Police spending has been protected.
extra_title: What's happened to police budgets?
rating_alternateName: Direct funding from government for police in England and Wales will continue to fall until 2020. Most local forces have the power to raise enough money to keep their budgets flat - but only if they raise the maximum amount they're allowed to.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Police budgets are being cut.
extra_title: What's happened to police budgets?
rating_alternateName: Direct government grants to the police have been cut for the past five years. They will continue to fall over the next few years. Most local forces have the power to maintain their budgets if they raise the maximum amount they are allowed to.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The policing minister has mentioned a few times the police are doing a great job. Well why then every year are you cutting police budgets?”
extra_title: What's happened to police budgets?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Over the last few years we have had to make some really difficult decisions around public sector spending … In the budget last year we protected police spending and we've also increased the spending on this area: counter-terrorism, is going up 30%.”
extra_title: What's happened to police budgets?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “You have cut spending by 25% over five years”
extra_title: What's happened to police budgets?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims
