claimReview_claimReviewed: Scotland Yard has logged 22,025 motorcycle muggings in 12 months – a rise of 50 per cent.
extra_title: Is moped crime rising in London?
rating_alternateName: The Metropolitan Police have recorded 22,025 crimes enabled by scooters, mopeds and motorcycles from June 2017 to May 2018, 50% more than the same period in 2016/17, but this does mask a recent falling trend month-by-month.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“Shocking figures released yesterday show the armed thieves are striking more than 60 times every day.”
“Scotland Yard has logged 22,025 motorcycle muggings in 12 months – a rise of 50 per cent.”
“The Metropolitan Police figures showed that crimes committed using mopeds, scooters and motorcycles soared by 50 per cent in the year to May, to 22,025.”
extra_title: Is moped crime rising in London?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: One in 14 adults was abused as a child in England and Wales.
extra_title: The scale of abuse during childhood: how much do we know?
rating_alternateName: This refers to sexual abuse and is roughly correct according to estimates from the Crime Survey.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Six million adults were abused as children in England and Wales.
extra_title: The scale of abuse during childhood: how much do we know?
rating_alternateName: This is correct according to estimates from the Crime Survey.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Child abuse: One in 14 adults 'abused as children' in England and Wales”
extra_title: The scale of abuse during childhood: how much do we know?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Six million adults were abused as children”
extra_title: The scale of abuse during childhood: how much do we know?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Unemployment is the lowest it has been since 1975.
extra_title: Is unemployment the lowest it has been since 1975?
rating_alternateName: This is correct looking at unemployed people as a percentage of all adults either working or looking for a job across the UK.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The employment figures were excellent this week. The lowest unemployment since 1975.”
extra_title: Is unemployment the lowest it has been since 1975?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The BBC is increasing the licence fee by £3.
extra_title: The government sets the licence fee, not the BBC
rating_alternateName: The licence fee is increasing by £3 a year but it is the government and not the BBC which sets the fee.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A screenshot shows a tweet from Jeremy Corbyn saying the London Bridge attacker was “murdered by British Police”.
extra_title: Fake Jeremy Corbyn tweet spreads after the London Bridge attack
rating_alternateName: The tweet is fake. Mr Corbyn did not say this.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The BBC made donations to the Conservative party.
extra_title: The BBC did not “donate” money to the Conservative party
rating_alternateName: These weren’t donations, they were appearance fees paid to individual MPs. Many media outlets pay fees to politicians from across the political spectrum.

claimReview_claimReviewed: London is losing 3,000 police officers from the streets.
extra_title: Is London losing 3,000 police officers?
rating_alternateName: This is the Metropolitan Police’s working assumption for how many officers will be lost between now and 2020.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “I talk to police officers in London desperately worried about the fact we're losing 3,000 officers from our streets.”
extra_title: Is London losing 3,000 police officers?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are more than 1,000 fewer armed police officers since 2010.
extra_title: Have armed police numbers been cut?
rating_alternateName: There are about 700 fewer now than in 2010. Labour's claim accurately quotes the latest published Home Office figures, but newer figures from the National Police Chiefs' Council have changed the picture. The numbers are expected to return to 2010 levels over the next few years.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Food, clothing and footwear make up the highest proportion of the poorest households’ spending.
extra_title: Will getting rid of EU tariffs help the worst off?
rating_alternateName: What makes up the biggest chunk depends on how you categorise people’s weekly spending. These items combined make up about a quarter of the poorest households’ spending.

claimReview_claimReviewed: When the UK leaves the EU, we can set our own tariffs.
extra_title: Will getting rid of EU tariffs help the worst off?
rating_alternateName: Correct, although we won’t have a completely free hand to set what we want due to World Trade Organisation rules.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Getting rid of EU customs union tariffs when we leave will help the worst off.
extra_title: Will getting rid of EU tariffs help the worst off?
rating_alternateName: If we set lower tariffs this may bring down costs for lowest-earning households, but tariffs are just one part of a bigger economic picture.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “When we leave, we can set our own tariffs. Tariffs set at the European level make food, clothing and footwear more expensive. They are the highest proportion of the poorest in society’s expenditure. If we can get rid of those tariffs, we help the worst off in society.”
extra_title: Will getting rid of EU tariffs help the worst off?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK share of the vote in the EU Council of Ministers is 8%, down from 17% when we joined.
extra_title: British influence in the EU Council of Ministers
rating_alternateName: It has declined, but a new system based on population makes the UK's vote worth 13%. A lot of Council decisions are made by consensus after negotiation, so vote share doesn't neatly capture the UK's influence.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 8%: the UK vote share in the Council, down from 17% in 1973
extra_title: British influence in the EU Council of Ministers
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: More trade for business — 200,000 UK businesses trade with EU countries and it's home to almost half our exports
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Stronger In on trade
rating_alternateName: HMRC estimated in 2012 that over 200,000 VAT-registered UK businesses trade with other EU countries. 44% of the UK’s exports went to other EU countries in 2014 — this share has been declining since the 2000s.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If we Vote Leave… We will trade with Europe without handing over permanent control to people we cannot vote out […] If we Vote Leave… We will control our own economy and trade
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on trade
rating_alternateName: We’ll still trade with Europe if we leave the EU. That trade will be controlled by, and may be affected by, any agreement we reach with the EU.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If we vote ‘remain’... The EU will continue to control… trade
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on trade
rating_alternateName: Trade policies for EU members are decided at EU level, so the UK can’t negotiate its own trade deals.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The EU has shrunk as a percentage of the world economy.
extra_title: The EU has shrunk as a percentage of the world economy
rating_alternateName: That’s correct. The EU economy has grown in size, but the rest of the world economy has grown faster.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "I think two things have really moved on since the referendum 40 years ago. The first is the economic picture. Europe has shrunk as a percentage of the world economy"
extra_title: The EU has shrunk as a percentage of the world economy
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: All the rest of the world trades with the EU under World Trade Organisation rules.
extra_title: The EU's other trade agreements
rating_alternateName: This is wrong. The EU has finalised 48 trade agreements with other countries of various kinds, beyond World Trade Organisation rules.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Mr Clarke, why can't we deal through the World Trade Organisation with the European Union, as all the rest of the world do?”
extra_title: The EU's other trade agreements
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The EU currently represents 15% of the world's economy and it’s forecast to go down to 12% by 2030.
extra_title: Is the EU becoming less important to the world economy?
rating_alternateName: There is no single estimate, but two separate IMF figures say the EU’s share (including the UK) of the global economy is around either 16% or 22% in 2017. That share has been decreasing and is expected to continue doing so. One estimate for 2030 says it could fall to around 12% (assuming the UK is no longer part of the EU).

claimReview_claimReviewed: "The EU currently represents just 15% of the world's economy and it’s forecast to go down to 12% by 2030."
extra_title: Is the EU becoming less important to the world economy?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Net migration to the UK could be 100,000 higher after Brexit under the government’s plans.
extra_title: Here’s why Migration Watch got their study on post-Brexit immigration wrong
rating_alternateName: The study this is based on is inaccurate and has been withdrawn.

claimReview_claimReviewed: We have decided to withdraw the paper issued today on post-Brexit migration levels. There was an error in the calculations which was unfortunately overlooked at the final stages of preparation. We apologise for the error and will rectify it in the course of producing a revised version.
extra_title: Here’s why Migration Watch got their study on post-Brexit immigration wrong
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of Britons getting citizenship of another EU country has doubled.
extra_title: UK citizens getting citizenship of another EU country
rating_alternateName: Correct, between 2015 and 2016.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Number of Britons getting EU citizenship of another country doubles”
extra_title: UK citizens getting citizenship of another EU country
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK has spent 100 million on security at Calais in the last three years.
extra_title: How much is the UK spending on security at Calais?
rating_alternateName: We haven’t seen evidence to confirm this. It's from a news report apparently based on an unpublished government briefing to journalists. An agreement on Thursday now means the figure is closer to £150m and covers others French ports as well.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “It's not the first time we’ve paid towards security at Calais. I think we spent about 100 million in the last three years.”
extra_title: How much is the UK spending on security at Calais?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 1.8 million migrants entered the EU illegally in 2015.
extra_title: Did 1.8 million migrants enter the EU illegally last year?
rating_alternateName: This is incorrect as far as available figures show. 1.8 million illegal border crossings were detected by EU member states in 2015, but this isn’t 1.8 million unique people as some are counted multiple times. It’s thought around one million migrants came over the same period.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “A massive 1.8 million illegal migrants entered Europe last year – six times more than in 2014”
extra_title: Did 1.8 million migrants enter the EU illegally last year?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: High levels of EU immigration mean the government hasn't been able to cut net migration to the tens of thousands
extra_title: Is EU immigration to blame for missing the net migration target?
rating_alternateName: Net migration from other EU countries isn't the only reason the government hasn't met its net migration target.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "We have seen many more people from the EU coming to Britain than originally anticipated … as a result, our action has not been enough to cut annual net migration to the tens of thousands"
extra_title: Is EU immigration to blame for missing the net migration target?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "I want to see immigration come down. That's why we've taken all the steps we have. It hasn't worked so far because of the large numbers coming from inside the EU"
extra_title: Is EU immigration to blame for missing the net migration target?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: When the five new countries in the process of joining the EU join, they will have the same rights as other members.
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on EU expansion
rating_alternateName: They would end up with the same rights. There might be some restrictions on workers from new countries at first.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Five more countries are in the process of joining, including Turkey.
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on EU expansion
rating_alternateName: Correct. The UK has a veto, but officially supports Turkey joining.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are now 28 member states of the EU, the most recent being Romania, Bulgaria and Croatia.
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on EU expansion
rating_alternateName: Correct, there are now 28 member states of the EU.

claimReview_claimReviewed: When we joined the EU, there were 9 member states.
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on EU expansion
rating_alternateName: There were 9 member states when we joined.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If we Vote Leave... We will control our borders.
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on immigration
rating_alternateName: A vote to leave doesn’t necessarily mean we will control immigration. It depends on what the government chooses to do with immigration policy, and what arrangements it negotiates.

claimReview_claimReviewed: They [migrants] also affect public services.
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on immigration
rating_alternateName: Impacts of immigration are likely to vary by local area. Immigrants may add to demand for and pressure on public services, but also contribute to financing and providing them.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Many migrants contribute to society.
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on immigration
rating_alternateName: Studies suggest recently-arrived EU immigrants contribute more to the public finances than they receive, although the effect is small.

claimReview_claimReviewed: More than a quarter of a million people came to the UK from the EU in the last 12 months – the equivalent of a city the size of Newcastle. If this continues for a decade, there will be over two million extra people.
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on immigration
rating_alternateName: Over a quarter of a million is correct according to official estimates, not quite as much as Newcastle’s population.

claimReview_claimReviewed: EU law controls UK migration policy.
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on immigration
rating_alternateName: EU law means the UK can’t control the number of EU citizens coming to the country, but we can perform border checks and refuse entry to certain people.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Voters don’t support a version of Brexit that will cost jobs.
extra_title: Employment or immigration: which matters more?
rating_alternateName: There’s polling evidence going both ways.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “How many people here voted to take their next door neighbour's job away?”
extra_title: Employment or immigration: which matters more?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Britain sends 50% of exports to the EU and only 8% to the 'BRICS' economies (Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa).
extra_title: Ask Full Fact: the UK’s trade with the EU
rating_alternateName: 44% of exports—of both goods and services—went to EU countries in 2014, and 8% to the BRICS. 50% to the EU would have been right a few years ago.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We do some 8% of our exporting to BRICS countries and some 50% to the EU.”
extra_title: Ask Full Fact: the UK’s trade with the EU
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) has increased at twice the rate in the North as in the rest of the country.
extra_title: Foreign Direct Investment in the North
rating_alternateName: It's correct that the number of deals has increased at twice the rate. We don’t know how much each of these investment deals was worth.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Thanks to George Osborne’s Northern Powerhouse, over the past year, foreign direct investment in the North has increased at double the rate of the rest of the country."
extra_title: Foreign Direct Investment in the North
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Roaming charges in Europe are lower because of the EU.
extra_title: The EU has reduced roaming charges
rating_alternateName: The EU has put a cap on the amount you can be charged for using your phone abroad, and prices have fallen. Networks won't generally be able to charge roaming fees at all from 2017.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Europe makes us better off. Being in means... lower phone roaming charges when travelling.
extra_title: The EU has reduced roaming charges
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government’s EU leaflet distributed before the referendum said that leaving the EU meant leaving the single market.
extra_title: The Conservative manifesto on the single market
rating_alternateName: The leaflet didn’t say outright that leaving the EU meant leaving the single market. It did contrast the advantages of “full access” to the market that the UK has as a member of the EU with the uncertainty and lack of full access that might occur if the UK voted to leave.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The 2015 Conservative manifesto committed the party to staying in the EU single market.
extra_title: The Conservative manifesto on the single market
rating_alternateName: The manifesto does say, “We are clear about what we want from Europe. We say: yes to the Single Market.” The manifesto also promises a referendum on EU membership, although staying in the EU and leaving its single market can be two different things.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “‘We are clear about what we want from Europe. We say yes to the single market.’ That was the manifesto that your prime minister and you stood on in the last election… It’s in the Tory party manifesto.”
extra_title: The Conservative manifesto on the single market
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “People voted to leave the European Union, they knew they were voting to leave the single market… Even in the leaflet that the government sent to every single household at the cost of £9 million to the taxpayer, it said quite clearly, leaving the European Union means leaving the single market.”
extra_title: The Conservative manifesto on the single market
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There is a £20bn ‘black hole’ in the EU’s finances, which will cost the UK an extra £2.4bn after the referendum.
extra_title: Is there a "£20bn black hole" in the EU's finances?
rating_alternateName: By December 2014, the EU owed £19.4bn in payments agreed in the past to support poorer regions. The UK won’t be forced to make additional payments outside of its regular contributions.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The EU’s unpaid obligations threaten the UK with an extra £2.4 billion bill after the referendum.”
extra_title: Is there a "£20bn black hole" in the EU's finances?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “And now we find that there is £20bn billion black hole in the EU's finances.”
extra_title: Is there a "£20bn black hole" in the EU's finances?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The EU gives British workers the entitlement to 28 days' paid holiday.
extra_title: How much of your paid holiday is down to the EU?
rating_alternateName: The EU minimum is 20 days. The British government increased it to 28 to cover bank holidays.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Over 26 million workers are entitled to paid leave because of the EU, so there are almost 750 million days of paid holiday taken.
extra_title: How much of your paid holiday is down to the EU?
rating_alternateName: That’s the correct number of employees in the UK, but multiplying them by the number of paid holidays they’re entitled to doesn’t work and doesn’t produce a number that the EU alone can take credit for.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “[Because of the EU] over 26 million workers in Britain benefit from being entitled to 28 days of paid leave”
extra_title: How much of your paid holiday is down to the EU?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Violent assaults on police officers have risen by a third in just four years.
extra_title: Are assaults on police officers rising?
rating_alternateName: The way data is collected was changed in 2017, so it isn’t possible to compare current rates with what they were four years ago. But assaults on officers that resulted in injuries rose by 27% in 2018/19 compared to 2017/18.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Officers are being injured on duty at a rate of 28 assaults a day.
extra_title: Are assaults on police officers rising?
rating_alternateName: In the year to March 2019, there were 10,399 assaults with injury on a constable, which equates to a daily average of 28. These numbers do not give the complete picture, however.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Shocking rise in police assaults: 28 attacks a day on officers in crime epidemic,”
extra_title: Are assaults on police officers rising?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Child poverty rose by half a million under the Coalition government.
extra_title: Child poverty—it's up but it's also down
rating_alternateName: That's true of one measure—absolute poverty is up from 2009/10. But relative poverty is down.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Child poverty rose by half-a-million under the last government to over four million."
extra_title: Child poverty—it's up but it's also down
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 55% of people in poverty are in working households.
extra_title: Are most working age people in poverty also in work?
rating_alternateName: 55% of working age people in poverty were in a working family, according to estimates from 2015/16.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 3.8 million people in work are living in poverty.
extra_title: Are most working age people in poverty also in work?
rating_alternateName: This is the estimated number in relative poverty in 2014/15. Newer figures since put the figure slightly lower.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "One in eight workers in the UK, that is 3.8 million people in work, are now living in poverty. 55% of people in poverty are in working households."
extra_title: Are most working age people in poverty also in work?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Cuts to tax credits will cost low-paid working families £1,300 a year.
extra_title: Will changes to tax credits cost families £1,300 a year?
rating_alternateName: £1,300 is a "rough" estimate of the average reduction in income next year (2016/17).

claimReview_claimReviewed: "The Tory conference was a feast of spin and deception. Fake claims to be on the side of working people while robbing three million low paid families of £1,300 a year with the Tax Credit cuts."
extra_title: Will changes to tax credits cost families £1,300 a year?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Tax credits originally cost £1.1bn. Now they've reached £30bn.
extra_title: Tax credits: how much has spending increased in 16 years?
rating_alternateName: This figure only covers half a year, when the first tax credits were introduced in 1999. They cost over £4bn in their first full year compared to £28bn today.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
"The original Tax Credit system cost £1.1 billion in its first year. This year, that cost has reached £30 billion."—George Osborne, Chancellor of the Exchequer, Summer 2015 Budget 
https://www.gov.uk/government/speeches/chancellor-george-osbornes-summer-budget-2015-speech
extra_title: Tax credits: how much has spending increased in 16 years?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There were 2,000 new social homes in 2014/15, compared to 12,000 social homes which were sold as part of the Right to Buy scheme.
extra_title: Are homes sold under Right to Buy being replaced?
rating_alternateName: These figure are correct for social homes sold and being built by local authorities in England.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "I mean I think 2,000 new social housing units came in in 2014-2015 as opposed to 12,000 which left social housing because of the right to buy."
extra_title: Are homes sold under Right to Buy being replaced?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The steel industry has been decimated over many years.
extra_title: 32,000 people work in the British steel industry
rating_alternateName: The number of people employed in steel in the UK - not including steel processing - has fallen from 320,000 in 1971 to 24,000 in 2016.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are 32,000 jobs at risk in the steel industry.
extra_title: 32,000 people work in the British steel industry
rating_alternateName: This is the number of people working in the whole steel industry in the UK in 2016. We don’t know with any certainty what the future holds for the steel industry.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “An industry [the steel industry] that has already been decimated over many years. [...] You know, there’s 32,000 people’s jobs at risk.”
extra_title: 32,000 people work in the British steel industry
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 400,000 more people are employed in the UK since the EU referendum.
extra_title: More people are in work since the Brexit vote
rating_alternateName: Employment has increased by around 450,000 since May to July 2016.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We’ve got 400,000 more people employed in this country [since the EU referendum]. We’ve got record low levels of unemployment.”
extra_title: More people are in work since the Brexit vote
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Half of British businesses are struggling to recruit the skilled labour they need.
extra_title: Are British businesses struggling with recruitment?
rating_alternateName: 52% of businesses surveyed by Lloyds Bank in June were struggling to recruit skilled labour, although we don't know the reasons why. We haven't been able to check the methods behind the survey directly.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Recent research shows that more than half of British businesses are struggling to recruit the skilled labour they need.”
extra_title: Are British businesses struggling with recruitment?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK has created more jobs than the rest of the EU put together.
extra_title: Has the UK created more jobs than the rest of the EU combined?
rating_alternateName: The UK has seen a larger rise in employment than the rest of the EU combined. Some countries have seen employment fall since 2010, so the comparison isn't that useful.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "For the first five years I was Prime Minister our economy created more jobs than the rest of the EU put together"
extra_title: Has the UK created more jobs than the rest of the EU combined?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are 10 times more staff dealing with benefits abuse than with tax evasion by the super-rich.
extra_title: Do benefit fraud investigators outnumber tax inspectors 10:1?
rating_alternateName: There are more people working on benefit fraud, but not 10 times more. 3,765 staff currently work at the DWP investigating benefit fraud and error, compared to 700 at HMRC who focus on the wealthiest individuals. Over 26,000 people at HMRC work on all tax enforcement and compliance.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 3,250 people investigate benefit fraud compared to 300 who investigate tax evasion.
extra_title: Do benefit fraud investigators outnumber tax inspectors 10:1?
rating_alternateName: This isn’t comparing like-with-like and the DWP figure is out of date. The staff mentioned work on all benefit fraud and error and tax evasion and avoidance, not just the illegal activities.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“Some 3,250 Department for Work and Pensions staff have been specifically investigating benefit fraud, while only 300 HMRC staff have been systematically investigating tax evasion…
 “Why have this Government had 10 times more staff dealing often with the poorest in society abusing benefits than with the super-rich evading their taxes?
extra_title: Do benefit fraud investigators outnumber tax inspectors 10:1?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Sub-standard care and staffing at weekends is responsible for thousands of deaths.
extra_title: Nobody knows how many lives could be saved by a seven-day NHS
rating_alternateName: There's no way to be sure. Research suggests thousands of "excess deaths" for patients admitted at weekends, but not that this is due to poor care.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Understaffing in hospitals at weekends is responsible for 11,000 deaths according to research.
extra_title: No evidence 11,000 NHS weekend deaths are caused by understaffing
rating_alternateName: The research doesn't say this. It did find 11,000 excess deaths but says to assume these are avoidable "would be rash and misleading".

claimReview_claimReviewed: "According to an independent study conducted by The BMJ, there are 11,000 excess deaths because we do not staff our hospitals properly at weekends."
extra_title: No evidence 11,000 NHS weekend deaths are caused by understaffing
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Muslim women are three times as likely to be unemployed, and twice as likely not to be in the jobs market in the first place, compared to women generally.
extra_title: Are Muslim women more likely to be unemployed?
rating_alternateName: This is correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“Muslim women are the most economically disadvantaged group in British society, according to a report by MPs.
They are three times more likely to be unemployed and looking for a job than women generally and more than twice as likely to be economically inactive, the Women and Equalities Committee said.
extra_title: Are Muslim women more likely to be unemployed?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Childhood diabetes in England and Wales is up 40% in four years.
extra_title: Is childhood type 2 diabetes up 40%?
rating_alternateName: This is in the right ball park. Data from both the NHS and the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health show this scale of increase across similar time periods.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Childhood diabetes is up 40% in four years,”
extra_title: Is childhood type 2 diabetes up 40%?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: £4,300 cost to UK families if Britain leaves the EU.
extra_title: The £4,300 question: would leaving the EU really make every household worse off?
rating_alternateName: At best that’s a red herring. Most economists seem to agree that leaving the EU would cost the UK economically but this amount is an unhelpful summary of the underlying research.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Leaving the EU would cause billions of pounds worth of damage to the NHS budget each year.
extra_title: Would leaving the EU cost the NHS?
rating_alternateName: Most economists predict that leaving the EU would harm economic growth and be an overall cost to the government’s budget. Whether this affects spending on the NHS would be depend on future political decisions.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“Based on IFS analysis, if we leave the EU, the public purse is likely to lose enough money each year to fund the whole of NHS England for 3 months.
Of course not all the public spending cuts would fall on the NHS. But it could still be as much as £10 billion a year by the end of the decade.
extra_title: Would leaving the EU cost the NHS?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Energy bills will rise by £500 million a year if the UK leaves the EU.
extra_title: Energy bills and Brexit
rating_alternateName: Not correct. This is one estimate of the cost of leaving the EU’s ‘internal energy market’—but leaving the EU won’t necessarily mean leaving the market. And the estimate doesn’t make any attempt to count effects of Brexit on bills.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Energy bills would soar by £500m a year if the UK left the EU, Amber Rudd, the energy secretary, will claim.”
extra_title: Energy bills and Brexit
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The impact of the UK being excluded from the IEM could be up to £0.5 bn per annum in the 2020s. Most of these impacts could be effectively mitigated if the UK is allowed to remain in the IEM, although there would be a loss of influence over policy design which has not been quantified in this analysis.
extra_title: Energy bills and Brexit
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Experts agree that… prices would rise
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Stronger In on prices
rating_alternateName: If we voted to leave the EU that could see prices rise in the short term due to the expectation that the value of the pound would fall. The longer term is more uncertain.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Lower prices for families — competition between businesses across Europe means lower prices in UK shops, cheaper flights and lower energy bills
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Stronger In on prices
rating_alternateName: The studies cited emphasise how trade competition in the EU might lower prices but don’t look at how other factors such as EU regulation and agricultural policy might raise prices. It’s difficult to say overall what the impact of being in the EU has had on prices in the UK.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If we left the EU without an alternative trade deal in place then we’d still have a choice about whether to put tariffs on imports.
extra_title: Post-Brexit trade tariffs
rating_alternateName: That’s correct. In general we’d have to apply the same tariffs to all our trading partners and keep them within limits agreed at the World Trade Organisation. It would be up to other countries, not us, to choose whether to charge tariffs on our exports.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Would we need to apply tariffs on goods coming into this country if we were out of the [EU] customs union? No we would not – that would be a voluntary choice for us, there is no need for tariffs.”
extra_title: Post-Brexit trade tariffs
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Leaving a customs union isn't the same thing as setting up a border.
extra_title: Will leaving the EU customs union mean border checks?
rating_alternateName: Leaving the EU customs union will involve some sort of border checks on goods entering Britain.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Will we continue membership of the customs union, or are we going to see border checks introduced between Northern Ireland and the Republic?... On Monday, the Prime Minister said the [EU] customs union was not a binary choice. I can't think of anything other than a binary choice is [sic] whether you have a border or whether you don't have a border.”
extra_title: Will leaving the EU customs union mean border checks?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The fact that he seems to confuse a customs union with a border, where they are actually two different issues, shows why it is important that it is this party that is in Government and not his.
extra_title: Will leaving the EU customs union mean border checks?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Predictions of negative economic consequences immediately after a vote to leave the EU haven’t come to pass.
extra_title: Brexit and economic apocalypse
rating_alternateName: That’s correct. Predicted lower growth and an emergency budget didn’t happen, although sterling has fallen significantly. Economists still expect there to be an impact on growth in the coming years, not least after we actually leave the EU.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We were told there would be a punishment budget and that didn't happen. We were told that growth will collapse and that hasn't happened. Yet again the Bank of England have upped their forecast. We were told that companies would flee the country. This wasn’t just after we left the EU—this was immediately after the referendum.”
extra_title: Brexit and economic apocalypse
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The average forecast for UK GDP growth this year was the same September as in June, despite the UK voting to leave the EU.
extra_title: Post-referendum predictions: have forecasts for the economy changed?
rating_alternateName: This is correct, but it isn’t the whole picture. Yes, the average forecast for UK GDP growth in 2016 was the same in September as it was in June. But the types of goods and services predicted to make up that growth was different.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“A monthly analysis of forecasts prepared for Chancellor Philip Hammond showed that dozens of independent experts believe national output will continue growing this year.
On average, they expect growth to continue at exactly the same rate as forecast before the EU referendum.
extra_title: Post-referendum predictions: have forecasts for the economy changed?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 86% of austerity has fallen on women.
extra_title: Has 86% of austerity fallen on women?
rating_alternateName: The House of Commons Library estimates that, looking at all changes to taxes and benefits from 2010-2017, 86% of the reduction in government spending is in spending on women. This is based on which person in a household receives a benefit or is taxed, so doesn’t factor in the “indirect” impact on partners and household budgets.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “86% of Tory austerity has fallen on women.”
extra_title: Has 86% of austerity fallen on women?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: In the last eight years, spending cuts led to the closure of children’s centres.
extra_title: Sure Start, school building and tuition fees: the Conservative and Coalition record
rating_alternateName: The number of children’s centres in England has fallen by around 500 from 2010 to 2017, and the number of Sure Start centres has fallen by around 1,200. Funding for Sure Start in England fell by 50% in real terms from 2010/11 to 2016/17.

claimReview_claimReviewed: In the last eight years, the “Building schools for the future” project has been stopped.
extra_title: Sure Start, school building and tuition fees: the Conservative and Coalition record
rating_alternateName: It was stopped in 2010 and replaced with a new scheme in 2011. The old scheme aimed to rebuild and refurbish all secondary schools in England. The new scheme is targeted at “school buildings in the worst condition across the country”.

claimReview_claimReviewed: In the last eight years, Education Maintenance Allowance has been taken away.
extra_title: Sure Start, school building and tuition fees: the Conservative and Coalition record
rating_alternateName: It was removed in England at the end of the 2010/11 school year, and replaced by a new bursary scheme. Government research suggests the new scheme has lowered participation in further education among students previously eligible for EMA.

claimReview_claimReviewed: In the last eight years, university tuition fees have trebled.
extra_title: Sure Start, school building and tuition fees: the Conservative and Coalition record
rating_alternateName: Correct, they went from a maximum of £3,000 to £9,000 for students beginning higher education in England in 2011/12. They’re now at £9,250.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If I look at the journey of the young person in my constituency, from a child to becoming an adult—children's centres had to close due to the cuts the government made over the last eight years. Then you went to school, your building schools for the future project, renewing our school buildings, stopped. You then got to further education, education maintenance allowance was taken away from you and then if you made it to university, your tuition fees were trebled. That isn’t investing in young people, that is taking away from young people.”
extra_title: Sure Start, school building and tuition fees: the Conservative and Coalition record
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The state is removing more children from their families than at any time since the 1980s.
extra_title: Are more children being taken from their families?
rating_alternateName: This is correct as far as available figures show. More children are becoming ‘looked after’ by a local authority than at any time since the mid-1980s, and increasing numbers are being adopted or placed with a special guardian. These figures don’t perfectly reflect the numbers of children who are away from their original parents.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The state is removing more children from their families than at any time since the 1980s”
extra_title: Are more children being taken from their families?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Labour would borrow one trillion to cover their promises.
extra_title: Would Labour borrow a trillion pounds?
rating_alternateName: The original claim is actually that Labour would spend (not borrow) a trillion pounds to cover their manifesto commitments. The figure hasn't been confirmed, and we don't know what time period it covers, and whether it refers to spending increases compared to now, or total spending.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Labour would borrow one trillion to cover their promises,”
extra_title: Would Labour borrow a trillion pounds?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “That’s absolute nonsense,”
extra_title: Would Labour borrow a trillion pounds?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Britain gives away £13 billion a year in foreign aid.
extra_title: The UK foreign aid budget: what did the government spend in 2017?
rating_alternateName: The UK spent £13.4 billion on foreign aid in 2016. Provisional figures for 2017 put the amount at just over £13.9 billion.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Tories just refused to support 6500 jobs and £1 billion for our economy by not guaranteeing that 3 new Royal Navy ships will be built in Britain.
extra_title: Did the Conservatives refuse to support 6500 British shipbuilding jobs?
rating_alternateName: These numbers assume that if a British shipbuilder won the contract, they would exclusively use British labour and goods. That’s uncertain. The £1 billion estimate is unconfirmed.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The Tories just refused to support 6500 jobs and £1 billion for our economy by not guaranteeing that 3 new Royal Navy ships will be built in Britain.”
extra_title: Did the Conservatives refuse to support 6500 British shipbuilding jobs?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Labour is pushing Theresa May for the UK to have access to the Single Market after Brexit.
extra_title: What is Labour’s policy on the customs union and single market?
rating_alternateName: Labour says it wants to be outside of the single market after Brexit, but has tabled amendments calling on the government to seek “full access to the internal market of the European Union”. Labour suggests the issue of free movement would have to be negotiated in this scenario. It’s hard to judge how feasible this would be as a negotiating position, but it seems to fall foul of the EU’s red lines.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Labour is pushing Theresa May for a UK-wide Customs Union.
extra_title: What is Labour’s policy on the customs union and single market?
rating_alternateName: Labour says it wants to whole of the UK to be outside the EU customs union after Brexit, but in a new customs union with similar levels of access, and the ability to strike free trade deals. This, like the government’s Chequers proposal, is likely to be unpalatable to the EU. It’s hard to judge how feasible this would be as a negotiating position, but it seems to fall foul of the EU’s red lines.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We’ve got a really clear position that we have had for a long time. We’ve been pushing Theresa May for a UK-wide Customs Union and access to the Single Market in order to protect jobs.”
extra_title: What is Labour’s policy on the customs union and single market?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The top 1% of earners in the UK are paying 28% of the tax burden.
extra_title: Do the top 1% of earners pay 28% of the tax burden?
rating_alternateName: This isn’t correct.  The highest earning 1% in the UK pay an estimated 28% of all income tax – not the total “tax burden”. This is close to a record level, but it isn’t quite the highest percentage ever.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "The top 1% of earners in this country are paying 28% of the tax burden. That is the highest percentage ever, under any Government."
extra_title: Do the top 1% of earners pay 28% of the tax burden?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: £1.2 billion is lost to benefit fraud.
extra_title: There’s no easy way to compare benefit and tax fraud.
rating_alternateName: This is out of date and newer estimates put this much higher at £2.3 billion for 2018/19.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The DWP employs 3,300 staff to investigate welfare fraud.
extra_title: There’s no easy way to compare benefit and tax fraud.
rating_alternateName: As of July 2018 the DWP employed 1,405 full-time equivalent specialists to investigate benefit fraud, and data suggests there may be another 2,000 or so doing related work.

claimReview_claimReviewed: £30 billion is lost to tax fraud.
extra_title: There’s no easy way to compare benefit and tax fraud.
rating_alternateName: In 2017/18 HMRC estimated the ‘tax gap’ (money that should have been collected in taxes but wasn’t) at around £35 billion per year. Not all of this is due to fraud.

claimReview_claimReviewed: HMRC employs 300 people to investigate tax fraud.
extra_title: There’s no easy way to compare benefit and tax fraud.
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. In February 2018 HMRC employed around 26,000 people “tackling all forms of non-compliance in the tax system”.

claimReview_claimReviewed: HMRC employs just 522 staff to tackle tens of billions of tax evasion by the super-rich.
extra_title: Do benefit fraud investigators outnumber super-rich tax inspectors 8:1?
rating_alternateName: It employed around 500 staff in March 2017 to work with taxpayers with assets over £10m, and another 500 staff to investigate the tax affairs of taxpayers with assets over £1 million, or an income over £150,000 a year. In 2016, they were estimated to account for around £2bn in lost tax revenue.

claimReview_claimReviewed: DWP employs 4,045 to tackle benefit fraud.
extra_title: Do benefit fraud investigators outnumber super-rich tax inspectors 8:1?
rating_alternateName: It employs around 4,000 full-time equivalent staff to deal with benefit fraud, as of October 2017. Of these, 1,900 are directly involved in investigations.  An estimated £2 billion in benefits were fraudulently claimed in 2017/18, according to the government.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “A report has revealed HMRC employ just 522 staff to tackle tens of billions of tax evasion by the super-rich but the DWP employ 4,045 to tackle benefit fraud.
extra_title: Do benefit fraud investigators outnumber super-rich tax inspectors 8:1?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “HMRC employ just 522 staff to tackle tax evasion by the super-rich but the DWP employ 4,045 to tackle benefit fraud.”
extra_title: Do benefit fraud investigators outnumber super-rich tax inspectors 8:1?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government has secured almost £160 billion extra since 2010 as a result of tax compliance activities.
extra_title: How much has the government recouped from tax evasion and avoidance?
rating_alternateName: Correct according to HMRC estimates, but a large part of this figure covers money the government thinks it will get in future as a result of actions already taken, rather than money actually saved so far.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We have taken action collectively as a Government over the last few years since 2010 when we first came in, and we have secured almost £160 billion in additional compliance revenues since 2010”
extra_title: How much has the government recouped from tax evasion and avoidance?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The amount of income tax paid by the super-rich has fallen from £4.4 billion to £3.5 billion since 2009.
extra_title: Are the super-rich paying less income tax?
rating_alternateName: The numbers are correct—up to 2014/15—but it's not a fair comparison. Tax rates changed in 2010 and some rich people moved their income around to avoid tax, which distorts the figures.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The amount of tax paid by the super-rich in income tax has fallen from 4.4 billion to 3.5 billion since 2009.”
extra_title: Are the super-rich paying less income tax?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Treasury loses £40 billion each year due to tax evasion and avoidance by the super-rich and the corporate elite.
extra_title: Does the Treasury lose £40 billion each year to the super-rich?
rating_alternateName: That’s a long way off from HMRC’s estimates, although there’s necessarily a lot of uncertainty here.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “I'll tell you where the money should come from, the money should come from tax avoidance and tax evasion. The super-rich and the corporate elite who rob from the Treasury £40 billion a year.”
extra_title: Does the Treasury lose £40 billion each year to the super-rich?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Capital gains tax has been cut
extra_title: Tax cuts: corporation tax, inheritance, capital gains and the bank levy
rating_alternateName: The main rate has been cut. But overall, policy changes under the Conservatives and the Coalition have tended to push revenues up.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Inheritance tax has been cut
extra_title: Tax cuts: corporation tax, inheritance, capital gains and the bank levy
rating_alternateName: Government policies since 2010 have tended to push down inheritance tax, mainly because of an increased allowance for passing on “the family home”.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Corporation tax has been cut
extra_title: Tax cuts: corporation tax, inheritance, capital gains and the bank levy
rating_alternateName: The rate of corporation tax has been cut step-by-step since 2010. That’s been partly but not completely offset by a reduction in allowances and efforts to tackle tax avoidance.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The bank levy has been cut
extra_title: Tax cuts: corporation tax, inheritance, capital gains and the bank levy
rating_alternateName: It has, but it’s been replaced by a surcharge on bank profits, which is expected to increase taxes on banking.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Can the PM explain to parents why cutting capital gains tax, cutting inheritance tax, cutting corporation tax, cutting bank levy are all more important than our children’s future?”
extra_title: Tax cuts: corporation tax, inheritance, capital gains and the bank levy
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Conservative-led changes to corporation tax, inheritance tax, capital gains tax and the bank levy will lose the government £70 billion between April 2016 and April 2022.
extra_title: Have the Conservatives brought in £70 billion worth of tax cuts?
rating_alternateName: The individual figures stand up to a degree of scrutiny, but this claim gives a limited picture of how these taxes have changed overall.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We asked the House of Commons to do some research in terms of the money that we would gain back if we reversed all of those tax breaks. As a whole it’s £70 billion in total by 2020.”
extra_title: Have the Conservatives brought in £70 billion worth of tax cuts?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Labour research in consultation with the House of Commons Library, using official costings of policy measures introduced since the Conservatives have been in power since 2010, reveals that from 2016/17 to 2021/22 over £70 billion will be handed out to a wealthy few individuals and businesses.”
extra_title: Have the Conservatives brought in £70 billion worth of tax cuts?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A new EU withdrawal bill allows the EU to choose the length of a further Brexit extension and the UK has no say in it.
extra_title: A new Brexit bill doesn’t allow the EU to unilaterally extend the Brexit date
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. If the EU suggests an extended exit date other than 31 January 2020, the government can ask parliament whether or not it approves of that proposal, and parliament can choose to reject it.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 1.1 million Brexit postal ballots are missing or rejected.
extra_title: No postal votes from the EU referendum are recorded as “missing”
rating_alternateName: No votes from the referendum are recorded as “missing”. Close to one million postal ballots weren’t returned, which can be due to a variety of reasons. An additional 170,000 or so were returned on time but not counted—mostly due to problems with identifying the voter.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The draft law that will start the process of leaving the EU has 133 words. The law enabling women to become MPs only has 70.
extra_title: The Article 50 bill
rating_alternateName: Close: the 1918 law on women MPs had 95 words. The general point that the length of a law has nothing to do with its importance is correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “That bill, the Article 50 bill, which is designed to do nothing more than to start the negotiating process, has 133 words and Angus [Robertson] criticises it for not having enough words. Well, the bit of legislation enabling women to become members of Parliament had 70 words in it.”
extra_title: The Article 50 bill
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The last government repatriated 100 powers from Brussels.
extra_title: Ask Full Fact: have 100 EU 'powers' been returned to the UK?
rating_alternateName: The Lisbon Treaty, negotiated under the previous Labour government, allowed the Coalition to reclaim around 100 'powers' (specific legislative acts).

claimReview_claimReviewed: "We want to see powers flowing away from Brussels, not to it. We have already taken action to return around 100 powers, but we want to go further."
extra_title: Ask Full Fact: have 100 EU 'powers' been returned to the UK?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Experts agree that… [if we left Europe] there would be less money for public services like the NHS.
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Stronger In on the economy
rating_alternateName: Most economists seem to agree that leaving the EU would cost the UK economically. If that happened, the government would need to raise taxes, cut other things, or borrow to keep NHS spending at the same level.

claimReview_claimReviewed: EU membership adds up to £91bn a year to the UK economy
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Stronger In on the economy
rating_alternateName: The study behind this claim estimated that being in the EU benefits the UK between £73-91 billion a year. These are very precise figures for a very uncertain impact.

claimReview_claimReviewed: For every £1 we put into the EU, we get back almost £10 in lower prices, more jobs and more investment.
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Stronger In on the economy
rating_alternateName: To compare the single membership fee that we pay into the EU to an estimate for many elements of the financial benefits that we might get from the EU is comparing apples to a basket of vegetables. The estimate for our financial benefit uses a precise figure for a very uncertain impact.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The EU will continue to control migration, trade, VAT, and vital security policies such as counter-terrorism. EU law will carry on having ultimate authority over British law
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on EU law
rating_alternateName: EU law does override UK law, and has mostly taken over control of trade, immigration from other EU countries, and VAT. The EU doesn’t control counter-terrorism or the intelligence services.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The £350 million a week we pay to the EU budget is the same as the cost of building a new NHS hospital every week or hiring 600,000 nurses.
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on our EU membership fee
rating_alternateName: We send £250 million not £350 million. That could pay for an NHS hospital but at the moment £85 million of it is spent in the UK paying for things like farmers and poorer areas, so we would have to cut that spending first.

claimReview_claimReviewed: We get less than half of this back and have no control over how it’s spent.
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on our EU membership fee
rating_alternateName: Based on the money actually paid to the EU less than half comes back as funding in the UK, which is ultimately controlled at EU level and mainly spent on farmers and poorer areas.

claimReview_claimReviewed: We pay about £350 million a week to the EU budget.
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on our EU membership fee
rating_alternateName: The UK pays around £250 million a week to the EU, not £350 million.

claimReview_claimReviewed: We will retake our seats on international bodies. […] We will have more international influence and use it to encourage more friendly international cooperation.
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on international influence
rating_alternateName: The UK already sits on many international bodies individually, as do representatives of the EU as a whole.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Stronger leadership on the world stage — shaping our future by sitting at the top table
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Stronger In on global influence
rating_alternateName: The UK already sits on many international “top tables” individually, as do representatives of the EU as a whole.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Tackling global threats like terrorism and climate change — with global threats that don't stop at borders, strength in numbers through the EU keeps UK families safer and protects our future
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Stronger In on EU collaboration
rating_alternateName: The EU has worked on these issues. Whether working as a group rather than individually keeps the UK safer is a matter of judgement.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Fighting cross-border crime — the EAW allows us to deport criminals from the UK and catch those fleeing justice across Europe
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Stronger In on cross-border crime
rating_alternateName: The European Arrest Warrant does allow the government to remove criminals from the UK to other EU countries, but a similar arrangement might be negotiated if we voted to leave.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Experts agree that jobs would be lost
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Stronger In on jobs
rating_alternateName: The latest minutes from the Monetary Policy Committee at the Bank of England do warn that some jobs might be lost, at least in the short term. This is in line with what other economists have said about the impact on the economy of leaving the EU.

claimReview_claimReviewed: More jobs — over 3 million jobs are linked to our trade with the EU, that's one in ten jobs (Source: HMT)
extra_title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Stronger In on jobs
rating_alternateName: Estimates show around three million jobs are linked to our trade with other EU countries, but don’t tell us anything about the number of jobs linked to British membership of the EU. Nobody is forecasting that these three million jobs would be lost if we left the EU.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Five out of six EU immigrants have indefinite leave to remain in the UK, or will have by the time the UK leaves the EU.
extra_title: Brexit: which EU citizens will have the right to stay in the UK?
rating_alternateName: This is not fully substantiated by the evidence and will depend on the arrangements we make upon leaving the EU. Whatever happens, EU citizens are not going to be forced to leave en masse.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Five out of six migrants who are here either already have indefinite leave to remain or ​will have it by the time we depart the [EU]”
extra_title: Brexit: which EU citizens will have the right to stay in the UK?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: All Commonwealth countries take 9% of UK exports.
extra_title: Trade with the Commonwealth
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The top 10 Commonwealth countries take 8% of UK exports.
extra_title: Trade with the Commonwealth
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If you look at the top 10 Commonwealth countries put together—that’s including India, including Pakistan, including Australia, including Canada—the top 10 make up simply 8% of our exports, not the 44% that the European Union has. And if you take all 52 or 54 Commonwealth countries, they make up just 9% of all our exports.”
extra_title: Trade with the Commonwealth
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The European Union makes two thirds of UK law.
extra_title: Is two thirds of UK law made by the EU?
rating_alternateName: That's about right if you count EU regulations as part of 'UK law'. The EU influence on UK-only laws is about 13%. But this counting exercise doesn't tell us very much.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Human rights aren’t devolved in Northern Ireland.
extra_title: Abortion, human rights, and devolution
rating_alternateName: In general human rights are a devolved matter in Northern Ireland, but the Assembly and Northern Ireland Ministers are required to comply with the European Convention on Human Rights.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “I fundamentally disagree with the idea of a British Prime Minister imposing whatever her view is on the people of Northern Ireland when it comes to a devolved issue.”
extra_title: Abortion, human rights, and devolution
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “It's not devolved human rights, though. Human rights aren’t devolved.”
extra_title: Abortion, human rights, and devolution
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Theresa May changed the law to remove protection from Commonwealth citizens and Diane Abbott voted against the change.
extra_title: How immigration law changed for Commonwealth citizens
rating_alternateName: Diane Abbott did vote against the law that changed the rules for Commonwealth citizens. The government disputes that this removes protection.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “In 2014 when Theresa May was home secretary she changed the law to remove the protection from Commonwealth citizens, and I voted against that.”
extra_title: How immigration law changed for Commonwealth citizens
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: At 16 we’re free from parental control, we can leave home, we can start a family, we can get married, we can start work, we can pay taxes, we can join the forces.
extra_title: How sweet is sixteen? Legal age limits in England and Wales
rating_alternateName: Correct, although in some cases parental consent is still required for under-18s.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “At 16 we’re free from parental control, we can leave home, we can start a family, we can get married, we can start work, we can pay taxes, we can join the forces.”
extra_title: How sweet is sixteen? Legal age limits in England and Wales
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK government killing British nationals fighting for Islamic State in Syria is lawful under international law.
extra_title: Is it legal to kill people fighting for Islamic State in Syria?
rating_alternateName: It depends on how you interpret international law. Different states interpret it differently. The UK government believes it can be lawful in some circumstances.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “To take them out using special services, I think, would be illegal under UK and international law.”
extra_title: Is it legal to kill people fighting for Islamic State in Syria?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “You can sometimes use lethal force. ... You can even do it on the street of your town in the UK, if it is strictly necessary to save life. That is lawful under English criminal law and under international law.”
extra_title: Is it legal to kill people fighting for Islamic State in Syria?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: New legislation has been introduced to change laws on workplace rights.
extra_title: Government proposes new zero hour contract legislation
rating_alternateName: The government has made a statement to parliament saying they intend to introduce new laws to change workers’ rights. The exact wording of the proposed law hasn’t been published yet.

claimReview_claimReviewed: New laws on workplace rights have come into effect.
extra_title: Government proposes new zero hour contract legislation
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The government has made a statement to parliament saying they intend to introduce new laws to change workers’ rights. But these new rights haven’t been passed as law and so aren’t in effect.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“Workers on zero-hour contracts, agency employees or "gig economy" workers are to be better protected by a package of workplace reforms, the government says.
“Under new legislation to be introduced on Monday, staff would have to be told details of their rights from their first day in a job, including eligibility for paid and sick leave.
extra_title: Government proposes new zero hour contract legislation
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“The government has introduced what it claims to be the biggest package of workplace reforms for 20 years after concerns that ministers have failed to appeal to voters who are “just about managing
.
“Legislation that comes into effect on Monday will increase fines for employers who have deliberately victimised their staff, and give workers details of their rights from the first day in their job.
extra_title: Government proposes new zero hour contract legislation
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK dropping our EU treaty commitment to "ever closer union" would make us less likely to be drawn into a federal Europe.
extra_title: Renegotiating "ever closer union"
rating_alternateName: Unlike opt-outs in specific areas of EU activity, this change wouldn't have a direct legal effect. Any impact would be mainly political.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "We want an end to our commitment to an 'ever closer union,' as enshrined in the Treaty to which every EU country has to sign up."
extra_title: Renegotiating "ever closer union"
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "If 'ever closer union' were abandoned as an objective, the consequences would be serious."
extra_title: Renegotiating "ever closer union"
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "People in Britain … do not want to be part of an ever-closer union to be dragged into a state called Europe. That may be for others, but it will never be for Britain, and it is time to recognise that specifically."
extra_title: Renegotiating "ever closer union"
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: EU law means that the UK will be covered by human rights laws even if we scrap the Human Rights Act.
extra_title: Does dropping human rights laws require leaving the EU too?
rating_alternateName: This is correct. The EU now has a stand-alone system of human rights law, which would remain in place even if we scrapped the older, separate system set up by the Human Rights Act and European Convention on Human Rights.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Even if we scrap the Human Rights Act, we'll still be beholden to EU laws"
extra_title: Does dropping human rights laws require leaving the EU too?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Only by leaving the EU will we escape human rights legislation"
extra_title: Does dropping human rights laws require leaving the EU too?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 47% of the population don’t earn enough money to bring in a wife or husband from outside the EU.
extra_title: You usually need to earn £18,600 a year to bring a non-EU partner to the UK
rating_alternateName: This is an old estimate for the proportion of British national employees who earned less than the £18,600 threshold. More recent estimates have put this at 41%, and it could be lower today. Non-British nationals who are settled in the UK can also bring in a partner if they meet the threshold.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If you want to marry and bring in someone from a country outside of the EU, you have to have a salary of over £18,600.
extra_title: You usually need to earn £18,600 a year to bring a non-EU partner to the UK
rating_alternateName: Correct, this has been the minimum income requirement before tax since 2012, although in some circumstances you can include your partner’s income in meeting the threshold.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “One of the very unfair things about our current system is, for example, if you want to marry and bring in someone from a country outside of the EU, you have to have a salary of over £18,600…. 47% of the population are not going to earn enough money to be able to bring in a wife or a husband from a country outside of the EU.”
extra_title: You usually need to earn £18,600 a year to bring a non-EU partner to the UK
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: It’s free to watch TV in prison.
extra_title: Does it cost more to watch TV in hospital than in prison?
rating_alternateName: In-cell TVs costs £1 per week for prisoners to rent, but they can be removed as a disciplinary measure.

claimReview_claimReviewed: It costs £8 per day to watch TV in hospital if you’re 82.
extra_title: Does it cost more to watch TV in hospital than in prison?
rating_alternateName: Costs vary by hospital. In some hospitals in England some TV channels are free for a limited number of hours, or free in children’s wards during the day. In others it can cost £8 per day for the cheapest TV package outside of these set hours, and in some hospitals it is free at all times. We’ve not seen any differences in the cost for adults based on their age.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Can anyone tell me why it costs £8 a day to watch telly in hospital when you’re 82, but it’s free in prison”.
extra_title: Does it cost more to watch TV in hospital than in prison?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There were 46,850 self-harm incidents in prisons in the year to March 2018, up 16%, and an average of 128 recorded a day.
extra_title: Violence and drugs in prison
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Violent incidents rose to 31,025, up 16%, of which 9,003 were on staff, which is up by a quarter in the year to March 2018.
extra_title: Violence and drugs in prison
rating_alternateName: Correct. Assaults on staff were up a quarter from around 7,160 to 9,000.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The amount of times drugs were found in prisons across England and Wales rose by 23% in one year. 20.4% of drug tests came back as positive.
extra_title: Violence and drugs in prison
rating_alternateName: Correct, including tests for psychoactive substances like spice.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“More than 46,850 self-harm incidents were recorded in the year to March 2018, up by 16 per cent on the previous year, with self-harm now recorded on average 128 times a day.”
“Violent incidents meanwhile rose to 31,025, up 16 per cent, and of which 9,003 were assaults on staff – a figure that has soared by more than a quarter (26 per cent) in the 12 months to March.”
extra_title: Violence and drugs in prison
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“The amount of times drugs were found in prisons across England and Wales rose by 23% in one year, Ministry of Justice figures reveal…”
“The figures for the year between March 2017 and March 2018 also reveal that 20.4% of drug tests came back as positive.”
extra_title: Violence and drugs in prison
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A record number of people killed themselves in English and Welsh prisons in 2016.
extra_title: Record self-inflicted deaths in prisons
rating_alternateName: That’s correct, going back to 1978. The rate of self-inflicted deaths per 1,000 prisoners is also close to a record high.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “A record number of people killed themselves in prisons in England and Wales in 2016, figures show.”
extra_title: Record self-inflicted deaths in prisons
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The prison population has doubled in 25 years.
extra_title: The rising prison population
rating_alternateName: It almost has, from 45,000 at the start of the 1990s to around 86,000 today in England and Wales. Prisons have been overcrowded almost constantly for the last two decades.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Over the last 25 years, the prison population has doubled”
extra_title: The rising prison population
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Irish GDP per head was lower than the UK before they cut corporation tax, and it’s now 50% higher.
extra_title: Would a corporation tax cut more than pay for itself, as Jeremy Hunt suggests?
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. We’ve seen no measures of GDP per head which placed Ireland below the UK before they cut corporation tax in 2015, and some measures show the difference is now is more than 50%.

claimReview_claimReviewed: When Ireland cut its corporation tax rate, their GDP went up.
extra_title: Would a corporation tax cut more than pay for itself, as Jeremy Hunt suggests?
rating_alternateName: Correct, recent estimates suggest the Irish economy grew by over 25% in 2015 due to companies relocating, although the impact on the underlying economy was considered more limited.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Cutting corporation tax will boost the growth rate of the economy.
extra_title: Would a corporation tax cut more than pay for itself, as Jeremy Hunt suggests?
rating_alternateName: There’s evidence this could happen over the long term, but it’s too limited and uncertain to put specific numbers on the effect. Cutting the tax is expected to cost more money than it raises through higher growth or investment.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The tax cuts that I’ve prioritised are corporation tax cuts … I’m doing that because I want to boost the growth rate of our economy … if we grew at 3-3.5% we’d have an extra £20 billion to spend”
extra_title: Would a corporation tax cut more than pay for itself, as Jeremy Hunt suggests?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “… the Republic of Ireland cut their Corporation Tax to twelve and a half percent; that’s what I want to do. When they did that they were a less wealthy country than us. Their GDP per head was lower. After they did that it actually went up to nearly 50 percent higher”
extra_title: Would a corporation tax cut more than pay for itself, as Jeremy Hunt suggests?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: About 92% of our land mass is not built on.
extra_title: Has 92% of the country not been built on?
rating_alternateName: It's estimated that between 88% and 99.9% of the UK isn’t ‘developed’ or built on. But that doesn’t mean all of the remainder is available for development.

claimReview_claimReviewed: But I believe the green belt should be built on and it should be built on soon, because we have, I think there is about 92% of our land mass just not built on at all.
extra_title: Has 92% of the country not been built on?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Labour are proposing stopping the 25% discount on council tax for single householders.
extra_title: It is not Labour policy to scrap the single occupant council tax discount
rating_alternateName: This is not Labour policy.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If you come to the UK illegally, you are an illegal migrant, and I’m afraid the law will treat you as such.
extra_title: Can refugees enter the UK illegally?
