rating_alternateName: Not in all cases. Specifically, refugees seeking asylum in the UK can’t be penalised for entering illegally if they are claiming asylum and coming from a place where their life or freedom are threatened. They may also stop over in other “safe” countries en route to the UK.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The UK should not be regarded as a place where you can automatically come and break the law by seeking to arrive illegally. If you come illegally, you are an illegal migrant, and I’m afraid the law will treat you as such.”
extra_title: Can refugees enter the UK illegally?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: In 2017 the UK resettled more refugees from outside Europe than any other EU member state.
extra_title: How many refugees does the UK take in?
rating_alternateName: Technically correct, but resettled refugees are only a subset of all refugees a country might take in. Overall, Germany, France, Austria and Sweden all granted asylum to more refugees than the UK did in 2017.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “In 2017 the UK resettled more refugees from outside Europe than any other EU member state (Eurostat figures).”
extra_title: How many refugees does the UK take in?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: British OAPs who have worked for 45 years get a total yearly benefit of £6,000.
extra_title: This image on benefits for pensioners and refugees is not correct
rating_alternateName: A British pensioner with 45 years’ worth of national insurance contributions is likely to get at least £500 a year more than this, and be eligible for more benefits on top.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Refugees or illegal immigrants living in Britain get a total yearly benefit of £29,900.
extra_title: This image on benefits for pensioners and refugees is not correct
rating_alternateName: Illegal immigrants cannot collect benefits, and refugees can on the same basis as UK nationals once their request for asylum is granted—but this figure is unusually high.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Under the Geneva Convention refugees should seek refuge in the first safe country they come to.
extra_title: Do refugees have to stay in the first safe country they reach?
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The UN Refugee Convention does not make this requirement of refugees, and UK case law supports this interpretation.  Refugees can legitimately make a claim for asylum in the UK after passing through other “safe” countries.

claimReview_claimReviewed: No one needs refuge from France.
extra_title: Do refugees have to stay in the first safe country they reach?
rating_alternateName: Although France is generally considered a “safe” potential country for asylum seekers, there is legal precedent to suggest France could potentially be considered a risk to an asylum seeker if the authorities fail to offer them the treatment they are entitled to.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The people trying to cross the Channel from France to the UK are not refugees.
extra_title: Do refugees have to stay in the first safe country they reach?
rating_alternateName: This cannot be known. It will be determined by immigration officials who review their asylum applications.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“[The people trying to cross the Channel from France to the UK] are not refugees…
“Because no one needs refuge from France. Or any of the other numerous safe countries they’ve passed though [sic] en route…
“And who under the Geneva Convention should seek refuge in the first safe country they come to. If they were genuine, that’s what they’d do. They’re not genuine. Just illegal migrants on the take.”
extra_title: Do refugees have to stay in the first safe country they reach?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Asylum seekers in the UK get somewhere to live, a cash allowance or both.
extra_title: We factchecked a viral video on asylum seekers
rating_alternateName: Correct, but only if they are “homeless or don’t have money to buy food”.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Asylum seekers in the UK can choose whether they want a flat, house, hostel or bed and breakfast.
extra_title: We factchecked a viral video on asylum seekers
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The government specifies that those eligible for support can’t choose where they live and may be placed in any of these types of housing. They are only eligible if they are homeless or don’t have money to buy food.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Asylum seekers get £37.75 for every person in their household, loaded onto a debit card each week.
extra_title: We factchecked a viral video on asylum seekers
rating_alternateName: If asylum seekers are homeless or don’t have money to buy food, they can apply for asylum support, which can include a cash allowance of this amount.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If an asylum seeker is refused asylum, they get somewhere to live and £35.39 per person on a payment card.
extra_title: We factchecked a viral video on asylum seekers
rating_alternateName: Correct, if they are homeless, unable to buy food and there’s a reason they can’t leave the UK yet. They can only get the payment card if they take the offer of somewhere to live.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Asylum seekers may see a doctor or get hospital treatment for free, and free prescriptions for medicine, free eye tests and free glasses.
extra_title: We factchecked a viral video on asylum seekers
rating_alternateName: Asylum seekers aren’t charged for GP visits, hospital treatment, or prescriptions. They may be eligible for free eye tests and vouchers for glasses.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Asylum seekers are offered a £300 maternity payment for having a baby.
extra_title: We factchecked a viral video on asylum seekers
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Asylum seekers are often here illegally.
extra_title: We factchecked a viral video on asylum seekers
rating_alternateName: It is legal to apply for asylum in the UK. You can’t be penalised if applying for asylum if you entered or are in the country illegally.

claimReview_claimReviewed: In March 2018 close to 50,000 people were in receipt of these kind of benefits.
extra_title: We factchecked a viral video on asylum seekers

claimReview_claimReviewed: 65% of assessed child refugees coming to the UK were actually adults.
extra_title: How many child asylum seekers are found to be adults?
rating_alternateName: Correct, but most child asylum seekers are not challenged about their age.

claimReview_claimReviewed: One in eight refugees who claimed to be children arriving in the UK were in fact adults.
extra_title: How many child asylum seekers are found to be adults?
rating_alternateName: This is correct for unaccompanied child refugees, but is an overestimate of the proportion of all child refugees found to be adults.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Nearly two thirds of supposed child refugees who were challenged about their real age after coming to Britain were found to be adults.”
extra_title: How many child asylum seekers are found to be adults?

claimReview_claimReviewed: “65% of assessed "child refugees" coming to UK were actually adults.”

claimReview_claimReviewed: “A new report has found that at least one in eight refugees who claimed to be children arriving in the UK were in fact adults.”
extra_title: How many child asylum seekers are found to be adults?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Illegal immigrants or refugees living in Britain get a total yearly benefit of £29,900.
extra_title: Who gets more, pensioners or refugees?
rating_alternateName: Illegal immigrants cannot collect benefits, and refugees can on the same basis as UK nationals once their request for asylum is granted—but this figure is unusually high.

claimReview_claimReviewed: British old age pensioners who have worked for 45 years get a total yearly benefit of £6,000.
extra_title: Who gets more, pensioners or refugees?
rating_alternateName: A British pensioner with 45 years’ worth of national insurance contributions is likely to earn at least £500 a year more than this, and be eligible for more benefits on top.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There were 6,507 suicides registered by coroners in 2018 - a rise of 11.8% on the previous year.
extra_title: Is the suicide rate up?
rating_alternateName: Technically correct, but some of this rise may be due to legal changes making it easier for coroners to record suicide as cause of death.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“Soaring suicide rates among young people is slowing down national life expectancy…
“There were 6,507 suicides registered by coroners in 2018 - a rise of 11.8% on the previous year.
extra_title: Is the suicide rate up?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Self-harming by teenage girls has doubled in the last 20 years.
extra_title: Has the number of teenage girls self-harming doubled?
rating_alternateName: The number of hospital admissions in England for girls under the age of 18 because of self-harm has doubled in that time. We don’t know how much of that is down to improved recording or to an actual increase in self-harm.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Self-harming by teenage girls doubles in 20 years”
extra_title: Has the number of teenage girls self-harming doubled?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 50% of mental health problems are established by age 14 and 75% by age 24.
extra_title: What age do mental health conditions develop at?
rating_alternateName: This was the finding of an American study that interviewed people to diagnose mental health conditions and asked them about when their condition began. The study’s authors said the findings were likely to be “conservative” and that some people might not remember when their condition started correctly.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 50% of mental health problems develop by the age of 14 and 75% by the age of 18.
extra_title: What age do mental health conditions develop at?
rating_alternateName: This was the finding of a study of New Zealanders born in the early 1970s that followed them throughout their lives. The study’s authors caution that it might not apply to all countries, particularly as around 90% of those who took part in the study were white.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We know that 50% of mental health problems develop before the age of 14 and that 75% develop before the age of 18."
extra_title: What age do mental health conditions develop at?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "75% of those with a mental health condition start developing it before the age of 18"
extra_title: What age do mental health conditions develop at?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “50% of mental health problems are established by age 14 and 75% by age 24.”
extra_title: What age do mental health conditions develop at?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of hospital beds for people with acute mental health conditions has fallen by 30%.
extra_title: Mental health: there are fewer beds, nurses and psychiatry trainees than in 2010
rating_alternateName: These years aren’t comparable due to a change in collection method from 2010. Between 2010 and 2017 there was a 22% drop.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of mental health nurses has fallen from 46,155 to 39,358 [since 2009].
extra_title: Mental health: there are fewer beds, nurses and psychiatry trainees than in 2010
rating_alternateName: This is the difference in the number of mental health and learning disabilities nurses between two different months which isn’t the best way to compare the figures. Comparing the figures in September 2009 and 2017 shows the drop has been larger.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of doctors in specialist psychiatry training fell from 3,187 in 2009 to 2,588 in the first quarter of this year.
extra_title: Mental health: there are fewer beds, nurses and psychiatry trainees than in 2010
rating_alternateName: This 20% drop was between September 2009 and March 2018, which isn’t a fair comparison. Comparing September 2009 and 2017 there was a 15% decrease.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“The number of hospital beds for people with acute mental health conditions, where a consultant psychiatrist is on hand to oversee treatment, has fallen by almost 30% since 2009.

“Over the same nine years, the data also show significant falls in the number of mental health nurses working in the NHS – from 46,155 to 39,358 – and in the number of doctors in specialist psychiatry training, from 3,187 in 2009 to 2,588 in the first quarter of this year.
extra_title: Mental health: there are fewer beds, nurses and psychiatry trainees than in 2010
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Millennials are on track to become the first generation to suffer worse health than their parents when they reach middle age, a study has warned.
extra_title: Millennial malaise: unhealthier than their parents?
rating_alternateName: A report by the Health Foundation says “The gains made as a society in improving the health of previous generations may well be eroded by the precariousness and instability of the lives some young people are facing.” We’ve asked it for more information.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Millennials are on track to become the first generation to suffer worse health than their parents when they reach middle age, a study has warned.”
extra_title: Millennial malaise: unhealthier than their parents?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There is a rising problem of mental stress among children because of exams.
extra_title: Exam stress for school children
rating_alternateName: There’s evidence to support this from children’s counselling services and the views of school leaders in England, but we don’t yet know much more about how common exam stress is across the UK more generally.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Faiza [Shaheen], do you think there is a rising problem of mental stress among children because of exams?”
extra_title: Exam stress for school children
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “It’s not a matter of thinking. It's a fact, isn't it? It’s just there.”
extra_title: Exam stress for school children
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: One in four mothers-to-be have mental health issues before they give birth.
extra_title: Mental health during pregnancy
rating_alternateName: Around one in four pregnant mothers included in a study by King’s College London had a mental health disorder when interviewed, but the study wasn’t designed to be representative of all pregnant women in the UK.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “One in four mothers-to-be have mental health issues BEFORE birth”
extra_title: Mental health during pregnancy
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: This Conservative government introduced parity of esteem for mental health services in the NHS.
extra_title: What is parity of esteem?
rating_alternateName: The government wants to achieve equality between the physical and mental health services provided to people, but it’s not there yet. The Coalition and Conservative government both introduced commitments to parity of esteem in legislation and official documents. The idea has been talked about for decades.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “It is this Conservative government that has introduced parity of esteem in relation to dealing with mental health in the National Health Service.”
extra_title: What is parity of esteem?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Conservative election manifesto gave no indication that the party would stop new onshore wind generators from accessing an existing subsidy.
extra_title: The Conservative manifesto's onshore wind pledge
rating_alternateName: The reference to ending "new public subsidy" for onshore wind is ambiguous. It doesn't, on the face of it, reference existing schemes, but has to be seen in the context of the clear aim to stop the construction of new wind farms.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Our manifesto said we would remove subsidies for onshore wind, and we will act on that manifesto pledge."
extra_title: The Conservative manifesto's onshore wind pledge
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "This announcement goes further than what had been previously indicated. It is not the scrapping of a 'new' subsidy that was promised but a reduction of an existing regime".
extra_title: The Conservative manifesto's onshore wind pledge
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Extending the grace period for the proposed early closure of the Renewables Obligation to onshore wind to include projects with planning applications in place, could mean funding being given to a further 7.1 gigawatts of projects.
extra_title: The proposed Renewables Obligation cut off: how much onshore wind capacity loses out?
rating_alternateName: Only 0.2 of the 7.1 gigawatts would be expected to qualify for the funding in the government's best estimate.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "… Lord Wallace, also raised the question of amending the grace period criteria to either allow all projects that had applied for planning permission access to the grace period or to consider extending the cut-off date to 8 October… Based on the department's analysis, allowing all projects with only a planning application in place could mean that anything up to 7.1 gigawatts could accredit under the renewables obligation. This figure represents all projects that had submitted an application but not yet received planning permission as at 18 June."
extra_title: The proposed Renewables Obligation cut off: how much onshore wind capacity loses out?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government's impact assessment showed that we would be £100 million worse off because of the early closure of the Renewables Obligation.
extra_title: Would early closure of the Renewables Obligation to onshore wind cost £100 million?
rating_alternateName: The government's best estimate is that the net present value of the early closure is about £160 million, a positive figure. The £100 million worse off estimate comes from making different assumptions about how the UK would generate electricity.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Does she acknowledge that, using the alternative methodology in the impact assessment, the net present value of deciding to close the RO early turned out to be minus £100 million? That means that we are £100 million worse off as a result of her taking that decision, instead of allowing the RO to continue."
extra_title: Would early closure of the Renewables Obligation to onshore wind cost £100 million?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The saving to the public purse from closing the Renewables Obligation (RO) to onshore wind a year early is up to £270 million a year.
extra_title: What effect on the public purse would closing the Renewables Obligation early have?
rating_alternateName: The government won't improve its finances by closing the RO early, as the scheme is paid for by energy suppliers and their consumers. £270 million is the government's upper estimate of how much the closure could save them.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "The estimated saving of closing the RO early to new onshore wind is up to £270 million per year."
extra_title: What effect on the public purse would closing the Renewables Obligation early have?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Closing the Renewables Obligation to onshore wind early will save households 30p a year.
extra_title: How much will closing the Renewables Obligation early save on your bills?
rating_alternateName: The government's best estimate is that the early closure will cut the average household's electricity bill by 30p, but there's some uncertainty to this estimate.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "To be clear, in the Government's impact assessment the overall estimation of what the measure will save is 30p for a household for a year."
extra_title: How much will closing the Renewables Obligation early save on your bills?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 69% of the public support onshore wind, which is the most popular renewable energy technology.
extra_title: What do Brits think about wind farms?
rating_alternateName: This is based on a survey where 70% of respondents stated they'd be happy to have a wind farm built in their local area. However, a DECC survey showed 65% of respondents supported onshore wind, which was less popular than solar power, wave and tidal power and offshore wind.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "... Something like 69% of the public support onshore wind—it is the most popular of the renewable energy-generating supply technologies"
extra_title: What do Brits think about wind farms?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The EU has set a 15% overall target for UK energy consumption from renewable sources in 2020.
extra_title: The UK's renewable energy target
rating_alternateName: The UK does have a 15% overall target. It also has a 10% target for renewables in transport energy consumption in 2020. The exact way in which the 15% target is met is up to the UK, so long as the 10% transport sub-target is met.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "As for the emissions angle, we know that we are driven by the European requirements for renewable energy, the formidable target of 15% of our energy from renewable sources by, I think, 2020, and Europe's target of 40% by 2030."
extra_title: The UK's renewable energy target
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "We have a 20% renewables target overall across all energy, which translates into a 30% target for renewable electricity and, I believe, there is a 12% renewable heat target, and therefore a 10% renewables target. There is no breakdown of those targets at a European level into those sub-sectors: it is simply an all-energy target, and there is no further subdivision into technology types."
extra_title: The UK's renewable energy target
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK missed its interim renewable energy target.
extra_title: Are we missing our targets on renewable energy?
rating_alternateName: The UK's target was for 5.4% of its energy consumption to come from renewable sources over 2013 and 2014. Provisional calculations show it met this target.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Last week it was revealed that we had missed our interim EU 2020 target for renewable energy generation."
extra_title: Are we missing our targets on renewable energy?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "We do not accept that we have missed it. Our interim reporting covers the period to the end of 2015, and we believe that we are on track to meet that target."
extra_title: Are we missing our targets on renewable energy?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Closing the Renewables Obligation to onshore wind a year early could threaten 19,000 jobs supported by the industry.
extra_title: How many jobs could be lost in onshore wind?
rating_alternateName: There were about 11,000 people directly employed by onshore wind and 8,000 in 'supply chain' roles in 2013, according to government estimates. It's uncertain how many people will see their employment threatened by the closure of the Renewables Obligation

claimReview_claimReviewed: "These changes to the financial support for onshore wind threaten the future of 19,000 jobs supported by that sector."
extra_title: How many jobs could be lost in onshore wind?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK oil and gas industry supports an estimated 375,000 jobs.
extra_title: How many jobs are supported by the UK's oil and gas industry?
rating_alternateName: 375,000 is the latest estimate of the total employment supported by the industry according to the industry itself.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The oil and gas industry supports more than 400,000 jobs.
extra_title: How many jobs are supported by the UK's oil and gas industry?
rating_alternateName: Over 400,000 was an older estimate. These figures are uncertain, and don't just include people directly employed by the industry.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "…the oil and gas industry in the United Kingdom supports an estimated 375,000 jobs".
extra_title: How many jobs are supported by the UK's oil and gas industry?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "…it is important to recognise that the North Sea supports hundreds of thousands of jobs—more than 400,000".
extra_title: How many jobs are supported by the UK's oil and gas industry?

claimReview_claimReviewed: Young people are finding it harder than ever to own their own home.
extra_title: It's harder for young people to own their own home
rating_alternateName: Correct. Young people are less likely to own their own home, and the gap in affordability has grown since a decade ago.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If you’re young, you’ll find it harder than ever before to own your own home.”
extra_title: It's harder for young people to own their own home
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Help to Buy ISAs won’t help you buy a home, because you still need to provide an initial exchange deposit when the contracts are signed and you haven’t been given the government bonus at that point.
extra_title: Help to Buy ISAs: do they work and were they mis-sold?
rating_alternateName: Since initial exchange deposits are negotiated between the buyer and the seller, it’s possible to negotiate them down. The seller can agree to receive the rest of the money when the purchase completes.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Help to Buy ISAs won’t help you with your mortgage deposit.
extra_title: Help to Buy ISAs: do they work and were they mis-sold?
rating_alternateName: Several banks have said that they will treat the bonus payments as part of the buyer’s savings when they apply for a mortgage, even though it won’t arrive in their bank account until after the sale is completed.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Treasury has backtracked on its stated original aim about Help to Buy ISAs
extra_title: Help to Buy ISAs: do they work and were they mis-sold?
rating_alternateName: This isn’t correct. The scheme was always intended to support the part of a house purchase that’s funded by the buyer, commonly known as a ‘deposit’ or ‘mortgage deposit’. The Treasury never said that it was meant to help with the initial exchange deposit that’s put down when contracts are exchanged.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “On Friday night the Treasury backtracked on the stated original aim, claiming it was never intended to boost deposits. A spokesman insisted the bonus was instead designed purely to reduce the size of buyers’ mortgages by boosting the equity they put in on completion.”
extra_title: Help to Buy ISAs: do they work and were they mis-sold?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If you're saving for a deposit to buy a home, it turns out the Help to buy ISA will definitely not boost this by 25% - despite what anyone might have told you”
extra_title: Help to Buy ISAs: do they work and were they mis-sold?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “…a major flaw in the ISA has been uncovered: savers won't receive the extra government money until after the property purchase has been completed. Ie, the extra money can't be used towards a deposit, which is the bit most of us are struggling with in the first place.”
extra_title: Help to Buy ISAs: do they work and were they mis-sold?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Sub-standard care and staffing at weekends is responsible for thousands of deaths.
extra_title: Nobody knows how many lives could be saved by a seven-day NHS
rating_alternateName: There's no way to be sure. Research suggests thousands of "excess deaths" for patients admitted at weekends, but not that this is due to poor care.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Water cannon may be deployed today in London for a pro-Brexit march.
extra_title: No, water cannon will not be deployed at the pro-Brexit march
rating_alternateName: This is untrue. The Met Police do not own any water cannon and they are not currently authorised for use in England and Wales. Both the Met Police and the Mayor of London’s office confirmed they will not be using water cannon.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "There are reports that water cannon may be deployed tomorrow in London”
extra_title: No, water cannon will not be deployed at the pro-Brexit march
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Half of maternity units don’t have consultants at the weekends.
extra_title: Do we have enough maternity consultants?
rating_alternateName: 43% of maternity units don’t have a consultant present during the day at weekends, according to a survey by the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Three quarters of maternity units don’t have consultants present overnight during the week.
extra_title: Do we have enough maternity consultants?
rating_alternateName: This is correct, according to a survey by the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Three in four labour wards have no consultants overnight. A major audit published today also reveals that almost half of hospitals lack senior specialists at weekends.”
extra_title: Do we have enough maternity consultants?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “A survey of 165 maternity units found that in 2014/2015 around 27% of labour wards have consultants physically present overnight on weekdays, falling to 15% at the weekend.
extra_title: Do we have enough maternity consultants?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 98% of junior doctors voted in favour of strikes.
extra_title: Did 98% of junior doctors vote to strike?
rating_alternateName: 98% of junior doctors who are members of the British Medical Association (BMA) and who voted in the ballot said they would be prepared to strike. Not all junior doctors are members of the BMA, and not all members voted. Taken as a proportion of all junior doctors (including some not affected by the changes), roughly 46-52% voted to strike.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Junior doctors row: 98% vote in favour of strikes"
extra_title: Did 98% of junior doctors vote to strike?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Putting a doctor through medical school “costs the taxpayer” £230,000.
extra_title: The cost of training a doctor
rating_alternateName: That’s wrong. About £64,300 of that comes in student loans, most of which the government gets back. The rest comes in grants for tuition, living costs and clinical placements.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Training a doctor costs £230,000.
extra_title: The cost of training a doctor
rating_alternateName: This is the overall cost of training a doctor according to the Department of Health. It isn't the cost to the taxpayer. £163,000 comes in non-repayable grants. Students will repay much of the rest, whether or not they work in the NHS.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Training a doctor costs over £200,000. So in return we will ask all new doctors to work for the NHS for four years, just as army recruits are asked to after their training.”
extra_title: The cost of training a doctor
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“It costs £230,000 to train a doctor in England and proposals set out in a consultation launched today (14 March 2017) include plans to obtain a return on this investment.” 
https://www.gov.uk/government/consultations/expanding-undergraduate-medical-education
extra_title: The cost of training a doctor
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “It costs the taxpayer £230,000 to train a doctor, over and above fees paid by individuals.”
extra_title: The cost of training a doctor
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The BMA misled junior doctors on whether their pay would be cut.
extra_title: Why is the government accusing the BMA of lying?
rating_alternateName: Ministers dispute suggestions that some doctors might get a 30% pay cut, which they blame on a pay calculator that was withdrawn by the BMA. The union hasn’t responded to our request for comment. There’s also a broader disagreement about what the government intended to do about pay at the time.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Of course we all regret the course that this dispute has taken, but it would not have done so had the BMA taken a responsible position from the beginning. If people lie to their members and say that they will have their pay cut and their hours raised, of course doctors will be angry.”—Ben Gummer, Health Ministe
extra_title: Why is the government accusing the BMA of lying?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Yesterday, the Secretary of State for Health accused the BMA of misleading junior doctors. Today, the Minister comes to the House and accuses the BMA of lying.”—Julie Cooper M
extra_title: Why is the government accusing the BMA of lying?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If a trusted body, such as the BMA, tells its members that they will have a pay cut of 30% and an increase in hours, but that statement is incorrect, does it constitute a lie? That is the question I would put back to her.”
extra_title: Why is the government accusing the BMA of lying?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: People with white-sounding names are nearly twice as likely to get call backs for jobs than people with ethnic sounding names.
extra_title: Job applicants with ethnic minority sounding names are less likely to be called for interview
rating_alternateName: In a 2009 experimental study, 10.7% of applicants with a white sounding name received a positive response, compared with 6.2% of applicants with an ethnic minority sounding name - making them 74% more likely to get a positive response.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Do you know that in our country today: even if they have exactly the same qualifications, people with white-sounding names are nearly twice as likely to get call backs for jobs than people with ethnic-sounding names?
extra_title: Job applicants with ethnic minority sounding names are less likely to be called for interview
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The gender pay gap is lower than it's ever been before.
extra_title: The pay gap, record employment and an extra £23 billion to GDP: women and the workplace
rating_alternateName: This is true. The pay gap is at a record low for full-time employees and for employees overall.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are more women in the UK in work than ever before.
extra_title: The pay gap, record employment and an extra £23 billion to GDP: women and the workplace
rating_alternateName: This is true, but it's almost always true: employment grows as the population grows. The employment rate for women aged 16-64 was also at a record high.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If women in the UK reached their full economic potential it would be worth £23 billion.
extra_title: The pay gap, record employment and an extra £23 billion to GDP: women and the workplace
rating_alternateName: This figure is from 2006. Some of the gains may have increased with the size of the economy, and higher prices mean that the cash figures would be larger. Some of the gains may already  have been achieved.

claimReview_claimReviewed: One in seven workers are self-employed, and the number is growing.
extra_title: Are more people self-employed?
rating_alternateName: One in seven is right, and the number and proportion of workers that are self-employed has been rising since the early 2000s, although it has fluctuated.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "One in seven of the labour force now work for themselves."
extra_title: Are more people self-employed?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Six million workers are paid below the living wage.
extra_title: Six million jobs pay below the living wage
rating_alternateName: Last year six million jobs were paid below the living wage, but some people have more than one job. We've got hold of some new figures suggesting at least 5.4 million people were paid less than the living wage.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "SIX MILLION workers below Living Wage—making mockery of Tory claim they will 'make work pay'"
extra_title: Six million jobs pay below the living wage
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Covid-19 deaths in care homes are rising.
extra_title: Covid-19 deaths in care homes have started to fall
rating_alternateName: This was true at the time, by one measure. By another measure it was probably not true. Now it seems clearer that deaths in care homes from suspected Covid-19 are falling.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “While, happily, it looks as though deaths in hospitals are falling, deaths in care homes continue to go up.”
extra_title: Covid-19 deaths in care homes have started to fall
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “I can tell him that he is not right in what he just said about the state of the epidemic in care homes. If he looks at the figures in the last few days, there has been a palpable improvement.”
extra_title: Covid-19 deaths in care homes have started to fall
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A survey found almost three quarters of voters believe social care should be a high priority for the government.
extra_title: Poll shows public thinks Brexit and NHS are most important issues facing the country
rating_alternateName: Correct, though the survey was of UK adults, not just voters.  The list of issues respondents were asked about was also far from comprehensive. Other polling shows Brexit and the NHS are the most important issues to the public overall.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“An overwhelming majority of voters want Boris Johnson to take urgent action to fix the social care crisis.
“A poll found almost three-quarters believe that the issue should be a high priority for his new government.
“It was ranked top of a list of problems needing action.”
extra_title: Poll shows public thinks Brexit and NHS are most important issues facing the country
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 87 people are dying a day waiting for care.
extra_title: It’s not certain that 87 people a day are dying waiting for care
rating_alternateName: NHS data shows the equivalent of 88 requests a day for social care support from councils in England did not reach a conclusion as the requester died. There are a number of limitations to this data so we can’t be sure how true this figure is.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The truth is our social care sector is a national scandal … 87 people dying a day waiting for care”
extra_title: It’s not certain that 87 people a day are dying waiting for care
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: One in three dementia patients are forced to sell their homes.
extra_title: How many people with dementia have to sell their homes to pay for care?
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. A poll found that 16% of respondents who said they had friends or family with dementia also said that person had to sell their home to pay for care. But there are other drawbacks which mean the results are not reliable.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “1 in 3 dementia victims forced to sell homes”
extra_title: How many people with dementia have to sell their homes to pay for care?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Local authorities are bringing in less money in council tax at the moment than they're spending out just in vulnerable adult and children care alone.
extra_title: Councils aren’t getting enough funding to meet demand for social care
rating_alternateName: Council tax revenues raised in England in 2017/18 were £500 million less than the adult and children’s social care budget for councils in the same year, according to the Local Government Association. Government data suggests council tax revenue was £5 billion higher. The main source of council budgets is money from central government, which has been falling in recent years.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “[Local authorities] are bringing in less money in council tax at the moment than they're spending out just in vulnerable adult and children care alone.”
extra_title: Councils aren’t getting enough funding to meet demand for social care
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Two billion was announced for social care last year.
extra_title: Social care: what’s the situation?
rating_alternateName: Correct. This was money for the NHS in England and councils to “support social care providers and relieve pressure on the NHS locally” until 2019/20.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There was no extra money announced for social care this week.
extra_title: Social care: what’s the situation?
rating_alternateName: Correct. The Prime Minister announced more money would be given to the NHS in England and has said that the budget for social care will be announced at a detailed review of public spending planned in 2019.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are 400,000 people who don’t get the social care they used to following cuts over the last eight years.
extra_title: Social care: what’s the situation?
rating_alternateName: The number of people in England receiving adult social care from their local council fell by around 425,000 between 2009/10 and 2013/14. Because of changes in the way the figures are collected we can’t compare this with more recent numbers.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There have been £6 billion of cuts to social care in the last eight years.
extra_title: Social care: what’s the situation?
rating_alternateName: This is the estimated cumulative difference between what councils in England wanted to spend and what they had the available budget to spend on adult social care between 2010 and 2017. The expected savings this year are planned to take the figure to £7 billion. We’ve asked the Association of Directors of Adult Social Services for more information about the figure.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Because of deep cuts, £6 billion worth of cuts over the last eight years, 400,000 very elderly and vulnerable people did not get the care support that they used to get before these cuts. That is costing the NHS £3 billion a year. And Damian said there was going to be a plan for that, there was no extra money whatsoever, this week, for social care.”
extra_title: Social care: what’s the situation?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “There was two billion last year, and you know that well, Jon.”
extra_title: Social care: what’s the situation?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: We’re spending record levels on our NHS—£149 billion a year.
extra_title: Health and social care: What do we spend?
rating_alternateName: That’s how much public spending on health across the UK came to in 2016/17. Most, but not all of this money goes to the NHS.

claimReview_claimReviewed: We spend £22 billion on social care.
extra_title: Health and social care: What do we spend?
rating_alternateName: Roughly correct looking at public spending on adult social care across the UK in 2016/17. Around £10 billion was spent on children’s social care.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We’re spending record levels on our NHS: £149 billion a year. £22 billion on social care.”
extra_title: Health and social care: What do we spend?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of elderly people being rushed into A&E; from care homes has risen by 62% since the Conservatives took power.
extra_title: Emergency admissions to hospitals from care homes are up 62%
rating_alternateName: This is the increase in the number of emergency admissions from care homes in England from 2010/11 to 2016/17. Roughly 90% of these admissions were people aged 60 plus in both 2010/11 and 2016/17.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The number of elderly people being rushed into A&E from care homes has risen by 62% since the Tories took power.”
extra_title: Emergency admissions to hospitals from care homes are up 62%
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There will be no cap on the amount people pay towards their social care under the Conservatives’ plans.
extra_title: What might people have to pay for their social care?
rating_alternateName: Correct at the time. Plans announced in the Conservative manifesto included no limit to the amount people pay for adult social care, although councils will pay when people have less than £100,000 left. However, since then the Prime Minister has said there will be a cap on the amount people will have to pay.

claimReview_claimReviewed: People won’t have to sell their homes under the Conservatives’ social care plans.
extra_title: What might people have to pay for their social care?
rating_alternateName: Most people will be able to defer selling their homes until after they die in order to pay for any kind of social care - although some may not be eligible.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We have been clearer about having this £100,000 level, which, you know, makes it very clear that people don't have to sell their homes.”
extra_title: What might people have to pay for their social care?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Well, Priti’s completely wrong … I mean, there is no cap on the amount of money that you have to pay.”
extra_title: What might people have to pay for their social care?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Increasing council tax to pay for social care is four times more useful in wealthy areas compared to more deprived ones.
extra_title: How much can councils raise to pay for social care?
rating_alternateName: There was roughly 3.5 times the difference between the council which could raise the most to pay for social care by increasing council tax and the council which would raise the least per over 65 year old.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The [social care] precept is perhaps four times of more use in wealthier areas than it is in more deprived areas where they get less of their total spend from local council tax, but where need is also highest.”
extra_title: How much can councils raise to pay for social care?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Over one million vulnerable people are unable to look after themselves due to reductions in spending on social care.
extra_title: Are there one million older people unable to look after themselves?
rating_alternateName: Analysis by Age UK found that there were 1.2 million over 65s who experienced difficulty with basic tasks such as eating and washing.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We’ve got over one million vulnerable people who can’t look after themselves because of cuts to social care.”
extra_title: Are there one million older people unable to look after themselves?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Deprived areas are facing the most significant cuts to adult social care budgets.
extra_title: Are the most significant council budget cuts in deprived areas?
rating_alternateName: Council spending on adult social care hasn’t reduced on average as steeply as for some other services, but the reductions have been highest in areas with the greatest need, according to the Institute for Fiscal Studies.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Deprived areas are facing the most significant council cuts.
extra_title: Are the most significant council budget cuts in deprived areas?
rating_alternateName: Councils that are most dependent on government grants—those which are poorest or in inner London—have seen their budgets reduced by more than other councils between 2009/10 and 2016/17.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “It's the actual deprived areas ... that are facing the most significant cuts through council cuts
extra_title: Are the most significant council budget cuts in deprived areas?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Roughly 40% of people on welfare are pensioners, and 10% or 20% are taking in-work benefits.
extra_title: Are 40% of welfare claimants pensioners?
rating_alternateName: We haven’t found figures to back this up. Around 56% of all welfare spending in Great Britain went to pensioners in 2016/17, counting pensions as part of the welfare bill.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "People forget actually that maybe 40% of people on welfare are actually old-age pensioners... another 10% or 20% are taking in-work benefits."
extra_title: Are 40% of welfare claimants pensioners?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The manual for certain benefits is three times the size of War and Peace.
extra_title: War and Peace and benefits regulations
rating_alternateName: This is right on one measure. Guidance for officials on administering JSA and Income Support has three times as many pages as the novel’s first edition.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “In the specific benefit that is discussed in your film which affects the protagonist, the manual for that is three times the size of War and Peace”
extra_title: War and Peace and benefits regulations
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A new police officer in 2010 has seen a real-terms increase in pay of 32%.
extra_title: Have some police officers had a 32% pay rise?
rating_alternateName: Correct given the pay progression this officer would have received if continually in post, but this increase is unlikely to reflect the experience of most officers today.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“[Jeremy Corbyn] failed to mention the automatic pay increases over and above the 1% that many public sector workers get.
“Indeed, a calculation suggests that a new police officer in 2010, thanks to progression pay and annual basic salary increases, and the increase in the personal allowance that is a tax cut for people, have actually seen an increase in their pay of over £9,000 since 2010, a real terms increase of 32%.
extra_title: Have some police officers had a 32% pay rise?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Taxpayers faced a bill of more than £140 million last year for criminals from other EU countries in British jails.
extra_title: 4,000 EU prisoners in England and Wales
rating_alternateName: This is based on the average yearly cost per prisoner in England and Wales, and the number of prisoners from other EU countries in prison in England and Wales at the end of December 2017. The estimate is very rough and spending on prisoners can vary depending on the prison they’re in.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There were more than 4,000 foreign criminals from other EU countries locked up in British jails last year.
extra_title: 4,000 EU prisoners in England and Wales
rating_alternateName: This is how many prisoners in England and Wales at the end of 2017 were citizens of other EU countries.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “TAXPAYERS faced a bill of more than £140million to keep more than 4,000 foreign criminals from other EU countries locked up in British jails last year, figures revealed today.”
extra_title: 4,000 EU prisoners in England and Wales
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 1.7 million people in Britain today are unemployed.
extra_title: Immigration and unemployment in the UK
rating_alternateName: Correct, as of July-September 2016. Although the figure hasn’t been adjusted to take into account the time of year, and by historic standards that’s a fairly low level of unemployment.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 600,000 people aged 18-24 are unemployed.
extra_title: Immigration and unemployment in the UK
rating_alternateName: That’s wrong, as of July-September 2016. About 520,000 people aged 18-24 were unemployed that summer. Taking the time of year into account, the ‘seasonally adjusted’ estimate was about 473,000.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of people who came to live in this country last year was the same as the population of Newcastle-upon-Tyne.
extra_title: Immigration and unemployment in the UK
rating_alternateName: Not far off, assuming the claim is referring to net migration. The best estimate is that about 335,000 more people came to live in UK than left in the year leading up to June 2016. Only 293,000 people live in Newcastle-upon-Tyne.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "It cannot be right that we have 1.7 million people in Britain today who are unemployed.”
extra_title: Immigration and unemployment in the UK
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “600,000 of them are between 18 and 24.”
extra_title: Immigration and unemployment in the UK
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “And this goes back to the key issue of immigration actually, because last week we allowed – the figures came out that we allowed this year a city the size of Newcastle-upon-Tyne to come to this country.”
extra_title: Immigration and unemployment in the UK
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “That is insane when you’ve got 1.7 million people unemployed. What we need to do is to get our own people back into work first before we bring people in to do other jobs."
extra_title: Immigration and unemployment in the UK
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The net migration target could only have been met if immigration of non-EU citizens was cut.
extra_title: The net migration target was never likely to have been met
rating_alternateName: Correct. Significant reductions to non-EU immigration will have been needed given the government can’t control the volume of EU immigration. But non-EU levels are now roughly what they were back in 2010, so the target is far from being met.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Home Office set a target to cut immigration down to the tens of thousands.
extra_title: The net migration target was never likely to have been met
rating_alternateName: This is correct, referring to net migration rather than just immigration. Governments since 2010 have continually mentioned this figure, though it’s not clear if it is still in place.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “[The Home Office] set the tone which was this, we have to cut immigration down to tens of thousands. They knew they weren’t going to be able to do that, because it was free for people to move about from Europe, so the only way that they could cut back on immigration was [to cut] people who came from outside of Europe."
extra_title: The net migration target was never likely to have been met
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Until 2004, immigration was around 50,000 a year and it’s risen since then.
extra_title: Immigration to the UK has been rising
rating_alternateName: 50,000 is wrong, although immigration did increase considerably after 2004 as new countries joined the EU.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We’ve always had immigration … up until 2004, we had levels of around 50,000 a year and it worked very well ... We then had uncontrolled, chaotic immigration since then.”
extra_title: Immigration to the UK has been rising
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Tories have scrapped Labour's policy to cap class sizes at 30 pupils.
extra_title: Factcheck: Has the cap on infant class sizes been scrapped?
rating_alternateName: The cap hasn't been scrapped, but there has been a three-fold increase in oversized classes under the Coalition.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The proportion of class sizes bigger than this has trebled. That means the number of youngest children taught in such classes has risen by over 60,000.
extra_title: Factcheck: Has the cap on infant class sizes been scrapped?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The recent and projected population increases are likely to increase demand for teachers and the number of class rooms, making it more challenging for local authorities to keep Key Stage 1 classes within the legal limit of 30 pupils per class.
extra_title: Factcheck: Has the cap on infant class sizes been scrapped?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: State expenditure is at a record high.
extra_title: State spending isn’t at a record high when you consider the size of the economy
rating_alternateName: The amount of money spent by the state is the highest it’s ever been in real and cash terms. But is not at a record high when compared to the size of the economy—the most useful measure.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Funding for schools has increased significantly in recent years.
extra_title: State spending isn’t at a record high when you consider the size of the economy
rating_alternateName: Spending on schools was around £50 billion in 2018/19. Spending per-pupil in England has fallen 8% since 2009/10.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Funding for the NHS has increased significantly in recent years.
extra_title: State spending isn’t at a record high when you consider the size of the economy
rating_alternateName: Correct, as it has done throughout almost its entire history.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Funding for pensions has increased significantly in recent years.
extra_title: State spending isn’t at a record high when you consider the size of the economy
rating_alternateName: The state pension has increased in recent years, but because the pension age has increased, fewer people are now eligible for the pension. So while state spending on pensioner benefits has risen since 2010 it has remained stable in the last few years.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“State expenditure is at a record high, reaching a colossal £841 billion this financial year…
“funding for vital areas such as the NHS, schools and pensions has increased significantly in recent years.
extra_title: State spending isn’t at a record high when you consider the size of the economy
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Local NHS has been allocated £570 billion to fund the NHS Long Term Plan.
extra_title: Will local NHS services in England have £570 billion to spend over the next five years?
rating_alternateName: Over the next five years across England, CCGs’ budgets are expected to total around £570 billion in cash terms. Funding is set to increase by around £3 billion each year in real terms.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Local NHS allocated £570 billion to fund the NHS Long Term Plan”
extra_title: Will local NHS services in England have £570 billion to spend over the next five years?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government will be putting more money into the NHS over the next five years, £394 million more a week.
extra_title: NHS England: £394 million more a week?
rating_alternateName: Spending increases announced for NHS England’s budget mean that £20.5 billion more will be spent on it in 2023/24 than in 2018/19. That’s £394 million more a week by 2023/24. This money doesn’t cover all health spending.

claimReview_claimReviewed: No longer sending money to the EU means we will have money to spend on priorities like the NHS.
extra_title: NHS England: £394 million more a week?
rating_alternateName: There is no guaranteed extra money to pay for increased NHS funding from stopping our payments to the EU budget. Other costs associated with Brexit are expected to outweigh the savings.

claimReview_claimReviewed: When the UK leaves the EU we won’t be sending vast amounts of money to the EU every year.
extra_title: NHS England: £394 million more a week?
rating_alternateName: Our net contribution to the EU budget is typically £9-10 billion a year. We will no longer contribute to it from 2021 onwards, but other costs and economic effects associated with leaving are expected to more than offset that saving.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “When we leave the EU we won’t be sending, you know, the vast amounts of money to the EU every year that we do at the moment. That means we will have money to spend on priorities like the NHS… We’ve set out that we’ll be putting more money into the NHS over the next five years, and it will mean £394 million more a week more going into our National Health Service.”
extra_title: NHS England: £394 million more a week?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We will take back control of our money, by putting an end to vast annual payments to the EU. Instead, we will be able to spend British taxpayer’s money on our own priorities, like the extra £394 million per week that we are investing in our long-term plan for the NHS.”
extra_title: NHS England: £394 million more a week?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Diabetes prescriptions are costing the NHS in England more than £1 billion a year, according to figures from NHS Digital.
extra_title: Do diabetes prescriptions cost £1 billion a year?
rating_alternateName: We can’t know how much it actually costs the NHS. £1 billion was the net ingredient cost in 2017/18 of items for diabetes prescribed in England through NHS primary care settings. There is no available information on what discounts the NHS might receive or extra costs relating to dispensing.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Diabetes prescriptions are costing the NHS in England more than £1 billion a year, according to figures from NHS Digital.”
extra_title: Do diabetes prescriptions cost £1 billion a year?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: NHS spending is going to increase by 3.4% a year.
extra_title: The latest plans for NHS England spending outstrip both main parties’ manifesto pledges
rating_alternateName: Correct according to the government’s latest plans to 2023/24 for the NHS in England. This is in real terms, taking inflation into account.

claimReview_claimReviewed: In 2017 Labour said a 2.2% increase in NHS funding would make it the envy of the world.
extra_title: The latest plans for NHS England spending outstrip both main parties’ manifesto pledges
rating_alternateName: Labour’s 2017 manifesto pledged roughly 2.2% annual funding increases for the NHS in England for the rest of the decade. In the same manifesto they said they wanted to “restore the NHS to its place as the envy of the world”. They didn’t directly connect this to their specific pledges.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Even Labour at the last election said that an increase of 2.2% would make the NHS the envy of the world. We'll be increasing spending by 3.4%.”
extra_title: The latest plans for NHS England spending outstrip both main parties’ manifesto pledges
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: MPs’ salaries have increased from £66,000 in 2010 to £77,000 in 2018.
extra_title: Pay rises: how much do nurses, the police, teachers and MPs get paid?
rating_alternateName: These figures don’t take account of inflation since 2010. In 2018 prices MPs’ pay has remained stable compared with 2010 at around £77,400.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A fully qualified nurse’s starting salary has not increased since 2010 when it was £22,000.
extra_title: Pay rises: how much do nurses, the police, teachers and MPs get paid?
rating_alternateName: These figures don’t take account of inflation. In 2018 prices, it was £25,000 a year in 2010, and in 2018 it’s £23,000.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A newly qualified teacher’s salary was £21,500 in 2010 and £22,000 in 2018.
extra_title: Pay rises: how much do nurses, the police, teachers and MPs get paid?
rating_alternateName: These figures don’t take account of inflation since 2010. In 2018 prices, a new teacher’s salary in a local authority-run school in England and Wales (outside of London) was £25,400 in 2010, and is now £23,000.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The police starting salary was £24,000 in 2010 and £23,000 in 2018.
extra_title: Pay rises: how much do nurses, the police, teachers and MPs get paid?
rating_alternateName: These figures don’t account for inflation. In 2018 prices their starting salary has fallen from the equivalent of £27,400 in 2010 to around £23,300 in 2018.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Delaying a decision about which runway to build costs the UK economy £6 million every day.
extra_title: Does delaying airport expansion cost us £6 million a day?
rating_alternateName: Whether or not you agree that a delay in the decision is imposing unnecessary costs on the UK economy, this probably isn’t the best estimate of what those costs are. Any precise figure will be uncertain.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Delay over Heathrow third runway decision costing UK up to £6m a day, say MPs”
extra_title: Does delaying airport expansion cost us £6 million a day?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The pound has fallen by 15%.
extra_title: The pound has fallen in value since the Brexit vote
rating_alternateName: Not quite, the exact fall depends which currency you compare it to. It’s fallen by 12% against the Euro and 5% against the US Dollar since May 2016.

claimReview_claimReviewed: We’ve got the slowest growth in Europe.
extra_title: The pound has fallen in value since the Brexit vote
rating_alternateName: The UK had the third-slowest year-on-year GDP growth in the EU, based on the latest figures for July-September 2017.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “So far the pound has tanked by 15%... We've got the lowest growth in the EU.”
extra_title: The pound has fallen in value since the Brexit vote
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The IMF said the pound was overvalued before the EU referendum.
extra_title: Was the pound overvalued before the EU referendum?
rating_alternateName: This is correct. Before the EU referendum, the IMF said that the pound was overvalued in 2015.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The pound is now undervalued, based on the IMF’s recommendations in February and June 2016.
extra_title: Was the pound overvalued before the EU referendum?
rating_alternateName: This is uncertain. When IMF said the pound was overvalued, they based their recommendations on the assumption that the UK would vote to remain in the EU. It's open to debate what value the pound should be at now that we've voted to leave.

claimReview_claimReviewed: NHS Trusts are in the worst financial crisis of their history, according to NHS Providers, with 80% of acute hospitals in deficit, although the NHS was in surplus in 2010.
extra_title: NHS trusts in deficit
rating_alternateName: 75% of acute hospitals are in deficit, according to the latest figures.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “NHS Trusts are in a financial crisis. According to NHS Providers, it seems to be the worst financial crisis in NHS history. 80% of acute hospitals now in deficit. There was a time in 2010, when the NHS was in surplus. What happened?”
extra_title: NHS trusts in deficit
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The "Stevens plan" for an extra £8bn into the NHS can help to fund better mental health services, among other things.
extra_title: There's only so much £8 billion will buy you in the NHS
rating_alternateName: £8bn is the minimum amount required to keep services at current levels.  It is not extra money to pay for extra services.

claimReview_claimReviewed: MPs would need to approve British military action in Syria.
extra_title: MPs don't have to approve military action in Syria
rating_alternateName: Legally, the government doesn't need the permission of Parliament to use military force. But there is a convention that it will consult MPs before doing so, where possible, and abide by the outcome of their vote.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Britain is not taking part in the action in Syria because MPs have so far refused to authorise the extension of airstrikes in neighbouring Iraq."
extra_title: MPs don't have to approve military action in Syria
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "I need to take it to Parliament"
extra_title: MPs don't have to approve military action in Syria
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Raising public sector pay in line with inflation will cost £4 billion.
extra_title: The cost of lifting the public sector pay cap
rating_alternateName: It's correct that it will cost £4 billion a year according to one estimate, although it's uncertain how accurate this will turn out to be.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We’ve calculated that it will cost £4 billion in order to pay public sector workers an inflation increase.”
extra_title: The cost of lifting the public sector pay cap
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Conservatives plan to take on 6,000 more police officers in 12 months at a cost of £750 million.
extra_title: Don’t compare Labour and Conservative costings for police recruitment
rating_alternateName: Correct. This covers police salaries as well as any costs associated with recruitment and training.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Labour have committed to hire 10,000 police officers at a cost of £3 billion.
extra_title: Don’t compare Labour and Conservative costings for police recruitment
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. Labour costed this at £770 million over five years in 2017, though this only covers police salaries and so the actual cost of recruitment would be higher.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Six people were stabbed in London on Saturday 6 July 2019, including three 12 year-olds.
extra_title: Metropolitan police taking part in London Pride were on duty
rating_alternateName: That’s correct. We don’t know their exact ages, but the three children stabbed were reportedly all younger than 12.

claimReview_claimReviewed: On duty police officers participated in the London Pride parade.
extra_title: Metropolitan police taking part in London Pride were on duty
rating_alternateName: Correct. The Metropolitan police taking part in the Pride parade were on duty.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK has a huge trade deficit with the EU.
extra_title: The UK’s trade deficit with the EU
rating_alternateName: The UK imported around £60 billion more goods and services from the rest of the EU than it exported there in the 12 months to September 2016, although it has a trade surplus in services alone.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We have a huge trade deficit with the European Union”
extra_title: The UK’s trade deficit with the EU
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Migration has amounted to 80% of UK population growth.
extra_title: Migration drives the majority of UK population growth—exactly how much is debatable
rating_alternateName: This combines a rough estimate of both migration to and from the UK and children born to immigrant parents. Without counting children, migration directly accounts for 60% of UK population growth since 2000.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Migration has amounted to, I think, 80% of the population increase, which is about one million every three years.”
extra_title: Migration drives the majority of UK population growth—exactly how much is debatable
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: EU migration is at record levels.
extra_title: Jobs figures can't show record EU migration
rating_alternateName: This is wrong. Figures released today only show the number of EU nationals and EU born in work, not the numbers coming to the UK. The most recent migration estimates don't show record levels, but EU migration is historically high and could hit a record count when figures are released next week.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“Record EU migration figures add to pressure on Cameron"
“Official figures published today show migration from the EU continuing to rise as the UK’s recovering economy sucked in workers from troubled Eurozone states."
“Today’s figures confirm how difficult it will be for the Prime Minister to meet his target of reducing net migration — the difference between those arriving and those leaving the UK for a year or longer — to under 100,000 by 2020 while migration from the EU continues at current levels.”
extra_title: Jobs figures can't show record EU migration
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Leaving the EU would or could cut net migration by 100,000
extra_title: Would net migration fall by 100,000 if the UK left the EU?
rating_alternateName: Nobody knows. It’s an unofficial “ball park figure” for one possible exit scenario and the prediction depends on assumptions which might or might not come true.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Leaving EU 'would cut migration by 100,000' - Migration Watch
extra_title: Would net migration fall by 100,000 if the UK left the EU?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Two thirds of manufacturing jobs, and 50,000 manufacturing apprenticeships, are reliant on Britain’s membership of the EU.
extra_title: Manufacturing jobs and the EU
rating_alternateName: This is wrong. Roughly 15% of manufacturing jobs can be said to be directly linked to demand from other EU countries. That doesn’t mean these jobs are dependent on the UK being an EU member. Both claims are based on older inaccurate figures, and use flawed comparisons.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“For UK manufacturing jobs, our EU membership is absolutely critical. Two thirds of British jobs in manufacturing are dependent on demand from Europe.
“That’s two thirds of our manufacturing base reliant on that single market access and Britain’s membership of the EU.”
“…That’s 50,000 apprenticeships which depend on our EU membership and leaving the EU could put those at risk.”
extra_title: Manufacturing jobs and the EU
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK pays nearly a fifth of all VAT going into the EU budget.
extra_title: Does the UK pay a fifth of the VAT going into the EU budget?
rating_alternateName: The UK is behind a significant share of the VAT revenue flowing into the EU budget. But it makes more sense to look at all contributions rather than a small part; VAT was only 12% of EU revenue in 2014.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "UK pays nearly a fifth of all VAT that goes into the EU budget"
extra_title: Does the UK pay a fifth of the VAT going into the EU budget?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK is spending more on foreign aid than the Home Office.

rating_alternateName: This is likely to be the case within a few years, although exact comparisons are tricky. Last year the Home Office spent more than was devoted to overseas aid, but aid spending is due to increase a lot.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "The £16 billion aid budget that dwarfs our Home Office spending"

extra_title: The ruling on the 'bedroom tax'
rating_alternateName: The decision affects victims of domestic violence whose homes have 'panic spaces', and disabled children who need overnight carers. It doesn't spell the end of the policy in general and is likely to be appealed to the Supreme Court.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Court of Appeal rules that ‘bedroom tax’ is unlawful”
extra_title: The ruling on the 'bedroom tax'

claimReview_claimReviewed: Last month MPs voted against removing the "tampon tax".

rating_alternateName: MPs didn't vote on whether to remove the tax (which can't be done without changing EU law). The amendment they voted against was on whether the government should have to set out a "road map" for how it will negotiate with the EU to get sanitary products exempt from VAT.

rating_alternateName: The numbers are accurate but very uncertain. The proportion of tax due but unpaid is lower under Labour but no longer falling.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Under the last Labour government the tax gap was falling by £1.5bn a year on average between 2005-06 and 2009-10. But under the Tories it has been increasing by an average of £1bn a year."

claimReview_claimReviewed: "On flood defence spending, over the last Parliament we spent £1.7 billion in capital spending—a real-terms increase on the £1.5 billion spent between 2005 and 2010. Our next six-year programme is £2.3 billion, which again represents a real-terms increase."

claimReview_claimReviewed: We have cut further education budgets by 50%.
extra_title: Spending for adult skills fell by 40% between 2010 and 2015
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. Spending on core adult skills fell by 40% in England between 2010/11 and 2015/16, taking inflation into account. Changes to funding make recent comparisons more complex but the overall picture is that non-apprenticeship core funding is set to fall slightly between 2016/17 and 2019/20, and adult apprenticeship funding is set to significantly rise.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The priority is, why have we cut FE budgets by 50%?”

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of apprenticeship starts has fallen by 70% over the last quarter.
extra_title: Has the number of people starting apprenticeships fallen?
rating_alternateName: Correct, apprenticeship starts in England in May to July this year were 72% lower than in February to April. Comparing neighbouring quarters isn’t always appropriate because differences can be due to the time of year. The fall is 59% comparing to May to July last year.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “There's a real crisis on the apprenticeship front because over the last quarter, the number of apprenticeship starts has fallen by 70%.”
