extra_title: Robots and the future of your job
rating_alternateName: That's one way of putting it. Mark Carney quoted an estimate that 15 million jobs in the UK could be automated over the next few decades. In the past, new technology has created new types of work and hasn't caused mass unemployment in the long run.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A million more pupils are in good or outstanding schools in England than five years ago.
extra_title: A million more pupils in good or outstanding schools? Not just a simple story of school improvement
rating_alternateName: Correct. This progress is partly due to Ofsted's changing inspection practice - which refined what was expected of schools and placed a greater emphasis on inspecting schools which fell below this expectation.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "We've made huge strides in the past five years—a million more pupils now in good or outstanding schools."

claimReview_claimReviewed: People with disabilities are set to see a real-terms cut of £1.2 billion a year across this parliament.
extra_title: Is spending on disability benefits going up or down?
rating_alternateName: Spending on all disability, incapacity, industrial injuries and carer’s benefits, including related housing benefit, is expected to fall by £1.2 billion by the end of this parliament. Spending won’t fall by this amount every year—it will fall by £295 million each year on average.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Spending on the main disability benefits will increase over the course of this parliament.
extra_title: Is spending on disability benefits going up or down?
rating_alternateName: Spending on Disability Living Allowance, Personal Independence Payments and Attendance Allowance (the ‘main disability benefits’ this claim is referring to) is expected to rise slightly over this parliament, after rising prices are taken into account. It won’t rise by as much as it has been in recent years.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Even after the U-turn over cuts to personal independence payments, disabled people are set to see a real-terms cut of £1.2bn a year across this parliament.”

claimReview_claimReviewed: “At the moment we have an NHS where if you have a stroke at the weekends, you're 20% more likely to die.”

extra_title: No evidence that junior doctors' strike will put 200 lives at risk

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Strike by doctors will put 200 lives at risk, says fellow NHS medic"

claimReview_claimReviewed: 98% of junior doctors voted in favour of strikes.
extra_title: Did 98% of junior doctors vote to strike?
rating_alternateName: 98% of junior doctors who are members of the British Medical Association (BMA) and who voted in the ballot said they would be prepared to strike. Not all junior doctors are members of the BMA, and not all members voted. Taken as a proportion of all junior doctors (including some not affected by the changes), roughly 46-52% voted to strike.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Junior doctors row: 98% vote in favour of strikes"
extra_title: Did 98% of junior doctors vote to strike?

claimReview_claimReviewed: Some grammar schools get less than £4,500 per pupil. Other state schools can receive as much as £8,000.
extra_title: Are grammar schools facing a crisis of funding?
rating_alternateName: Correct. In 2016/17 English grammars received on average £4,500 per pupil while other state schools received £5,200.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Many of the 163 grammars are facing a crisis under May, even though she promised to champion them. Some get less than £4,500 per pupil, among the lowest funding in the UK. Other state schools can receive as much as £8,000.”

claimReview_claimReviewed: Free schools are being opened in areas that do not need them.
extra_title: Most, but not all, free schools help meet demand for school places
rating_alternateName: It depends what you mean by ‘need’. 83% of free schools since 2013 have been opened in areas that need extra school places, but free schools can also be opened with the intention of driving up standards. Across this parliament, the Department for Education expects about half of new places in mainstream free schools to create spare capacity in their local area.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “There is evidence that certain free schools are being opened in areas that do not need them, and my view is that there should be equality, that money should be spread right across the system to give every child a good school in the area where he lives.”

claimReview_claimReviewed: 80% of selective schools are rated as outstanding compared to 20% of all state schools. 99% of selective schools are rated good or outstanding.

rating_alternateName: This is correct. 82% of selective schools were rated outstanding as of August 2016, compared to just over 20% of all state schools. 99% of selective schools received the top two ratings compared to 88% of all schools.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “In fact, 99% of existing selective schools are rated good or outstanding – and 80% are outstanding, compared with just 20% of state schools overall.”

claimReview_claimReviewed: Licensed gambling has grown 57% over the last decade.
extra_title: Gambling spend down since 2008 on average
rating_alternateName: Gambling yield has grown 57% over the last decade if you exclude the National Lottery. Including the National Lottery it has grown 40%. However, this growth is largely due to the changes in how online gambling is classified. This growth doesn’t necessarily mean people are gambling more.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Licensed gambling has grown by 57% over the last decade boosted by online and smartphone access.”
extra_title: Gambling spend down since 2008 on average

claimReview_claimReviewed: Bus fares have gone up by 60% since 2010.
extra_title: Bus fares have risen faster than wages since 2010
rating_alternateName: Correct, looking at one measure which includes coach fares too. However, this increase doesn’t factor in the rise in wages over the same period.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Bus fares have gone up by 60% since 2010.”
extra_title: Bus fares have risen faster than wages since 2010
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The minimum wage should be £18 an hour, because in 1999 one hour’s pay at minimum wage could buy you 72 Freddos, but in 2017 it could only buy you 30 Freddos.
extra_title: The price of Freddos has risen five times faster than inflation
rating_alternateName: Actually, you could have got 36 Freddos in 1999. More broadly, Freddos are not a good measure of inflation. The price of Freddos rose about five times faster than inflation from 1999 to 2017, but the minimum wage also rose above inflation in that period.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Water bills are up 40% since privatisation.
extra_title: Water rip-off? Are water bills up 40% since privatisation?
rating_alternateName: Correct in real terms in England and Wales between 1989 and 2014/15. Most of that rise happened between 1989 and 1995. Bills have fallen slightly in real terms since 2009/10.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “New reports have revealed the staggering public cost of privatised water – water bills are up 40% since privatisation.”
extra_title: Water rip-off? Are water bills up 40% since privatisation?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Over 2.5 million people now officially live in energy poverty.
extra_title: The government hasn’t u-turned on energy price caps
rating_alternateName: This is an underestimate: almost 3.7 million households may be living in some form of fuel poverty across the UK, although the data is not directly comparable due to differences in how it is measured.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Theresa May u-turned on a pre-election promise to cap energy bills.
extra_title: The government hasn’t u-turned on energy price caps
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The government did introduce a bill that would allow for energy price caps as promised. At the moment it’s progressing through parliament.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“SPOT THE DIFFERENCE Theresa May making a pre-election promise to put a cap on energy bills to protect hard up families from the big 6 energy firms
Over 2.5 million people now officially living in energy poverty because Theresa May u-turned on her energy cap promise
extra_title: The government hasn’t u-turned on energy price caps
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The trains don’t run on time.
extra_title: Are rail fares out of control?
rating_alternateName: Around 87% of trains in Britain arrived at their destination within five or 10 minutes of their schedule, in the year to May 2018. Around 62% arrived within a minute of their schedule.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Rail fares are out of control.
extra_title: Are rail fares out of control?
rating_alternateName: The average rail fare in Britain has increased by 20% in real terms since 1995, though it dropped by 1%, factoring in inflation, between 2017 and 2018.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The prices are out of control, the trains don’t run on time”.
extra_title: Are rail fares out of control?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Before the EU referendum George Osborne claimed up to 820,000 jobs could be lost within two years if Britain chose to leave.
extra_title: What’s happened to employment since the vote to leave the EU?
rating_alternateName: Correct. Mr Osborne did claim this. He was referring to Treasury analysis which said the worst case scenario following a leave vote could increase the number of unemployed people by 820,000.

claimReview_claimReviewed: More foreigners have jobs than before the EU referendum.
extra_title: What’s happened to employment since the vote to leave the EU?
rating_alternateName: Correct, the number of people born outside the UK in employment has increased over the past two years.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A record number of Britons are now in work.
extra_title: What’s happened to employment since the vote to leave the EU?
rating_alternateName: Correct. Around 32 million people are in work, the highest since records began. Around 76% of all adults aged 16-64 are in work.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “…a record number of Britons are now in work and more foreigners have jobs than before the referendum… Before the vote George Osborne claimed up to 820,000 jobs could be lost within two years if Britain chose to leave.”
extra_title: What’s happened to employment since the vote to leave the EU?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Labour’s plans to nationalise certain industries would cost at least £196billion and savers and pensioners could suffer further losses of £9 billion.
extra_title: There are some problems with this estimate of Labour’s nationalisation plans
rating_alternateName: The analysis this is based on says either one or the other of these things happens, not both.  Regardless its method is disputed and doesn’t factor in the potential economic benefits of nationalisation.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“Labour's nationalisation plans would cost at least £196bn, according to the Confederation of British Industry…
“It also said that under Labour's plans, savers and pensioners could suffer an estimated £9bn loss to their holdings, which translates into £327 for every household in the country.
extra_title: There are some problems with this estimate of Labour’s nationalisation plans
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The price tag for Labour’s renationalisation plans is beyond eye-watering – close to £200 billion. And that’s only the starting point. It doesn’t take into account the maintenance and development of the infrastructure, the trickle down hit to pension pots and savings accounts, or the impact on the country’s public finances.
extra_title: There are some problems with this estimate of Labour’s nationalisation plans
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: After nine years of a Conservative government, child poverty is up 50%.
extra_title: Viral post about Conservatives’ record in government gets lots of things wrong
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. There’s no single measure of child poverty, but depending on which you use it has risen by up to 5% or fallen by up to 3% between 2009/10 and 2017/18, under coalition and Conservative governments.

claimReview_claimReviewed: After nine years of a Conservative government, food bank use is up 1,000%.
extra_title: Viral post about Conservatives’ record in government gets lots of things wrong
rating_alternateName: The increase is over 1000%, looking at the number of three-day food packages handed out by the Trussell Trust, which runs a network of food banks in the UK. This does not cover all food banks in the UK though. The period covers coalition and Conservative governments.

claimReview_claimReviewed: After nine years of a Conservative government, homelessness is up 170%.
extra_title: Viral post about Conservatives’ record in government gets lots of things wrong
rating_alternateName: The estimated number of rough sleepers is up 165% in England between 2010 and 2018, under coalition and Conservative governments. But this data is known to undercount rough sleeping so those figures are not definitive. Also many people who aren’t sleeping rough are also defined as homeless. The number of households that were homeless for any reason increased by 41% between 2009/10 and 2017/18 in England.

claimReview_claimReviewed: After nine years of a Conservative government, the NHS waiting list has increased by 70%.
extra_title: Viral post about Conservatives’ record in government gets lots of things wrong
rating_alternateName: In May 2019 there were 4.4 million referrals for treatment on the NHS in England, where the treatment had not yet begun. That’s an increase of 70% compared to May 2010. The period covers coalition and Conservative governments.

claimReview_claimReviewed: After nine years of a Conservative government, police numbers are down 20%.
extra_title: Viral post about Conservatives’ record in government gets lots of things wrong
rating_alternateName: The total police workforce in England and Wales fell by 17% between March 2010 and March 2019, under coalition and Conservative governments. Police officer numbers fell by 14% in the same period.

claimReview_claimReviewed: After nine years of a Conservative government, crime is up 30%.
extra_title: Viral post about Conservatives’ record in government gets lots of things wrong
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. There’s no perfect measure of crime, but best estimates suggest it has fallen in England and Wales between 2009/10 and 2018/19, under coalition and Conservative governments.

claimReview_claimReviewed: After nine years of a Conservative government, local government funding is down 50%.
extra_title: Viral post about Conservatives’ record in government gets lots of things wrong
rating_alternateName: Government funding for local authorities in England fell by 49% between 2010/11 and 2017/18 in real terms, under coalition and Conservative governments. Councils have other revenue sources, and total “spending power” fell 29% in real terms in the same period.

claimReview_claimReviewed: After nine years of a Conservative government, public sector pay is down 15%.
extra_title: Viral post about Conservatives’ record in government gets lots of things wrong
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. Between May 2010 and July 2019 in Great Britain, , under coalition and Conservative governments, average weekly earnings in the public sector (excluding financial services) decreased by 1-2% in real terms.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“Everyone needs reminding that after 9 years of a Tory Government:
“Child poverty + 50%
“Food-bank use + 1,000%
“Homelessness + 170%
“NHS waiting list + 70%
“Police numbers - 20%
“Crime + 30%
“Local gov funding - 50%
“Public sector pay - 15%”
extra_title: Viral post about Conservatives’ record in government gets lots of things wrong

claimReview_claimReviewed: We spent just over £1 trillion bailing out the banks after the financial crisis.
extra_title: £1 trillion was not spent on bailing out banks during the financial crisis
rating_alternateName: Incorrect, the total government spend was £137 billion. Most of this has been paid back and around £27 billion is still outstanding. Around £1 trillion worth of financial guarantees were provided to investors—but these were promises designed to restore confidence in the banks, not cash for spending.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We spent just over £1 trillion bailing out the banks after the financial crisis. So if we did it for the bankers then why wouldn’t we do it what is needed for our fishermen and our farmers now?”
extra_title: £1 trillion was not spent on bailing out banks during the financial crisis
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Airports have been built with foreign aid money where planes can’t take off and land because of winds.
extra_title: Was foreign aid money spent on an airport that doesn’t run flights?
rating_alternateName: St Helena airport, which was built with £285 million of foreign aid, was unable to run commercial flights when it first opened due to wind shear on the island. But since October 2017 it has run commercial flights.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We know airports have been built [using foreign aid] and actually the runways are in the wrong direction because of the winds… it’s in one of the continents abroad. We know we’ve got that airport where we can’t take off and land because of the winds, the cross winds there.”
extra_title: Was foreign aid money spent on an airport that doesn’t run flights?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There were 17,000 fewer police officers in 2015 than in 2010.
extra_title: What happened to council funding, welfare spending and police numbers under the Coalition?
rating_alternateName: Correct for England and Wales.

claimReview_claimReviewed: £22 billion was taken out of welfare between 2010 and 2015.
extra_title: What happened to council funding, welfare spending and police numbers under the Coalition?
rating_alternateName: This is how much more would have been spent in real terms on social security payments across the UK between 2010/11 and 2015/16, had changes introduced between 2010 and 2015 not taken place.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There were 25% cuts to local government spending between 2010 and 2015.
extra_title: What happened to council funding, welfare spending and police numbers under the Coalition?
rating_alternateName: Correct for England, looking at a comparable measure of council funding which includes central government grants, council tax and business rates, called “core spending power”.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “You’re rising in the polls at the moment but isn’t there a danger of people breathing new life into a party which brought us through austerity: huge cuts, 25% cuts in local government spending, £22 billion out of welfare and 17,000 fewer police officers.”
extra_title: What happened to council funding, welfare spending and police numbers under the Coalition?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: National Insurance Contributions are being used to reduce the national debt.
extra_title: What happens to the money from National Insurance Contributions?
rating_alternateName: Some are. This doesn’t mean anyone isn’t getting paid what they’re currently due in pensions or benefits—the UK government invests the NICs that don’t go towards paying pensions and benefits on reducing the national debt.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Our NI payments being used to reduce the national debt, no wonder the UK pensions are so small”
extra_title: What happens to the money from National Insurance Contributions?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: We can't attract junior doctors from around the world because they won’t actually earn enough to meet the minimum income requirements.
extra_title: Are junior doctors paid enough to get a UK visa?
rating_alternateName: A first-year junior doctor typically earns £26,500, rising to £31,000 in their second year. To get a visa, most non-EEA junior doctors usually have to be earning £30,000, or £20,800 if they’re under 26. However, at the end of 2017 the threshold was effectively £55,000.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “And because of the quite, quite meaningless limits set on what people can earn, we can't attract junior doctors from around the world because they won’t actually earn enough to meet the minimum income requirements”.
extra_title: Are junior doctors paid enough to get a UK visa?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Since 2000, almost as many British military personnel have died in training or exercises as were killed in Iraq.
extra_title: Deaths during military training: worse than Iraq?
rating_alternateName: Correct, although some deaths may not have been directly related to the training.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Try this on for size, this figure truly shocked me. Since 2000, 135 military personnel have died while taking part in training and exercise… In Iraq, we lost only slightly more than that, just over 150 lives. We're killing almost as many of our own with training."
extra_title: Deaths during military training: worse than Iraq?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK is making progress towards meeting its 2020 targets on renewable energy.
extra_title: Is the UK making progress towards its 2020 renewables target?
rating_alternateName: It has met its interim targets, but that doesn’t mean it will meet the target for 2020. Without further action from the government the target will be missed.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “...[we are] making progress towards our 2020 renewables target of 15%”
extra_title: Is the UK making progress towards its 2020 renewables target?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: That is accurate assessment of where we are if we do not take action, but I am determined to take action so that we exceed that and reach the 15%.
extra_title: Is the UK making progress towards its 2020 renewables target?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK missed its interim renewable energy target.
extra_title: Are we missing our targets on renewable energy?
rating_alternateName: The UK's target was for 5.4% of its energy consumption to come from renewable sources over 2013 and 2014. Provisional calculations show it met this target.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Last week it was revealed that we had missed our interim EU 2020 target for renewable energy generation."
extra_title: Are we missing our targets on renewable energy?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "We do not accept that we have missed it. Our interim reporting covers the period to the end of 2015, and we believe that we are on track to meet that target."
extra_title: Are we missing our targets on renewable energy?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The EU has set a 15% overall target for UK energy consumption from renewable sources in 2020.
extra_title: The UK's renewable energy target
rating_alternateName: The UK does have a 15% overall target. It also has a 10% target for renewables in transport energy consumption in 2020. The exact way in which the 15% target is met is up to the UK, so long as the 10% transport sub-target is met.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "As for the emissions angle, we know that we are driven by the European requirements for renewable energy, the formidable target of 15% of our energy from renewable sources by, I think, 2020, and Europe's target of 40% by 2030."
extra_title: The UK's renewable energy target
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "We have a 20% renewables target overall across all energy, which translates into a 30% target for renewable electricity and, I believe, there is a 12% renewable heat target, and therefore a 10% renewables target. There is no breakdown of those targets at a European level into those sub-sectors: it is simply an all-energy target, and there is no further subdivision into technology types."
extra_title: The UK's renewable energy target
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The EU referendum outcome is "on a knife edge".
extra_title: Is the EU referendum outcome "on a knife edge"?
rating_alternateName: This is uncertain. While two polls have shown a narrow gap between the 'remain' and 'leave' camps, others have shown significant gaps between the two. Different methods give different results, with telephone polls showing 'remain' with a strong lead and online polls showing a more narrow gap.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "EU referendum outcome on a knife edge, new poll reveals"
extra_title: Is the EU referendum outcome "on a knife edge"?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "UK exit from European Union on a knife edge, as poll shows British public are now 50/50 over leaving"
extra_title: Is the EU referendum outcome "on a knife edge"?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: MPs were forced out of hospital and their sick beds to vote in Commons.
extra_title: Did some MPs have to leave their sickbeds to vote on Brexit?
rating_alternateName: A convention allowing unwell or pregnant MPs who are on parliamentary grounds to vote without entering the division lobby wasn’t applied to a vote on the Brexit bill last week. This meant one sick MP, and two heavily pregnant MPs who wanted to vote were obliged to physically enter the lobby.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “MPs forced out of hospital and their sick beds to vote in Commons because Theresa May was scared of being defeated”
extra_title: Did some MPs have to leave their sickbeds to vote on Brexit?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Judges are going to decide on whether the UK will leave the EU.
extra_title: Are judges deciding whether the UK will leave the EU?
rating_alternateName: The courts will decide whether Parliament has to have a say or not, rather than the government going ahead with Brexit by itself. It’s not directly a question about whether the vote should be upheld, which isn’t a legal matter.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Now you have a situation where you have people in court, at the High Court, to ask this question, which this government never dealt with: does the Prime Minister have the right to use the royal prerogative to trigger Article 50?”
extra_title: Are judges deciding whether the UK will leave the EU?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “You don't seriously believe that a vote of the people of this country, who decided to leave the European Union, should be decided by a judge in chambers…?”

claimReview_claimReviewed: “He’s not asked to decide it”
extra_title: Are judges deciding whether the UK will leave the EU?

claimReview_claimReviewed: Officers from the EU law enforcement agency, Europol, are immune from prosecution.
extra_title: Ask Full Fact: Europol and diplomatic immunity
rating_alternateName: This isn't correct. Europol staff working on an investigation in a member state are in the same position as ordinary officers when it comes to criminal prosecution.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A poll shows that 80% of British people want to quit the EU.
extra_title: Factcheck: Daily Express EU "poll" is biased and wide of the mark
rating_alternateName: This "ballot" says nothing about the state of nationwide opinion. Recent professional polls show that around 36% to 48% of people support leaving.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "80 per cent of Britons want to quit EU in biggest poll for 40 years."
extra_title: Factcheck: Daily Express EU "poll" is biased and wide of the mark
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Lancet says 6.5 million migrants have registered with GPs in the last 10 years.
extra_title: How many migrants have registered with GPs in the last decade?
rating_alternateName: According to the ONS, that’s how many new GP registrations there were between 2007 and 2017 where the person’s previous address was abroad. But migrants who moved between homes in the UK may have been double counted and we don’t know how many were only here short-term.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There’s been an increase in the number of EU staff in the NHS since the referendum.
extra_title: EU staff in the NHS: what has happened since the referendum?
rating_alternateName: Around 4,400 more EU nationals worked for the NHS in England in June 2018, compared to June 2016. But some of the increase could be down to more staff reporting their nationality. The proportion of staff who report they are EU nationals is about the same in 2018 as in 2016.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of EU nurses coming to the UK has fallen by 90% since the Brexit vote.
extra_title: EU staff in the NHS: what has happened since the referendum?
rating_alternateName: The number of nurses and midwives from the EEA joining the Nursing and Midwifery Council’s register fell by 91% from 2015/16 to 2017/18.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of EU nationals leaving the NHS jumped by 14% in 2017.
extra_title: EU staff in the NHS: what has happened since the referendum?
rating_alternateName: That’s correct for staff in England, comparing the number who left in 2016 with the number who left in 2017.

claimReview_claimReviewed: EU nationals have fallen as a percentage of those joining the NHS.
extra_title: EU staff in the NHS: what has happened since the referendum?
rating_alternateName: EU nationals made up 8% of new staff (whose nationality was known) joining the NHS in England in the year to June 2018. That compares to 11% in the year to June 2016. It’s possible that the number in June 2016 was unusually high.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “And in fact there’s been an increase in the number of EU staff in the NHS since the referendum.”
extra_title: EU staff in the NHS: what has happened since the referendum?

claimReview_claimReviewed: Most students who immigrate to the UK return home after study.
extra_title: How many international students leave after studying in the UK?
rating_alternateName: The available evidence is contradictory. Most student immigrants come from outside the EU on a temporary visa and a minority still have the right to remain after a few years. But emigration figures suggest the number staying in the UK may be higher than this.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Most students return home after study.”
extra_title: How many international students leave after studying in the UK?

extra_title: Counting the cost of human rights law
rating_alternateName: The direct cost to the state of European Court of Human Rights judgments has been several million pounds in the past 15 years. Claims in the billions rely on doing effective calculations for the wider cost to the UK, which is impossible.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Human rights laws cost Britain £42bn in rulings and payouts"
extra_title: Counting the cost of human rights law

claimReview_claimReviewed: One third of those who have won a case against the UK at the European human right court were terrorists, criminals or prisoners.
extra_title: The human rights victories won by criminals
rating_alternateName: Around half of successful cases involved someone convicted or suspected of a criminal offence at some point. The answer depends on how you define "criminal".

claimReview_claimReviewed: "A third of those who have won against Britain at the European Court of Human Rights are terrorists, prisoners or criminals, figures show."
extra_title: The human rights victories won by criminals

claimReview_claimReviewed: Many judges at the European Court of Human Rights aren't legally qualified, and are appointed politically.
extra_title: Human rights court: "pseudo-judges" or super judges?
rating_alternateName: None of the judges at the Court are obviously unqualified based on their CVs, although they are voted in by a political body.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
"The European Court of Human Rights is no more than a joke. It is full of judges, many of whom are not even legally qualified
they are not actually real judges; they are pseudo-judges
who are political appointees from the member states who have been sent to make political decisions, not legal decisions"
extra_title: Human rights court: "pseudo-judges" or super judges?

claimReview_claimReviewed: Since the Conservatives came into government in 2010, they have delivered more affordable homes than Labour did in its last seven years in office.
extra_title: Affordable homes: comparing Labour and Conservative records
rating_alternateName: Correct. 346,000 more affordable homes were added in the seven years to 2016/17, compared to 333,000 in the seven years before that. Since 2011/12, the kinds of affordable homes being built have been typically more expensive “affordable rented” homes.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Since we came into office in 2010, we have delivered more affordable homes than the previous Labour Government did in their last seven years in office.”
extra_title: Affordable homes: comparing Labour and Conservative records

claimReview_claimReviewed: Nigel Farage once flirted with the idea of there being a second EU referendum.
extra_title: Deja-EU referendum?
rating_alternateName: During interviews earlier this year Mr Farage said that he might be starting to think we should have a second referendum as he felt the proportion voting to leave would be larger than in 2016. He also said he feared we may have to have a second referendum if Parliament rejects the final deal with the EU.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Nigel Farage, you once flirted with the idea of a second referendum?”
extra_title: Deja-EU referendum?

claimReview_claimReviewed: “No, I didn't, I said I feared. I feared because there is a great Brexit betrayal going on, that parliament may force a second referendum upon us. I pray they don’t, but I do fear and I think some of the people in this panel would like a second referendum.”

rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Taylor Review found that 58% of people working on zero hour contracts did not want more hours.
extra_title: How many people on zero hours contracts want more hours?
rating_alternateName:
Incorrect, it was actually 68%, which refers to people on the contracts who’ve specified a view of their hours. It’s 57% if you include people who didn’t specify a view.
Newer official figures put the same figures at around 72% and 63% respectively.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Matthew Taylor wrote a very good report on this. He discovered that 58% of people working on zero-hours contracts do not want more hours, it suits their lives, they have flexible lives.”
extra_title: How many people on zero hours contracts want more hours?

claimReview_claimReviewed: A survey found 11% of workers who report having taken a financial hit from the coronavirus pandemic have been evicted.
extra_title: How many people have been evicted as a result of coronavirus?
rating_alternateName: Housing charity Shelter says there has been a spike in evictions, though not nearly as large a spike as this survey found.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “A third of workers have already taken a financial hit from the coronavirus pandemic, a poll showed tonight…Shockingly, 11% say they have been evicted from their homes – despite the temporary ban on rental evictions.”
extra_title: How many people have been evicted as a result of coronavirus?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Private renting is making millions of people ill.
extra_title: Quarter of private renters experience sickness over housing worries—but we don’t know if private renting is the cause
rating_alternateName:
A survey found almost a quarter of private renters agree that housing worries have made them ill in the past year. 
This doesn’t mean the sickness was specifically caused by renting privately as opposed to any other type of housing situation.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Private renting is making millions of people ill with almost half of England’s 8.5 million renters experiencing stress or anxiety and a quarter made physically sick as a result of their housing, campaigners have said.”
extra_title: Quarter of private renters experience sickness over housing worries—but we don’t know if private renting is the cause
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Since the mid-1990s house prices have gone up nearly three times.
extra_title: How much more difficult is it to buy a home?
rating_alternateName: Correct. From 1996 to 2018, the average UK house price increased by around 300%.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Since the mid-1990s the incomes of people in their twenties have gone up by 20%.
extra_title: How much more difficult is it to buy a home?
rating_alternateName: Median weekly earnings for all employees aged 22-29 increased by 14% from 1997 to 2018 in real terms. If you don’t adjust for inflation—which is more appropriate when comparing to changes in house prices over the same period—the increase is 72%.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “I bought my first flat when I was 29... since then, that was nearly 30 years ago, the incomes of people in their twenties has gone up by about 20%. House prices have gone up by nearly three times.”
extra_title: How much more difficult is it to buy a home?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are more homeless UK citizens than the entire population of Iceland.
extra_title: The estimated number of homeless people in Britain is broadly comparable to the population of Iceland
rating_alternateName: We don’t have definitive numbers but these figures are broadly comparable. The charity Shelter calculated that an estimated 320,000 people in Great Britain were homeless at the start of 2018. We don’t know how many are UK citizens. The population of Iceland at the end of 2018 was around 360,000.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Less than 29,000 homes for social rent were built under Labour in Scotland.
extra_title: The state of social renting in Scotland
rating_alternateName: Around that many homes for social rent (and funded by the government) were built between 2000/01 to 2006/07. But the data doesn’t include those homes for social rent that didn’t receive any government funding.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Six council homes were built under Labour in Scotland.
extra_title: The state of social renting in Scotland
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. This reflects a single year under the Labour-Lib Dem coalition in Scotland. Almost all social housing new-builds (several thousand each year) were started by housing associations during that time.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The SNP has delivered 52,600 homes for social rent.
extra_title: The state of social renting in Scotland
rating_alternateName: This is how many were completed between 2007/08 and 2017/18. This figure isn’t complete, as it doesn’t include homes for social rent that weren’t partially funded by the government.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The SNP has delivered 9,799 council homes.
extra_title: The state of social renting in Scotland
rating_alternateName: Correct. This doesn’t include homes completed by councils without any government funding.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Labour built 61,000 homes for social rent in Scotland.
extra_title: The state of social renting in Scotland
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. 37,000 new-build social homes were started under eight years of Labour-Lib Dem coalition government in Scotland.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Scotland’s youth unemployment rate fell by 0.3 percentage points over the last year.
extra_title: Scottish government uses non-official data on youth unemployment
rating_alternateName: This is based on experimental data so isn’t a “national statistic”. The most reliable data shows that youth unemployment in Scotland increased by 0.8 percentage points (from 8.9% to 9.8%) in the year to July 2019, compared to the year before.

claimReview_claimReviewed: One in six people in the US get food poisoning each year and one in 66 people in the UK get food poisoning each year.
extra_title: You can’t really compare rates of food poisoning between the US and UK
rating_alternateName: These estimates are both correct based on government figures, but they’re not      comparable due to differences in methodology and how the data was collected.

claimReview_claimReviewed: US food standards allow for rat hairs in paprika.
extra_title: You can’t really compare rates of food poisoning between the US and UK
rating_alternateName: US food standards set limits above zero for rat hair in paprika, beyond which enforcement action is mandatory.

claimReview_claimReviewed: US food standards allow for rat droppings in ginger.
extra_title: You can’t really compare rates of food poisoning between the US and UK
rating_alternateName: US food standards set limits above zero for rat droppings in ginger, beyond which enforcement action is mandatory.

claimReview_claimReviewed: US food standards allow for insect fragments in peanut butter.
extra_title: You can’t really compare rates of food poisoning between the US and UK
rating_alternateName: US food standards set limits above zero for insect fragments in peanut butter, beyond which enforcement action is mandatory.

claimReview_claimReviewed: US food standards allow for maggots in orange juice.
extra_title: You can’t really compare rates of food poisoning between the US and UK
rating_alternateName: US food standards set limits above zero for maggots in orange juice, beyond which enforcement action is mandatory.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “No wonder 1 in 6 in the US get food poisoning each year but only 1 in 66 in the UK.
extra_title: You can’t really compare rates of food poisoning between the US and UK
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Scotland has the highest taxes anywhere in Europe.
extra_title: Scotland doesn’t have the highest taxes in Europe
rating_alternateName: Incorrect, a number of European countries have higher income tax rates than Scotland.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “They (Scotland) have the highest taxes anywhere in Europe”
extra_title: Scotland doesn’t have the highest taxes in Europe
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A report suggests an independent Scotland would have to make public expenditure reductions.
extra_title: Would an independent Scotland have to keep the pound and cut public spending?
rating_alternateName: The report, commissioned by the Scottish National Party, actually says that public spending could continue to grow. This does depend on sufficient growth in the economy after independence.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A report suggests an independent Scotland would have to keep the pound.
extra_title: Would an independent Scotland have to keep the pound and cut public spending?
rating_alternateName: A report commissioned by the Scottish National Party recommends that an independent Scotland' should keep "the pound sterling for a possibly extended transition period”, although it does not rule out Scotland moving to its own currency in the longer term.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “But the report suggested Scotland would have to make public expenditure reductions. And also keep the pound. That was a line I read.”
extra_title: Would an independent Scotland have to keep the pound and cut public spending?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Spending on NHS Scotland has gone up by £4 billion to £13 billion.
extra_title: NHS Scotland: how much is being spent?
rating_alternateName: This is the planned increase in day-to-day spending on health in Scotland between 2006/07 and 2018/19. It doesn’t account for inflation though, once that is added the increase is £2 billion.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We have regularly increased investment in the Health Service since the Scottish Government came to power. Investment in the Health Service has gone up £4 billion to £13 billion.”
extra_title: NHS Scotland: how much is being spent?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Scotland gets 20% more per head because of money that comes from England under the Barnett formula.
extra_title: Scotland spends 20% more per head on public services than England
rating_alternateName: It’s correct that spending on public services in Scotland is 20% higher per head than in England. But this money comes from the block grant from the UK Treasury, rather than from England specifically. An increasing proportion of the Scottish government’s budget also comes from taxes it raises.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “You’ve got 20% more per head because of the money that comes from England under the Barnett formula.”
extra_title: Scotland spends 20% more per head on public services than England
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The deficit in Scotland is three times that of the UK as a whole.
extra_title: How big is Scotland’s deficit compared to the UK as a whole?
rating_alternateName: This is correct as a proportion of GDP, whether or not revenue from the North Sea is included.  In monetary terms, the UK deficit is larger.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Scottish onshore economy is as strong as the UK’s generally.
extra_title: Comparing Scottish and UK growth rates
rating_alternateName: There’s more than one way to look at this. The UK’s economy has been growing faster than Scotland’s recently, according to official estimates.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The strength of the Scottish onshore economy is equivalent to the position of the UK”
extra_title: Comparing Scottish and UK growth rates
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Crime is starting to rise.
extra_title: Is crime now starting to rise?
rating_alternateName: Crime is falling in England and Wales according to the Crime Survey. Police are recording more violent and sexual offences but these may not reflect genuine rises in the crimes.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "crime [is] starting to rise"
extra_title: Is crime now starting to rise?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: £350 million has been invested in projects that will fall on the wrong side of the cut-off deadline for the Renewables Obligation (RO) subsidy.
extra_title: Onshore wind: how much investment would be affected by early closure of the subsidy?
rating_alternateName: This much has been invested in some of the projects expected to qualify for the RO before the early closure was announced, according to an industry body. It’s not known how many of those projects will miss out on funding due to the early closure.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We have had estimates from the independent renewable energy group to say that the projects that have fallen just the other side of this cut-off deadline that the Government have imposed have costs in the region of £350 million.”
extra_title: Onshore wind: how much investment would be affected by early closure of the subsidy?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Wind generates about 10% of the UK's power
extra_title: How much of our energy comes from wind? MPs disagree
rating_alternateName: That's right—it generated 10% of the UK's electricity in 2014/15, although the amount varied within the year.

claimReview_claimReviewed: At the windiest times onshore wind turbines generate 7% of the UK's electricity.
extra_title: How much of our energy comes from wind? MPs disagree
rating_alternateName: That was right in the first quarter of 2015.

claimReview_claimReviewed: At the time of the Energy Bill’s second reading debate, 1% of the UK’s electricity was being generated by wind.
extra_title: How much of our energy comes from wind? MPs disagree
rating_alternateName: That's right.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“Before the debate today, I checked and discovered that 1% of our power is currently being generated from wind, 30% from coal and 42% from gas.”
John Redwood MP
“I would simply say that when we talk about this, whatever the personal positions that may come into it, we should not try to introduce personal facts, because some of the things said today are simply untrue. The figure for the contribution of UK wind to our electricity mix during the past 24 hours is 5%, not 1%.”
extra_title: How much of our energy comes from wind? MPs disagree
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“[John Redwood MP] has pointed out that now onshore wind generates 1% of generating capacity. At most, when the wind is blowing, it is 7% or 8%.”
Christopher Pincher MP
“The hon. Gentleman is wrong about the figures. Wind generates about 10% of our power.”
extra_title: How much of our energy comes from wind? MPs disagree
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government's impact assessment showed that we would be £100 million worse off because of the early closure of the Renewables Obligation.
extra_title: Would early closure of the Renewables Obligation to onshore wind cost £100 million?
rating_alternateName: The government's best estimate is that the net present value of the early closure is about £160 million, a positive figure. The £100 million worse off estimate comes from making different assumptions about how the UK would generate electricity.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Does she acknowledge that, using the alternative methodology in the impact assessment, the net present value of deciding to close the RO early turned out to be minus £100 million? That means that we are £100 million worse off as a result of her taking that decision, instead of allowing the RO to continue."
extra_title: Would early closure of the Renewables Obligation to onshore wind cost £100 million?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Extending the grace period for the proposed early closure of the Renewables Obligation to onshore wind to include projects with planning applications in place, could mean funding being given to a further 7.1 gigawatts of projects.
extra_title: The proposed Renewables Obligation cut off: how much onshore wind capacity loses out?
rating_alternateName: Only 0.2 of the 7.1 gigawatts would be expected to qualify for the funding in the government's best estimate.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "… Lord Wallace, also raised the question of amending the grace period criteria to either allow all projects that had applied for planning permission access to the grace period or to consider extending the cut-off date to 8 October… Based on the department's analysis, allowing all projects with only a planning application in place could mean that anything up to 7.1 gigawatts could accredit under the renewables obligation. This figure represents all projects that had submitted an application but not yet received planning permission as at 18 June."
extra_title: The proposed Renewables Obligation cut off: how much onshore wind capacity loses out?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Changes in government energy policy since 2015 may have added £120 a year to household bills.
extra_title: Renewable subsidy cuts might raise bills in the long term, but we don’t know by how much
rating_alternateName: The confidence of energy investors has been shaken, according to the Energy and Climate Change Committee. If so this could raise household bills in the long term. But the specific £120 figure isn’t particularly credible.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Changes in government energy policy since the last election have chased off investors and may have added £120 a year to household bills, according to a parliamentary report.”
extra_title: Renewable subsidy cuts might raise bills in the long term, but we don’t know by how much
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: We are concerned that the Government appears to be considering only short-term costs to consumers when making energy policy decisions. Increasing policy uncertainty leads to increased risk premiums, which will result in consumers paying more in the long-run.
extra_title: Renewable subsidy cuts might raise bills in the long term, but we don’t know by how much
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: We accept that the calculation of the £3.14bn cost above is a somewhat simplistic analysis based on arguably anecdotal evidence from one investor exploring an overseas market.
extra_title: Renewable subsidy cuts might raise bills in the long term, but we don’t know by how much
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Closing the Renewables Obligation to onshore wind a year early could threaten 19,000 jobs supported by the industry.
extra_title: How many jobs could be lost in onshore wind?
rating_alternateName: There were about 11,000 people directly employed by onshore wind and 8,000 in 'supply chain' roles in 2013, according to government estimates. It's uncertain how many people will see their employment threatened by the closure of the Renewables Obligation

claimReview_claimReviewed: "These changes to the financial support for onshore wind threaten the future of 19,000 jobs supported by that sector."
extra_title: How many jobs could be lost in onshore wind?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Greenhouse gas emissions fell by 15% between 2010 and 2014, one of the biggest reductions in a single parliament.
extra_title: UK carbon emissions are falling
rating_alternateName: That’s right.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Greenhouse gas emissions fell by 8% in 2014, the largest fall in a single year.
extra_title: UK carbon emissions are falling
rating_alternateName: That’s right for carbon dioxide emissions. Looking at all greenhouse gases, the reduction was slightly higher in 2009.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Between 2010 and 2014 the UK’s greenhouse gas emissions fell by 15%, one of the biggest reductions in a single parliament. Indeed, in 2014 we saw a reduction of 8%, the largest reduction measured in a single year."
extra_title: UK carbon emissions are falling
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: While some EU member states' population are shrinking, forecast put the UK's population at 70 million in the next decades. The UK is predicted to be the most populous country in the EU by 2050. Net migration into the UK is over 300,000 a year.
extra_title: Population, immigration, and EU renegotiation
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Unlike some other member states, Britain's population is already expanding. Our population is set to reach over 70 million in the next decades and we are forecast to become the most populous country in the EU by 2050. At the same time, our net migration is running at over 300,000 a year. That is not sustainable."
extra_title: Population, immigration, and EU renegotiation
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The EU referendum was “advisory” only.
extra_title: Was the EU referendum “advisory”?
rating_alternateName: The referendum wasn’t legally binding, but there’s plenty of scope for argument about whether politicians should feel obliged to implement the result anyway.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "The [EU] referendum was an advisory referendum”
extra_title: Was the EU referendum “advisory”?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “This was not an advisory referendum”
extra_title: Was the EU referendum “advisory”?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: a referendum on any topic can only be advisory for the lawmakers in Parliament”
extra_title: Was the EU referendum “advisory”?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The EU budgeted up to €3.9 billion in 2014 for spending that could be used to promote itself.
extra_title: How much does the EU spend on promoting itself?
rating_alternateName: The EU did spend money on promoting itself, and some EU publications certainly appear biased. But we can't put a precise figure on "propaganda" spending.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "EU 'spends £500m a year promoting itself'"
extra_title: How much does the EU spend on promoting itself?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "The EU spent €664 million (£536m) directly on publicity and communication spending in 2014. More widely, the EU committed up to €3.9 billion (£3.1bn) to budgets that contained provisions for EU promotional spending and 'corporate communication of the political priorities of the Union'"
extra_title: How much does the EU spend on promoting itself?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The EU budget will be up 6.9% in 2016, throwing off the Prime Minister's promise to have secured a 3% cut.
extra_title: The EU budget has its limits
rating_alternateName: EU budget spending commitments will be lower in 2016 than in 2015, and the 3% cut referred to by the Prime Minister was to spending limits over seven years, not spending in any particular year.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "EU budget: up! -3% he promised, he got +6.9%"
extra_title: The EU budget has its limits
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Indoor and outdoor air pollution claim at least 40,000 UK lives a year.
extra_title: How to interpret today's reports about air pollution
rating_alternateName: Estimates suggest that every year, the equivalent of 40,000 deaths in the UK are attributable to exposure to outdoor air pollution. Adding deaths attributable to indoor air pollution is thought to increase this figure, but it’s not known exactly by how much. This doesn’t mean that this number of people die prematurely every year because of air pollution, as it’s not the sole cause of deaths.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Indoor and outdoor air pollution ‘claiming at least 40000 UK lives a year’”
extra_title: How to interpret today's reports about air pollution
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The danger was revealed in a 106-page report by the Royal College of Physicians and the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health, which warns around 40,000 people in Britain die early each year because of outdoor air pollution.”
extra_title: How to interpret today's reports about air pollution
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Households are £900 worse off due to increased energy bills since 2010.
extra_title: Energy bills under the Conservatives
rating_alternateName: That's adding up the increase in average electricity and gas bills in each of the six years from 2010 to 2016 (adjusting for inflation) if energy use stayed the same over this time. It hasn't. The Committee on Climate Change has said that household bills in 2016 were lower than they were in 2008, due to reductions in energy use.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Over and over they’ve promised to get bills down but under them households are almost £900 worse off due to increase[d] energy bills since 2010.”
extra_title: Energy bills under the Conservatives
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Migration to the UK has dropped following the EU referendum.
extra_title: Too soon to say if EU referendum has led to genuine falls in immigration
rating_alternateName: Estimates including three months after the referendum suggest net migration has fallen since the previous year, although the change isn’t statistically significant. It’s too soon to say what effect the result has had on immigration.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Net migration to the UK has fallen by 49,000 to 273,000.
extra_title: Too soon to say if EU referendum has led to genuine falls in immigration
rating_alternateName: Estimates show this for the 12 months leading to September 2016. The changes aren’t statistically significant so we can’t say for sure, but may well be showing a genuine fall.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Net migration to UK falls to 273,000”
extra_title: Too soon to say if EU referendum has led to genuine falls in immigration
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “THE BREXIT EFFECT? Migration to the UK has DROPPED in the quarter after Britain voted to leave the European Union – to the lowest level in two years”
extra_title: Too soon to say if EU referendum has led to genuine falls in immigration
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Net migration to UK falls by 49,000 after Brexit vote”
extra_title: Too soon to say if EU referendum has led to genuine falls in immigration
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Pensioners are getting £1,250 more a year than they did when the Conservatives entered government.
extra_title: £1,250 more a year for pensioners
rating_alternateName: Pensioners who receive the full basic state pension in 2017/18 are getting £1,250 more in cash per year than those receiving it in 2010/11. However, in real terms the increase is only £558.82 extra per year, and only for pensioners receiving the full basic state pension.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “£1,250 more a year for pensioners. That’s a record we can be proud of.”
extra_title: £1,250 more a year for pensioners
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: More under-18s are being prosecuted for selling cannabis while the number of those aged 18 or over prosecuted has fallen.
extra_title: Cannabis kids: are more under-18s being prosecuted for supplying the drug?
rating_alternateName: Correct, in England and Wales. The number of 10-17 year-olds prosecuted between 2012/13 and 2016/17 increased, while the number of adults fell. Despite this many more adults are still being prosecuted overall.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Police catch 11 year-olds being used to sell drugs.
extra_title: Cannabis kids: are more under-18s being prosecuted for supplying the drug?
rating_alternateName: We’ve not seen the evidence for this, though other data on the number of young people prosecuted for drug offences suggests it’s possible.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Police catch 11‑year‑olds being used to sell drugs… More under-18s are being prosecuted for selling the drug [cannabis] even though the number of adult dealers taken to court is falling, a report has shown.”
extra_title: Cannabis kids: are more under-18s being prosecuted for supplying the drug?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Upskirting is not illegal because there is no specific crime covering the act.
extra_title: Upskirting: what’s the legal situation?
rating_alternateName: Upskirting offenders have been prosecuted under existing laws but there is criticism these don’t go far enough. A new bill would specify upskirting as a criminal act if passed.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “A Liberal Democrat MP has tabled a parliamentary bill that would make it a criminal offence to take a photo up a person’s skirt without their permission. Wera Hobhouse introduced the bill after discovering “upskirting” is not illegal because there is no specific crime covering the act.”
extra_title: Upskirting: what’s the legal situation?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Councils are making it a criminal offence to be poor.
extra_title: Is it a crime to be poor?
rating_alternateName: It’s considerably more complicated than that. Councils and police are often responding to perceived anti-social behaviour from rough sleepers rather than poverty or homelessness in itself, but to address it they do use powers that can, directly or indirectly, lead to a criminal penalty.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Councils are making it a criminal offence to be poor”
extra_title: Is it a crime to be poor?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Almost 300 people under 18 were flagged up last year under the Prevent Strategy because of concerns about the far right.
extra_title: Far right extremism: a growing problem?
rating_alternateName: This is correct according to figures from the National Police Chiefs' Council. 1 in 7 under-18s referred were on far-right grounds.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There has been an increase in far-right referrals under the Prevent strategy and in some areas of the country these are outnumbering other referrals.
extra_title: Far right extremism: a growing problem?
rating_alternateName: The Home Office told us that "in some areas of the country, far right referrals under the strategy account for more than other types", but the data isn't routinely published so we don't know the exact figures. Across the UK the number of far right referrals has increased, but it is lower as a proportion of all referrals.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The Prevent strategy is seeing a growth in far-right referrals. In some areas of the country, these Prevent referrals outnumber those about the other parts we are worried out.”
extra_title: Far right extremism: a growing problem?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “New figures show that almost 300 youths under 18 were flagged up last year under the government’s Prevent strategy amid concerns about the growing influence of the far right.”
extra_title: Far right extremism: a growing problem?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 250,000 pieces of extremist material have been taken down from the Internet since February 2010.
extra_title: Removing extremist online material
rating_alternateName: As of 21 December 2016, 249,091 pieces of extremist content have been taken down by the Counter Terrorism Internet Referral Unit, according to official figures.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “250,000 pieces of [extremist] material have been taken down since February 2010 from the Internet.”
extra_title: Removing extremist online material

claimReview_claimReviewed: The statistics which show that 7,810 more doctors are working in the NHS than a year ago include thousands of medical students who are not qualified.
extra_title: The number of doctors working for the NHS in England has increased in the past year
rating_alternateName: The statistics include some final year students who could register as a doctor earlier than normal, due to the Covid-19 pandemic. This doesn’t mean they are “not qualified”.

claimReview_claimReviewed: If you removed medical students from the NHS workforce statistics, the number of doctors has actually fallen.
extra_title: The number of doctors working for the NHS in England has increased in the past year
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The number of doctors working for the NHS in England has increased if these final year students are excluded, although to a lesser extent.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Boris Johnson & Matt Hancock just tweeted its [sic] “fantastic” news 7,810 more doctors are now working in our NHS than a year ago.“Both “forget” to mention that figure includes thousands of medical students not qualified doctors!”
extra_title: The number of doctors working for the NHS in England has increased in the past year
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: NHS staff do 11 hours a week unpaid overtime on average.
extra_title: Mirror claims NHS staff work 11 hours unpaid overtime on average but it’s probably more like two hours
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The NHS staff survey suggests NHS staff in England do around two hours unpaid overtime on average, but even this figure should be taken with a pinch of salt.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “NHS Heroes forced to work for free. Poll reveals staff do an average 11 hrs extra a week unpaid… & that was before virus.”
extra_title: Mirror claims NHS staff work 11 hours unpaid overtime on average but it’s probably more like two hours

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are a record 6,000 more doctors and a record 12,000 more nurses than a year ago
extra_title: Increase in doctors and nurses does not include Covid-19 returners
rating_alternateName: This is correct, according to workforce statistics published by NHS Digital for March 2020. It does not include returners or trainees who joined the workforce during the Covid-19 pandemic.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“Good news on the NHS just out:
Record doctors: 6,000 more than a year ago
Record nurses: 12,000 more than a year ago
Well on our way to delivering 50,000 more nurses by end of the Parliament.
extra_title: Increase in doctors and nurses does not include Covid-19 returners
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: We put up nurse pay last month.
extra_title: Nurse pay up over the past few years but down on 2010
rating_alternateName: Correct. In 2018 the government and the NHS staff council agreed a three year pay deal which saw pay for nurses increase annually in April between 2018/19 and 2020/21.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Last year some nurses starting their career got a pay rise of over 15%.
extra_title: Nurse pay up over the past few years but down on 2010
rating_alternateName: We don’t know exactly what Mr Hancock is referring to here but it doesn’t seem right. Nurses towards the lower end of the pay scale may have seen a cash terms salary increase of 3% to 12% between 2019/20 and 2020/21. These figures are lower when you factor inflation in.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We put up nurses’ pay last month, and in fact last year we had the fastest rise, the biggest rise in pay—especially for nurses when they are starting their career and the lowest paid nurses, who got a pay rise, very significant, of over 15%. So there has been a significant pay rise for nurses.”
extra_title: Nurse pay up over the past few years but down on 2010
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Royal College of Nursing (RCN) has told nurses not to use the term “ladies” or “lady.”
extra_title: The Royal College of Nursing hasn’t told nurses to call women by gender-neutral terms
rating_alternateName: The RCN internal style guide recommended using “women” or “woman” instead of “ladies” or “lady” in written documentation.  This was not guidance to nurses on how to speak to patients.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Nurses have been told not to call female patients “ladies”  and to use gender-neutral language in political correctness gone mad.”
extra_title: The Royal College of Nursing hasn’t told nurses to call women by gender-neutral terms

claimReview_claimReviewed: “…gendered terms like “chairman” are banned – as is “lady”.”
extra_title: The Royal College of Nursing hasn’t told nurses to call women by gender-neutral terms
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK is the only country in the EU whose health service is heavily dependent on foreign clinical staff.
extra_title: UK has one of the highest levels of foreign-born doctors and nurses in the EU
rating_alternateName: The UK has one of the highest levels of foreign-born doctors and nurses in the EU, but it’s not the highest.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We are the only country in the EU whose health service is heavily dependent on foreign clinical staff: Germany: 7% UK: 28%+”
extra_title: UK has one of the highest levels of foreign-born doctors and nurses in the EU

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of school places in the country has expanded by 800,000 since 2010.

rating_alternateName: Correct, they've increased by around 825,000 in primary and secondary schools in England since 2010.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "We’ve expanded the number of school places in the country by over 800,000 since 2010 ".
extra_title: 825,000 more English school places since 2010

claimReview_claimReviewed: 1,620 schools, most rated outstanding, haven’t been inspected for six years or more. 290 haven’t been inspected for more than a decade.
extra_title: Ofsted hasn’t inspected 300 schools for a decade or more
rating_alternateName: Correct. 1,620 state schools in England, most of which were rated outstanding in their last inspection, have not been inspected for six years or more. Of these, 296 have not been inspected for between ten and eleven years.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Last year, 91% of school places created were in good or outstanding schools.
extra_title: Ofsted hasn’t inspected 300 schools for a decade or more
rating_alternateName: Correct. Between 2015/16 and 2016/17, 91% of new primary and secondary school places were created in schools that were last rated good or outstanding.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “A National Audit Office report found 1,620 schools, mostly outstanding, had not been inspected for six years or more, and 290 for a decade or more.”

claimReview_claimReviewed: Hundreds of thousands of children are in overcrowded classrooms.
extra_title: Primary class sizes in England and Wales
rating_alternateName: Hundreds of thousands of children were in classes of more than 30 last year. That’s been true for at least the last decade, although it’s become more common to have large primary school classes recently.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of infants in large classes in Wales has increased by 18% over the last three years.
extra_title: Primary class sizes in England and Wales
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 40,000 primary age children were taught in classes of 36 or more in England in 2016.
extra_title: Primary class sizes in England and Wales
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Seven years of Tory failure and broken promises have left our schools in a terrible state. Hundreds of thousands of our children are paying the price, crammed into classrooms like sardines.”

claimReview_claimReviewed: “This is a massive own goal from Labour. In Wales, where they administer schools with the Lib Dems, the numbers of infants in large classes has risen by 18 per cent in just 3 years.”

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are 1.8 million more children in good or outstanding schools.
extra_title: 1.8m more pupils in good or outstanding schools
rating_alternateName: Correct. 1.8 million more pupils were in good or outstanding schools in 2016 than in 2010. This progress is partly due to Ofsted's changing inspection practice.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “1.8 million more children in good or outstanding schools.”
extra_title: 1.8m more pupils in good or outstanding schools

claimReview_claimReviewed: Class sizes are soaring under the Conservatives.
extra_title: Class sizes under the Conservatives
rating_alternateName: The average class size in English state primary schools has been increasing. It rose from 26.4 pupils in 2010 to 27.1 in 2016. In secondary schools, average class sizes have dropped from 20.5 to 20.4 in the same period.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We have a crisis in school places and class sizes soaring thanks to [Theresa May’s] government.”
extra_title: Class sizes under the Conservatives

claimReview_claimReviewed: Spending on schools is being cut.
extra_title: School spending: up or down?
rating_alternateName: Spending per pupil is set to fall in real terms, by 8%, according to the Institute for Fiscal Studies.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The schools budget has been increased over the past few years.
extra_title: School spending: up or down?
rating_alternateName: The cash amount has risen, but that doesn’t take into account inflation or rising pupil numbers.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “[Nicky Morgan] wrote me a letter just on Saturday saying that the school budget is going to be protected in real terms—which isn’t true. The Institute of Fiscal Studies says 8% cut.”
extra_title: School spending: up or down?

claimReview_claimReviewed: “I’m afraid I just don’t recognise that picture. The schools budget is the highest it’s ever been this year at £40 billion. It has gone up by £4 billion since 2011/12”.
extra_title: School spending: up or down?

claimReview_claimReviewed: Disadvantaged pupil attainment has risen, including among poor pupils from black, Asian and minority ethnic communities.
extra_title: Is the performance of disadvantaged pupils improving?
rating_alternateName: Broadly yes, but there's not such a clear trend for the attainment gap.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Disadvantaged pupil attainment has risen, including among poor pupils from black, Asian and minority ethnic communities."
extra_title: Is the performance of disadvantaged pupils improving?

claimReview_claimReviewed: Three in four academy chains contain secondary schools which could be seen as 'coasting'  under the government's definition.
extra_title: Coasting schools: three strikes and you're out
rating_alternateName: It's impossible to know yet how many schools will be labelled 'coasting', as it depends on performance in 2015 and 2016.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Three quarters of academy chains contain school below 'coasting' definition, research finds"
extra_title: Coasting schools: three strikes and you're out
