claimReview_claimReviewed: 40% of fines for pupil absence go unpaid.
extra_title: How many truanting fines go unpaid by parents?
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. About 20% of fines went unpaid in England in 2012/13. 63% were paid within the maximum time limit, but some of the remainder were withdrawn rather than unpaid.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Unemployment in the West Midlands Combined Authority has risen by 25% in a year.
extra_title: MP’s claim about rising unemployment in the West Midlands is wrong
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The unemployment rate in the area decreased from 6.7% to 5.9% between 2017/18 and 2018/19.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“Unemployment up 25% since last year.
“ONS Claimant count in the WMCA (West Midlands Combined Authority) Area.
extra_title: MP’s claim about rising unemployment in the West Midlands is wrong
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Nine of the ten most deprived council areas in this country have seen cuts that are almost three times the average of any other council.
extra_title: Have the most deprived councils seen the biggest reductions in funding?
rating_alternateName: The figures used in this analysis aren’t comparable over time in this way. But analysis by the National Audit Office shows that these ten councils have all had a greater proportion of their funding reduced than the percentage across all councils put together.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Official figures show that nine of the ten most deprived council areas in this country have seen cuts that are almost three times the average of any other council.”
extra_title: Have the most deprived councils seen the biggest reductions in funding?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The roads in north Wales are better than in Buckinghamshire.
extra_title: England v Wales: how bad are the roads?
rating_alternateName: In Buckinghamshire, 4% of A roads, and 5% of B and C roads are in poor condition. In Gwynedd in North Wales, 11% of A, B and C roads are in poor condition. We don’t know if these figures are directly comparable.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “[The roads in north Wales are] much better than in Buckinghamshire... the truth is, our road repairs have been very, very bad and it is deteriorating.”
extra_title: England v Wales: how bad are the roads?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: North Wales doesn’t get its fair share of infrastructure spending compared to the rest of the UK.
extra_title: Infrastructure spending: does North Wales get its fair share?
rating_alternateName: It’s not possible to say from available data. Specifying who benefits from infrastructure projects is often neither fair nor possible to do.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “You're not getting what you deserve in infrastructure, not just in rail and transport. You in North Wales do not get your fair share, neither does my area.”
extra_title: Infrastructure spending: does North Wales get its fair share?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK has nine out of the 10 poorest regions in northern Europe.
extra_title: Does the UK have the poorest regions in northern Europe?
rating_alternateName: Incorrect, this is out of date. In 2016, the UK had six of the 10 regions with the lowest GDP per person, from a group of nearby countries. This isn’t a good measure of how rich or poor people in those regions are.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The UK has nine out of the 10 poorest regions in northern Europe (seven of them in England).”
extra_title: Does the UK have the poorest regions in northern Europe?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Wages are lower today than they were ten years ago.
extra_title: Have wages fallen in the past ten years?
rating_alternateName: Yes, the official headline measure of median weekly wages for full time workers is lower than ten years ago.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Yet she can’t explain why people’s wages are lower today than they were ten years ago...”
extra_title: Have wages fallen in the past ten years?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Supermarket prices for bacon have gone up, partly because of the UK’s vote to leave the EU.
extra_title: What have bacon butties got to do with Brexit?
rating_alternateName: This is incorrect. Wholesale prices for bacon products have risen in the past few months, partly due to a fall in the exchange rate after the UK voted to leave the EU. But the price paid in shops has fallen this year.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Some shop suppliers have raised their prices by up to 38%, according to purchasing company Beacon, causing price increases at the till of up to 19%, as supermarkets pass the cost on to consumers.”
extra_title: What have bacon butties got to do with Brexit?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The average farmer made £28,300 in subsidies last year and £2,100 from agriculture. The average cereal farmer lost £9,500 on agriculture.
extra_title: Do farmers make more from subsidies than agriculture?
rating_alternateName: The basic point is correct. Last year farmers did make more from subsidies on average than from agriculture. Whether or not the exact figures are correct depends on whether you look at subsidies or all payments that farmers receive from government schemes.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Last year the average farm made £2,100 from agriculture and £28,300 from subsidies. The typical cereal farmer actually lost £9,500 by farming cereals.”
extra_title: Do farmers make more from subsidies than agriculture?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The food and drinks industry say they face significant disruption and economic damage if EU nationals continue to leave the UK.
extra_title: The food and drinks industry after the EU referendum
rating_alternateName: The UK's Food and Drink Federation has warned of this disruption, although we don’t know yet how many EU nationals in the industry will end up leaving the UK.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Today we hear stark warnings from the food and drink industry that they face significant disruption and economic damage if European nationals continue to leave.”
extra_title: The food and drinks industry after the EU referendum
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK paid out £674 million in health costs to European countries, but received only £49 million in return. Addressing this could “transform the financial situation of the NHS”.
extra_title: How much does the UK recover in health costs from the EU?
rating_alternateName: The figures are broadly correct for 2015, although addressing this situation would in itself only have a marginal impact on the financial situation of the NHS.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Londoners are set to get six times more funding for transport infrastructure per head than the North East and North West regions, and eight times that on offer in Yorkshire & the Humber.
extra_title: Regional investment in transport: we don’t know exactly who gets what
rating_alternateName: These estimates are correct, using rough information from a government list of planned infrastructure projects. That information isn’t complete, and the comparison ignores funding which isn’t allocated to specific regions. If general funding was included, the regional differences are likely to be smaller.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“The total cost of London's Crossrail between this financial year (2016-17) and 2020-21 will be £4.6bn – more than the £4.3bn going to all transport projects in the entire north over the same period. 
“The £1,900 spent on transport for every Londoner is more than six times the per head funding on offer in the North East (£300) and North West (£290). It's nearly eight times as the £250 per head on offer in Yorkshire & the Humber.
That actually looks generous compared to other regions, like the South West (£219) and East Midlands (£193).”
extra_title: Regional investment in transport: we don’t know exactly who gets what
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 68% of Wales’s exports go to the EU.
extra_title: Do two thirds of Welsh exports go to the EU?
rating_alternateName: Correct, although this is counting goods exports only.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “How can abandoning membership of the customs union that takes 68% of Wales’s exports ... cause anything other calamitous self-harm?”
extra_title: Do two thirds of Welsh exports go to the EU?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: At the moment, Scotland gets more money from the UK government than it sends back.
extra_title: Scotland's public finances
rating_alternateName: True in 2016, although it hasn’t always been the case.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Scotland’s public finances haven’t always benefited from being part of the UK.
extra_title: Scotland's public finances
rating_alternateName: Correct. Scotland’s was a net contributor to the rest of the UK in 2005/6, and for four years from 2007/8 until 2011/12.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Scotland at the moment is a net beneficiary of the fiscal union between England and Scotland. That hasn’t always been the case, but it is at the moment. However, Scotland would be a net contributor to the EU”
extra_title: Scotland's public finances
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Scotland will have to leave the EU whether or not it becomes independent.
extra_title: Could Scotland stay in the EU?
rating_alternateName: It’s very likely that Scotland would have to re-apply to join the EU on independence, although in theory it could stay in without a hiatus if all member countries agreed to write it into the EU treaties.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Scotland will be leaving the European Union. It will leave the European Union either as a member of the UK, or were it independent, it’s very clear from the Barroso document it would not be a member of the European Union.”
extra_title: Could Scotland stay in the EU?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: If part of the territory of a Member State would cease to be part of that state because it were to become a new independent state, the Treaties would no longer apply to that territory. In other words, a new independent state would, by the fact of its independence, become a third country with respect to the EU and the Treaties would no longer apply on its territory.
extra_title: Could Scotland stay in the EU?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: If the UK leaves the EU single market and relies only on its membership of the World Trade Organisation, there would be 80,000 jobs lost in Scotland.
extra_title: Scottish jobs after Brexit
rating_alternateName: The numbers aren’t certain, but a forecast for the Scottish government suggests that in 10 years there would be 80,000 fewer jobs in Scotland if the UK leaves the single market, compared to the number there would be if it stays in the EU. The report expects every scenario outside the EU to mean fewer jobs.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “But the fact is, if it is a hard Brexit, if we go out with the single market with no provisions in place for the trade, then we will lose jobs... However, the Scottish Parliament had a forecast produced that out with the single market, there would be 80,000 jobs lost in Scotland.”
extra_title: Scottish jobs after Brexit
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The American economy is growing fast.
extra_title: Comparing economic growth across the world
rating_alternateName: US GDP grew 2.3% in real terms in 2017, according to the IMF. That’s faster than the UK but slower than the EU. The IMF expects US growth to slow slightly in the coming years.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Far East economy is “going gangbusters”.
extra_title: Comparing economic growth across the world
rating_alternateName: The GDP of East Asia grew by 5.6% in real terms in 2017 and Southeast Asia grew by 5.3%, according to the IMF. It forecasts growth in East Asia to slow slightly in coming years.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The reason that I think we should leave the customs union is because I want to have essentially free trade with Europe but also free trade with the rest of the world, with America which is growing fast, with the Far East which is going gangbusters at the moment”
extra_title: Comparing economic growth across the world
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Labour pledged to scrap all controls on immigration
extra_title: Labour didn’t vote to scrap all immigration controls
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. Labour passed a motion at its party conference to extend free movement and ruling out certain forms of immigration systems. This doesn’t mean scrapping all immigration controls.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Labour to scrap all controls on immigration”
extra_title: Labour didn’t vote to scrap all immigration controls
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Theresa May knew about the Windrush issue in 2014  - there was a report in 2014 which reported on these stories.
extra_title: What was known about Windrush in 2014?
rating_alternateName: The report included stories of individuals of the Windrush generation facing difficulties proving their immigration status. We don’t know whether Theresa May saw the report first-hand, though the Home Office was made aware of the findings.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Theresa May knew [about the Windrush issue] in 2014  - there was a Legal Action Group report in 2014 which reported on all these stories."
extra_title: What was known about Windrush in 2014?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A majority of voters say violence against MPs is “worth it” to get their way in Brexit.
extra_title: Poll about support for violence against MPs is flawed
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. A majority said the “risk of violence” is “a price worth paying”. There’s a big distinction between the two, and survey it’s based on suffers from a number of flaws.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Violence against MPs “worth it” to get way in Brexit, say majority of voters in poll”
extra_title: Poll about support for violence against MPs is flawed

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Most voters think risk of violence against MPs is 'price worth paying' over Brexit”
extra_title: Poll about support for violence against MPs is flawed

claimReview_claimReviewed: Knife crime has soared to a record high.
extra_title: Knife crime at eight-year high
rating_alternateName: Correct, for England and Wales, though comparable data only goes back to 2011 and there are some data issues.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Knife murders fell 14% due to increased stop and search operations in London.
extra_title: Knife crime at eight-year high
rating_alternateName: Homicides involving a knife are down, and stop and searches in London for offensive weapons are up but there’s no evidence to support the idea that one is causing the other.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“Knife crime has soared to a record high, figures revealed yesterday.
“One glimmer of hope was a 14 per cent fall in the number of knife murders – largely due to increased stop and search operations in London.
extra_title: Knife crime at eight-year high
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A British soldier was attacked by a Muslim gang that hates the armed forces.
extra_title: There’s no evidence that this man was attacked because he’s in the armed forces
rating_alternateName: A member of the armed forces was hit by a car outside a nightclub in West Yorkshire, sustaining serious injuries. The police and the judge sentencing his attacker have both said there is no evidence that the attack was politically motivated. The judge said Mr Adams-Mitchell was not the intended victim of the attack.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Violent crime is at record levels.
extra_title: Violent crime is not at record levels
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. Several reliable sources indicate that overall violent crime in England and Wales is far lower now than it was in the 1990s. Police figures show violent crimes at their highest recorded level, but these are unreliable.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Knife crime is at record levels.
extra_title: Violent crime is not at record levels
rating_alternateName: Police and hospital figures show knife crimes at or near their highest recorded levels. Knife crime is almost certainly rising at the moment, but no source is strong enough for us to be certain that it’s at record levels.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Nine in 10 major businesses in the UK have had cyber-attacks in the last year.
extra_title: How many major businesses have experienced a cyber-attack?
rating_alternateName: This figure refers to businesses reporting having experienced some form of information security breach in the last year. The survey it's based on isn't representative of the frequency of cyber-attacks in all large businesses across the UK.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "GCHQ themselves have recently said that nine out of 10 major businesses in the UK have been attacked over the course of the last year."
extra_title: How many major businesses have experienced a cyber-attack?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of deaths in police custody is at the highest level in five years.
extra_title: How many deaths occur in police custody?
rating_alternateName: There were 17 deaths in 2014/15, according to official figures; the highest in four years, rather than five.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Deaths in police custody at highest level for five years."
extra_title: How many deaths occur in police custody?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of police officer could be the lowest since the 1970s following funding cuts.
extra_title: Police numbers: back to the 1970s?
rating_alternateName: The cuts have yet to be announced and we don't know how they'd affect officer numbers. A cut of 14,000 officers would mean the lowest number since the 1970s.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Planned government spending cuts will see at least 22,000 police jobs being lost, leaving the public protected by the lowest numbers of officers since the 1970s, according to a private estimate circulating among police chiefs."
extra_title: Police numbers: back to the 1970s?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Only a tiny proportion of rapes ever reach trial.
extra_title: Reported rapes that reach trial
rating_alternateName: Around one in ten rapes or attempted rapes reported to police in England and Wales are brought to trial. Research from 2013 estimated that between one in twenty and one in thirty rape cases end up at trial.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Only a tiny proportion of women and indeed men who are raped in this country ever reaches trial in the first place. There is a huge problem of underreporting.”
extra_title: Reported rapes that reach trial
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A woman in her twenties will earn 95p for every pound that young men of their age earn.
extra_title: Age, motherhood and the gender pay gap
rating_alternateName: That’s what you’d expect on average. If you knew nothing about two people apart from the fact that one was a woman, one was a man, and both were working and in their twenties, you’d expect the woman to earn about 5% less than the man.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The gender pay gap increases after women become mothers.
extra_title: Age, motherhood and the gender pay gap
rating_alternateName: There’s evidence that the pay gap increases significantly after parents have children.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Women are getting ahead of men in terms of pay before they become mothers.
extra_title: Age, motherhood and the gender pay gap
rating_alternateName: We’ve not seen clear evidence that women are getting ahead on average, even though women and men are paid more equitably in their 20s than later in life.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If you’re a woman in your twenties you will earn 95p for every pound that young men of your age earn.”
extra_title: Age, motherhood and the gender pay gap
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: …there is no single measure that fully deals with the complex issue of the differences between men’s and women’s pay
extra_title: Age, motherhood and the gender pay gap
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “…women are going ahead of men before they have children and when they are concentrating on their careers, but what clearly is not happening is women are not maintaining their position ahead of men once they make different decisions about the priority of family life.”
extra_title: Age, motherhood and the gender pay gap
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The delays in cancer care waiting times are the longest since targets were first introduced.
extra_title: Cancer care waiting times
rating_alternateName: There are a number of cancer care waiting times. Targets for the proportion of patients being treated within 62 days of being urgently referred by a GP are being missed. In January 2017 the proportion meeting the target was the lowest since targets were set in 2009. The rest of the targets were all hit.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “And today, figures were released, for the first time, showing devastating delays in people waiting for cancer care, the longest delays for most people since the targets were first put there.”
extra_title: Cancer care waiting times
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: George Osborne promised to eliminate the deficit by 2015.
extra_title: Did George Osborne promise to eliminate the deficit by this year?
rating_alternateName: In 2010 he said that the government's aim was for the deficit to be eliminated by 2015. While an aim isn't a promise, the government's performance on the deficit has been worse than was aimed for.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Five years ago, the newly elected chancellor and the prime minister came to this house… we were promised, specifically by this chancellor, that by today, the deficit would be eliminated, and debt would be under control and falling dramatically. People put their trust in that commitment."
extra_title: Did George Osborne promise to eliminate the deficit by this year?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Childcare costs in England have risen up to seven times faster than wages.
extra_title: Have childcare costs risen up to seven times faster than wages?
rating_alternateName: This is roughly the case for parents of children under two in London from 2008 to 2016, according to research by the TUC. The exact changes are unclear. In England overall it is three to four times faster.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Childcare costs in England rise up to seven times faster than wages”
extra_title: Have childcare costs risen up to seven times faster than wages?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Parents are subsidising a new flagship "free" nursery scheme for three- and four-year-olds in England from their own pockets.
extra_title: Are parents paying for free nursery places?
rating_alternateName: 28% of childcare providers responding to a survey said that if they provided the new 30 hours of free childcare, there were additional costs on top for more hours, or other goods and services. We don’t know how representative this is of all childcare providers, and it’s based on a low response rate.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Parents are subsidising a new flagship "free" nursery scheme for three- and four-year-olds in England from their own pockets, a survey suggests.”
extra_title: Are parents paying for free nursery places?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The rise in deaths is the largest for almost fifty years, prompting concerns about a crisis in elderly care.
extra_title: What’s behind the rise in deaths?
rating_alternateName: Provisional data suggests the increase in deaths in England and Wales from 2014 to 2015 was the largest annual rise since 1968. The rate of death—the number of deaths per 1,000 population—is also thought to be up. The ONS told us the higher number of deaths was due to the flu.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Biggest annual rise in deaths for almost fifty years prompts warnings of crisis in elderly care”
extra_title: What’s behind the rise in deaths?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are 23,000 Syrian refugees coming to the UK.
extra_title: Two UK schemes have resettled 11,000 Syrian refugees
rating_alternateName: That’s a target for 2020, based on two government resettlement schemes. Of that target, 20,000 are specifically from the Syrian conflict. These schemes aren’t the only way for refugees to enter the UK.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK's Syrian refugee programme is slightly ahead of schedule.
extra_title: Two UK schemes have resettled 11,000 Syrian refugees
rating_alternateName: Roughly correct. Just over 10,000 refugees from the Syrian conflict have come to the UK via a government scheme from September 2015 to December 2017. The target for the scheme is 20,000 by May 2020. Individuals arriving before July 2017 had Humanitarian Protection, rather than refugee status.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We as a country are doing one of the biggest programmes we have ever done, 23,000 refugees coming to this country. We are slightly ahead of the schedule that David Cameron set out [...] There are 23,000 Syrian refugees coming to this country, on top of refugees from elsewhere.”
extra_title: Two UK schemes have resettled 11,000 Syrian refugees
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Only half the UN's appeal for Syrian aid was funded last year.
extra_title: Humanitarian aid to Syria in 2015
rating_alternateName: That's about right—in 2015 the appeal received $4 billion (56%) out of the $7.2 billion it wanted.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Nearly half of the aid sent to Syria came from the US and UK compared to 1% or less for other countries such as Saudi Arabia and Japan.
extra_title: Humanitarian aid to Syria in 2015
rating_alternateName: That was correct of one of the UN's funds. Taking the two main funds together the UK and US made up 38% of funding, and Japan gave just under 3%.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“We only managed to see half the UN appeal funded last year.”
Justine Greening, Secretary of State for International Development
“When you look down the list of countries that are stepping up to the plate, and the United Kingdom is the biggest donor after the United States, those two countries make up nearly half of the assistance this year for Syrian refugees. Saudi Arabia is giving something like 1%, Japan is giving 1%, Russia is giving 0.3%, France is giving 0.2%. It is a very patchy situation.”
extra_title: Humanitarian aid to Syria in 2015
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: MPs would need to approve British military action in Syria.
extra_title: MPs don't have to approve military action in Syria
rating_alternateName: Legally, the government doesn't need the permission of Parliament to use military force. But there is a convention that it will consult MPs before doing so, where possible, and abide by the outcome of their vote.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Britain is not taking part in the action in Syria because MPs have so far refused to authorise the extension of airstrikes in neighbouring Iraq."
extra_title: MPs don't have to approve military action in Syria
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "I need to take it to Parliament"
extra_title: MPs don't have to approve military action in Syria
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Conservative manifesto promised that per-pupil schools funding would be protected, and it’s now being cut.
extra_title: Schools funding: a manifesto breach?
rating_alternateName: Spending on English schools overall is increasing but per-pupil funding is set to fall in the next few years, once inflation is factored in. The Conservative manifesto promised to protect funding per pupil, but not necessarily in real terms.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government has protected the schools budget.
extra_title: Schools funding: a manifesto breach?
rating_alternateName: That was correct in the recent past, and in the near future in terms of the overall amount. But per-pupil funding once inflation is taken into account is set to fall over the next few years.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The manifesto on which [the PM] fought the last election promised that ‘under a future Conservative government, the amount of money following your child into school will be protected’... she was clearly elected on a pledge not to cut school funding and that’s exactly what is happening.”
extra_title: Schools funding: a manifesto breach?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We are seeing record levels of funding going into our schools. We have protected the schools budget.”
extra_title: Schools funding: a manifesto breach?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Under a future Conservative Government, the amount of money following your child into school will be protected. As the number of pupils increases, so will the amount of money in our schools. On current pupil number forecasts, there will be a real-terms increase in the schools budget in the next Parliament.
extra_title: Schools funding: a manifesto breach?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The National Audit Office said that schools face real term cuts of 8% by 2019/20.
extra_title: Schools will have less to spend per pupil by 2020
rating_alternateName: The National Audit Office said that although overall spending on schools will increase between 2014/15 and 2019/20, increasing pupil numbers and staff costs mean they will need to spend 8% less per pupil.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “A report by the National Audit Office has said schools face cuts of 8% in real terms by 2019/20.”
extra_title: Schools will have less to spend per pupil by 2020
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 97% of Labour activists back a "Remain alliance" election pact.
extra_title: Claim that 97% of Labour activists support remain alliance is flawed
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. This is based on a survey of supporters of a pro-remain Labour campaign group. It is not representative of all Labour activists.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “EXCLUSIVE: 97% of Labour activists back "Remain alliance" election pact”
extra_title: Claim that 97% of Labour activists support remain alliance is flawed
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: If the EU parliamentary election results happened at a general election under first past the post, the Brexit party would have a majority of over 240 seats.
extra_title: Would the Brexit party win a majority of 240 seats at a general election?
rating_alternateName: This is reasonable based on the best available estimates—but it’s very unlikely that these results would be replicated at a general election. EU election results can’t be used as a proxy for how people would vote in a general election.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “As you know the Brexit Party won the European elections by a very substantial margin… If the first past the post had been used, we would have a parliamentary majority of over 240 seats.”
extra_title: Would the Brexit party win a majority of 240 seats at a general election?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 58% of votes cast in the recent EU parliamentary elections were votes to leave, and 41.5% were votes to remain.
extra_title: What do the EU election results tell us about public support for leave and remain?
rating_alternateName: This assumes that all Labour voters supported leave, which is far from clear. It’s also not the case that all people voted for a party based on their Brexit policy.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 12% of the electorate voted for no deal in the 2019 EU parliamentary elections, not one third of the country.
extra_title: Did one third of voters support a no deal Brexit at the EU elections?
rating_alternateName: One third of votes cast were for parties that support a no deal Brexit. But as turnout was 37%, this amounts to 13% of eligible voters voting for a party that supports no deal. Not all people who voted for no deal-supporting parties necessarily prefer a no deal Brexit themselves, though.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “@BBCr4today asserted “at least a third of the country voted for a no deal Brexit”… This is simply NOT true. FACT 1/3 of the 37% of people voted for no deal. That’s about 12% of the electorate or rather 88% of people did NOT vote for no deal”
extra_title: Did one third of voters support a no deal Brexit at the EU elections?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 17.4 million people voted to leave and 16.1 million voted to remain in the EU referendum.
extra_title: How did different constituencies vote in the 2016 EU referendum?
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 406 constituencies voted to leave, 242 voted to remain in the EU referendum.
extra_title: How did different constituencies vote in the 2016 EU referendum?
rating_alternateName: Best estimates show it was probably about 410 to 240.

claimReview_claimReviewed: In the 2016 EU referendum, 148 Labour constituencies voted to leave, 84 to remain. 247 Conservative constituencies voted to leave, 80 to remain.
extra_title: How did different constituencies vote in the 2016 EU referendum?
rating_alternateName: Best estimates are that 249 Conservative constituencies probably voted to leave, and 81 to remain (based on the 2015 general election seat distribution). For Labour it was 148 for leave, and 84 for remain.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Nine regions voted to leave and three voted to remain in the EU referendum.
extra_title: How did different constituencies vote in the 2016 EU referendum?
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 160 MPs are for leave and 486 are for remain.
extra_title: How did different constituencies vote in the 2016 EU referendum?
rating_alternateName: That’s pretty close to survey results of all the MPs just before the 2016 referendum. There has since been a general election and some MPs could have changed their view.

claimReview_claimReviewed: By constituency 406 Leave | 242 Remain
extra_title: How did different constituencies vote in the 2016 EU referendum?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: By MP 160 Leave | 486 Remain
extra_title: How did different constituencies vote in the 2016 EU referendum?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The 2016 EU referendum was the largest democratic exercise in the UK’s history.
extra_title: The EU referendum wasn’t quite the largest democratic exercise in UK history
rating_alternateName: Not quite. More people voted in the 1992 general election. It also had a higher turnout rate, as did other elections in the 20th century.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The 17.4 million votes to leave the EU in 2016 was the largest mandate for anything in British political history.
extra_title: The EU referendum wasn’t quite the largest democratic exercise in UK history
rating_alternateName: No single electoral option has received more votes in UK history than the vote to leave the EU in 2016. But a handful of referendum options and political parties have received a higher percentage share of a national vote.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Who now represents the 17.4million Leave voters – the largest mandate for anything in British political history?”
extra_title: The EU referendum wasn’t quite the largest democratic exercise in UK history
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The referendum in 2016 was the biggest democratic exercise in our history”
extra_title: The EU referendum wasn’t quite the largest democratic exercise in UK history
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If you look back to what happened in the referendum, we saw the biggest democratic exercise in our history.”
extra_title: The EU referendum wasn’t quite the largest democratic exercise in UK history
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Labour are pushing for a divisive second referendum which rips up their manifesto pledge to respect the result of the largest democratic exercise in our nation’s history and would take us back to square one.”
extra_title: The EU referendum wasn’t quite the largest democratic exercise in UK history
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: You can sign the Revoke Article 50 petition repeatedly using the same email address.
extra_title: Is it possible to repeatedly sign a parliamentary petition using the same email address?
rating_alternateName: It’s possible to use the same email address twice but no more than that.

claimReview_claimReviewed: You can sign the Revoke Article 50 petition using any name you want.
extra_title: Is it possible to repeatedly sign a parliamentary petition using the same email address?
rating_alternateName: It is possible to sign using a false name.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Oh, this is going to be a fun afternoon. You can sign any name you want to the Revoke Article 50 petition and use the same email address repeatedly. Let the games begin!”
extra_title: Is it possible to repeatedly sign a parliamentary petition using the same email address?

claimReview_claimReviewed: 58% of coronavirus deaths in Scotland are from care facilities.
extra_title: It’s not true that 58% of Covid-19 deaths in Scotland were in care homes
rating_alternateName: This is not correct. The report from the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), which this figure comes from, says that in May 45% of Covid-19 deaths were in care homes.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 21% of coronavirus deaths in England are in care facilities.
extra_title: It’s not true that 58% of Covid-19 deaths in Scotland were in care homes
rating_alternateName: Correct up to May. This was reported by the ECDC based on figures from the Office for National Statistics.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 25% of coronavirus deaths in Wales are in care facilities.
extra_title: It’s not true that 58% of Covid-19 deaths in Scotland were in care homes
rating_alternateName: Correct up to May. This was reported by the ECDC based on figures from the Office for National Statistics.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 37% of coronavirus deaths in Germany are in care facilities.
extra_title: It’s not true that 58% of Covid-19 deaths in Scotland were in care homes
rating_alternateName: Correct up to May.This was reported by the ECDC.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 66% of coronavirus deaths in France are from care facilities.
extra_title: It’s not true that 58% of Covid-19 deaths in Scotland were in care homes
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The ECDC report says 66% of cases reported by long term care facilities were in nursing homes for the elderly. Around 50% of all deaths were in long term care facilities for all age groups.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 66% of coronavirus deaths in Spain are from care facilities.
extra_title: It’s not true that 58% of Covid-19 deaths in Scotland were in care homes
rating_alternateName: Correct up to May. This was reported by the ECDC.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 53% of coronavirus deaths in Sweden are in care facilities.
extra_title: It’s not true that 58% of Covid-19 deaths in Scotland were in care homes
rating_alternateName: This is not correct. The ECDC report says 53% of care homes in Stockholm county reported Covid-19 cases. 50% of all Covid-19 related deaths in Sweden amongst over-70s were in long term care facilities.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 51% of coronavirus deaths in Belgium are in care facilities.
extra_title: It’s not true that 58% of Covid-19 deaths in Scotland were in care homes
rating_alternateName: Correct up to May.This was reported by the ECDC.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 61% of coronavirus deaths in Norway are in care facilities.
extra_title: It’s not true that 58% of Covid-19 deaths in Scotland were in care homes
rating_alternateName: Correct up to May.This was reported by the ECDC.

claimReview_claimReviewed: At the SNP party conference, the SNP voted to increase the state pension in an independent Scotland to match the EU average.

rating_alternateName: The conference voted in favour of a resolution supporting the commissioning of a plan looking at how pension levels could be increased. It also mentioned that the OECD average should be set as a target.

claimReview_claimReviewed: At the annual party conference today, the SNP just voted to increase the state pension in an independent Scotland to match the EU average - £355 per week.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “For what it's worth, physical correction of children is in decline in almost every Western country, in Scotland and in the rest of the UK.”

claimReview_claimReviewed: 69% of the public support onshore wind, which is the most popular renewable energy technology.

rating_alternateName: This is based on a survey where 70% of respondents stated they'd be happy to have a wind farm built in their local area. However, a DECC survey showed 65% of respondents supported onshore wind, which was less popular than solar power, wave and tidal power and offshore wind.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "... Something like 69% of the public support onshore wind—it is the most popular of the renewable energy-generating supply technologies"
extra_title: What do Brits think about wind farms?

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK is 15th in the international educational league tables, behind Vietnam.
extra_title: The UK's international education ranking
rating_alternateName: In 2015, the UK ranked 15th in the world for the performance of 15 year olds in science, behind Vietnam in 8th place. But we’re not necessarily as far behind Vietnam as this might suggest.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We are 15th in the international educational league tables. We are behind Vietnam.”

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Scottish government’s budget has been cut dramatically since 2010/11.

rating_alternateName: It fell on any measure between 2010-11 and 2013-14. Since then it’s either flatlined, risen slightly, or returned to roughly the same value—it depends on what you include.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The budget in Scotland has been continually cut by Westminster.
extra_title: Has the Scottish Government budget increased or decreased since 2010?
rating_alternateName: It’s been cut, but not every year. It fell between 2010-11 and 2013-14 any way you look at it. Since then it’s risen or stayed the same, depending what you include.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The idea that saying there has been no interference from Westminster is a farce because our budget has been cut and it is continually cut by Westminster.”

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Department will never be able to measure whether Universal Credit actually leads to 200,000 more people in work, because it cannot isolate the effect of Universal Credit from other economic factors in increasing employment”
extra_title: 200,000 more people in work under Universal Credit? The government can’t know the answer
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There were 3,700 drug-related deaths in England and Wales last year.
extra_title: Are drug related deaths in the UK the highest in the EU?
rating_alternateName: Roughly correct, there were 3,756 registered in 2017. Around half of these will have happened in 2016 because of the time it takes to hold an inquest and then register the death.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There were nearly 1,000 drug-related deaths in Scotland last year.
extra_title: Are drug related deaths in the UK the highest in the EU?
rating_alternateName: Correct, there were 934 registered in 2017.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK has the highest death rate in the EU from drugs.
extra_title: Are drug related deaths in the UK the highest in the EU?
rating_alternateName: Estonia had the highest rate of drug-related deaths per million people aged 15 to 64 in the EU, based on research using data from 2015 and 2016. The UK placed joint-third alongside Ireland.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Scotland’s drug-related death rate is the highest in the EU.
extra_title: Are drug related deaths in the UK the highest in the EU?
rating_alternateName: Correct if you compare Scotland to a league table of EU sovereign countries. This is based on a comparison of the drug-related death rate per million people aged 15 to 64 in 2015 and 2016.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Scotland's drug-related death rate is the highest in the EU, what can be done to resolve this?”
extra_title: Are drug related deaths in the UK the highest in the EU?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The figures incidentally are nearly 1,000 drug-related deaths in Scotland last year, and 3,700 in England and Wales, and the UK is the highest death rate in the EU from drugs.”
extra_title: Are drug related deaths in the UK the highest in the EU?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are four million 17 year-olds that turn 18 before the November election.
extra_title: This image claiming there are four million 17 year-olds who’ll be able to vote in the election is not about the UK
rating_alternateName: Incorrect—there are only around 725,000 17 year-olds in the UK. The general election is set to be on 12 December.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“Did you know that 4 MILLION 17-year-olds turn 18 before the November election?
If you are 17 ½ you can register to vote NOW.
extra_title: This image claiming there are four million 17 year-olds who’ll be able to vote in the election is not about the UK
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The European Union makes two thirds of UK law.
extra_title: Is two thirds of UK law made by the EU?
rating_alternateName: That's about right if you count EU regulations as part of 'UK law'. The EU influence on UK-only laws is about 13%. But this counting exercise doesn't tell us very much.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The NHS had a deficit of over £800 million last year and is predicted to have a £2 billion deficit this year.
extra_title: Hospitals in the red: the size of the NHS provider deficit
rating_alternateName: This is correct for NHS providers. It stood at £830 million last year and it's expected to rise, with some forecasting £2 billion or more in 2015/16.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Migration is linked to 82% of population growth (between 2001 and 2016).
extra_title: Is 82% of population growth driven by migration?
rating_alternateName: “Linked to” here combines an estimate of both net migration and children born to immigrant parents. This is likely to be on the right scale but too precise a figure, as it rests on a number of assumptions and uncertain data sources.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Migration linked to 82% of growth in the population”
extra_title: Is 82% of population growth driven by migration?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Every five minutes, 70 children will be born in the UK, 20 to mothers not born here.
extra_title: One born every minute? How many migrants arrive in the UK and how many children do they have?
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. In 2016 the equivalent of around seven children were born every five minutes, of whom around two were born to mothers not born in the UK.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Every five minutes 60 people migrate to the UK.
extra_title: One born every minute? How many migrants arrive in the UK and how many children do they have?
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The equivalent of around five and a half people migrated to the UK every five minutes in the year to September 2017. Net migration was around two every five minutes.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “In the next five minutes 70 children will be born in the UK, 20 of those to mothers not born here. 60 people will have migrated here in that time as well.”
extra_title: One born every minute? How many migrants arrive in the UK and how many children do they have?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Each air strike in Syria will cost £508,000, enough to pay for up to 20 public sector workers.
extra_title: Air strikes: how many teachers and nurses could we pay for instead?
rating_alternateName: The £508,000 figure is a rough estimate, and estimating how many workers it would "pay for" is trickier than you might think.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Golf can reduce the risk of early death.
extra_title: Research suggesting health benefits of golf could also suggest benefits of being rich
rating_alternateName: Golfers identified in a study had a lower death rate than other over 65s but the research didn’t say golf was the reason why.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Round of golf once a month can reduce risk of early death.”
extra_title: Research suggesting health benefits of golf could also suggest benefits of being rich
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: One in ten patients admitted to hospital are suffering from a form of diabetes linked to being overweight and inactive
extra_title: The Mail’s diabetes front page needs context
rating_alternateName: This needs context. One in ten patients admitted to English hospitals in 2018/19 had type 2 diabetes, but a small fraction of those were admitted for their diabetes specifically.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“One in ten patients admitted to hospital are suffering from a form of diabetes linked to being overweight and inactive…
“[Data from NHS Digital] revealed there were 1,749,025 admissions for type 2 diabetes in 2018/19…
extra_title: The Mail’s diabetes front page needs context
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: One in four people is hooked on prescription drugs.
extra_title: We can’t say how many people are ‘hooked on’ prescription drugs
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. Research by Public Health England into the prescribing of five specific types of drug found there wasn’t enough evidence to say how many people were addicted. One in four adults in England received a prescription for at least one of the drug types they looked at in 2017/18.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 11.5 million Brits, or one in four, were prescribed addictive drugs last year.
extra_title: We can’t say how many people are ‘hooked on’ prescription drugs
rating_alternateName: Correct for adults in England in 2017/18. This is the number of people who had received at least one prescription for one of five specific types of potentially addictive drug.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “One in four people is hooked on prescription drugs”
extra_title: We can’t say how many people are ‘hooked on’ prescription drugs
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK has lost its measles free status just three years after the virus was eliminated.
extra_title: Being ‘measles free’ doesn’t mean there are no cases of measles
rating_alternateName: The World Health Organisation no longer judges measles to have been eliminated in the UK – but that doesn’t mean there was ever a year when there were no cases of the disease.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The UK has lost its ‘measles-free’ status with the World Health Organisation (WHO) – three years after the virus was eliminated in the country.”
extra_title: Being ‘measles free’ doesn’t mean there are no cases of measles
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: One in three people aged 30 are going to live to 100.
extra_title: You’ve less than a one in three chance of reaching 100
rating_alternateName: This appears to be an overestimate. The latest estimates from the   Office for National Statistics say that men aged 30 have a 12.5% (one in eight) chance of reaching 100, while women aged 30 have a 17.2% chance (one in six).

claimReview_claimReviewed: “One in three people aged 30 are going to live to 100,”
extra_title: You’ve less than a one in three chance of reaching 100
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Cocaine use in Britain has doubled in the last five years.
extra_title: Has cocaine use really doubled in five years?
rating_alternateName: There isn’t enough available evidence to say this. These figures are based on an analysis of wastewater in parts of London and Bristol, which can’t tell us very much about the picture across Britain.

claimReview_claimReviewed: One in 50 Londoners snorts cocaine on a daily basis.
extra_title: Has cocaine use really doubled in five years?
rating_alternateName: There isn’t enough available evidence to say this and we don’t know enough detail about the methodology behind this claim to assess its accuracy.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Cocaine use in Britain has more than doubled in five years, analysis of waste water reveals”
extra_title: Has cocaine use really doubled in five years?

extra_title: Has cocaine use really doubled in five years?

claimReview_claimReviewed: There has been a rise in deaths from heart disease.
extra_title: The heart disease death rate isn’t increasing
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The number of under 75s in the UK dying from heart disease increased slightly between 2016 and 2017. But the total number of deaths from heart disease decreased.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The death rate from heart disease has increased for the first time in 50 years.
extra_title: The heart disease death rate isn’t increasing
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The death rate continues to fall.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Shock rise in heart disease deaths — Experts call for action after rates increase for first time in 50 years”
extra_title: The heart disease death rate isn’t increasing

claimReview_claimReviewed: Ten minutes’ exercise each week cuts risk of early death by a fifth.
extra_title: Reports on the benefits of 10 minutes of exercise need a health warning
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. A new study has found that American adults aged 40-85 who did 10-59 minutes of moderate physical activity per week (not just 10) had an 18% lower risk of dying than inactive adults during a follow-up period.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Ten minutes’ exercise each week cuts risk of early death by a fifth”
extra_title: Reports on the benefits of 10 minutes of exercise need a health warning

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Exercising for just 10 minutes a WEEK can slash your chances of dying early by almost a FIFTH, study claims”

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Conservative election manifesto gave no indication that the party would stop new onshore wind generators from accessing an existing subsidy.
extra_title: The Conservative manifesto's onshore wind pledge
rating_alternateName: The reference to ending "new public subsidy" for onshore wind is ambiguous. It doesn't, on the face of it, reference existing schemes, but has to be seen in the context of the clear aim to stop the construction of new wind farms.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Our manifesto said we would remove subsidies for onshore wind, and we will act on that manifesto pledge."
extra_title: The Conservative manifesto's onshore wind pledge

claimReview_claimReviewed: "This announcement goes further than what had been previously indicated. It is not the scrapping of a 'new' subsidy that was promised but a reduction of an existing regime".

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK oil and gas industry supports an estimated 375,000 jobs.
extra_title: How many jobs are supported by the UK's oil and gas industry?
rating_alternateName: 375,000 is the latest estimate of the total employment supported by the industry according to the industry itself.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The oil and gas industry supports more than 400,000 jobs.
extra_title: How many jobs are supported by the UK's oil and gas industry?
rating_alternateName: Over 400,000 was an older estimate. These figures are uncertain, and don't just include people directly employed by the industry.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "…the oil and gas industry in the United Kingdom supports an estimated 375,000 jobs".
extra_title: How many jobs are supported by the UK's oil and gas industry?

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK is short of skilled electricians, plasterers, joiners, chefs and nurses.
extra_title: What skills are we short of in the UK?
rating_alternateName: There’s no simple definition of a shortage skilled profession in the UK, but nurses and chefs are on the official Shortage Occupation List, because they’re considered to need workers from overseas. The other professions mentioned aren’t currently on that list, but some employers still report difficulties in recruiting them, especially joiners.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We as a country are short of skilled people [...] We are short of electricians, plasterers, joiners, chefs [and] nurses.”
extra_title: What skills are we short of in the UK?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: One in nine UK workers are migrants.
extra_title: Are one in nine UK workers migrants?
rating_alternateName: About one in nine UK workers were estimated to be foreign nationals in 2016.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Free movement of people across the EU means that migrants now fill one in nine jobs in Britain.
extra_title: Are one in nine UK workers migrants?
rating_alternateName: About one in nine UK workers were estimated to be foreign nationals in 2016, including nationals from outside the EU.  This proportion has been increasing, which the ONS has said is mostly down to EU immigration.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “FREE movement of people across the EU means migrants now fill one in nine jobs in Britain, official figures have revealed”
extra_title: Are one in nine UK workers migrants?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 95% of new workers are foreigners.
extra_title: Foreigners working in the UK
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. These employment figures don’t tell us the number of new workers, only the overall change in employment. The claim also defines “foreigners” as all people born outside the UK, including those who are UK citizens. About 450,000 more people in the UK were employed in July-September 2016 than had been the year before, and roughly half of the increase was due to an increase in the number of non-British citizens.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “95% of new workers are foreigners”
extra_title: Foreigners working in the UK
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A million more pupils are in good or outstanding schools in England than five years ago.
extra_title: A million more pupils in good or outstanding schools? Not just a simple story of school improvement
rating_alternateName: Correct. This progress is partly due to Ofsted's changing inspection practice - which refined what was expected of schools and placed a greater emphasis on inspecting schools which fell below this expectation.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "We've made huge strides in the past five years—a million more pupils now in good or outstanding schools."
extra_title: A million more pupils in good or outstanding schools? Not just a simple story of school improvement
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: British pupils are suffering because teachers are struggling to cope with an influx of foreign students speaking different languages.
extra_title: Is immigration affecting the performance of native English speakers in schools?
rating_alternateName: The proportion of pupils with English as an additional language has been rising. But research suggests the performance of pupils with English as their first language isn't affected by this.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "British pupils are suffering because teachers are struggling to cope with an influx of foreign students speaking a total of 300 different languages, a union has said".
extra_title: Is immigration affecting the performance of native English speakers in schools?

claimReview_claimReviewed: Research finds short term breaks from school are harmful to pupil attainment.
extra_title: Research doesn't prove short breaks from school cause poorer pupil attainment
rating_alternateName: The research doesn't prove that holidays cause poorer attainment, only that pupils with higher rates of absence overall perform less well.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The myth that pulling a child out of school for a holiday is harmless to their education has been busted by this research.
extra_title: Research doesn't prove short breaks from school cause poorer pupil attainment
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 72% of free schools are located in areas with a shortage of places.
extra_title: Seven in ten free schools are in areas needing more school places
rating_alternateName: DfE analysis shows 7 in 10 open free schools are (or 75% of open and approved free schools). Many of the schools won't be operating at full capacity yet.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "72% [of free schools] are located in areas with a shortage of places"
extra_title: Seven in ten free schools are in areas needing more school places

claimReview_claimReviewed: Torbay and North Yorkshire councils approve the highest percentage of term-time holidays in England.
extra_title: The end of holiday fines?
rating_alternateName: These two councils had the highest percentage of authorised term-time holidays in England for 2014/15. There are big differences between councils.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The case of a father who successfully challenged a conviction for taking his daughter on holiday during school term-time will be heard in the highest court in the land… in the last year, many councils have relaxed their fines policy, as they wait for the conclusion of this case.”

extra_title: The end of holiday fines?

claimReview_claimReviewed: From Monday 16th May 2016 when we receive any referrals from schools for a Penalty Notice for a holiday alone to be issued, we will only issue a PN for holiday absences where there are other unauthorised absences which take the attendance percentage below 90%”
extra_title: The end of holiday fines?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Department for Education research shows missing school for even a day can impact pupil attainment.
extra_title: Mixed evidence on the link between term time holidays and attainment
rating_alternateName: This research finds as pupil absence rates increase, they do worse in tests at ages 10/11 and 15/16. Missing a single day doesn’t always show this for some pupils though, if the absence is an authorised holiday. Either way, the findings can’t prove that missing school is the cause of worse performance, or at least that if it is a cause, it's the main one. The evidence is more mixed looking specifically at holidays as a reason for absence.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “This new research is further evidence that missing school for even a day can mean a child is less likely to achieve good grades, which can have a damaging effect on their life chances.”
extra_title: Mixed evidence on the link between term time holidays and attainment

extra_title: Are changes to maintenance grants being made through an arcane loophole?
rating_alternateName: The way in which proposals are being introduced isn't unusual. The debate is over whether the government should have made the time for MPs to debate the changes in the chamber of the House of Commons following opposition from the Labour Party.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The Tories … [are] trying to force through the sweeping changes in committee hoping no-one would notice.”

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Supreme Court has ruled that the benefit cap is "right and fair".
extra_title: The Supreme Court didn't endorse the benefit cap
rating_alternateName: Not correct. The Supreme Court ruled that the benefit cap is legal, not that it's right or fair. The judgment can't be taken as an endorsement of this policy.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK’s aid budget is set to have more than doubled from 2010 to 2020.
extra_title: UK development aid spending
rating_alternateName: Not quite correct, even though there’s a few ways to look at it. The UK spent £8.5 billion on aid in 2010 and is on course to spend £15.3 in 2020, or £13.1 billion after inflation.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Back in 2010 the overseas aid budget was around £7 billion a year. By 2020 it will have more than doubled to over £15 billion a year... surely the government priority should be to look after the elderly, vulnerable and disabled people in our own country, before we hand money over to other countries?”
extra_title: UK development aid spending

claimReview_claimReviewed: Parts of London have the highest productivity in Europe.
extra_title: Productivity in the UK workplace: London vs. the rest
rating_alternateName: This is correct by one measure, but it isn't based on a fair comparison.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The gap between productivity in London and the UK’s 2nd, 3rd and 4th cities is greater than in any other major economy in the world.
extra_title: Productivity in the UK workplace: London vs. the rest
rating_alternateName: There is a significant ‘productivity gap’ between London and other cities in the UK; and it does seem to be relatively large compared to the largest European economies. We haven’t seen an analysis wide-ranging enough to claim that it’s greater than all other major economies.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Parts of London have the highest productivity in Europe…”
extra_title: Productivity in the UK workplace: London vs. the rest

claimReview_claimReviewed: The percentage of judges that are from ethnic minorities has fallen in the past year.

rating_alternateName: This is what the official statistics appear to show, but in fact there has been a slight rise in the proportion of ethnic minority judges compared to 2015. It's now 6.5% of those whose ethnicity is recorded, up from 5.9%. The apparent fall is due to a change in methodology.
