claimReview_claimReviewed: The government's claim to have spent more on flood defence schemes misrepresents its record.
extra_title: The government defence on flood defences
rating_alternateName: Funding for flood defences have increased overall, although it was originally set to fall. There do seem to have been cuts made in particular areas, such as staff at the Environment Agency.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "We were … surprised to hear you claim at Prime Minister's Questions this afternoon that you 'are spending more on flood defence schemes'. This is simply a misrepresentation of what has happened since you took office five and a half years ago."
extra_title: The government defence on flood defences
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: For every £1 spent on legal aid, the state saves £6.
extra_title: How much money does legal aid save the country?
rating_alternateName: This claim has evolved down a chain of several different pieces of research and should be treated with caution. Academics say that we need more research about the savings that spending on legal aid can bring.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "For every £1 spent on legal advice and aid, the state saves around £6 on other forms of spending"
extra_title: How much money does legal aid save the country?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "For every £1 spent on legal aid the state saves £6"
extra_title: How much money does legal aid save the country?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The prime minister’s Chequers deal is more unpopular than the Poll Tax.
extra_title: Is the Chequers deal on Brexit more unpopular than the Poll Tax?
rating_alternateName: Not quite. Recent polling suggests that the Chequers deal is supported by fewer people than the Poll Tax was at its least popular, but fewer people also oppose it outright.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The Chequers deal is now more unpopular with the British people than the Poll Tax was.”
extra_title: Is the Chequers deal on Brexit more unpopular than the Poll Tax?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The Prime Minister’s Chequers plan is even more unpopular than the Poll Tax.”
extra_title: Is the Chequers deal on Brexit more unpopular than the Poll Tax?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: EU law means that the UK will be covered by human rights laws even if we scrap the Human Rights Act.
extra_title: Does dropping human rights laws require leaving the EU too?
rating_alternateName: This is correct. The EU now has a stand-alone system of human rights law, which would remain in place even if we scrapped the older, separate system set up by the Human Rights Act and European Convention on Human Rights.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Even if we scrap the Human Rights Act, we'll still be beholden to EU laws"
extra_title: Does dropping human rights laws require leaving the EU too?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Only by leaving the EU will we escape human rights legislation"
extra_title: Does dropping human rights laws require leaving the EU too?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Parliament will have to change the Terrorism Act after judges declared that parts of it are incompatible with human rights.
extra_title: Miranda’s rights: will the Terrorism Act be changed?
rating_alternateName: The ruling doesn't mean that the law is no longer in force or that Parliament has to revise it. A declaration of incompatibility is a formal signal from judges that an Act should be changed. It generally is, but doesn't have to be.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“A key clause in the Terrorism Act 2000 is incompatible with the European convention on human rights, the master of the rolls, John Dyson, has said as part of a court of appeal judgment...
“The court of appeal’s judgment on Tuesday will force government ministers to re-examine the act.
extra_title: Miranda’s rights: will the Terrorism Act be changed?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “As a result of this ruling the law will have to be changed so that journalists are better protected
extra_title: Miranda’s rights: will the Terrorism Act be changed?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK is the best country for education in 2019.
extra_title: Does the UK have the best education system in the world?
rating_alternateName: This is based on data that measures public perception of different educational systems. It is not good data for objectively ranking education systems. Objective measures suggest the UK has a good public education system, but not the world’s best.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are 1.9 million more children studying in good or outstanding schools since 2010.
extra_title: Nearly 2 million more children are in good or outstanding schools since 2010
rating_alternateName: Correct, comparing Ofsted ratings between 2010 and 2017. This progress has been influenced by Ofsted’s changing inspection practices—which refined what was expected of schools and placed a greater emphasis on inspecting schools which fell below this expectation.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Under Conservative-led governments there are 1.9 million more children studying in good or outstanding schools.”
extra_title: Nearly 2 million more children are in good or outstanding schools since 2010
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: School standards in Scotland are falling.
extra_title: Scottish schools
rating_alternateName: Correct according to various sets of pupil tests, although international tests suggest that standards are improving in some subjects.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “School standards are falling in Scotland.”
extra_title: Scottish schools
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Finland, South Korea and Canada, which all have the most comprehensive systems, have been repeatedly shown to have the best educated children in the world.
extra_title: Finland, Canada and South Korea rank highly for education
rating_alternateName: Finland, South Korea and Canada have done consistently well in tests that compare 15 year-olds internationally, although these tests aren’t a perfect guide to the relative performance of different education systems. We haven’t seen definitive evidence that the success of these systems is due to the fact they’re comprehensive.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If you look at the countries that have the best educated children around the world, there are three countries that come up again and again and again… Finland, South Korea and Canada. And they have the most comprehensive systems.”
extra_title: Finland, Canada and South Korea rank highly for education
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: England has been named second worst nation for child happiness.
extra_title: England not named world's second worst nation for child happiness
rating_alternateName: The research only shows England's performance compared to 14 other countries, not worldwide. Other surveys tell a different story.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "England named 'second worst nation' for child happiness"
extra_title: England not named world's second worst nation for child happiness
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Spanish government hasn’t said that it would veto an independent Scotland joining the European Union.
extra_title: EU membership: Spain vs Scotland
rating_alternateName: Correct, although it has said that Scotland would have to leave the EU and re-apply from the outside.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “No other EU member state has said that it would veto an independent Scotland’s membership... The Spanish have not said that. Go home and Google this evening, the Spanish government have not said that they would veto.”
extra_title: EU membership: Spain vs Scotland
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 94% of people in Wales don’t want independence.
extra_title: Welsh views on independence
rating_alternateName: On average 6% of people in Wales said they wanted independence when presented with a range of options on how Wales should be governed. This is comparing polls which ask a consistent question over the last five years. Other polls have asked slightly different questions and found a higher proportion in favour of independence, but it’s always in the minority.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “I do think we need to listen very carefully to the people of Wales. 94% of the people of Wales have repeatedly shown in poll after poll that actually, whilst being very proud to be Welsh, we are actually not in the least bit interested in an independent Wales.”
extra_title: Welsh views on independence
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Conservatives’ poll lead has fallen following recent policy announcements on tax and spending.
extra_title: Little evidence the Conservatives’ poll lead is narrowing
rating_alternateName: There’s little evidence for this: this is comparing polls from two different companies which use different polling methods. Recent polls have generally shown Conservative leads approaching or exceeding 20 percentage points.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Tory lead is slashed in half after tax U-turn: Bombshell Mail on Sunday poll shows May plummeting by 11 points ...denting hopes of a landslide”
extra_title: Little evidence the Conservatives’ poll lead is narrowing
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 800,000 people pay a higher tax rate than someone who earns £1m.
extra_title: Do you pay a higher tax rate than a millionaire?
rating_alternateName: Some people do pay higher tax rates than those earning £1m, but only when their income rises between certain amounts. The estimate of 800,000 people affected only applies to relatively high earners, but marginal tax rates affect low earners too.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “800,000 people pay a higher tax rate than someone who earns £1m”
extra_title: Do you pay a higher tax rate than a millionaire?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The wealthiest are paying more and more tax.
extra_title: What do the wealthiest pay in tax?
rating_alternateName: There’s no one-line answer: it depends on who you define as the wealthiest.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The amount of tax paid by the wealthiest in our society has risen and risen in the last few years”
extra_title: What do the wealthiest pay in tax?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK has taken in only 216 Syrian refugees.
extra_title: Has the UK only taken in 216 Syrian refugees?
rating_alternateName: The UK has taken in around 5,000 Syrian refugees. The 216 figure refers to an additional number resettled from around Syria under one particular scheme.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Number of Syrian refugees Britain has taken in would fit on a Tube train"
extra_title: Has the UK only taken in 216 Syrian refugees?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: "The UK has accepted 216 Syrian refugees. Germany has accepted 800,000."
extra_title: Has the UK only taken in 216 Syrian refugees?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A senior judge has said that many of the people in the Calais "jungle" migrant camp aren't refugees, but want the UK's "economic benefits".
extra_title: "The judge who dared to tell the truth"?
rating_alternateName: One line in a recent judgment says "many are probably not refugees", but want to apply for asylum in the UK instead of France "due to perceived advantages". His judgment doesn't mention benefits.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK's welfare system, public services and lax border controls explain the presence of migrants at Calais trying to cross.
extra_title: Why are there so many migrants at Calais?
rating_alternateName: Benefits aren't available to illegal immigrants, although asylum seekers get some support and use of public services. It's hard to say how secure the border is.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
"The two most fundamental reasons why the migrants are massing at Calais rather than in Italy.
First, we are rightly considered a global soft-touch which will provide them with limitless welfare, free healthcare and education.
And second, the illegal immigrants are getting through our lax border controls, which only encourages more to come and try their luck"
extra_title: Why are there so many migrants at Calais?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Government spending on flood defences until 2021 has heavily favoured London and the South East.
extra_title: We don’t know if there’s a north/south divide in flood defence spending because the data was taken offline
rating_alternateName: There isn’t enough data available to prove this, and previous estimates  don’t clearly show this divide. Figures from the Environment Agency that could have helped shed light seem to have been taken offline.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The government’s planned spending on flood defences until 2021 also heavily favours London and the south-east of England.”
extra_title: We don’t know if there’s a north/south divide in flood defence spending because the data was taken offline
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: According to analysis by Labour, Tory spending on flood defences overwhelmingly favours the South East… with Environment Agency spending falling 15 per cent in the North West, 14 per cent in Yorkshire and 3 per cent in the East Midlands between 2016 and 2018. Over the same period, the South East has seen a rise in spending of 14.5 per cent.
extra_title: We don’t know if there’s a north/south divide in flood defence spending because the data was taken offline
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Taxpayers will pick up a £2 million security bill for Eugenie’s wedding.
extra_title: The Princess and the PCs: What will policing Princess Eugenie’s wedding cost?
rating_alternateName: This hasn’t been confirmed, but seems in the right ballpark based on reported costs for previous weddings.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Taxpayers will pick up a £2 million security bill for Eugenie’s wedding,”
extra_title: The Princess and the PCs: What will policing Princess Eugenie’s wedding cost?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The royal family brings in £400m a year in private revenue, of which £360m is kept by government under the Sovereign Act 2011.
extra_title: How does the royal family make money?
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The Crown Estate brought in £330 million in 2017/18, this money goes to the government who then give the Queen a grant based on 25% of the Crown Estate’s income two years previously.But the Crown Estate isn’t the royal family’s private property. The Queen pays tax to government on her other private incomes.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Queen takes 15% of the crown estate profit each year - around £60m.
extra_title: How does the royal family make money?
rating_alternateName: Historically the Queen received a grant from the government based on 15% of the income from the Crown Estate, but this has gone up to 25% to pay for refurbishments to Buckingham Palace. In 2019/20 this will equate to about £82 million.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Family brings in 400 million a year in private revenue that under the “sovereign act 2011” the government keeps £360 million of.”
extra_title: How does the royal family make money?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Family brings in £1.8 b per year in tourism.”
extra_title: How does the royal family make money?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: An extra £1 billion will be invested on mental health spending by 2021.
extra_title: Unanswered questions on “extra £1 billion” for mental health
rating_alternateName: NHS England says it has committed to spending this much extra on mental health services in 2020/21 from its existing budget, over and above what is spent at the moment. If this is the whole rise in mental health spending in England over the next five years, then the spending will rise more slowly than on other parts of the NHS. If it isn’t, then we’re no closer to knowing how much will be spent on mental health.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “New investment in mental health services… An extra £1 billion will be invested in mental health care by 2021”
extra_title: Unanswered questions on “extra £1 billion” for mental health
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Half of everything we sell to the rest of the world goes to the EU.
extra_title: Do half the UK's exports go to Europe?
rating_alternateName: The proportion of all goods and services exported going to the EU was 44% last year.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Half of everything we sell to the rest of the world we sell to Europe"
extra_title: Do half the UK's exports go to Europe?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: UK universities get 15% extra money in funding from the EU, on top of what the government gives them.
extra_title: How much money do British universities get from the EU?
rating_alternateName: 15%, or a little higher, is a rough estimate of additional EU research and development funding; this isn't only for universities. British higher education providers get at least 2.6% of their total income from the EU, or around 16% of their research income.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "UK universities receive an additional 15% in funding from the EU, on top of what the UK government gives them. Much of this is for research and development. The UK receives the second largest share of EU research funding."
extra_title: How much money do British universities get from the EU?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Since 1987 more than 200,000 UK students have studied or worked in Europe on the Erasmus exchange programme, 15,000 in 2012 alone.
extra_title: British students and the EU
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Over 200,000 students have studied or worked abroad under the Erasmus education programme since its establishment in 1987. In fact, just shy of 15,000 UK students studied in the EU in 2012 alone"
extra_title: British students and the EU
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government has broken a manifesto pledge by removing drugs from the Cancer Drugs Fund.
extra_title: Did the government keep its promise on the Cancer Drugs Fund?
rating_alternateName: In its manifesto the Conservative Party promised to continue to invest in the Fund, which has seen spending rise. But drugs have been removed from the list. And beyond 2016 it could be replaced by a new system.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Now [the government is] having to remove drugs from the Cancer Drugs Fund, breaking one of David Cameron's key election pledges to cancer patients."
extra_title: Did the government keep its promise on the Cancer Drugs Fund?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There's a "massive gap" of 100,000 units a year between what housing is needed and what is being built.
extra_title: How large is the housing gap?
rating_alternateName: There's a few different ways of looking at it but 100,000 seems to be a pretty reasonable estimate of the gap (for 2014).

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Does the Prime Minister not think it is time to reconsider the question of the funding of the administration of housing, as well as, of course, the massive gap of 100,000 units a year between what is needed and what is being built?"
extra_title: How large is the housing gap?

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of hospital beds fell by 25,000 in the last six years of the last Labour government.
extra_title: Who's cutting hospital bed numbers?
rating_alternateName: Correct, the number of overnight beds in the English NHS actually fell by slightly more—about 26,000—between 2003/04 and 2009/10.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The average length of time for staying in hospital has virtually halved since the year 2000.
extra_title: Who's cutting hospital bed numbers?
rating_alternateName: It hasn’t quite halved but it has fallen. The average length of stay overnight was eight days in 2000 and is about five days now.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government is cutting the number of hospital beds.
extra_title: Who's cutting hospital bed numbers?
rating_alternateName: This is right, the number of overnight beds in the English NHS has fallen.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “When hospitals are struggling to provide essential care why is the government cutting the number of beds in our National Health Service?”
extra_title: Who's cutting hospital bed numbers?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Thanks to medical advances, to the use of technology, to the quality of care, what we see in hospital stays is actually that the average length of time for staying in hospital has virtually halved since the year 2000. But let us look at Labour’s record on this issue, in the last six years of the last Labour government, 25,000 hospital beds were cut”
extra_title: Who's cutting hospital bed numbers?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 98% of NHS trusts are in deficit.
extra_title: How many NHS trusts are in deficit?
rating_alternateName: This was roughly correct for acute trusts in the third quarter of 2015/16. But by the end of 2015/16 it was 65% of all NHS trusts, of which 75% were acute trusts (hospitals).

claimReview_claimReviewed: “It was 98% of [NHS] trusts in deficit, I forget the exact number.”
extra_title: How many NHS trusts are in deficit?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Solar installations are down 94%.
extra_title: Labour makes misleading claim on solar energy
rating_alternateName:
This is misleading, because it compares two especially extreme months (March and April 2019), which almost always see a major drop in new solar capacity. 

Overall, the amount of new solar capacity being generated has stagnated significantly since 2017.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Last week, we learned that the Conservatives have effectively collapsed the solar industry, with a 94% drop in installations.”
extra_title: Labour makes misleading claim on solar energy

extra_title: What effect on the public purse would closing the Renewables Obligation early have?
rating_alternateName: The government won't improve its finances by closing the RO early, as the scheme is paid for by energy suppliers and their consumers. £270 million is the government's upper estimate of how much the closure could save them.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "The estimated saving of closing the RO early to new onshore wind is up to £270 million per year."
extra_title: What effect on the public purse would closing the Renewables Obligation early have?

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The overall teacher vacancy rate is 0.3% and has remained under 1% for the past 15 years.”

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Some research has shown that top universities make offers to 55% of white applicants, but only to 23% of black ones. The reasons are complex, but unconscious bias is clearly a risk."

rating_alternateName: The DWP has carried out internal 'Peer Reviews' in 40 individual cases since February 2012 after the suicide or apparent suicide of a customer.

"We've got 60 people who have committed suicide and their suicides are linked to benefits [...] the Department of Work and Pensions is supposed to be reviewing 60 cases where people have committed suicide"—Jonathan Bartley, Green Party Work and Pensions spokesperson, 5 May 2015

claimReview_claimReviewed: If more money is spent in Northern Ireland then the Barnett formula means Scotland and Wales will also receive more.
extra_title: Northern Ireland and the Barnett formula
rating_alternateName: It will depend on political negotiations. The Barnett formula isn’t set out in law.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If the DUP gets this hard-headed negotiated, 2.5 billion, 2 billion, 2.5 billion that they are asking for, the Barnett Formula says that the other devolved powers are going to have to have their share, too. That's about 3 billion for Wales, about 8 or 9 billion for Scotland.”
extra_title: Northern Ireland and the Barnett formula
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 8.4 million people are watching S4C every week in the UK.
extra_title: The hunt for 8.4 million Welsh-speaking telly addicts
rating_alternateName: S4C's annual report actually says 578,000.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "I am sure he will welcome the news in S4C's annual report that 8.4 million people are watching S4C every week in the UK
extra_title: The hunt for 8.4 million Welsh-speaking telly addicts
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are more hospital beds.
extra_title: NHS: More beds, more doctors, and more flu vaccines?
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. The number of beds available in NHS hospitals in England has been falling for the last thirty years, something experts put down to medical innovations. 1,300 fewer beds were used by patients fit to be discharged in November 2017 compared to the year before.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are more doctors.
extra_title: NHS: More beds, more doctors, and more flu vaccines?
rating_alternateName: Correct. It was 109,000 in September 2017, an increase of 11,900 since the same month in 2010.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are more flu vaccines available than ever before.
extra_title: NHS: More beds, more doctors, and more flu vaccines?
rating_alternateName: In October, the Chief Medical Officer for England said that there were “more people eligible than ever before” for the flu vaccine this winter, and NHS England said it aimed to treat up to 21 million people. Public Health England doesn’t yet have complete figures on how many people received the vaccine this winter.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We’ve got more beds, more doctors, more flu vaccines available than ever before.”
extra_title: NHS: More beds, more doctors, and more flu vaccines?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A quarter of nurses need a second job.
extra_title: Are nurses taking a second job to survive?
rating_alternateName: 23% of respondents to a survey of Royal College of Nursing members said they had taken an “additional paid job”, such as agency nursing, to help pay everyday bills and living expenses. We don’t know how representative this is of all nurses and this is based on a low response rate (8%).

claimReview_claimReviewed: Many nurses have to go to food banks.
extra_title: Are nurses taking a second job to survive?
rating_alternateName: Media reports show that at least some individual nurses and trainees have visited food banks. We do not have solid evidence of the scale of use.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “A quarter of our nurses need a second job. Many of them have to go to food banks.”
extra_title: Are nurses taking a second job to survive?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Around a dozen other European countries have banned zero hours contracts.
extra_title: Zero hours contracts: is the UK "the odd one out"?
rating_alternateName: Not all have an explicit ban, but it’s correct that most EU countries outlaw these contracts, heavily restrict them, or don’t see them widely used. The UK is one of around half a dozen European countries where zero hours contracts are both legal and fairly common.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “In her speech on the steps of Downing Street, [Theresa May] also addressed insecure workers, saying ‘you have a job but that doesn’t always mean you have job security’. Does that mean that she’s proposing to... ban zero hours contracts as more than a dozen European nations have already done?”
extra_title: Zero hours contracts: is the UK "the odd one out"?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Zero hours contracts are not allowed in Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, Denmark, France, Germany, Hungary, Italy, Netherlands, Poland and Spain. It seems we’re the odd one out.”
extra_title: Zero hours contracts: is the UK "the odd one out"?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK received 24,000 asylum applications last year, far fewer than other EU countries.
extra_title: UN wrong on asylum seekers in Britain
rating_alternateName: It's 31,000 including family members, the sixth highest number in the EU. Adjusting for population size, the UK is 18th out of 30 European countries.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "The perspective has been largely lost, and very much so, in the United Kingdom … in 2014, Germany received 175,000 asylum applications; Sweden, 75,000; Italy, 63,000; France, 59,000; and the United Kingdom, 24,000."
extra_title: UN wrong on asylum seekers in Britain
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Royal Mail is part-owned by the German government.
extra_title: Who owns Britain’s trains, energy and postal service?
rating_alternateName: We’ve not seen any information on who all of the Royal Mail’s shareholders are and have asked them for more information.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The energy market is mainly owned by the French government.
extra_title: Who owns Britain’s trains, energy and postal service?
rating_alternateName: The French government is a major shareholder in the energy company EDF but not in any of the other Big Six providers. Other international companies have stakes in other members of the Big Six.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The railways are owned by the Dutch and German government.
extra_title: Who owns Britain’s trains, energy and postal service?
rating_alternateName: Governments in Germany, the Netherlands and France are shareholders in the companies and parent companies running around a dozen UK rail franchises.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The energy market is owned by the French government mainly, your railways are owned by the Dutch and German government and the Royal Mail's part-owned by the German government so they are state-owned, [it’s] just not Great Britain that owns them.”
extra_title: Who owns Britain’s trains, energy and postal service?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Cannabis use causes a quarter of psychosis cases.
extra_title: Factcheck: does cannabis cause a quarter of psychosis cases?
rating_alternateName: That's not what the research shows. High-potency cannabis (or skunk) is linked to 24% of cases in South London, but that's not representative of the rest of the country.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Cannabis causing a quarter of psychosis"
extra_title: Factcheck: does cannabis cause a quarter of psychosis cases?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Dementia and Alzheimer’s disease are now the leading causes of death.
extra_title: The biggest cause of death depends on how you count them
rating_alternateName: It depends how you categorise illnesses. More people died of dementia and Alzheimer’s disease than any other single cause in 2015 but, as a group, cancers were the most common cause of deaths.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Dementia is the single greatest health crisis faced by this country. New figures by the ONS reveal that dementia and Alzheimer's disease are now the leading cause of death”
extra_title: The biggest cause of death depends on how you count them
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The cost of mental ill health to the economy, the NHS and society as a whole is £105 billion a year.
extra_title: Does mental ill health cost £105 billion a year?
rating_alternateName: £105 billion is an estimate of the annual economic and social costs of mental ill health from health charity Centre for Mental Health. It doesn’t just count public costs though: about half of it is made up of an estimate of the cost to individuals from the lower quality of life due to having mental health difficulties. It’s an uncertain estimate.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “...the cost of mental ill health to the economy, the NHS and society as a whole is £105 billion a year”
extra_title: Does mental ill health cost £105 billion a year?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: People from black and minority ethnic populations are most affected by detentions under the Mental Health Act.
extra_title: The number of detentions under the Mental Health Act is rising
rating_alternateName: If you're black and minority ethnic, you're more likely to be detained than if you're white. Overall, more white people are detained, since they make up a larger portion of the population.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Four times as many black people are being detained as white people.
extra_title: The number of detentions under the Mental Health Act is rising
rating_alternateName: If you're black, you're about four times as likely to be detained than if you're white. Overall, more white people are detained, since they make up a larger portion of the population.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of people detained under the Mental Health Act has increased by 47% in ten years.
extra_title: The number of detentions under the Mental Health Act is rising
rating_alternateName: Correct in England between 2005/06 and 2015/16.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Detention rates under the Mental Health Act are too high. And it is people from black and minority ethnic populations who are affected the most.”
extra_title: The number of detentions under the Mental Health Act is rising
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The number of people detained under the [Mental Health] Act is rising at an alarming rate - up 47% in 10 years. We detain almost four times as many black people as white people.”
extra_title: The number of detentions under the Mental Health Act is rising
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: One in 10 children aged between five and 16 have a mental health problem.

rating_alternateName: This is correct according to a survey conducted in 2004. More up-to-date research is due to be published in 2018.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “One in 10 children aged between five and 16 have a mental health problem.”
extra_title: How many children have mental health disorders?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: In the EU at least 83m people (27%) suffer from mental health problems.
extra_title: About 27% of Europeans are likely to experience a mental health problem in a year
rating_alternateName: Research agrees that 27% of Europeans experience at least one mental disorder in a year. Population growth means it's probably over 120m people by now.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "In the EU at least 83 million people (27%) suffer from mental health problems (16.7 million in the UK)."
extra_title: About 27% of Europeans are likely to experience a mental health problem in a year

claimReview_claimReviewed: The proportion of the NHS budget spent on private providers rose much more quickly under the last Labour government than it has since then.
extra_title: How much more is the NHS spending on private providers?
rating_alternateName: This is overstating the available figures, which only show spending since 2006/07. The growth rate is similar under both governments, and is higher under Labour counting its spending up to 2010/11.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The rate of use of non-NHS healthcare was much higher; the growth rate was much higher under Tony Blair's Labour than it has been under the Conservative and Coalition governments.”
extra_title: How much more is the NHS spending on private providers?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK no longer has an NHS according to the WHO’s definition.
extra_title: Ask Full Fact: Does the World Health Organisation think the UK no longer has an NHS?
rating_alternateName: Incorrect. There has been privatisation of services according to the WHO’s definition, because more NHS care is run by private sector companies. But the WHO didn’t say this means there’s no longer an NHS.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Terrifyingly, according to the World Health Organisation definition the UK no longer has a NHS”
extra_title: Ask Full Fact: Does the World Health Organisation think the UK no longer has an NHS?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: …a process in which non-government actors become increasingly involved in the financing and/or provision of health care services.
extra_title: Ask Full Fact: Does the World Health Organisation think the UK no longer has an NHS?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Disadvantaged children who go to grammar school progress twice as fast than their better-off peers.
extra_title: Do poor grammar schools pupils make twice as much progress?
rating_alternateName: That’s the finding of one study, from 2004. The relatively few poor children who attend grammar schools seem to progress more than wealthier children, but those in the schools around them perform worse.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “When you look at disadvantaged children who go to grammars their progress is twice as fast in a grammar school as their better off peers.”
extra_title: Do poor grammar schools pupils make twice as much progress?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Poorer children are less likely to get into grammar schools.
extra_title: Poorer children are less likely to go to grammar schools
rating_alternateName: Poorer children are less likely to go to grammar schools even if they are high achievers. It’s not certain if this is because poorer children are less likely to apply, or less likely to get in, or a bit of both.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The problem is that not enough children from lower [socio-]economic backgrounds get access into grammar schools—that’s why there isn’t the social mobility you’re talking about.”
extra_title: Poorer children are less likely to go to grammar schools
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The attainment gap between rich and poor pupils in grammar schools is virtually zero.
extra_title: Poor children at grammar schools seem to do well
rating_alternateName: The gap between disadvantaged pupils and their peers at GCSE level is around three percentage points on average in grammar schools, compared to around 23 in other mainstream state schools. This might reflect more about the types of children that go to grammar schools rather than the effectiveness of the schools themselves.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “When we look at the impact of grammar schools, if you look at attainment, for disadvantaged and non-disadvantaged children, the attainment gap in grammar schools is virtually zero, which it isn’t in other schools”
extra_title: Poor children at grammar schools seem to do well
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Grammar schools don’t benefit most pupils.
extra_title: Grammar schools benefit some pupils but the majority do worse
rating_alternateName: The advantage for pupils who attend grammar schools is outweighed by the disadvantage for those who don’t.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Grammar schools benefit some pupils.
extra_title: Grammar schools benefit some pupils but the majority do worse
rating_alternateName: The evidence suggests pupils who get into grammar schools do better than they would under comprehensive education, but the majority who don’t get in do worse.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Children, if they are in a class with their own ability, are likely to hit off each other and do better as a result”
extra_title: Grammar schools benefit some pupils but the majority do worse
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “All the evidence demonstrates that grammar schools will benefit a limited few but will not benefit others and do not raise standards overall.”
extra_title: Grammar schools benefit some pupils but the majority do worse

claimReview_claimReviewed: New grammar schools may be required to set up feeder primary schools in poorer areas.
extra_title: The government’s proposals could change what we know about selection
rating_alternateName: The government is proposing and consulting on this option. Pupils' backgrounds are part of what makes current grammar school different from other schools, so proposals like this could mean that research about current grammar schools won't be a perfect guide to the impact that new grammar schools would have on social mobility.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The Secretary of State for Education suggested on Monday that new grammar schools may be required to set up feeder primary schools in poorer areas. Will the children in those feeder primaries get automatic places at grammar school or will they be subject to selection?”
extra_title: The government’s proposals could change what we know about selection
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: £72 million is going towards specific areas of the country, including Scarborough, to help improve the quality of education.

rating_alternateName: Correct. The “Opportunity Areas” programme will provide £72 million for 12 areas of the country ranked low for social mobility. North Yorkshire, including Scarborough, will seek to improve early years education, maths and literacy skills and secondary school places through the programme.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A report by the Social Mobility Commission says there isn’t a north/south divide on social mobility, it says the picture is more mixed than this.

rating_alternateName: That’s correct. The report said the strongest divide was between London and the rest of the country.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Scarborough was in there and I think the education was highlighted in that report and that is why there is £72 million going towards specific areas in the country, of which Scarborough is one, to help really improve the quality of education.”
extra_title: Is social mobility in England still all about the North/South divide?

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Worth it for the 120,000 more 6-year-olds on track to become confident readers as a result of our focus on phonics".

rating_alternateName: Today a journey from Leeds to London takes around two hours. extra_title: Social care funding: how did the sector react to the latest plans?
rating_alternateName: That's right, although how far the measures will go varies by area. Experts have estimated the funding gap for adult social care at between £2.8 billion and £3.5 billion by 2020.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The NHS Confederation says cuts to social care will put pressure on hospitals.
extra_title: Social care funding: how did the sector react to the latest plans?
rating_alternateName: That's right.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
"The problem is to do with adult social care. This morning on BBC Radio 4, the NHS Confederation said that 'cuts to social care and public health will continue to pile more pressure on hospitals and will worsen deficits in the acute sector'."
Jeremy Corbyn
"If he wants to swap quotations, this is what the Chairman of the Local Government Association says: 'The LGA has long called for further flexibility in the setting of council tax… Today's announcement will go some way to allowing a number of councils to raise the money needed… The £1.5 billion more increase in the Better Care Fund, announced today is good news'."
extra_title: Social care funding: how did the sector react to the latest plans?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Women aren’t allowed to breastfeed babies in the House of Commons.
extra_title: Can MPs breastfeed in the House of Commons?
rating_alternateName: Breastfeeding is not allowed in the House of Commons chamber and committees, though it is allowed in other areas of the Palace of Westminster.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “There’s still a problem with breastfeeding in public, including, I believe, in the House of Commons. I believe that women aren’t allowed to feed babies in the House of Commons. I may be wrong, but if that's the case, that's ridiculous.”
extra_title: Can MPs breastfeed in the House of Commons?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “That's not true... I don't know about the chamber, I have to say, because I haven’t actually seen anybody doing it in my seven years that I’ve been there. But obviously in the building and everything else but I think it probably has been done and I hope it wouldn't be a problem if it were to be done.”
extra_title: Can MPs breastfeed in the House of Commons?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Four million people have diabetes.
extra_title: Four million people have diabetes—probably
rating_alternateName: This seems about right. We can only be sure about the three and a half million people diagnosed with diabetes. Another half a million may be undiagnosed, according to estimates.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Number of people with diabetes reaches over 4 million"
extra_title: Four million people have diabetes—probably
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: In the six years from 2010 rail fares have risen 25% on average.
extra_title: Rail fares: up 25% in six years?
rating_alternateName: That's right in cash terms - consumer prices have gone up by about 14% over the same period. The 25% increase is for 'regulated' fares, which make up about half of all fares.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Analysis by Labour shows that since 2010, commuters' rail fares have risen by 25 per cent on average"
extra_title: Rail fares: up 25% in six years?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are eight million foreigners living in the UK.
extra_title: Those "eight million foreigners" living in the UK
rating_alternateName: There are an estimated eight million people who were born abroad living in the UK, although according to the census that was already the case in 2011.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "8 million foreigners living in Britain"
extra_title: Those "eight million foreigners" living in the UK
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: A new English language test has been introduced for nurses which means that some people who would otherwise have been able to practice can’t.
extra_title: Where have all the (EU) nurses gone?
rating_alternateName: English language tests have been a requirement for nurses from outside of the EU since 2005. In January 2016 these were extended to include nurses from the EU/EEA. It’s been cited as one of a number of reasons, including Brexit, behind falling nursing recruitment.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are now more nurses from the European Union going home than coming to the UK.
extra_title: Where have all the (EU) nurses gone?
rating_alternateName: In the year to September 2017 the number of nurses from the EU leaving the NHS in England outweighed those joining it for the first time in at least five years. We don’t know if they left the UK or what jobs they went on to do.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If you look at the numbers, it would appear that the big change over the last couple of years has been that we've now got European Union nurses going home rather than coming here… It would seem that part of that apparently, I can't quite believe this, was some new language test was introduced which actually did mean that some people who would otherwise have got in couldn’t get in.”
extra_title: Where have all the (EU) nurses gone?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 10,000 EU staff have left the NHS because they don’t feel they are needed or wanted any more.
extra_title: NHS staff from the EU: one year on from the referendum
rating_alternateName: 10,000 EU staff did leave the NHS in the year following the referendum vote (excluding those working in GP surgeries), but we don’t have information about why any of these staff left. This continues a rising trend in the last few years.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “10,000 people [from the EU] already walked away from the National Health Service, because they don’t feel they’re needed or wanted any more.”
extra_title: NHS staff from the EU: one year on from the referendum
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Free schools improve neighbouring schools.
extra_title: Good neighbours: do free schools help others improve?
rating_alternateName: Near new free schools, bad schools tend to get better and good schools tend to get worse but the evidence doesn't prove that free schools are the cause.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Free Schools are raising standards for other pupils across their local communities, especially in some of the poorest performing schools.
extra_title: Good neighbours: do free schools help others improve?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: We make it very clear — in the report and in press interviews — that there seems to be a pattern suggesting free schools raise standards for neighbouring schools, especially in the most underperforming schools. We have not said that free schools lift results for every school in a local authority.
extra_title: Good neighbours: do free schools help others improve?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: it is too early to draw conclusions on the quality of education provided by free schools or their broader system impact" Education Select Committee, 21 January 201
extra_title: Good neighbours: do free schools help others improve?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The number of GP training places is rising.
extra_title: Is the NHS recruiting enough new GPs?
rating_alternateName: This is correct in England, although not all the places are being filled.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are 1,000 fewer GPs now than there were when Theresa May became Prime Minister.
extra_title: Is the NHS recruiting enough new GPs?
rating_alternateName: This uses figures that aren’t comparable, but it’s still almost certain that the number of GPs in England has fallen since last year, and could have fallen by over 1,000.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The government promised to recruit an extra 5,000 GPs by 2020.
extra_title: Is the NHS recruiting enough new GPs?
rating_alternateName: Correct.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“The government promised to recruit an extra 5,000 GPs by 2020, where are they? …
“There are 1,000 less GPs than there were the day she became Prime Minister
extra_title: Is the NHS recruiting enough new GPs?

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We are seeing more GPs, we are seeing more training places for our GPs.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Conservatives are levelling up per pupil funding.
extra_title: Is schools spending going to be at record levels?
rating_alternateName: Per pupil spending on schools in England is set to increase over the next three years to roughly the level it was at in 2009/10.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Conservatives are giving a record £14 billion to schools.
extra_title: Is schools spending going to be at record levels?
rating_alternateName: Once you account for inflation the increase between 2019/20 and 2022/23 is £4.3 billion in England. This isn’t a record increase in terms of spending per pupil (which is the most meaningful measure).

claimReview_claimReviewed: “We’re giving schools a record £14 billion, levelling up per pupil funding across the country.”
extra_title: Is schools spending going to be at record levels?

rating_alternateName: Correct, for UK undergraduate applicants between 2015 and 2017.

claimReview_claimReviewed: A quarter of Oxford colleges did not admit a single black student in a whole year group at least once between 2015 and 2017.
extra_title: Black and ethnic minority students at the University of Oxford
rating_alternateName: Correct, for undergraduate students from the UK who took up their place between 2015 and 2017.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Eight Oxford colleges are less than 1% black.
extra_title: Black and ethnic minority students at the University of Oxford
rating_alternateName: Correct, for undergraduate students from the UK who took up their place between 2015 and 2017.

claimReview_claimReviewed: BME students make up 17.9% of all British Oxford undergraduates. That’s pretty close to the percentage of BME people among 17-24-year-olds in England and Wales – 18.3%.
extra_title: Black and ethnic minority students at the University of Oxford
rating_alternateName: Correct, for undergraduate students from the UK who took up their place in 2017, and looking at those in the 2011 census who would be between 17 and 24 today.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “You are twice as likely to get into @UniofOxford as a white applicant (24%) than a black applicant (12%). Why? 1/4 Oxford colleges did not admit a single black student in a whole year group at least once between 2015-17. 8 colleges less than 1% black. Why?”

claimReview_claimReviewed: One in five asylum seekers in the EU are from Syria.
extra_title: Are only one in five asylum seekers Syrian?
rating_alternateName: This was correct for the EU asylum applications in spring 2015 (the latest figures available). But this was before a more recent surge in arrivals, and there is evidence to suggest that a high proportion of these people are from Syria.

claimReview_claimReviewed: 19 Liberal Democrat MPs refused to support a motion to stop privatisation of the NHS.
extra_title: It’s misleading to claim the Lib Dems refused to support an end to NHS privatisation
rating_alternateName: The motion in question would not have stopped privatisation in the NHS, nor would it have necessarily repealed the Health and Social Care Act.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UKIP leader Paul Nuttall has said that he wants to privatise the NHS.
extra_title: UKIP and the NHS
rating_alternateName: Mr Nuttall has been critical of the NHS model of a publicly-owned healthcare provider in the past. He has since said that he thinks there could be more private sector involvement in the NHS. UKIP’s policy is still for an NHS that’s free at the point of use.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “I’d just like to direct this to the Deputy Leader of UKIP. Your leader, Paul Nuttall, said that he’d like to privatise the NHS.”

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK received 24,000 asylum applications last year, far fewer than other EU countries.
extra_title: UN wrong on asylum seekers in Britain
rating_alternateName: It's 31,000 including family members, the sixth highest number in the EU. Adjusting for population size, the UK is 18th out of 30 European countries.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "The perspective has been largely lost, and very much so, in the United Kingdom … in 2014, Germany received 175,000 asylum applications; Sweden, 75,000; Italy, 63,000; France, 59,000; and the United Kingdom, 24,000."
extra_title: UN wrong on asylum seekers in Britain
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Tesco wasted 119 million meals last year.
extra_title: Did Tesco waste 119 million meals last year?
rating_alternateName: This is true, if you define a meal as 0.5kg of food. It’s likely to equal a very small proportion of the food wasted by Tesco’s customers or across its supply chain.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Tesco food waste rose to equivalent of 119m meals last year”
extra_title: Did Tesco waste 119 million meals last year?

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Supermarket threw away equivalent of 119million meals last year despite initiatives to tackle the problem”
extra_title: Did Tesco waste 119 million meals last year?

claimReview_claimReviewed: “Tesco food waste increases to the equivalent of 119m meals in 2016”
extra_title: Did Tesco waste 119 million meals last year?

claimReview_claimReviewed: The NHS had a deficit of over £800 million last year and is predicted to have a £2 billion deficit this year.
extra_title: Hospitals in the red: the size of the NHS provider deficit
rating_alternateName: This is correct for NHS providers. It stood at £830 million last year and it's expected to rise, with some forecasting £2 billion or more in 2015/16.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The UK population is 61.6 million, of whom 194,000 are refugees.
extra_title: Ask Full Fact: how many refugees are in the UK population?
rating_alternateName: The latest estimate of the UK population was 64.6 million, as of 2014. The UN's latest estimate suggests that there were 117,000 refugees living in the UK that year.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Last year the UK took in 558,000 people from developed countries alone.
extra_title: How many migrants are coming to Europe and the UK?
rating_alternateName: 558,000 people is the total number of foreign nationals that moved to the UK in 2014, not just asylum seekers, and not just people from developed countries.

claimReview_claimReviewed: One million migrants are expected in the EU this year and 800,000 have already arrived.
extra_title: How many migrants are coming to Europe and the UK?
rating_alternateName: One million people will seek asylum in the EU in 2015, according to the OECD; around half of them may already have arrived. All these estimates are uncertain.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "One million migrants will have fled to Europe by the end of this year, according to a shock report. Around 500,000 have already illegally crossed EU borders with another 300,000 arriving by sea. A further 200,000 are expected in the next three months. Last year the UK took in 558,000 people from developed countries alone."
extra_title: How many migrants are coming to Europe and the UK?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The Prime Minister says the number of nurses is up by 3,000 since the last election, while a Labour MP says it's down by 2,500.
extra_title: Factcheck: How nurse numbers can be up as well as down
rating_alternateName: It depends who you count, how you count them, and what time period you count from.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
"Today, there are 2,500 fewer nurses in our NHS than in May 2010." - Tom Blenkinsop MP, 17 December 2014 
http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201415/cmhansrd/cm141217/debtext/141217-0001.htm#14121730000005

extra_title: The EU, the Gherkin and 'freedom of panorama'
rating_alternateName: The suggestion is to apply copyright protection to images of public buildings for commercial use. It's at an early stage, and may not be taken up by EU legislators.

claimReview_claimReviewed: More people are eligible for support under PIP than DLA.
extra_title: Are people with mental health conditions now receiving higher disability benefit payments?
rating_alternateName: It’s unlikely. PIP was designed so that fewer people would be eligible than would be the case under DLA. A quarter of people claiming DLA for mental health conditions did not qualify for PIP when reassessed.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Two thirds of people with mental health conditions claiming PIP receive the higher daily living allowance compared to less than a quarter under DLA.
extra_title: Are people with mental health conditions now receiving higher disability benefit payments?
rating_alternateName: The figures are correct, 66% compared to 22%, but fewer people are claiming PIP, and only 39% of those who have moved from DLA to PIP have been awarded more money than they were receiving under DLA.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If you look at the figures two thirds of people with mental health conditions who are in receipt of, who are claiming Personal Independence Payments and are in receipt of that, two thirds of them actually get awarded the higher daily living rate allowance. That two thirds compares to less than a quarter under the previous DLA arrangements.”
extra_title: Are people with mental health conditions now receiving higher disability benefit payments?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: “one of the effects of the transition from DLA to PIP is that more people are now eligible for support—particularly those, as it happens, with mental health problems”
extra_title: Are people with mental health conditions now receiving higher disability benefit payments?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: The most vulnerable people claiming Employment and Support Allowance will continue to get extra money despite benefit cuts.
extra_title: ESA: "extra money" for some
rating_alternateName: Those in the ESA support group will be getting more than other claimants, but the real value of the benefit will fall over time.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "[Harriet Harman] asked specifically about employment and support allowance, and it is really important that we get this right. There are two groups of people on ESA, with the first being the support group, who will continue to get extra money—more than on jobseeker's allowance—for as long as they need it."
extra_title: ESA: "extra money" for some
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There was an £8 billion increase in revenues from additional rate taxpayers after the top rate of tax was reduced from 50p to 45p.
extra_title: Did cutting the 50p rate of tax raise £8 billion?
rating_alternateName: Revenues did increase by that much, but tax receipts were artificially low in 2012/13 and artificially high in 2013/14 due to people ‘deferring’ income from one tax year to another in order to benefit from the lower tax rate. So this can’t be described as the amount of money raised by the reduction in the rate.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“Figures published this morning by HMRC contain, for the first time, the income tax data for 2013-14, which was when the 50p rate was reduced to 45p.
“The data reveal that in that year there was an £8 billion increase in revenues from additional-rate taxpayers, which completely defies the predictions made by the Labour party at the time
extra_title: Did cutting the 50p rate of tax raise £8 billion?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are 18 million GP appointments a year for self-treatable conditions.
extra_title: Could 18 million GP appointments be seen by pharmacists?
rating_alternateName: This is a very rough figure based on uncertain and out of date data. It uses self-reported data from about 60 GPs on 5,000 appointments in 2015, and applies this to the total number of GP appointments in 2008.

claimReview_claimReviewed: There are 2.1 million A&E; visits a year for self-treatable conditions.
extra_title: Could 18 million GP appointments be seen by pharmacists?
rating_alternateName: 2.1 million A&E; visits in England received no treatment in 2016/17. It’s not possible to say from this how many could have been self-treated.

claimReview_claimReviewed: Visits to a GP or A&E; for self-treatable conditions cost the NHS £850 million a year.
extra_title: Could 18 million GP appointments be seen by pharmacists?
rating_alternateName: We have limited evidence on the number of self-treatable appointments, so any cost estimate is fairly rough. How much could be saved by avoiding these appointments depends on whether the number of staff or buildings used could be reduced as a result.

claimReview_claimReviewed:
“NHS England said there are 18 million GP appointments and 2.1 million A&E visits for self-treatable conditions a year at a cost of £850 million to the NHS.”
Daily Mirror, 12 February 2018 (p.5 of print edition)
“There are 18 million GP appointments and 2.1 million visits to A&E every year for conditions that could be dealt with at home, costing £850 million.”
extra_title: Could 18 million GP appointments be seen by pharmacists?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: Labour will borrow £500 billion more in government.
extra_title: Will there be half a trillion pounds of borrowing under Labour?
rating_alternateName: We don’t know yet what all of Labour’s policies will cost or raise. This figure refers to planned investment spending, not all of which the party says will come from public borrowing.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “If he looks ahead to what his policies would produce for this country: half a trillion pounds of borrowing, £500 billion pounds more borrowing under the Labour party”
extra_title: Will there be half a trillion pounds of borrowing under Labour?
rating_alternateName: No verdict for Individual claims

claimReview_claimReviewed: 100,000 illegal migrants have been stopped from making the crossing to the UK in the past year.

rating_alternateName: The data doesn't allow us to say this. This is an unofficial projection based on Home Office data and depends upon the assumption that foiled attempts to cross the border have continued at the same rate as in April to July this year for the rest of the year.

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Almost 100,000 illegals stopped at the UK border"
extra_title: We don't know that 100,000 illegal migrants have been stopped at the border

claimReview_claimReviewed: "Illegal migrants shock as 100,000 tried to sneak into Britain in the past year"

rating_alternateName: We haven’t seen evidence that GPs are asking patients to prove they need to see them over the telephone. Some people do have concerns about whether taking initial consultations over the phone provides the best quality of care, saves GPs time overall, or saves the NHS money.

extra_title: Will you have to prove you need to see your GP?

claimReview_claimReviewed: Telephone-based GP consultation models have proved... popular and successful. There is growing evidence to suggest that investment in telephony infrastructure can be cost effective due to the GP time savings that are being achieved.

claimReview_claimReviewed: The richest 1% of people in the UK own more than twenty times the wealth of the poorest 20% in the UK.

rating_alternateName: Finding out what the wealthiest own is harder than you might expect, but this is a reasonable claim that’s based on a well-regarded set of estimates. It’s important not to confused inequalities of wealth with inequalities of income, which are much lower.

claimReview_claimReviewed: “The richest one percent of the UK population own more than 20 times more wealth than the poorest 20 percent combined.”
